801 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Finn


05042-09 Calendar No. 3


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 518; 625 N.Y.S.2d 809; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 165



February 21, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner director of state developmental center commenced a proceeding to challenge a do not resuscitate order for a mentally retarded individual issued by a physician after consultation with his sister, who was his legal guardian. Petitioner claimed that the order was improperly written under N.Y. Pub. Health Law art. 29-B.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner director of state developmental center challenged a do not resuscitate order (DNR) that was written under N.Y. Pub. Health Law art. 29-B (DNR statutes) by a mentally retarded patient's physician after consultation with the patient's legal guardian. The court granted the petition and struck down N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2965(3)(c)(iv). The court held that: (1) there was no evidence before the court demonstrating to a reasonable medical certainty that the patient's present medical condition would make cardiopulmonary resuscitation a medical futile treatment; (2) the right to decline treatment could not be exercised by a third-party; (3) the DNR statutes did not define the term "extraordinary burden," and, thus, that part of the DNR statutes was unconstitutionally uncertain and vague.


OUTCOME: The court granted petitioner director of state developmental center's request to strike down a do not resuscitate order written by a physician for a mentally retarded individual.


HEADNOTES

Health - "Do Not Resuscitate" Orders - Controversy Ripe for Judicial Review A proceeding commenced by a developmental center pursuant to Public Health Law article 29-B challenging a "do not resuscitate" order obtained by the guardian of a mentally disabled adult who resides in the center is not prematurely commenced even though the parties have not participated in any dispute mediation system as contemplated by the relevant statute (see, Public Health Law § 2972). The statute clearly provides that the Department of Health or a duly authorized agency may commence an action or proceeding to enjoin a violation of this article. The Office of Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities and, by extension, the center, has the responsibility for ensuring that the personal and civil rights of persons receiving care and treatment are adequately protected (Mental Hygiene Law § 13.07 [c]). The person here is such a person and the instant proceeding is properly before the court.

Health - "Do Not Resuscitate" Orders - Securing Order on Behalf of Mentally Incapacitated Adult - Determination of Decision-Making Abilities A physician's determination that an adult incapacitated patient in a facility lacks decision-making abilities must be made with a reasonable degree of medical certainty, must be in writing and must contain the physician's opinion regarding the cause and nature of the patient's incapacity as well as its extent and probable duration (Public Health Law § 2963 [2]). Thus, where the guardian of a mentally disabled adult obtained a "do not resuscitate" (DNR) order from the patient's physician, and no capacity determination was made before writing the DNR order and the written report made after the examination did not address capacity, the Public Health Law was violated even though no dispute exists that the person is profoundly retarded. The capacity determination must be made in each case because the statute presumes all persons have capacity notwithstanding that a guardian has previously been appointed.

Health - "Do Not Resuscitate" Orders - Surrogate Order - Determination of Medically Futile Treatment The "do not resuscitate" (DNR) order obtained by the guardian of a mentally incapacitated adult residing in a developmental center, which was not supported by a finding that the patient's current medical condition would make resuscitation a medically futile treatment was, in effect, a "living will", to become effective prospectively in the event of an illness severe enough to cause respiratory and cardiac arrest and, thus, was a violation of Public Health Law § 2965 (3) (c) which requires a surrogate DNR order to be supported by the current medical condition of the patient. "Medically futile" means that resuscitation would be unsuccessful in restoring cardiac and respiratory function or that the patient will experience repeated arrests in a short period of time before death occurs (Public Health Law § 2961 [12]). Here no evidence was presented that the patient's present medical condition would make resuscitation a medically futile treatment. Although he has chronic illnesses, the patient is not acutely ill and his illnesses are not life-threatening. Further, living wills cannot be imputed to those who are incompetent to make them.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Surrogate "Do Not Resuscitate" Orders - Vagueness of "Extraordinary Burden" Element The "do not resuscitate" order obtained, pursuant to Public Health Law article 29-B, by the guardian of a mentally incapacitated adult residing in a developmental center, based upon the physicians' opinion that resuscitation would place an "extraordinary burden" on the patient is rescinded since the "extraordinary burden" section (Public Health Law § 2965 [3] [c] [iv]) fails to pass constitutional muster. The Public Health Law does not define "extraordinary burden" and the term, subject to numerous meanings, is uncertain and vague. Although his life as a developmentally disabled person may seem a small possession from the perspective of some, it remains his possession and no person or court should substitute its judgment as to what would be an acceptable quality of life for another. The "extraordinary burden" provision opens the door to the treatment of the mentally and developmentally disabled as second-class citizens and any perceived possible diminution in their "quality of life" could be a basis for the denial of life-saving treatment.

 

802 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 715; 213 N.Y.L.J. 24



 February 6, 1995 

 

803 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Owens


INDICTMENT NUMBER 481-94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 15; 623 N.Y.S.2d 719; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 52



February 3, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree. The matter came before the court for a hearing on defendant's motion for an order suppressing physical evidence and several statements allegedly made to a law enforcement official.


OVERVIEW: Defendant filed a motion to suppress physical evidence, namely a semiautomatic pistol, and several statements allegedly made to a law enforcement official. The court granted the motion to suppress in all respects. It made the factual determination that the stop of defendant's van was a so-called "pretext stop" and thus insufficient in law to serve as a predicate for the seizure of the gun. The court reasoned that the police officers admitted that they were following defendant and subsequently stopped the van because they believed he was carrying a gun. It observed that their belief was based upon their trained observations and experience, although not sufficient to establish the basis necessary for a lawful stop. The court stated that it was obliged to suppress the gun and the ensuing statements as fruits of a poisoned tree.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to suppress physical evidence and several statements made to a law enforcement official in all respects.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Unlawful Search and Seizure - Illegal Pretext Stop of Vehicle The gun seized from defendant is suppressed where the police officers observed him in an area known for previous drug and weapon possession arrests, observed him adjust his waistband, but did not see an actual object or bulge in his waistband, observed him enter the passenger side of a van, and followed and stopped the van when the driver turned without signaling, since the stop of the van was a "pretext stop" which violated the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution. The police may not use traffic infractions to justify a stop of an individual when the police action is motivated by other reasons, namely, some suspicion that falls short of a reasonable suspicion that an occupant of a vehicle has committed, is in the process of or is about to commit a crime. Here, the police officers admitted that they stopped the van not because of the traffic infraction but because they believed the defendant was carrying a gun. Their belief was based upon their trained observations and experience, but these factors are insufficient to establish the basis necessary for a lawful stop.

 

804 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cintron


Indict. No. 5816/94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 881; 622 N.Y.S.2d 662; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 27



January 23, 1995, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the indictment charging him with aggravated unlicensed operation of a motor vehicle in the first degree, in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511(3), alleging ex post facto and double jeopardy violations.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511(3), which made it a class E felony to drive a vehicle with 10 or more license suspensions in effect, presented ex post facto problems because it imposed additional penalty for earlier crimes. Defendant also argued that he had already pleaded guilty to the crime in question, so that he could not be indicted again. The court found that the statute did not present ex post facto problems: the statute imposed a stiffer penalty for the current crime because it was repeated, rather than adding penalties for previous crimes, and, once the law was enacted, defendant had notice that continuing to drive with numerous license suspensions would result in stiff penalties. The court found that defendant had not pleaded guilty to the current crime because the crime resulting in the guilty plea and the current crime had different docket numbers.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss, holding that the statute in question was a recidivist law, which created a stiffer penalty for the offense because it was a repeated one rather than imposing additional penalty, or putting defendant in jeopardy again, for earlier crimes.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Aggravated Unlicensed Operation of Motor Vehicle - Utilizing Suspensions That Occurred Prior to Effective Date of Statute - No Ex Post Facto Law Defendant may be charged with a violation of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511 (3) for operating a motor vehicle while he had in effect 10 or more suspensions, imposed on at least 10 separate dates for failure to answer, appear or pay a fine on a summons issued for a traffic violation, even though some of the suspensions occurred prior to the effective date of the statute, since section 511 permits utilization of suspensions occurring prior to the effective date to create the necessary predicate, and utilization of these suspensions does not make section 511 (3) an unconstitutional ex post facto law. Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511 (3) is a recidivist statute, not unlike the laws which enhance punishment for predicate felons. The punishment to be imposed would not be punishment for earlier license suspensions but only a stiffened penalty for the present crime because it is a repetitive one. Moreover, defendant was given fair warning by the amendment to section 511 that his continued operation of a motor vehicle while his license suspensions were in effect would be regarded as felonious conduct.

Motor Vehicles - Former Jeopardy - Prosecution of Two Separate Traffic Violations The People did not subject defendant to double jeopardy when they prosecuted him for violating Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511 (3) after he pleaded guilty to driving with tinted windows, and paid a fine, since the fine receipt indicates a docket number different than the docket number for the section 511 violation and, thus, these cases are separate. More importantly, defendant failed to produce any documentation, i.e., plea minutes, showing that his guilty plea to the tinted windows charge was meant to satisfy the section 511 charge. Hence, defendant's claim that prosecution on the section 511 charge constitutes double jeopardy is without support in the record.

 

805 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Homier Distrib. Co. v. City of Albany


RJI #: 0193-033627, Index #: 8245-92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 723; 621 N.Y.S.2d 826; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 14



January 12, 1995, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed a motion for partial summary judgment in its action against defendant City of Albany seeking a declaration that the city's transient sales tax it collected under Albany, N.Y. Code § 7-240 violated the Commerce Clause, and U.S. Const. Art. I, § 8. The taxpayer also sought attorney' fees and damages pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. §§ 1983 and 1988. The company had paid the city's transient sales tax under protest.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer sold consumer products. Its retail sales occurred primarily at prescheduled sales throughout the state. The taxpayer collected sales tax on and filed sales tax returns for its sales within the state. The taxpayer was required to obtain a transient retail business license and pay a transient sales tax for a sale in the city. The court in denying the taxpayer's motion, held that because the Albany, N.Y. Code § 7-240 did not differentiate based on where a retailer's business was located, exempted those merchants who conducted permanent retail business in the city, and taxed the gross receipts of all transient retail merchants, both from in state and out of state, the ordinance was not per se unconstitutional. It further found that the ordinance was not unconstitutional because even though the ordinance had an indirect incidental effect on interstate commerce, the ordinance served a legitimate purpose of producing revenue and the taxpayer did not pay more than its fair share. The court ruled that because the taxpayer failed to show that a federally protected right was violated, it failed to state a claim under 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 and was not entitled to attorneys' fees.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxpayer's motion for partial summary judgment in its action against the city, which sought to declare the city's transient sales tax in violation of the Commerce Clause and the Constitution.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Validity of Municipal Ordinance That Taxes Transient Retailers A city ordinance requiring plaintiff foreign corporation and transient retailer to pay a retail business tax based on the gross amount of sales at the same rate as other property is taxed is not per se unconstitutional. The States and their political subdivisions are prohibited from discriminating against interstate trade in that they may not tax a transaction more heavily when it crosses State lines than when it occurs entirely within the State (see, US Const, art I, § 8, cl [3]). Here, the tax is not imposed based on the in-or out-of-State origin of the merchandise sold by transient retailers or the location of the transient retailer in or out of this State. This tax differentiates between retailers based upon whether they intend to conduct retail sales on a permanent or temporary basis in the city and without regard to any interstate element. Thus, the differential tax treatment here does not result solely from the sites of their activities in or out of State, and does not provide a direct commercial advantage to in-State retailers. Further, the ordinance does not impose the type of simple economic protectionism of in-State business for which a virtually per se rule of invalidity has been erected.

Constitutional Law - Commerce Clause - Validity of Municipal Ordinance That Taxes Transient Retailers A city ordinance requiring plaintiff foreign corporation and transient retailer to pay a retail business tax based on the gross amount of sales at the same rate as other property is taxed does not violate the Commerce Clause (see, US Const, art I, § 8, cl [3]). The ordinance may have some indirect incidental effect on interstate commerce in that a portion of transient retailers who are subject to the gross receipts tax do business or are based in other States and cross State lines to conduct retail sales in the city. Nevertheless, the ordinance taxes all transient businesses evenly, regardless of whether their permanent home is in or out of State, based upon the reasonable distinction between retail merchants with permanent businesses in the city who pay property taxes and transient retailers who do not (and instead pay taxes at the same rate as property is taxed in the city). The ordinance serves the legitimate municipal public purpose of producing revenues by requiring transient retailers to pay their fair share of municipal costs already paid by permanent retailers in the city.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Counsel Fees Where a city ordinance mandating that transient retailers pay a sales tax based upon gross receipts is upheld as constitutional against plaintiff transient retailer's challenge and, thus, plaintiff was not deprived of any rights under 42 USC § 1983, plaintiff is not entitled to attorney's fees and costs under 42 USC § 1988. To state a claim under section 1983, plaintiff must allege, at a minimum, conduct by a person acting under color of law which deprived it of a right, privilege or immunity guaranteed by the Federal Constitution or the Federal laws. Plaintiff did not satisfy that burden, since no Federally protected right was violated.

 

806 of 992 DOCUMENTS


St. James Church v. Board of Educ.


Index No. 94-1411, RJI No. 94-0242-M


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MADISON COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 471; 621 N.Y.S.2d 486; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 587



December 23, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff church filed a motion for summary judgment in its declaratory judgment action brought against board of education of a school district (district), which enacted a policy under which it would no longer provide, rent, or lease transportation for pupils between the public school site and the church's released-time religious education program site.


OVERVIEW: The sole reason the district no longer leased its buses to the church was because it believed it lacked authority to lease buses for an entirely religious undertaking. The school argued that it was a specified entity under the plain language of N.Y. Educ. Law § 1501-b(1)(h), to which the district could lease buses. The court granted summary judgment in favor of the church. The programs to which the students were transported were educational and the leasing of buses to the church did not advance any religious purpose. Neither taxpayer money nor taxpayer property was being given to the church. Nor did the mere lease of a bus for transportation by itself aid or advance religion. The district was selling a service to a not-for-profit corporation for legislatively approved purposes. Those distinctions saved the lease from violating the Constitution. There was no realistic danger that the community would think that the district was endorsing religion in the leasing of buses to the church, and any benefit to religion in that context was insignificant. To refuse to lease buses to the church solely based on the religious viewpoint of the program offered would constitute discrimination.


OUTCOME: The court granted the church's motion for summary judgment and declared that the church was an entity to which the district was authorized to lease buses and the refusal of the district to lease buses to the church because of the religious nature of the not-for-profit corporation and/or the religious content of the instruction to which the buses transported youths would constitute discrimination.


HEADNOTES

Schools - Board of Education - Leasing Buses to Church Education Law § 1501-b (1) (h) authorizes defendant school district to lease buses to plaintiff church, a not-for-profit corporation in a rural community, to transport students from school to and from released-time religious classes located at the church. Education Law § 1501-b (1) (h) directs that a school district may, in its discretion, lease buses to any not-for-profit corporation which provides, inter alia, education or employment for youths or adults in a rural county. Educational means serving to educate; instructive. It is impossible to exclude some instruction because of its religious content. The fact that the material is taught from a religious perspective does not make it any less educational. Thus, the programs to which the students are transported are educational within the statutory definition.

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Freedom of Religion - School District's Right to Lease Buses to Church Defendant school district may lease buses to plaintiff church, a not-for-profit corporation located in a rural community, to transport students from school to and from released-time religious classes located at the church without violating any State or Federal constitutional requirement of separation of church and State. First, the New York Constitution prohibits the use of tax dollars to advance religious purposes and the First Amendment of the US Constitution forbids government from favoring religion over nonreligion. Here, the leasing of buses to plaintiff does not advance any religious purpose. It is a straight financial transaction in which not a dollar of taxpayer money is expended. In addition, the mere lease of a bus for transportation by itself does not aid or advance religion. The district is not providing a service but selling a service to a not-for-profit corporation for legislatively approved purposes (see, Education Law § 1501-b [1] [h]). Second, the Establishment Clause prohibits governmental policies that aid or handicap religion. It does not forbid all interaction of church and State. The District need only satisfy the statutory criteria of the Education Law as to the identity of the organization and the services offered; it need not go beyond these requirements and analyze the content of the educational program offered. Third, defendant's refusal to lease the buses solely on the basis of the religious viewpoint of the program offered would violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the US Constitution.

 

807 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Miller v. Town of Gorham


Index # 81483


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ONTARIO COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 250; 620 N.Y.S.2d 735; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 547



December 5, 1994, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed a motion for summary judgment in his action against defendant town alleging illegal disbursements of public funds in violation of N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer initiated an action alleging that the town illegally disbursed public funds to a retired public employee pursuant to resolutions by the town board. The taxpayer alleged that the town failed to comply with N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law §§ 51(90) and (92). The court held that the action was time-barred under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 215(4). The court determined that citizen taxpayer actions under N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 51 were subject to the one year statute of limitation set forth in N.Y. C.P.L.R. 215(4) and not the six year limitations period under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 213(1) as asserted by the taxpayer. The court determined that the one year limitations period applied because the taxpayer's action was one to recover monies for the benefit of the political subdivision, similar to claims under article 7-A of the State Finance Law. The court also ruled that the mere showing of an illegal official act was insufficient to warrant relief without proof of potential waste or injury, and in the taxpayer's action there was not a potential waste or injury because the retired employee was entitled to the disbursed funds.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxpayer's motion for summary judgment and granted summary judgment in favor of the town.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Taxpayer's Action - Disbursement of Public Funds to Compensate Retired Town Employee for Unused Benefits Plaintiff taxpayer's action against the Town for alleged illegal disbursement of funds based upon the Town Board's adoption of two resolutions permitting payment to a retired Water District employee as reimbursement for unused past benefits is dismissed. General Municipal Law § 90 and 92 authorize governing boards of political subdivisions of the State, including towns, to provide for employee benefits by resolution. Here, the two resolutions were passed and adopted prior to the effective date of retirement. In addition, at an organizational meeting in January 1967, this particular employee was mentioned by name in connection with a resolution concerning sick leave and Water District employees were specifically granted the same benefits as allowed to all town employees.

Limitation of Actions - What Statute Governs - One-Year Statute of Limitations - Taxpayer Action against Municipality for Illegal Disbursement of Funds Plaintiff taxpayer's action against the Town for alleged illegal disbursement of funds based upon the Town Board's adoption of two resolutions permitting payment to a retired Town employee as reimbursement for unused past benefits, commenced three years after the resolutions were passed, is dismissed as untimely. A citizen taxpayer action under General Municipal Law § 51, similar to a taxpayer's right of action for return of illegally paid funds commenced under the State Finance Law, must be commenced within one year (see, CPLR 215 [4]).

Municipal Corporations - Taxpayer's Action - Illegal Actions of Municipal Officials Plaintiff taxpayer's action against the Town for alleged illegal disbursement of funds based upon the Town Board's adoption of two resolutions permitting payment to a retired Town employee as reimbursement for past benefits is dismissed. The mere showing of an illegal official act is insufficient to warrant relief and proof of potential waste or injury to property is required. Here, this would involve enjoining the payment of monies to which the recipient would presumably be otherwise entitled, except for the alleged illegal act on the part of a Town official.

 

808 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Camilla


94-631


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 272; 620 N.Y.S.2d 897; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 543



December 2, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner lesbian partner filed an adoption petition to adopt the child of her partner, who was the child's biological mother. The court clerk returned the petition, pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 115-b(5), on the ground that the petition was facially incomplete because lesbian partner was not a "qualified adoptive parent," under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 115(1)(b). Lesbian partner requested that the court accept the petition.


OVERVIEW: Lesbian partner argued she did not have to "pre-certify," as the stepparent exemption under N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 115-d(8) applied to the case because she wished to adopt the child as a "second parent." The court held that the lesbian partner established good cause to waive the preplacement certification, as she and the child's biological mother had lived together in a committed relationship for nine years, the child had lived continuously with her biological mother and lesbian partner since her birth, and the biological mother consented to the adoption. The court noted that the child was already in the custody of lesbian partner and would have remained there whether or not the court required lesbian partner to become pre-certified. The court reasoned that § 115(1)(b) was not intended to apply to the case because it was enacted to screen adoptive parents for fitness. Most importantly, the court opined that the language of § 115(1)(b) reflected the traditional nuclear family structure as it existed at the time the statute was enacted, 1938, but that prohibiting homosexual would-be parents from adopting would not have reflected the reality of the 1990s.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the clerk to accept lesbian partner's adoption petition for filing.


HEADNOTES

Adoption - Adoption by Same Sex Couples - Waiver of Preplacement Certification Petitioner, the lesbian partner of a child's biological mother, may adopt the child without obtaining preplacement certification where she has demonstrated good cause to waive such certification. The child has lived continuously with her mother and petitioner, petitioner has already assumed the parental role and is discharging parental responsibilities and the biological mother consents to the proposed adoption. Domestic Relations Law § 115 (1) (b), which mandates that the adoptive parent be certified as a qualified parent, was not intended to apply to these facts and the purpose of the statute would not be advanced by requiring petitioner to become certified as a "qualified adoptive parent" as a condition precedent to her filing the adoption petition.

Adoption - Adoption by Same Sex Couples - Application of Preplacement Certification Exemption to Second-Parent Adoption Petitioner, the lesbian partner of a child's biological mother, may adopt the child without obtaining preplacement certification since Domestic Relations Law § 115-d (8), which provides that precertification shall not apply to a petition brought by a stepparent for the adoption of a stepchild where the stepchild has resided with the natural parent and the stepparent for a continuous period of at least one year, exempts petitioner from becoming certified as a "qualified adoptive parent". The child has lived continuously with her mother and petitioner, petitioner has already assumed the parental role and is discharging parental responsibilities and the biological mother consents to the proposed adoption. Domestic Relations Law § 115-d (8) should apply to all "second-parent" adoptions. The purpose of this adoption is not to create a nonmatrimonial legal status for the relationship between the petitioner and the child's biological mother, but to give legal recognition to the child's relationship to her second-parent.

Adoption - Adoption by Same Sex Couples - Termination of Biological Parent's Rights Petitioner, the lesbian partner of a child's biological mother, may adopt the child without terminating the biological parent's rights, notwithstanding that Domestic Relations Law § 117 (1) (a) automatically relieves the natural parents of all parental duties toward and responsibilities for the child once an order of adoption is made, since Domestic Relations Law § 117 (1) (d) provides that the biological parent's rights will not be terminated where the adoptive parent is a stepparent. The exception in section 117 (1) (d) applies to all "second-parent" adoptions. Thus, petitioner is not rendered unsuitable to adopt because the biological parent's rights would have to be terminated.

 

809 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bell


94-655


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, TOWN OF CLARKSTOWN, ROCKLAND COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 432; 620 N.Y.S.2d 923; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 575



December 2, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed a motion to dismiss the charges of driving with a suspended license in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511(2)(a).


OVERVIEW: Defendants alleged that an impediment to conviction on the charge of driving with a suspended license, second degree in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511(2)(a), existed due to the fact that such revocation could only have been imposed for a finite period and could not have continued indefinitely. The court rejected their arguments and denied their motions, holding that the statute was clear on its face. It imposed a minimum period of revocation and so stated. Nothing could have been clearer than the language of the statute providing for the minimum period of revocation based upon certain occurrences and/or violations of the N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law. The court refused to declare the statute unconstitutional, finding that defendants were well within the statutory period of court "custody," having been placed on probation and remaining on probation at the time of their arrests. The court held that it would have been acting recklessly if it attempted to set forth a rule which would have had the net effect of decreeing that a one-year revocation was well within the meaning and intent of the statute, but two or three or four years was not.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motions to dismiss the charge of driving while under suspension were denied.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Revocation or Suspension of Operator's License - Duration of Revocation Period for Alcohol-Related Conviction Vehicle and Traffic Law § 1193 (2) (b) (3), which provides that a driver's license "shall be revoked" for a minimum period of one year upon the holder's conviction of an alcohol-related driving offense, is not unconstitutionally vague for failing to specify the actual duration of the suspension period. The statute is clear on its face and imposes only a minimum period of revocation. The revocation continues until such time as the holder reapplies for the restoration of driving privileges but the court cannot continue the revocation for a period longer than that which it has the defendant in its "custody". Consequently, there is no legal impediment to prosecuting a defendant on a charge of driving with a suspended license in the second degree (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511 [2] [a]), as opposed to the lesser charge of unlicensed operation (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 509 [1]), where the arrest occurred after the expiration of the minimum revocation period while the defendant was on probation and thus still within the statutory period of court "custody" (CPL 410.50 [1]). Furthermore, since the crimes of driving with a suspended license in the second degree and operating without a valid driver's license are both of a malum prohibitum nature, the jury must be instructed that they must find that the defendant knew that his driving privileges were revoked, and that the failure of the People to establish scienter on the part of the defendant would warrant a finding of not guilty.

 

810 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lindemann v. American Horse Shows Ass'n


Index No.: 124754/94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 937; 624 N.Y.S.2d 723; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 591



December 1, 1994, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant horse shows association moved to vacate a temporary restraining order granted to plaintiffs in a suit for injunctive relief and damages whereby plaintiffs alleged that defendant, in exercising its exclusive control over equestrian sport to bar plaintiffs from competition, violated antitrust provisions of the Donnelly Act, violated plaintiffs' due process rights and its acts constituted a breach of contract and fiduciary duty.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed suit against defendant association asking for injunctive relief to prevent suspension and for damages. Plaintiffs had been criminally indicted for killing a horse for the insurance proceeds and contended that defendant unreasonably denied them a request for an adjournment during a hearing to prepare their defense and for the opportunity to present exculpatory evidence. Plaintiffs alleged that defendant, in exercising its exclusive control over equestrian sport to bar plaintiffs from competition, violated antitrust provisions of the Donnelly Act, violated plaintiffs' due process rights, and alleged its acts constituted a breach of contract and fiduciary duty. The court denied defendant's motion to vacate a temporary restraining order and held that the determination by defendant suspending plaintiffs was arbitrary and capricious and imposed without a meaningful hearing and in the absence of substantial evidence. The court held that an arbitrary action by a private organization carried many of the earmarks of a deprivation of due process and concluded that defendant did not afford plaintiffs a genuine opportunity to present evidence rebutting the accusation.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant horse shows association's motion to vacate a temporary restraining order granted to plaintiffs and concluded that the determination by defendant suspending plaintiffs was arbitrary and capricious and imposed without a meaningful hearing and in the absence of substantial evidence. The court nullified defendant's determination and defendant was enjoined from proceeding with any suspension except after a hearing.


HEADNOTES

Associations - Suspension from Membership - Validity of Rule Providing for Suspension upon Indictment A rule promulgated by a private association, which governs and controls all horse shows, contests and exhibitions in the United States and the persons deemed eligible to perform therein, providing for suspension or expulsion after a hearing of any person indicted for any act of cruelty or abuse to a horse is not on its face improper, but was improperly applied to suspend plaintiffs, association members who had been indicted for equine insurance fraud, because the hearing afforded was arbitrary, unfair and illusory. Any member subject to suspension or expulsion from an association which controls its field is entitled to fair notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard. Here, the hearing was called on 20 days' notice and plaintiffs were denied an adjournment to prepare their defense and for the opportunity to present exculpatory evidence unless they would agree to a voluntary suspension. While an indictment and not guilty plea is enough under the association's rules to trigger the requirement for a hearing and, if unrefuted or unexplained, may be the basis for suspension, it cannot be the predicate for suspension without a meaningful hearing as to the merits, an opportunity to present rebuttal evidence and the weighing of alternatives to indefinite suspension. The association's rule calling for such hearing and the exercise of responsible discretion was wholly illusory in its application because the hearing panel considered only whether the indictment alleged cruelty and what the public perceptions might be about the accusations. Nor, in exercising its discretion, did the hearing panel weigh the consequences of suspension on the individuals charged. Moreover, to the extent the association's rule permits suspension not only of the accused but also the accused's spouse, family members, companions, employees, agents or others, it constitutes a kind of Bill of Attainder.

 

811 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New Amber Auto Serv. v. New York City Envtl. Control Bd.


Index No. 116462/94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 113; 619 N.Y.S.2d 496; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 519



November 9, 1994, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended January 19, 1995.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff auto body shop filed a motion for judgment declaring New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 24-141, which prohibited the release of detrimental substances into the air, and New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 15, § 31-53, which allocated the burden of proof in administrative hearings, unconstitutional, in an action stemming from fines assessed against plaintiff by defendant New York City Environmental Control Board.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff auto body shop was fined for allowing aerosol paint fumes to escape into the air. In denying plaintiff's motion for judgment, the court held that New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 24-141 was not void for vagueness. The court held that the statute gave the person of ordinary intelligence a reasonable opportunity to know what was prohibited and that the law provided adequate standards for its application. The court held that the plain meaning of "detriment" in § 24-141 and the definitions of the terms "air contaminant" and "odorous air contaminant" in New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 24-104, together with the non-exclusive list of substances in § 24-141, including paint, the emission of which was proscribed, provided adequate notice to plaintiff. The court next held that New York City, N.Y., Rules of the City of New York, tit. 15, § 31-53, did not violate the U.S. Const. amend. XIV for failure to define the burden of proof, as it was the preponderance of the evidence in civil matters generally, including administrative matters.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion for judgment of plaintiff auto body shop. The court held that the administrative code provisions proscribing the release of aerosol paint into the air were not void for vagueness, and that the failure of the rule governing administrative hearings to expressly state the burden of proof did not violate due process.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Air Contaminants Administrative Code of the City of New York § 24-141, which prohibits emission of air contaminants that may cause detriment to the health, safety, welfare or comfort of any person, or injury to plant and animal life, is not unconstitutionally vague on its face or as applied to plaintiffs who were issued notices of violations for emitting paint fumes and noxious cooking odors and fumes, since section 24-141 provides sufficient notice to those to whom it is directed. A statute is unconstitutionally vague on its face if it specifies no comprehensible standard or guide capable of interpretation or when it cannot validly be applied to any conduct. The statute here has a core meaning that can reasonably be understood and it can validly be applied. The terms air contaminant and odorous air contaminant are defined in section 24-104. The provision is rationally related to the legislative objective which is to protect the health, safety, welfare and comfort of human, plant and animal life. In addition, section 24-141 (b) contains a list of examples of odorous air contaminants, which includes paint. Although section 24-141 (b) does require the exercise of some degree of administrative judgment, it does not have the broad power to punish all emissions.

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Hearing Procedures before Environmental Control Board Defendant Environmental Control Board did not violate plaintiff's due process rights during a proceeding charging it with violating New York City's Air Pollution Control Code (Administrative Code of City of NY § 24-101 et seq.) where plaintiff received timely and adequate notice of the hearing and had an opportunity to present evidence and to cross-examine witnesses. In addition, plaintiff was afforded the right to appeal the adverse decision of the Administrative Law Judge.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Regulation - Hearing Procedures before Environmental Control Board - Standard of Proof That part of the Environmental Control Board Rules and Regulations which provides that the complainant has the burden of proof in establishing that a person or entity has committed or caused an environmental violation (15 RCNY 31-53 [a]) is not unconstitutionally vague for failure to set out in writing the complainant's standard of proof at the hearing. The standard of proof in civil administrative hearings is a preponderance of the evidence and defendant Environmental Control Board follows this procedure. In addition, plaintiff would have been advised of this standard at the hearing had it asked.

 

812 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Raab


Index No. 26384/94


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, FIRST DISTRICT, CRIMINAL TERM, NASSAU COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 382; 621 N.Y.S.2d 440; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 571



November 7, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with trespass in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 140.05, moved for an order pursuant to N. Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30, 170.35, 100.15, and 100.40 dismissing the information on the grounds that the information was facially insufficient and that the instant prosecution was violative of defendant's right to free speech and expression under U.S. Const. amend. I and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that the superseding information, filed subsequent to the filing of the instant motion, was facially insufficient. The court held that the factual allegations of the superseding information together with the supporting depositions filed with it were sufficient to establish, if true, each and every element of the offense of trespass and the defendant's commission thereof and established a prima facie case against defendant. The element of knowledge had adequately been pleaded by the nonhearsay factual allegations that defendant was told to stop distributing literature and, on failing to stop, was then told to leave by an authorized representative of the church and by police officers. Whether defendant actually possessed the requisite knowledge upon which to base a conviction for trespass was a factual issue which must be determined at trial. On the issue of freedom of expression, the court applied the factors in Melara to find that defendant failed to demonstrate a significant degree of State involvement in the church feast sufficient to support a finding that the allegedly unconstitutional conduct of the church and its representatives constituted State action.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss was denied. The fact that defendant may have had a defense of knowledge, to the prosecution did not provide a ground upon which to dismiss the information for facial insufficiency. Defendant failed to demonstrate a significant degree of State involvement sufficient to support a finding that the allegedly unconstitutional conduct of the church and its representatives constituted State action.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Information - Facial Sufficiency - Trespass Charge against Political Candidate Distributing Literature at Church Festival The information charging defendant political candidate with trespass arising from his distribution of campaign literature on church premises during a festival is facially sufficient. The superseding information contained nonhearsay factual allegations indicating that posted signs prohibited distribution of literature and that complainant, a representative of the church, and police officers requested defendant to cease distribution, and when defendant refused to stop they asked defendant to leave the premises. In addition, two supporting depositions confirmed that complainant had authority to exclude from church premises any person who intentionally violated diocese and church rules, that signs were posted and that the police were instructed to arrest anyone who refused to cease distribution of literature and to leave church property. The factual allegations of the superseding information together with the supporting depositions establish, if true, each and every element of the offense of trespass and defendant's commission thereof.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - State Involvement in Church Festival Defendant political candidate, who was arrested for trespass when attempting to distribute literature at a church feast against a diocese and church rule, was not denied his right to freedom of speech since he failed to demonstrate a significant degree of State involvement in the church feast sufficient to support a finding that the allegedly unconstitutional conduct of the church and its representatives constituted State action. The source of authority for the private action is not derived from the State, but is instead a private diocese and church rule prohibiting the distribution of literature on church property. Also, merely because a town building permit and gambling and liquor permits were required for the function does not elevate the private activity to the level of State action. In addition, the presence of police officers to patrol the church grounds and enforce church rules does not constitute meaningful State participation in the private activity. Finally, gambling, sale of alcoholic beverages and a park-like atmosphere did not effect a delegation of a traditional State function to the church sufficient to support a finding of State action. A private activity is not deemed to constitute State action merely because it is subject to State regulation.

 

813 of 992 DOCUMENTS


R & R Disposal Carting v. Town of Clarkstown


Index No. 4018/94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ROCKLAND COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 196; 620 N.Y.S.2d 215; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 548



November 3, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff disposal company filed an action against defendant town seeking a preliminary injunction that would have enjoined the town during the pendency of the action from enforcing the terms of a stipulation of civil compromise entered in the town justice court. The town filed a cross-motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: The disposal company and town entered into an agreement to settle the disposal company's liability for civil penalties that resulted from the disposal company's violation of a local law. The town alleged that there was a balance that remained and the disposal company argued that the local law was subsequently declared unconstitutional and invalid by the United States Supreme Court. The town argued that the declaration only applied retroactively in all cases that were still open on direct review. The court found however that retroactivity applied to all events, regardless of whether such events predated or postdated the court's announcement of the new rule of law. The court held that the disposal company was entitled to a preliminary injunction because it demonstrated a likelihood of ultimate success on the merits, irreparable injury, and a balancing of the equities in the disposal company's favor. The court noted that a preliminary injunction was to be used sparingly and only when there was a clear showing of a right to such relief.


OUTCOME: The granted the disposal company's application for a preliminary injunction upon conditions that the disposal company post an undertaking.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Retroactive Application of Judicial Decision - Application to Prior Stipulation of Settlement Plaintiff waste disposal corporations, who stipulated with defendant town to settle their civil liability for allegedly violating a local law, are entitled to a permanent injunction restraining defendant from enforcing the terms of the settlement stipulation on the ground that the local law was subsequently declared unconstitutional and invalid by the United States Supreme Court. Plaintiffs are entitled to the relief sought, since the United States Supreme Court decision applies retroactively to all events, regardless of whether such events predate or postdate the Court's announcement of the new rule of law.

 

814 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bissinger


Docket No. 93N085500


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


163 Misc. 2d 667; 625 N.Y.S.2d 823; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 609



October 24, 1994, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended.
Subsequent civil proceeding at Bissinger v. City of New York, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 70155 (S.D.N.Y., Sept. 24, 2007)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought dismissal of the charges against him for unlicensed general vending in violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 20-453.


OVERVIEW: Defendant sold photographs of individually posed combinations of his backdrops with persons at a particular location. Defendant contended that § 20-453 did not apply to his activities because he was engaged in "street performance" and that his activities were an artistic expression protected by the First Amendment. Dismissing the charges against defendant, the court held that § 20-453 did not apply to defendant's activities because he sold memorializations of performances rather than "goods" or "wares" and thus defendant did not fit the definition of a "general vendor" contained in New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 20-452. The court determined that even if New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 20-453 was applicable, the regulation was unconstitutional as applied to defendant because, although it was content-neutral and sufficiently narrowly tailored to serve a significant governmental interest, it did not leave defendant an ample alternative channel for communication of his expression. Licenses were only available on a first-come, first-served basis and the wait for a license was more than five years. Thus, defendant was effectively foreclosed from communicating his ideas.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the charges against defendant for unlicensed general vending.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Unlicensed General Vending - Photographing Tourists on City Street for Fee The complaint charging defendant with unlicensed general vending and failure to display an appropriate tax certificate (Administrative Code of City of NY § 20-453) arising from defendant having charged $ 5 to take photographs of people in front of a backdrop cloth on a city street is dismissed since the physical portion of what defendant sells--memorialization of his individually posed and stylized performances--does not fit the statutory language of "goods" or "services", and defendant does not fit the definition of "general vendor" within the meaning of Administrative Code § 20-452. The photographs do not exist until after defendant has completed his performance and since they are all different, they are not souvenir photographs. In addition, the photograph cannot be displayed or spread out for viewing by any potential customer because it does not exist. Rather, the activities are comparable to those of a street musician or mime, because these types of activities involve no possession of wares or stock of goods on display.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Photographing Tourists on City Street for Fee Defendant's activities in charging $ 5 to take a person's picture in front of a backdrop cloth on a city street are "protected expression" by the First Amendment of the US and NY Constitutions even though his street performing and photographic endeavors may never be displayed in a museum or formal forum for the display of "art", since his expressive purpose is to perform for any audience which wishes to see, hear and/or participate and to produce and memorialize festive and joyous figurative and literal pictures of the city. Neither defendant's photographic endeavors, nor the sale of them, are outside the protection of either State or Federal First Amendment protection of expression. Thus, the activities, being "expression" (whether or not they are "art"), are constitutionally protected.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Time, Place and Manner Restrictions - Photographing Tourists on City Street for Fee The unlicensed vending regulation (Administrative Code of City of NY § 20-453), which requires vendors to annually obtain a license to lawfully sell goods or services on the street, is unconstitutional as applied to defendant who, without a vendor's license, charged $ 5 to take a person's picture in front of a backdrop cloth on a city street, since the regulation is not reasonably limited as to the time, place and manner of defendant's expression. To be reasonable, such restrictions must be content-neutral, narrowly tailored and leave open ample alternative channels for communication of the information. The vending licenses are issued on a first-come, first-served basis and the waiting period is at least five years. Although the licensing restriction is content-neutral and narrowly tailored to serve the legitimate interest of regulating and maintaining pedestrian traffic, it appears unconstitutional as applied here because it closes off the only method for defendant to capture and communicate the idea he wishes to express--performance and photographic memorialization, with street audience participation in a bustling street setting. He is precluded from using the desired public location within any reasonable time because of the license unavailability, and he is deprived of what he claims are elements of his expression--street sights, sounds and atmosphere.

 

815 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of N. & S. Am. v. Abrams


Index No. 1407186/93


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 850; 618 N.Y.S.2d 504; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 468



October 7, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The court considered the motions for summary judgment filed by petitioners, landowner and buyer, and the opposition to the motions filed by respondents, State and State attorney general (State), and the State's motion for leave to conduct discovery. The landowner and the buyer argued that the real property sale was valid, including subsequent contract modifications, and that N.Y. Relig. Corp. Law § 12(1) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The landowner was a religious corporation that obtained a court order as required by § 12(1) approving the sale of real property to the buyer. The landowner and the buyer modified the contract of sale several times but did not seek court approval after the modifications. A member of the religious corporation and the State challenged the sale. The religious corporation filed the proceeding seeking a declaration that the sale was valid and that the modifications did not require court approval. In the alternative they claimed that § 12(1) was unconstitutional. The landowner and the buyer filed motions for summary judgment, and the State filed a motion for leave to conduct discovery. The court denied the motions for summary judgment and granted the motion for leave to conduct discovery. The court held that § 12(1) applied to the landowner's sale of the property to the buyer, and that under § 12(1) the modifications were each new contracts which also had to be approved by the court. The part of § 12(1) requiring notice to the State did not violate the Free Exercise Clause or the Establishment Clause. The State demonstrated ample need for discovery, so its motion was granted.


OUTCOME: The court denied the landowner's and the buyer's motions for summary judgment, and it granted the State's motion for leave to conduct discovery.


HEADNOTES

Religious Corporations and Associations - Sale of Real Property - Court Approval Plaintiff Greek Orthodox Church, which contracted to sell church-owned property that was not used as a place of worship, was required to obtain court approval of the sale pursuant to Religious Corporations Law § 12. Religious Corporations Law § 12 (1) provides that a "religious corporation shall not sell, mortgage or lease for a term exceeding five years any of its real property without applying for and obtaining leave of the court". The language of the statute, i.e., "any of its real property", does not limit application of the statute to property used as a place of worship. Had the Legislature intended to limit section 12 it could have done so. Thus, section 12 applies to the sale, mortgage or lease of any real property by a religious corporation, not merely to property used as a place of worship.

Religious Corporations and Associations - Sale of Real Property - Court Approval for Subsequent Contract Modifications Where plaintiff Greek Orthodox Church contracted to sell church-owned land with court approval (see, Religious Corporations Law § 12), and subsequently modified the contract of sale regarding price, the church is required to obtain nunc pro tunc approval of said modifications (see, Religious Corporations Law § 12 [9]). Religious Corporations Law § 12 (1) applies when a religious corporation shall "sell, mortgage or lease for a term exceeding five years any of its real property". A modification of a contract results in the establishment of a new agreement between the parties which pro tanto supplants the affected provisions of the original agreement while leaving the balance of the agreement intact. Thus, by entering into an agreement to modify the price to be paid on the original contract the church entered into a new contract of sale which had to be approved by the court pursuant to section 12 (1).

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Notice to Attorney-General of Sale of Church Property - Establishment of Religion Religious Corporations Law § 12 and 2-b (1) (d-1), which provide that certain churches are required to notify the Attorney-General when obtaining leave of court to sell, mortgage or lease real property, do not intrude into or entangle with the internal affairs of plaintiff Greek Orthodox Church which sold certain of its real property and, thus, they pass constitutional muster pursuant to Lemon v Kurtzman (403 US 602). The notice insures that the sale is in the best interest of the corporation and its members and that the proceeds are properly disbursed. The purpose is secular and the statute was not motivated by an intent to endorse or disapprove religion. Also, the notice neither advances nor inhibits religion. The notice requirement does not foster an excessive government entanglement with religion. Routine regulatory interaction, such as the notice requirement, which involves no inquiries into religious doctrine, no delegation of State power to a religious body and no detailed monitoring and close administrative contact between secular and religious bodies, does not violate the nonentanglement command.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Notice to Attorney-General of Sale of Church Property - Freedom of Religion Religious Corporations Law § 12 and 2-b (1) (d-1), which provide that certain churches are required to notify the Attorney-General when obtaining leave of court to sell, mortgage or lease real property, do not violate the Freedom of Religion Clause. The notice requirement has no effect on and places no burden on the members of the church to practice their religion--either by pressuring them to commit some act forbidden by their religion or by preventing them from engaging in conduct mandated by their faith. Any inquiry by the Attorney-General only involves the terms of the real estate transaction; it involves no inquiry into religious beliefs nor does it involve the regulation or prohibition of conduct undertaken for religious reasons.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Notice to Attorney-General of Sale of Church Property - Discrimination among Religions Religious Corporations Law § 12 and 2-b (1) (d-1), which require that certain churches, including plaintiff Greek Orthodox Church, notify the Attorney-General when obtaining leave of court to sell, mortgage or lease real property, while other churches which are hierarchically structured are not required to notify the Attorney-General, do not discriminate between religious denominations since they meet a compelling State interest and are narrowly tailored. Hierarchically structured churches must obtain approval by their top executive to protect against abuse in the transfer of real property and the statutory notice affords nonhierarchical corporations the same type of safeguards, thereby satisfying a compelling State interest. Also, the statute is narrowly tailored, particularly as applied to plaintiff church, which failed to notify the Attorney-General of a sale of real property, since plaintiff failed to prove it is a hierarchical church, and did not demonstrate that the church structure protects its members from abuses in the transfer of real property. Where the particular church does not assure that its members have an opportunity to review the sale of real property, the statute provides for notice to the Attorney-General to allow the Attorney-General to perform that role in a particular proceeding. As such, the de minimis statutory obligation of notice to the Attorney-General is narrowly tailored to meet its objectives.

 

816 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Griffin


Dkt. No. 94K046646


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 764; 617 N.Y.S.2d 440; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 435



September 19, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended December 13, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss a charge of aggravated failure to appear or pay traffic fines under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511-d.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's motion to dismiss a charge of aggravated failure to appear or pay traffic fines under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511-d was denied because proof that defendant received notice of his license suspension was not required. Defendant contended that mailing of a notice of suspension upon failure to appear did not establish that he had received actual notice. The court held that actual notice was not necessary because N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511-d was a strict liability statute. The court declined to address constitutional issues because a trial court should presume legislation to be constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charge because proof of receipt of a suspension notice was not necessary to establish the offense.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Revocation or Suspension of Operator's License - Aggravated Failure to Answer Appearance Tickets Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511-d, which provides that a person is guilty of aggravated failure to answer appearance tickets when he has in effect 20 or more suspensions, imposed on at least 20 separate dates, for failure to answer a summons, is a strict liability statute and proof of notice of suspensions is not required in order to prosecute the defendant for violating the section. The Legislature clearly omitted from section 511-d any language referring to mental culpability. Moreover, section 511-d's reference to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 226 does not build a notice requirement into section 511-d. Section 226 (3) (a), pertaining to the suspension of the privilege to drive for failing to answer, does not include a notice requirement; although section 226 (3) (b), which provides for a default conviction, imposes a notice requirement, it is inapplicable here since the People are proceeding under section 226 (3) (a) rather than section 226 (3) (b).

 

817 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Citizens for a Safer Community v. City of Rochester


Index #93-08421


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 822; 627 N.Y.S.2d 193; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 671



September 16, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff community group and defendant city sought summary judgment in plaintiff's action against defendant seeking to have a gun control ordinance declared invalid and illegal and to permanently enjoin defendant from enforcing the law.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff community group brought an action against defendant city in which it sought to have a gun control ordinance declared invalid and illegal. Plaintiffs and defendant sought summary judgment. The court found that the gun control ordinance did not constitute an impermissible ban but rather a reasonable regulation as to place and circumstances of possession. The court held that defendant had the right to enforce the ordinance to the extent that it restricted the possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns, possessed simultaneously with ammunition feeding devices, resulting in a combined capacity of six rounds or more, and/or with the specified accessories. The court found that the defendant had the right to enforce the rest of the ordinance except for the portions that sought to regulate guns made by certain manufacturers and to regulate air guns and imitation weapons.


OUTCOME: The court found that defendant city had the right to enforce the gun control ordinance to the extent that it restricted the possession of certain guns. The court found for plaintiff community group in part, holding that defendant could not enforce the portions of the ordinance which regulated specific manufacturers' guns, air guns, and imitation weapons.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Right to Bear Arms - Validity of Municipal Gun Control Law A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is a valid exercise of the police power that does not violate the Second Amendment to the United States Constitution. The Second Amendment limits only the power of Congress to infringe upon the right to keep and bear arms necessary for the militia; it creates no bar to State or local action. Furthermore, plaintiffs' Second Amendment challenge to the ordinance must also fail since all members of the military as well as military uses of firearms are exempted under the express terms of the ordinance, the guns subject to the law are not military weapons, and plaintiffs have not alleged that they are members of the State or Federal National Guard, nor that the banned weapons are in use by these military groups. Moreover, the State and Federal National Guard constitute the "well regulated militia" of the Second Amendment.

Civil Rights - Right to Bear Arms - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is a lawful exercise of the police power that does not contravene Civil Rights Law § 4 which establishes the right to keep and bear arms for a "well regulated militia". Plaintiffs have failed to meet the burden of demonstrating that the weapons proscribed by the ordinance will be used for the purpose specified in Civil Rights Law § 4 and that they have more than a mere technical association with an unorganized, reserve militia.

Municipal Corporations - Control of Guns - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is a lawful exercise of the police power. The ordinance does not constitute a ban on all military-style rifles without regard to the circumstances of possession, but rather a reasonable regulation as to place and circumstances of possession.

Statutes - Federal Preemption - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is a lawful exercise of the police power that is not preempted by Federal law because of conflicts with the Civilian Marksmanship Program (10 USC §§ 4307-4317). There is no conflict between the stated purposes of the Program, which permits participating gun clubs to store and possess certain weapons so long as they are stored in conformity with local law (32 CFR 543.17), and the challenged ordinance. Furthermore, since there are no licensed shooting galleries or ranges within defendant City, no competition or training conducted under the auspices of the Program could occur within the City limits, the only geographical area in which the law is applicable.

Local Laws - Preemption by State - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is a lawful exercise of the police power that is not preempted by State gun control laws. The State has not, either directly or indirectly, regulated all aspects of gun possession and use as to time, place and circumstance. General Municipal Law § 139-d, which regulates commercial storage of firearms and explosives, does not evince a legislative intent to prohibit regulation by a municipality of the individual possession of semiautomatic rifles or shotguns. However, local regulation of "air guns", spring guns, and imitation arms is preempted by State and Federal laws (General Business Law § 871 [2]; 15 USC § 5001 [g]).

Constitutional Law - Taking of Property - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber and which limits an individual from selling a gun within the City except through a licensed gun dealer, is a lawful exercise of the police power and does not constitute a taking of property and an unlawful interference with the dominion and control of a property. The ordinance does not in any way seek to control the disposition of a licensed firearm within the City, nor does it seek to control any intrafamily transfer of a gun. The ordinance imposes no limits on gunsmiths or licensed gun dealers and imposes no fees on the transfer of any gun.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber and which limits an individual from selling a gun within the City except through a licensed gun dealer, is a lawful exercise of the police power. Constitutional free speech rights are not violated by the ordinance's limitation on the private advertisement for sale of guns within the City. Regulation of commercial speech that is narrowly tailored, as here, to achieve the legitimate governmental purpose of limiting the proliferation of illegally possessed firearms, is not violative of constitutional free speech rights.

Municipal Corporations - Control of Guns - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns - No Infringement on Right to Self-Defense A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is a lawful exercise of the police power that does not unlawfully infringe upon the right to self-defense. The limitation of the kinds of guns or the number of rounds available in a single magazine, detailed in the ordinance, is not an important component of self-defense. Therefore, the ordinance has no impact on the statutory right to defend oneself.

Declaratory Judgments - When Remedy Appropriate - Validity of Chemical Testing Provision of Municipal Gun Control Ordinance A declaratory judgment action is not a proper remedy to determine the validity of a municipal gun control ordinance which, inter alia, provides for chemical testing for the alcohol and drug content of the blood of individuals possessing firearms, rifles, shotguns, or air guns in public places. Plaintiffs have shown no controversy involving an immediate threat of injury arising from the obligation to consent to blood or alcohol tests as required by the ordinance and they therefore lack standing to seek declaratory relief relative to this provision.

Municipal Corporations - Control of Guns - Delegation of Authority to Chief of Police A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, specifically provides that the chief of police may grant permits to persons seeking to shoot clay pigeons or to target shoot at ranges, does not create an invalid delegation of legislative authority to the chief of police. Rather, the ordinance grants the chief of police authority of a very specific nature, reasonably limited, in relation to the complexity of the particular area to be regulated.

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is violative of equal protection to the extent that it further prohibits certain specifically named assault weapons without regard to magazine capacity while excluding other identical assault-type weapons produced by different manufacturers. While the regulation of various types of weapons may be related to a legitimate State purpose, the ordinance's unequal treatment of identical weapons cannot withstand an equal protection challenge since there is no difference in the danger posed to society by identical guns produced by different manufacturers, and no such distinction can be found through an exercise of reason. Accordingly, to the extent that the ordinance names individual weapons and excludes others that are identical, it may not be enforced by the City.

Judgments - Summary Judgment - Submission of Sworn Proof In a declaratory judgment action to determine the validity of a municipal gun control ordinance, defendant City sufficiently resisted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment by submitting sworn proof in the form of an affidavit of a City official which sets forth the items, facts, and primary sources of information upon which the City Council relied in adopting the legislation. The City Council was not limited to enacting legislation only upon sworn evidence.

Municipal Corporations - Control of Guns - Regulation of Semiautomatic Rifles and Shotguns A municipal gun control ordinance, which, inter alia, proscribes possession of semiautomatic rifles and shotguns having ammunition feeding devices permitting them to be loaded with a combination of more than six rounds in the feeding device and chamber, is a valid exercise of the police power since there is a rational relationship between the control of semiautomatic weapons and and a legitimate municipal interest. The underlying investigation conducted by the City Council presented a state of facts from which a rational relationship between the ordinance and a legitimate municipal interest may be presumed.
