Municipal Corporations - Control of Guns - Regulation of "Air Guns" - Vagueness The portion of a municipal gun control ordinance which seeks to regulate "air guns" is vague and overbroad, and thus unenforceable, to the extent that the ordinance's definition of "air guns" would include and make criminal, not only traditional "air guns", but also such items as staple and nailing guns, slingshots, and many toys. When read as a whole, the law does not give individuals within the City reasonable notice of prohibited conduct. Those charged with enforcement of the law would almost certainly be compelled to discriminatory enforcement to avoid an otherwise unintended result of arresting all housing contractors, handymen, and many of the City's children for technical violations of the law.

 

818 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Schrader


Docket No. 94N020237


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 789; 617 N.Y.S.2d 429; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 445



September 9, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought dismissal of the accusatory instrument charging him with violating N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 21, § 1050.6(b)(2), by begging in the New York City transit system, as violative of freedom of speech as guaranteed by the N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with one count of unlawful solicitation, or begging, in the subway, in violation of N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 21, § 1050.6(b)(2). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument on grounds that the city transit authority rule, which banned all begging in the New York City transit system, was violative of freedom of speech as guaranteed by the N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8. The court reviewed the scope of the freedom of speech under the state constitution and, while it agreed that the state constitution granted greater protection to the individual liberties and rights of its citizens than the Federal Constitution, denied defendant's motion, concluding that the rule did not violate defendant's freedom of speech under the New York Constitution. The court reasoned that while begging was a form of protected speech, the transit system was a nonpublic forum, open only to limited speech activities, and expressly not extended to begging. Because the regulation against begging was reasonable, to provide safe and efficient transportation to passengers, the restriction was not violative of the state constitution.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion because the rule did not violate defendant's freedom of speech under the New York Constitution; while begging was a form of protected speech, the transit system was a nonpublic forum, open only to limited speech activities, and expressly not extended to begging.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Speech - Validity of Ban on Begging in New York City Transit System A rule of the New York City Transit Authority which bans all begging in the New York City transit system (21 NYCRR 1050.6 [b] [2]), but allows solicitation for needy causes by registered charities, is not unconstitutional as violative of freedom of speech as guaranteed by the New York Constitution (art I, § 8), whether the ban on begging is viewed as content-based or merely as an incidental restriction on expressive activity. The Authority's ban on begging satisfies the constitutional requirement that a government restriction on access in a nonpublic forum, such as the transit system, be reasonable and viewpoint neutral. While begging is constitutionally protected speech, begging can lawfully be banned within the limited boundaries of the transit system as a reasonable safety precaution. Furthermore, the distinction made between beggars and organized charities is a reasonable one in light of the nature and function of the transit system. The inherently alarming quality of solicitations by individual beggars approaching passengers in close and confined passageways and on narrow platforms is an intrinsically dangerous situation, both in terms of potential accidents and in terms of increased assaults and thefts. Additionally, registered charities may be investigated and overseen, limiting the risk of fraudulent solicitations.

 

819 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Perez


Indictment No. 967/85


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 750; 616 N.Y.S.2d 928; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 426



September 6, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: First Revision October 31, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to vacate conviction for possession of narcotics with intent to sell pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10(1)(h) and the court's inherent power to issue a writ of error coram nobis, seeking retroactive application of caselaw to her case in which direct appeal had been concluded.


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved to vacate conviction pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10(1)(h). The court found that defendant satisfied none of the elements to vacate the conviction pursuant to § 440.10(1)(h). Defendant did not object to the language of the charge on an element of the crime. Defendant's motion to dismiss for lack of evidence made no reference to her knowledge of the weight of the narcotics, thus at no point during trial did defendant preserve that specific issue for appellate review. Nor did defendant's appeal raise the specific issue that she presented in this motion. At trial the prosecution based their case on the "drug factory" statutory presumption in N.Y. Penal Law § 220.25(2), which was subsequently interpreted, but not amended or found unconstitutional. The court refused to determine retroactive effects of that case as irrelevant. The writ of error coram nobis was denied, as abrogated by § 440.10.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to vacate judgment of conviction was denied because defendant failed to satisfy any element of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10(1)(h). Defendant's motion to vacate based on the writ of error coram nobis was denied because that common law writ was abrogated by § 440.10.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Vacatur of Judgement of Conviction A judgment convicting defendant of criminal possession of a controlled substance based upon the "drug factory" statutory presumption of possession (Penal Law § 220.25 [2]) should not be vacated under CPL 440.10 (1) (h) as having been obtained in violation of due process of law because the trial court failed to instruct the jury on her knowledge of the weight of the narcotic allegedly possessed pursuant to People v Ryan (82 NY2d 497). Defendant did not register any objection to the language used by the court in defining the elements of each crime and the People's burden with respect to each element, and stated a single general objection to the fact that the room presumption was charged. Moreover, defendant's motion to dismiss for lack of evidence made no reference whatever to the specific issue of knowledge of the weight of the narcotics. Thus, defendant did not preserve for appellate review the specific issue whether the People adduced legally sufficient evidence establishing that she had knowledge of the weight of the narcotics (CPL 470.05 [2]). Nor did defendant's appeal raise the specific issue which she raises in this motion.

Crimes - Controlled Substances - Effect of People v Ryan on "Drug Factory" Presumption The statutory "drug factory" presumption (Penal Law § 220.25 [2]) of "knowing possession" of a narcotic drug in open view in a room by each and every person in close proximity to the narcotic drug at the time of discovery is unaffected by the holding in People v Ryan (82 NY2d 497) that "knowing possession" as used in Penal Law article 220 includes knowledge of both the nature and weight of the substance possessed and, therefore, that there is a mens rea element associated with the weight of drug. The clear and unambiguous purpose of section 220.25 (2) is to provide proof of knowing possession for narcotics found in the specific circumstances delineated in the statute. To limit the applicability of the presumption to the nature of the substance, and thereby exclude it from the quantity, ignores the language of the statute and eviscerates the intent of the Legislature. Accordingly, where defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance based upon the "drug factory" presumption, it cannot be said with respect to her CPL 440.10 motion to vacate the judgment of conviction after the direct appeal process had been concluded through retroactive application of the Ryan holding that there has been, since the appeal a retroactively effective change in the law controlling such issue.

Crimes - Vacatur of Judgment of Conviction - Retroactive Application of People v Ryan - Failure to Preserve Issue or Pursue Issue in Perfected Appeal Where defendant was convicted of criminal possession of a controlled substance based upon the "drug factory" presumption of possession (Penal Law § 220.25 [2]), her motion pursuant to CPL 440.10 (2) (a) to vacate the judgment of conviction made after the direct appeal process had been concluded seeking retroactive application to her case of People v Ryan (82 NY2d 497) cannot be entertained. An appellate court, evaluating defendant's claim of error at the trial, clearly would have found sufficient facts within the four corners of the record of defendant's trial to adjudicate defendant's claim. Defendant failed to preserve the issue in the trial court and to pursue the specific issue in the appeal which was eventually perfected. Such unjustifiable failure cannot serve to expand appellate review through collateral attack in direct contravention of CPL 440.10 (2) (c).

Crimes - Vacatur of Judgment of Conviction - Writ of Error Coram Nobis A motion by defendant to vacate the judgment convicting her of criminal possession of a controlled substance based on the court's inherent power to issue a writ of error coram nobis is denied. The claim of error asserted--that the People presented no evidence at trial of her knowledge of the weight of the heroin she allegedly possessed in contravention of the holding in People v Ryan (82 NY2d 497), which she seeks to have retroactively applied to her case in which the direct appeal process has been concluded--is covered by CPL 440.10 and, thus, resort to coram nobis is unavailable.

 

820 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Poplaski


Index Nos. 8454-57/94, 13038-39/94


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, FIRST DISTRICT, NASSAU COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 209; 616 N.Y.S.2d 434; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 372



August 17, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed an application for an order dismissing an accusatory statement, claiming that it violated his rights under the First, Fifth, Sixth, and Fourteenth Amendments of the United States Constitution.


OVERVIEW: Defendant allegedly contacted six boys ranging in age from 12 to 15, through a computer bulletin board. Once he made contact, defendant had numerous phone conversations with said children where he claimed an ability to hypnotize them and directed them to masturbate. Defendant was arrested and charged him with four counts of endangering the welfare of a child. Defendant maintained that the police coerced him into making his statement and into consenting to a search of his residence. The court held that defendant's right to free speech was not violated. The government's interest in protecting children was firmly established in case law and the restrictions on defendant's right to have sexually explicit conversations with children was not constitutionally guaranteed. The court also denied defendant's motion to dismiss the complaints on the grounds that they were duplicitous.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motions to dismiss the accusatory statements against him because the criminal informations satisfied the statutory requirements and the informations were not conclusory and therefore were sufficient. Plaintiff was not required to provide depositions, expert or otherwise, stating how the alleged phone conversations were injurious to the moral welfare of children.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Endangering Welfare of Child - Engaging in Sexual Conversations on Telephone - Freedom of Speech Defendant was appropriately charged with a violation of Penal Law § 260.10 (1), endangering the welfare of a child, for allegedly calling children on the telephone and engaging in sexual conversations. The statute is not an unconstitutional restriction on defendant's right to free speech. The legislative intent of this statute is to protect the physical health, morals, and well-being of children, and defendant's alleged solicitude relates not only to sexual offenses but to other dangers as well. Also, nothing in the language of the statute, its legislative history, or the case law indicates this statute is meant to curtail acts and not speech and, thus, the statute does proscribe defendant's alleged activity. In addition, the right to free speech is not absolute. Where there is a compelling State interest, such as the interest here to protect the well-being of children, restrictions on speech may exist.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Endangering Welfare of Child - Overbreadth - Vagueness Penal Law § 260.10 (1), endangering the welfare of a child, is not overly broad or vague and, thus, defendant was appropriately charged with a violation of section 260.10 (1) when he allegedly called children on the telephone and engaged in sexual conversations. In order for a statute to be constitutional, the statute must give notice to the accused of the illegality of his act. Section 260.10 (1) uses ordinary terms to express ideas which find adequate interpretation in common usage and understanding. The statute gives notice that a person may not knowingly engage in conduct which is likely to be injurious to the physical, mental, or moral welfare of a child. Here, defendant knowingly contacted six children between the ages of 12 and 15 and allegedly encouraged, instructed and directed them to masturbate. This is precisely the sort of behavior that the statute intends to prohibit.

Crimes - Information - Sufficiency of Information Charging Endangering Welfare of Child The criminal information charging defendant with violations of Penal Law § 260.10 (1), endangering the welfare of a child, for allegedly calling children on the telephone and engaging in sexual conversations, satisfies CPL 100.15 and 100.40 and, therefore, should not be dismissed. CPL 100.15 and 100.40 require that the information contain both an accusatory part designating the offenses charged and a factual part containing nonhearsay allegations which provide reasonable cause to believe that the defendant committed the offense. The information in this case contains both parts. In addition, the information is not conclusory. Although the People did not provide depositions stating how the alleged phone conversations were injurious to the moral welfare of the children, the victims' depositions describe in detail what, when and how the defendant committed the alleged crimes.

Crimes - Information - Duplicitous Information - Endangering Welfare of Child - Crime Committed by Multiple Acts The criminal information charging defendant with violations of Penal Law § 260.10 (1), endangering the welfare of a child, for allegedly calling children on the telephone and engaging in sexual conversations, was not duplicitous. CPL 200.30 prohibits duplicitous counts in accusatory instruments, requiring that each count of an indictment may charge only one offense. Crimes which by nature may be committed either by a single act or by multiple acts do not necessarily encompass more than one offense and are not duplicitous. Endangering the welfare of a child by its nature may be committed by multiple acts, and readily permits characterization as a continuing offense over a period of time. Thus, the fact that the depositions contain allegations of more than one conversation with the complainants does not render the information duplicitous.

Crimes - Information - Duplicitous Information - Endangering Welfare of Child - Sufficiency of Notice of Time, Place and Manner of Offense Charged The criminal information charging defendant with violations of Penal Law § 260.10 (1), endangering the welfare of a child, for allegedly calling children on the telephone and engaging in sexual conversations, was not duplicitous or in violation of US Constitution Sixth Amendment and NY Constitution, article I, § 6 on the ground that it failed to provide the accused with fair notice of the charges and the manner, time and place of the underlying conduct in order to allow the defendant to prepare a defense. The depositions alleging phone conversations "about one year ago" and "during the month of November 1993" do give defendant sufficient notice of the charges against him. Unless a date is itself an essential ingredient of the crime, it is not vital to the sufficiency of an indictment. Here, the supporting depositions and informations set forth the approximate date and time of each violation. Moreover, each information alleges a different offense involving a different victim, and notifies defendant of the charges against him, the place of the occurrence, and how defendant perpetrated the crime.

 

821 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grumet v. Cuomo


Index No. 4210-94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 913; 617 N.Y.S.2d 620; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 448



August 9, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Revised November 4, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff individuals filed an action against defendant state that sought a declaration that 1994 N.Y. Laws 241 and 279 were unconstitutional. The individuals applied for a temporary restraining order and for preliminary injunctive relief enjoining implementation of chapters 241 and 279.


OVERVIEW: The individuals contended that 1994 N.Y. Laws 241 and 279, which was enacted when the United States Supreme Court found that 1989 N.Y. Laws 748 violated the Establishment of Religion Clause of the First Amendment of the United States Constitution, was unconstitutional as well. The court held that facially, under chapters 241 and 279, the conditions established for the creation of the new school district were religion-neutral, reasonable and appropriate, and effectuated a legitimate state function. The manner in which the new school district was to be created further assured a religion-neutral shield to the new legislation. The court held that the individuals had not demonstrated the irreparable harm required in order for a temporary restraining order to have been granted. Nor had the individuals met their heavy burden of likelihood of ultimate success. The court noted that but for a declaration of unconstitutionality, the relief sought was exactly the relief sought by the individuals in their complaint.


OUTCOME: The court denied the individuals' application for a temporary restraining order.


HEADNOTES

Injunctions - Temporary Restraining Order - Enjoining Funding and Operation of New School District Plaintiffs are not entitled to a temporary restraining order to enjoin funding and operation of a school district, formed under chapters 241 and 279 of the Laws of 1994 and located in a municipality comprised mostly of Hasidic Jews. The relief requested is the same relief sought by plaintiffs in their complaint, but for a declaration that the statutes are unconstitutional. Temporary injunctions which give the same relief expected to be obtained by final judgment are granted with caution and only when required by urgent situations or grave necessity, and then only on the clearest of evidence. First, plaintiffs have not met their heavy burden of likelihood of ultimate success on the merits. Facially, the conditions established by the Legislature for the creation of new school districts under chapter 241 appear religion-neutral, reasonable, and appropriate, and effectuate a legitimate State function. Second, plaintiffs' claim, as citizen-taxpayers, that they will suffer irreparable harm because moneys for the school year will be unconstitutionally disbursed and expended is meritless. No harm is apparent inasmuch as the State aid will be disbursed for the education of the children regardless of the school district they attend. Third, the balance of equities does not favor plaintiffs. An injunction would have serious disruptive effects on defendants and the children. In addition, dissolution of the school district pending the outcome would cause administrative expense and disruption for no practical reason and to no effect.

 

822 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Glendora v. Kofalt


Index No. 3288/94


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 166; 616 N.Y.S.2d 138; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 365; 76 Rad. Reg. 2d (P & F) 827



July 28, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 3, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff filmmaker filed an action in the Supreme Court of New York, seeking monetary damages and equitable relief from defendant cable company for its refusal to broadcast portions of her films. The cable company sought a grant of its motion to dismiss the complaint, or a declaratory judgment that N.Y. Exec. Law § 829(3) unconstitutionally infringed its free speech interests and press rights, and, alternatively, was preempted by federal law.


OVERVIEW: The filmmaker filed an action against the cable company, seeking equitable relief and damages, after it refused to air portions of the filmmaker's non-obscene films. The court granted the filmmaker's cross-motion to compel the broadcast of her film but dismissed the remainder of the action. The court held that (1) N.Y. Exec. Law § 829(c) was not preempted by the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984, Pub. L. No. 98-549, codified at 47 U.S.C.S. § 521 et seq., because both merely forbade the cable company from editing non-obscene programming on public educational and government (PEG) access channels; (2) N.Y. Exec. Law § 829(c) did not abridge the cable company's free speech rights because it contained a content-neutral prohibition against editorial control of PEG channel programming that burdened no more speech than was necessary to promote the substantial government interest in fostering public programming; (3) The filmmaker was collaterally estopped from pursuing federal constitutional claims that she had already litigated; and (4) The filmmaker lacked standing to claim that the cable company violated her N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8 rights because it was not a state actor.


OUTCOME: The court granted the filmmaker's cross-motion to compel the broadcast of her films, but dismissed the remainder of the action. A state law did not infringe upon the cable company's free speech rights by prohibiting it from censoring non-obscene material submitted for broadcast on PEG access channels because it burdened no more speech than was necessary to promote the substantial government interest in fostering public programming.


HEADNOTES

Radio and Television - Cable Television - Censorship Prohibited on Public Access Channels - No Federal Preemption Plaintiff's action for equitable relief and monetary damages based upon defendant cable television company's cancellation of plaintiff's scheduled public access program, allegedly in violation of Executive Law § 829 (3), which prohibits censorship on public access channels, is not preempted by the Federal Cable Television Consumer Protection Act of 1992 (Pub L 102-385, amending 47 USC § 521 et seq.). The Federal law also forbids a cable operator from exercising editorial control over public access programming unless the programming contains obscene or sexually explicit materials or materials soliciting or promoting unlawful conduct. Plaintiff's program only involved allegations of misconduct by a home improvement contractor. In the absence of any allegations that plaintiff's program is obscene, sexually explicit, or that it solicits or promotes unlawful conduct, there is no conflict between the operations of the State and Federal statutes. In either case, defendant is prohibited from exercising editorial control over public access programming.

Radio and Television - Cable Television - Prohibition against Censorship of Public Access Programming Not Violative of Cable Operator's Constitutional Right to Freedom of Speech Executive Law § 829 (3), which prohibits a cable operator from exercising editorial control over its public educational and government access programming, does not unconstitutionally abridge defendant cable television company's First Amendment right to freedom of speech so as to require dismissal of plaintiff's action for equitable relief and monetary damages based upon defendant's alleged violation of the statute in refusing to broadcast on its public access channel material submitted by plaintiff. The statute's incidental restriction on the First Amendment rights of cable operators survives constitutional scrutiny under the intermediate balancing test applicable to such a content-neutral regulation since the regulation promotes the substantial governmental interest of enhancing and encouraging public interest in cable television by providing speakers with lesser market appeal access to cable systems.

Judgments - Collateral Estoppel - Cable Operator's Refusal to Broadcast Public Access Programming In plaintiff's action for equitable relief and monetary damages based upon defendant cable television company's refusal to broadcast on its public access channel material submitted by plaintiff, the causes of action alleging a violation of plaintiff's constitutionally protected rights to freedom of speech and press are dismissed on collateral estoppel grounds. The determination made in plaintiff's related Federal action that plaintiff did not state a claim under the United States Constitution because defendants were private persons and not State actors bars plaintiff from relitigating that issue in this action. Similarly, the lack of State involvement also bars any State constitutional claims. The fact that a cable company is considered a public utility does not imbue any of the defendants with the power or authority of the State.

Negligence - What Constitutes - Cable Operator's Cancellation of Scheduled Public Access Programming In plaintiff's action for equitable relief and monetary damages based upon defendant cable television company's refusal to broadcast on its public access channel material submitted by plaintiff, the cause of action alleging that defendants were negligent in cancelling plaintiff's scheduled programming must be dismissed since the undisputed facts clearly demonstrate that defendants intentionally cancelled plaintiff's program.

Libel and Slander - Actionable Words - Cable Operator's Cancellation of Scheduled Public Access Programming In plaintiff's action for equitable relief and monetary damages based upon defendant cable television company's refusal to broadcast on its public access channel material submitted by plaintiff, the cause of action alleging damage to plaintiff's reputation must be dismissed since the complaint does not allege, nor do the facts indicate, that defendants engaged in either libel or slander.

Negligence - Negligent Infliction of Emotional Distress - Cable Operator's Cancellation of Scheduled Public Access Programming In plaintiff's action for equitable relief and monetary damages based upon defendant cable television company's refusal to broadcast on its public access channel material submitted by plaintiff involving allegations of misconduct by a home improvement contractor, the cause of action alleging negligent and intentional infliction of mental disturbance must be dismissed in the absence of any proof that plaintiff suffers from any definite physical symptoms purporting to indicate any mental injury caused by defendants' conduct.

 

823 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Carmille A. v. David A.


Docket No.: O-9699/92


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 22; 615 N.Y.S.2d 584; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 342



July 26, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner wife filed a supplemental petition, alleging that respondent husband failed to obey a modified order of protection. At the dispositional phase of the supplemental proceeding brought under N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 846, the court civilly committed the husband to two terms of incarceration, for six months and four months to run consecutively. The husband filed a motion, seeking reargument of the dispositional order.


OVERVIEW: The husband argued that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 8 did not authorize imposition of consecutive commitments. He cited a recent decision of the Third Department, which stated that in its view the statute, on its face, prohibited consecutive commitments. The court found that the holding, in a practical sense, constituted a judicial fiat that regardless of the number of separate willful violations committed by a respondent under an extant order of protection, the respondent risked civil commitment under Family Court auspices for only up to six months. The court declared that study of the legislative history underlying article 8 and the plain language of the statute as well as the public policy imbued therein prompted the conclusion that the appellate court in the recent decision engaged in judicial legislation. The court concluded that it was not bound by the holding. The court found that the grant of authority in N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act §§ 846 and 846-a implicitly invoked the power to make such commitments run concurrently or consecutively where appropriate.


OUTCOME: The court denied the husband's motion seeking reargument of the dispositional order. The court concluded that it had the authority to issue consecutive civil commitments for willful distinct and separate violations of the order of protection, albeit the total term of the consecutive commitments exceeded six months.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child - Order of Protection - Imposition of Consecutive Commitments Exceeding Six Months for Distinct Violations Pursuant to Family Court Act § 846-a, a guilty respondent may be committed to jail for a term not to exceed six months for each separate failure to obey an order of protection, and such commitments may run concurrently or consecutively. Moreover, two individual contempts committed with respect to one order of protection constitute separate offenses for Sixth Amendment purposes and, therefore, the imposition of consecutive commitments for those contempts in excess of a total period of six months does not invoke jury trial relief applicable where the potential sentence for a criminal offense exceeds six months' imprisonment.

 

824 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Tug Buster Bouchard Corp. v. Wetzler


Index No. 7649-92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 474



July 19, 1994, Decided  
July 27, 1994, Filed


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, tug corporations, commenced a proceeding pursuant to N.Y.C.P.L.R. 78, seeking an order cancelling the notices of deficiency issued by respondent, the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance, against them. The corporations also sought a declaration that § 301 of the New York Tax Law was unconstitutional, and directing the Department to reimburse them for attorney's fees incurred in connection with the litigation.


OVERVIEW: The corporations alleged that § 301 of the New York Tax Law was unconstitutional on the ground that it facially discriminated against interstate commerce in violation of the Commerce Clause of the U.S. Constitution and 42 U.S.C.S. §1983. Their recoupment of attorney's fees for litigation was sought pursuant to 42 U.S.C.S. § 1988. Based on the corporations' verified petition and attached exhibits, their memorandum of law in support of the petition, the department's answer, the corporations' reply and attached exhibits, the corporations' reply memorandum of law, the department's memorandum of law, and the corporations' supplemental memorandum of law, the court granted the petition, excepting recovery of attorney's fees pursuant to § 1988.


OUTCOME: The court granted the corporations' petition, cancelling the notices of deficiency issued by the department. The court also declared the New York Tax Law facially discriminated against interstate commerce in violation of the Commerce Clause and that the statute was, therefore, unconstitutional. Attorney's fees pursuant to § 1988 were denied, but the corporations were awarded motion costs, all costs and disbursements incurred from the litigation.

 

825 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Great Expectations Creative Management v. Attorney-General of New York


Index No: 5844/92 001, Motion No. 31


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 352; 616 N.Y.S.2d 917; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 404



July 11, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff dating service sought a declaratory judgment in the Supreme Court of New York, New York County, that its activities would not be subject to N.Y. Gen. Bus. Law § 394-c because it did not engage in "social referral services" as defined in the statute and argued that the statute was unconstitutionally vague and that the regulations constituted unconstitutional price control.


OVERVIEW: The dating service wanted to bring its operations to New York, but brought this action to determine if the controlling statute would be applicable to its operations. The court rejected the dating service's assertion that because they did not actually do the "matching" of the people, they should not be subject to the statute. The court found that the statute applied to not only those who did the matching, but also agencies (such as the dating service) that made available the means for persons to do their own matching. The court concluded that the statute therefore would apply to any operations that the dating service set up in the state. The court concluded that the price restrictions in the statute were constitutional because the legislature was operating within the bounds of their police power when they sought to guard against abuse in a limited manner as a matter of public policy.


OUTCOME: The court held that the statute would be applicable to the dating service's proposed operations, that it was a constitutional exercise of the state's police powers, that it was not vague or ambiguous, and that it did not constitute unconstitutional price control.


HEADNOTES

Declaratory Judgments - When Remedy Appropriate - Declaration That Business Not Engaged in Regulated Conduct - Statute Regulating Social Referral Services Plaintiff, a videotape dating service planning to commence operations in New York, may maintain a declaratory judgment action pursuant to CPLR 3001 seeking to obtain a declaration that it does not engage in "social referral services" so as to subject it to regulation under General Business Law § 394-c. Plaintiff is not attempting to obtain an advisory opinion. Rather, plaintiff should not be required to expend substantial funds, enter into contracts, acquire facilities, hire employees and do advertising before knowing whether it must conform its activities to a regulatory statute, which it challenges both as to scope and validity. When, as here, there is a genuine controversy as to disputed relations, a declaratory judgment as to future obligations, which would enable parties to avoid loss and injury, is appropriate.

Consumer Protection - Social Referral Services - Regulation of Videotape Dating Service Plaintiff, a videotape dating service planning to commence operations in New York, engages in "social referral services" and would thus be subject to regulation under General Business Law § 394-c, which covers any service for a fee "providing matching of members of the opposite sex, by use of computer or any other means, for the purposes of dating and general social contact". The scope of the statute is not limited to service agencies which actively match individuals, but encompasses those agencies, such as plaintiff, which make available the means for persons to do their own matching. Plaintiff is acting more than a mere computer "dater bank" when it makes the matching of members available by use of its technological facilities. Furthermore, the adoption by the Legislature of the language "any other means" contemplated that matching could be made by techniques or technologies which were unknown at the time of the statute's enactment in 1971.

Consumer Protection - Social Referral Services - Validity of Regulatory Statute General Business Law § 394-c, which subjects to regulation any "social referral service" which, for a fee, provides "matching of members of the opposite sex, by use of computer or any other means, for the purposes of dating and general social contact", is a constitutional exercise of the State's police power to prevent fraudulent and unscrupulous services. In addition, the statute is not unconstitutionally vague or ambiguous. The statutory language conveys sufficiently definite warning as to the proscribed conduct when measured by common understanding and practices. Furthermore, the statutory $ 250 maximum fee limitation does not constitute unconstitutional price control. As long as the Legislature has chosen a limited degree of regulation as a matter of public policy to guard against abuse and exorbitance, the courts may approve legislative price regulation as a legitimate exercise of the police power. Accordingly, plaintiff, a videotape dating service planning to commence operations in New York, would be subject to regulation under the statute.

 

826 of 992 DOCUMENTS


A.S. v. J.G.


Docket No. F-80-93, X-3378-93, Family Unit No. 5840


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, ROCKLAND COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 10; 615 N.Y.S.2d 579; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 319



July 8, 1994, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended September 9, 1994. As Revised.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother challenged an order from the hearing examiner (New York), which declared that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 545(1) was unconstitutional and held that respondent father did not owe child support from the date for which the mother's eligibility for public assistance was first effective and reduced the father's child support obligation.


OVERVIEW: The father was held by the court to be the father of the mother's child and the matter was referred to a hearing examiner for a hearing on support. The hearing examiner denied awarding child support retroactive to the date that the child first received public assistance, as was required by N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 545(1). She held that the statute was unconstitutional in that it permitted child support to be awarded prior to the filing of the petition if the child was in receipt of public assistance, and that it denied equal protection to children who did not receive public assistance. On appeal, the court reversed. The statute involved neither a suspect classification nor a fundamental interest. Children were not treated differently. The child support rights were assigned to the local commissioner if public assistance had been received. The statute did not involve consequences that might be severe or damage that was irreparable. The conclusion of unconstitutionality was not inescapable. The statute was not clearly and unequivocally violative of the constitution and arguments could be advanced to support the enactment's rationality.


OUTCOME: The court reversed the hearing examiner's decision as to the constitutionality of the statute and modified the determination by requiring child support to be retroactive to the last date that the mother's eligibility for public assistance was effective prior to the filing of the paternity petition against the father.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Hearing Examiners - Power to Determine Constitutionality of Statute - Support Order in Paternity Proceeding Involving Child Receiving Public Assistance In a paternity proceeding involving a child receiving public assistance, the Hearing Examiner erred in declaring unconstitutional, as violative of equal protection, the provision of Family Court Act § 545 (1), which mandates that where a child is in receipt of public assistance, child support be awarded retroactively to the "earlier of the date of the application for an order of filiation", or the date for which the child's "eligibility for public assistance was effective". While a Hearing Examiner may, in certain limited circumstances, enter a declaration of unconstitutionality, the Hearing Examiner herein erred in entering such a declaration based only upon the assertion of unconstitutionality made by the pro se respondent without establishing an adequate record or notifying the Attorney-General of the proceeding as required by CPLR 1012 (b). Hearing Examiners and courts of inferior jurisdiction should be very circumspect before making a determination that a statute is unconstitutional. The statute herein is not clearly and unequivocally unconstitutional. In the absence of a complete review of the statutory framework, it cannot be said that the challenged classification lacks a rational basis and bears no reasonable relationship to some legitimate legislative objective.

Children Born out of Wedlock - Paternity Proceeding - Retroactive Support Order Where Child is Receiving Public Assistance Pursuant to Family Court Act § 545 (1), which, in a paternity proceeding involving a child receiving public assistance, requires the court to order support retroactively to the date the child's "eligibility for public assistance was effective", support should only be awarded retroactively to the date for which the eligibility for the public assistance the child is then receiving was effective and should not include prior periods of public assistance that may have occurred many years before. Accordingly, where petitioner first went on public assistance in 1984 and went on and off public assistance several times thereafter, with her last application being from September 18, 1991 to January 29, 1993, the child support order in this paternity proceeding will be retroactive only to September 18, 1991, which was the last date that petitioner's eligibility for public assistance was effective prior to the filing of the paternity petition on February 13, 1992.

 

827 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. State


Index No.: 111070/93, Cal. No.: 45, Index No.: 401210/93, Cal. No.: 53


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 493; 616 N.Y.S.2d 851; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 418



June 21, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 3, 1994.
Modified by Campaign for Fiscal Equity v. State, 205 A.D.2d 272, 619 N.Y.S.2d 699, 1994 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 11329 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, Nov. 15, 1994)
Related proceeding at Hussein v. State of New York, 81 A.D.3d 132, 914 N.Y.S.2d 464, 2011 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 114 (N.Y. App. Div. 3d Dep't, Jan. 13, 2011)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, city and school boards, filed an action against defendant State, seeking a judgment declaring the method for distributing education funds to be unconstitutional and requesting an injunction. The State filed a motion to dismiss the complaints and challenged the legal sufficiency of the pleadings filed by the city and the school boards.


OVERVIEW: The State asserted that the city and the school boards lacked the capacity to bring this action either in their own right or on behalf of other individuals such as schoolchildren. The court noted that the education article of N.Y. Const., art. XI, § 1 was intended to assure only a sound basic education as opposed to a state-wide equality of all public educational facilities and services. The court, thus, concluded that the portion of the complaint, which asserted that the State had not adopted a systematic method for financing education so as to meet the state-wide minimum standards, could possibly warrant judicial interference in the school financing system. The court also determined that the complaints filed by the city and the school boards did not set forth a requisite complaint of intentional discrimination, and thus, application of a rational basis standard mandated dismissal of that portion of the complaints. The court also concluded that a financing system, which was discriminatory in effect albeit not in intent, may have violated civil rights recognized by the N.Y.C.P.L.R. 291(2).


OUTCOME: The court granted the State's motions to dismiss in part. and denied them in part..


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Standing of Municipality and School Boards to Challenge State's Public School Financing System The City of New York and various City Community School Board Districts lack standing to challenge the State's public school financing scheme as violative of equal protection and the education article of the State Constitution (NY Const, art XI, § 1) since they have failed to demonstrate any exception to the general rule that municipalities and school boards, as political subdivisions created by the State, lack the substantive right to challenge the constitutionality of acts of the State Legislature. The municipal plaintiffs have not demonstrated that any State action would require them to violate a constitutional proscription nor do their claims for additional State school funding create proprietary rights under the home rule article of the Constitution (NY Const, art IX) such as would enable them to sue the State. In addition, plaintiffs also lack the capacity to assert the constitutional and statutory claims on behalf of school children who reside within the City.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Constitutionality of Public School Financing System under Education Article - Adherence to Minimum Educational Standards Plaintiffs' challenge to the State's public school financing scheme as violative of the education article of the State Constitution (NY Const, art XI, § 1) states a viable cause of action to the extent that the complaint alleges that education has fallen below the State-wide minimum standard of educational quality and quantity fixed by the Board of Regents because of a "gross and glaring inadequacy" in funding. The education article requires the State to provide public school students with a sound basic education, and the provision of a sound basic education must be equated with adherence to minimum educational standards approved by the Board of Regents.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Constitutionality of Public School Financing System - Equal Protection Heightened Scrutiny Analysis Not Applicable In view of the holding in Board of Educ. v Nyquist (57 NY2d 27) that the State's public school financing scheme does not violate equal protection under the rational basis standard despite disparities in per pupil expenditures caused by differences in the value of assessable property among school districts, plaintiffs' challenge to the current financing system on similar equal protection grounds must be dismissed for failure to state a cause of action. The standard of more careful scrutiny applicable when challenged State action results in intentional discrimination against a class of persons should not be applied to plaintiffs' equal protection claims in the absence of any allegation of intentional discrimination which would trigger a heightened scrutiny analysis.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Validity of Public School Financing System under Federal Civil Rights Act Plaintiffs' challenge to the State's public school financing scheme as violative of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 USC § 2000d et seq.) by creating and perpetuating a dual system which adversely affects the quality of education available to New York City's predominantly minority student body is dismissed for failure to state a cause of action absent a showing of deliberate discrimination. However, plaintiffs state a cause of action to the extent that they allege violations of 34 CFR 100.3, which also prohibits discrimination based upon race, color or national origin but only requires a mere showing of discriminatory effect. Liability under the regulation has been sufficiently pleaded based upon the allegation that a substantial number of students are being deprived of meaningful education on the ground of race, color or national origin.

Schools - State Aid to School Districts - Constitutionality of Public School Financing System under Antidiscrimination Clause Plaintiffs' challenge to the State's public school financing scheme as violative of the constitutional proscription against discrimination in civil rights "because of race, color, creed or religion" (NY Const, art I, § 11) states a viable cause of action in view of the statutory declaration of the "opportunity to obtain education" as a "civil right" (Executive Law § 291 [2]). A system which is discriminatory in effect may violate civil rights recognized by the statute. Accordingly, plaintiffs' discrimination claim is viable without an allegation of discriminatory intent.

 

828 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Tug Buster Bouchard Corp. v. Wetzler


Index No. 7649-92, RJI No. 01-92-ST3892


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SPECIAL TERM, ALBANY COUNTY


1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 473



June 9, 1994, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner corporations filed an action pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 seeking to cancel the various notices of deficiencies issued by respondent Commissioner of the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance declaring N.Y. Tax Law § 301 unconstitutional and directing the Commissioner to reimburse them for attorney's fees.


OVERVIEW: The corporations provided barge and towing services and the vessels operated by the corporations were powered by marine diesel fuel purchased from various suppliers located within the adjoining state. The Commissioner assessed tax deficiencies against the corporations pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 301, known as the Petroleum Business Tax. The corporations argued that the Petroleum Business Tax was unconstitutional in that it violated the Commerce Clause of the United States Constitution by discriminating against interstate commerce. The Commissioner argued that the tax was not a use tax, but a privilege tax. In granting the petition, the court held that the imposition by other states of a tax statute similar to § 301 would have resulted in multiple taxation in situations involving consumers who purchased their fuel from an out-of-state source, which would have had a discriminatory effect against interstate commerce in that it would favor local, intrastate commerce by way of potentially lower intrastate fuel prices than fuel purchased interstate because one less tax would be involved. The court further found that the challenged tax was clearly a "use" tax, not a "privilege" tax.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition filed by the corporations and found the tax unconsitutional.

 

829 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Aumick v. Bane


Index No. 2881/93


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


161 Misc. 2d 271; 612 N.Y.S.2d 766; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 217



May 18, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner public assistance applicants requested class certification in a declaratory judgment action against respondent Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services (commissioner) challenging the validity of N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 158(f).


OVERVIEW: The action was filed on behalf of a proposed class of public assistance applicants and recipients of Home Relief, who had resided in the state of New York for less than six months. Section 158(f) included a durational residency requirement which resulted in lower benefits to needy persons who had been residents for less than six months. The court held that declaratory judgment should be entered finding the statute unconstitutional, found that the applicants were entitled to a permanent injunction, and a restoration of benefits. The court found that the criteria utilized for the classification, namely, residency for a period of six months, was unrelated in any way to the determination of need. The court also determined that the applicants' further application for class action certification should be denied. The parties were unable to demonstrate the number of persons who were adversely affected by the durational residency requirement.


OUTCOME: The court entered declaratory judgment finding a durational residency requirement for the public assistance applicants was unconstitutional, ordered a permanent injunction, a restoration of benefits, and denied the application for class certification in a suit involving the commissioner.


HEADNOTES

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Durational Residency Requirement as Violative of State's Duty to Provide Aid to Needy The amendment to Social Services Law § 158 (f) (L 1992, ch 41), which, effective until July 1, 1994, establishes a durational residency requirement for the Home Relief program, resulting in reduced benefits for needy persons who have been residents of the State for six months or less and have come from States without comparable public assistance benefits, is unconstitutional as violative of the State's constitutional duty to aid the needy (NY Const, art XVII, § 1) since it creates a classification for purposes of Home Relief benefits, residency for a period of six months, that is unrelated in any way to the determination of need.

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Durational Residency Requirement as Violative of State Equal Protection The amendment to Social Services Law § 158 (f) (L 1992, ch 41), which, effective until July 1, 1994, establishes a durational residency requirement for the Home Relief program, resulting in reduced benefits for needy persons who have been residents of the State for six months or less and have come from States without comparable public assistance benefits, is unconstitutional as violative of the equal protection requirements of NY Constitution, article I, § 11. Although the State has a legitimate interest in reducing the public assistance caseload, as well as reducing the cost of the Home Relief program, the accomplishment of such result by arbitrarily denying full benefits to one class of persons, which are available to all other longer term residents, cannot be justified as rationally related to a legitimate State interest.

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Durational Residency Requirement as Violative of Federal Equal Protection and Right to Travel The amendment to Social Services Law § 158 (f) (L 1992, ch 41), which, effective until July 1, 1994, establishes a durational residency requirement for the Home Relief program, resulting in reduced benefits for needy persons who have been residents for six months or less and have come from States without comparable public assistance benefits, is unconstitutional as violative of the right to travel and equal protection, as guaranteed by the United States Constitution. The right to travel is violated by laws deterring migration into a State, or by statutes which seek to penalize the exercise of the right to travel. A statute which, as here, creates a classification which touches on the fundamental right of interstate movement, must be judged by the stricter constitutional standard of whether it promotes a compelling State interest; the conservation of the taxpayers' purse is not a sufficient State interest to sustain a durational residency requirement. In any event, the classification created by the statute does not bear a rational relationship to a legitimate State interest for equal protection purposes.

Social Services - Public Assistance - Home Relief - Unconstitutionality of Six-Month Durational Residency Requirement - Constitutionality of Lack of Notice of Residency Requirement The amendment to Social Services Law § 158 (f) (L 1992, ch 41), which, effective until July 1, 1994, establishes a durational residency requirement for the Home Relief program, resulting in reduced benefits for needy persons who have been residents for six months or less and have come from States without comparable public assistance benefits, is unconstitutional. However, respondents' administrative procedures in failing to provide petitioners with notice of reduced benefits did not constitute a violation of petitioners' due process rights. The initial approval of an application for public assistance, notwithstanding the fact that the grant represents a reduced amount as compared to other residents, must be distinguished from the reduction or termination of benefits after a receipt thereof for a period of time. In any event, one year after the enactment of the law, the local Departments of Social Services were instructed by the State Department of Social Services to provide applicants with notice of the residency limitation at the time of requesting Home Relief benefits.

Actions - Class Actions - Denial of Class Action Certification in Action to Declare Unconstitutional Six-Month Durational Residency Requirement for Home Relief Benefits Although petitioners, who were granted reduced Home Relief benefits pursuant to the six-month durational residency requirement established by the amendment to Social Services Law § 158 (f) (L 1992, ch 41), are granted judgment declaring the statute unconstitutional and are entitled to a restoration of benefits, their application for class action certification pursuant to CPLR 901 (a) is denied in view of the statute's July 1, 1994 expiration date and the fact that the parties are unable to demonstrate the number of persons who have been adversely affected by the durational residency requirement, for purposes of the Home Relief program. In addition, the State has represented that the Department of Social Services would adhere to the doctrine of stare decisis in this case.

 

830 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York State Dep't of Taxation & Fin. v. St. Regis Group


Index No. 93463, IAS No. 44-1-93-0821, Index No. 93476, IAS No. 44-1-93-0824


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ST. LAWRENCE COUNTY


161 Misc. 2d 383; 613 N.Y.S.2d 833; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 238



May 13, 1994, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant companies brought motions for orders dismissing the forfeiture actions, brought against them by plaintiff New York State Department of Taxation and Finance (state), pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(3), for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.


OVERVIEW: The companies contended that exclusive jurisdiction over the seizure cases lied in the federal courts because New York had no jurisdiction to enforce its tax laws with respect to Indian commerce on an Indian reservation. The court held that despite state law having been used as a standard of measurement to determine whether introduction of alcohol into Indian country was lawful, the enforcement mechanisms provided for in federal law respecting alcohol on Indian reservations were exclusively a federal concern, and the federal courts had exclusive jurisdiction over such seizures. The court held that Congress had preempted the field of regulating trade with Indians on reservations and had left no room for the application of supplementary state tax laws that imposed additional burdens. The court held that the state's seizure and failure to promptly return the liquor upon learning the importer's identity as an Indian trader constituted a burden on Indian traders which was impermissible. The court dismissed the action for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, holding that the burdens imposed by the tax statutes were significant and were, accordingly, preempted by federal law.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the department's forfeiture action against the companies.


HEADNOTES

Statutes - Federal Preemption - Indian Trader Statutes - State Registration Requirements for Distributors of Alcoholic Beverages New York's taxing scheme under Tax Law articles 18 and 37, to the extent that it imposes on the Indian trader an elaborate recordation system for distributors (Tax Law § 421) to insure the collection of State taxes upon liquor bound for an Indian reservation and authorizes the seizure and forfeiture of alcoholic beverages and the vehicles carrying such beverages when the alcoholic beverages are imported into the State by an unregistered distributor, without distinguishing Indian traders (Tax Law § 1845), places an impermissibly "significant" burden on Indian trade and is thus preempted by the Federal Indian Trader statutes (25 USC § 261 et seq.). While, under Federal law, State law may be used as a standard of measurement to determine whether introduction of alcohol into Indian country is lawful (18 USC § 1161), the enforcement mechanisms as provided for in Federal law respecting alcohol on Indian reservations (18 USC §§ 1154, 1156) are exclusively a Federal concern, and the Federal courts have exclusive jurisdiction over such seizures. Furthermore, since the sale of liquor on an Indian reservation to an Indian is exempt from sales and excise taxes, a similar exemption for the distributor recordation and registration requirements is applicable to defendants herein. Accordingly, New York has no subject matter jurisdiction to maintain a forfeiture action arising from the seizure of liquor being transported by an unregistered Indian trader to an Indian reservation.

 

831 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Jay-Jay Cabaret v. State


INDEX NO.: 609/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


164 Misc. 2d 673; 629 N.Y.S.2d 937; 1995 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 276



April 4, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, club operator, brought a motion seeking leave to amend its complaint in an action in which plaintiff sought a declaratory judgment regarding the validity of defendant New York State Liquor Authority's (SLA) "table dancing" and six-foot rules and whether female dancers whose upper torsos were covered by a liquid latex bra violated N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 53.1(s).


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff, club operator, brought a motion seeking leave to amend its complaint in a declaratory judgment action in which plaintiff sought a declaration regarding the validity of defendant New York State Liquor Authority's (SLA) rules governing "table dancing," its six-foot rule, and whether female dancers whose upper torsos were covered by a liquid applied latex bra violated N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 53.1(s). The court granted plaintiff's motion for leave to amend the complaint and found that plaintiff made a sufficient showing, based upon the SLA's official records to prove the nonexistence of appropriate statutory authority for the rule in issue. The court declared defendant's six-foot rule was null and void, for want of statutory authority to promulgate it and the court enjoined defendant from enforcing the rule. The court concluded that a declaratory judgment action did not lie on the issue of whether the use of the liquid latex bras rendered plaintiff's premises disorderly because plaintiff specifically denied that its activities were within the proscribed parameters of the rule and plaintiff was required to first exhaust its administrative remedies.


OUTCOME: The court declared that defendant New York State Liquor Authority's (SLA) six-foot rule was null and void because defendant did not have statutory authority to promulgate it and the court enjoined defendant from enforcing it against plaintiff, club operator. The court directed plaintiff to exhaust its administrative remedies on the issue of whether the use of the liquid latex bra on female dancers violated SLA rules.


HEADNOTES

Pleading - Amendment - Additional Theories of Recovery Plaintiff, a cabaret operator which, in its original complaint, sought a declaratory judgment as to the validity of the State Liquor Authority's rules governing "table dancing", is granted leave pursuant to CPLR 3025 (b) to serve an amended and supplemental complaint adding two additional theories of recovery that the rule banning topless dancers from performing within six feet of bar patrons (9 NYCRR 53.1 [s]) is invalid as being promulgated without statutory authority and also violative of the constitutional separation of powers doctrine (NY Const, art III, § 1) since defendants have failed to demonstrate that the proposed amendment is palpably insufficient as a matter of law or is totally devoid of merit nor have defendants demonstrated any prejudice to them arising from the proposed amendment. The amended and supplemental complaint merely sets forth additional theories of recovery based upon the same set of facts as originally pleaded.

Intoxicating Liquors - Licenses - Topless Dancing - Validity of Proximity Rule Banning Topless Dancing within Six Feet of Bar Patrons A rule of the State Liquor Authority (SLA) banning topless dancers from performing within six feet of bar patrons (9 NYCRR 53.1 [s]) regardless of how "orderly" the licensed premises may otherwise be is null and void for want of statutory authority to promulgate it. Topless dancing is a constitutionally protected form of expression that cannot be "categorically" banned in the absence of evidence that such a ban is sufficiently functionally related to the exercise of the State's police power as to overcome the State constitutional guarantee of freedom of expression. Plaintiff, a cabaret operator, has made a sufficient showing, based upon official records maintained and produced by the SLA, that there is no appropriate statutory authority to support such a categorical, "no-fault" proximity rule. However, to the extent that plaintiff seeks a declaratory judgment that its use of liquid applied latex bras does not render the premises "disorderly", the complaint is dismissed as premature since plaintiff must first exhaust its administrative remedies.

 

832 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schulz v. State


Index No. 3284-93, RJI No. 0193-034407


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


160 Misc. 2d 741; 610 N.Y.S.2d 711; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 107



March 21, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff citizens filed an action against defendants, State of New York and others, seeking a declaration that certain lump sum member item appropriations by the legislature violated the state constitution. The defendants filed a motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: The lump sum member item legislative appropriation singled out by the plaintiffs made available to the director of the budget funds for services and expenses or for contracts with municipalities and/or private not-for-profit community agencies. The plaintiffs claimed that the appropriations bill was unconstitutional because it violated the separation of powers doctrine, lacked specificity, and violated the prohibition against giving state money private individuals or organizations. The court found that the appropriations bill did not violate the doctrine of separation of powers because nothing in the bill provided that the legislature would have the power to determine how the money provided for would be spent. The mere fact that, in the spirit of comity, the legislature was allowed input into how the money was spent did not make the bill illegal. The court also found that providing more detail in how the money would be spent would have been impracticable given the hundreds of programs involved. Finally, the court found that the grant of public funds to the private entities was not unconstitutional because the funds were granted for a public purpose rather than a private purpose.


OUTCOME: The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss the plaintiffs' action for declaratory relief.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Separation of Powers - Lump-Sum Appropriations Bill - Effect of Provision Permitting Legislative Recommendations as to Expenditure

1. The 1994 Aid to Localities Budget, which provides for a $ 48 million lump-sum member-item appropriation, does not violate the New York Constitution's separation of powers doctrine merely because the bill permits the Legislature to recommend to the executive how the funds being appropriated should be spent. The bill does not contain a specific legislative direction providing that the Legislature has the power to segregate (itemize) the lump-sum appropriation. In fact, nothing in the legislation permits the Legislature to determine how the $ 48 million should be spent. Moreover, not only is there no delegation of power to the Legislature, the bill contains an affirmative grant of power to the executive to determine how the $ 48 million should be awarded. The executive may choose to give effect to legislative recommendation, but the extent to which the legislative recommendations are followed is in the discretion of the executive.

Legislature - Lump-Sum Appropriations Bill - What Constitutes Itemization

2. The 1994 Aid to Localities Budget, which provides for a $ 48 million lump-sum member-item appropriation, does not violate New York Constitution, article VII, § 4, which requires that items of appropriation added by the Legislature "refer each to a single object or purpose", since the appropriation is specifically for "services and expenses or for contracts with municipalities and/or private not-for-profit community agencies". While "itemization" is required in budget bills, there is no specific standard for such itemization and it is not a proper function of the courts to police the degree of itemization necessary. Here, the degree of itemization is that which would enable the Governor to perform his complementary review function of exercising a line-item veto. In addition, the appropriation involved makes it impracticable and unworkable for the Legislature to provide further detail. Finally, a specific level of detail in budget bills cannot be required, not only because of the practical difficulty of articulating such a standard to apply to the variety of appropriations in the budget, but also because the necessary level of detail is self-determined through the implementation of the constitutional budget process.

Constitutional Law - Gift of Public Funds - Lump-Sum Appropriations Bill - Public Purpose

3. The 1994 Aid to Localities Budget, which provides for a $ 48 million lump-sum member-item appropriation, does not violate either New York Constitution, article VII, § 8 or article VIII, § 1 which prohibit (1) the gift or loan of State credit or money to private entities for private purposes, and (2) the gift or loan of money or property of a municipality or school district to private entities for private purposes, respectively. Here, the items appropriated to the Department of Economic Development were for a public purpose because economic underdevelopment and stagnation are threats to the public. The items appropriated to the Division for Youth and to the Natural Heritage Trust are for a public purpose because the expenditure of public money for recreation, entertainment, amusement, education and enlightenment of the public is for a public benefit and purpose. The appropriation to the Division of Housing and Community Renewal is valid because urban redevelopment programs are for a public purpose. Finally, those appropriations for services and expenses or for contracts with municipalities and/or private, not-for-profit community agencies are valid because the agencies provide a variety of programs to the public.

Parties - Necessary Parties - Recipients of Allegedly Unconstitutional Budget Bill Appropriations

4. Plaintiffs' complaint challenging, on constitutional grounds, the 1994 Aid to Localities Budget, which provides for a $ 48 million lump-sum member-item appropriation, is dismissed for failure to join, as necessary parties, identified recipients of the alleged unconstitutional appropriations. These entities have at least a colorable claim to the appropriations; thus they have a right to be heard before the court deprives them of any claim they may have to funds appropriated. Notice and the opportunity to be heard are required before one's rights may be adversely affected.

 

833 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Malcolm


Indictment Number: 1568/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


161 Misc. 2d 90; 612 N.Y.S.2d 746; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 220



March 16, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The prosecutor filed a motion to enhance defendant's sentence for first degree robbery for defendant's perjured testimony during the jury trial. Defendant opposed the motion on the basis that defendant had testified truthfully and that enhancement violated defendant's state constitutional guarantees of due process and the right to testify on his own behalf.


OVERVIEW: Defendant admitted to some guilty conduct during his grand jury testimony. However, at trial, defendant denied that testimony and claimed he was elsewhere when the robbery occurred. Defendant was convicted by the jury for first degree robbery. The prosecution filed a motion to enhance defendant's sentence based on perjury. The court granted the enhancement. The court found that constitutional challenges to enhancement were without merit. The enhancement for perjured trial testimony did not impermissibly chill defendant's exercise of the right to testify on his own behalf, because there was no right to perjured testimony. Defendant's due process rights were not violated when perjury was used to enhance the sentence, even though it was not separately charged and tried, because the perjury occurred in front of the court, involved basic adjudicative facts, the perjury was material to the issues, and the perjury was only one factor considered in light of the sentencing goals. The court found that defendant's case was appropriate for the enhancement because there was overwhelming evidence of defendant's pattern of perjury, slander, and manipulation, which made rehabilitation unlikely.


OUTCOME: The court granted the prosecutor's motion to enhance defendant's first degree robbery sentence and sentenced defendant to an indeterminate sentence of 4 to 12 years.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Imposition of Enhanced Sentence Based upon Defendant's Trial Perjury A sentencing Judge is authorized to consider a defendant's trial perjury in enhancing a defendant's sentence under New York's indeterminate sentencing laws. Sentence enhancement based on the defendant's trial perjury does not impermissibly chill the defendant's constitutional right to testify since the right to testify is not a license to commit perjury. Nor is sentence enhancement a denial of due process merely because the defendant was not formally charged and tried for the perjury. Due process is ensured by adherence to the specific standards set forth by the United States Supreme Court when a trial court considers a defendant's trial perjury in imposing sentence. Accordingly, in this case in which defendant was convicted of the knifepoint robbery of complainant's jacket, defendant's denial at trial of any involvement in the crime after he admitted before the Grand Jury that he and an accomplice forcibly took complainant's jacket, and his accusation under oath that his first assigned attorney suborned perjury by advising him to testify falsely before the Grand Jury in order to "get probation", establishes a pattern of flagrant perjury in the proceedings against him so as to warrant the enhancement of his sentence from a term of 3 to 9 years which would have otherwise been imposed to a term of 4 to 12 years.

 

834 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Morrisey


Docket Nos. 93N055650, 93N055651


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


161 Misc. 2d 295; 614 N.Y.S.2d 686; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 228



March 15, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended July 8, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, who were charged with disruption or disturbance of a religious service in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.21, filed motions to dismiss based on unconstitutionality and in the interest of justice.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with disruption or disturbance of a religious service in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.21. Defendants argued that the charges were unconstitutional. The court found no violation of the establishment clause, because classification the violation as a class A misdemeanor was an attempt to protect individuals' rights of religious freedom. The law did not violate defendants' rights to freedom of religion, because they were free to express their beliefs; however, they could not intentionally interfere with the progress of a religious service. The law was not overbroad where the conduct prohibited was only proscribed when it was coupled with the intent to prevent the conduct of a religious service. Lastly, defendants' motion to dismiss in the interest of justice was denied, because they failed to show factors that would compel the court to dismiss the accusatory instrument.


OUTCOME: The court held that the law was not unconstitutional and denied defendants' motion to dismiss on that basis. The motion to dismiss in the interest of justice was denied because the relevant grounds presented were insufficient to compel the court to exercise this discretionary authority.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Disruption or Disturbance of Religious Service - Establishment Clause Defendants' motion to dismiss charges of disruption, or disturbance of a religious service (Penal Law § 240.21) on the ground that the statute violates the Establishment Clause by designating the statute as a class A misdemeanor, while the disruption of a nonreligious assembly is designated in the Penal Law as a violation (see, Penal Law § 240.20), is denied. The Legislature may designate an offense a class A misdemeanor when the proscribed conduct interferes with a fundamental right. Here the purpose of Penal Law § 240.21 is not to establish any right; its purpose is to protect the rights of those individuals who choose to exercise their fundamental right of freedom of religion.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Disruption or Disturbance of Religious Service - Freedom of Religion Defendants' motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument charging them with disruption, or disturbance of a religious service (Penal Law § 240.21) on the grounds that, as applied, the statute is an unconstitutional infringement of their First Amendment right to freedom of religion is denied. An individual may not exercise his or her own constitutional rights and in this process infringe on the constitutional rights of others. Additionally, an individual may not exercise claimed First Amendment rights at any time or at any place.
