Here, where it is acknowledged by defendants that their actions were intended as "an attempt to prevent the sacrilege of a Mass" and the complaint alleges considerable disruptive conduct by the defendants, including blocking the way of the priest and the deacon at the beginning of the service and shouting several things that did not constitute a prayer of any type at the priest, the conduct, if as alleged, infringed on the rights of those persons in attendance who were exercising their freedom of religion and who were participating in a Mass. The challenged statute is not intended to punish the exercise of religion but rather it is intended to protect the rights of persons to exercise their own religious beliefs without impermissible interference.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Disruption or Disturbance of Religious Service - Overbreadth Defendants' motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument charging defendants with disruption, or disturbance of a religious service (Penal Law § 240.21) on the ground that the statute is facially overbroad and therefore unconstitutional is denied. A person is guilty of that offense if he or she makes unreasonable noise or disturbance while within 100 feet of a lawfully assembled religious service, with intent to cause annoyance or alarm or recklessly creating a risk thereof. The statute is not meant to proscribe the conduct of an individual who is standing fewer than 100 feet from a religious service and whose conduct is not coupled with the requisite intent to disturb the service or recklessly creating a risk thereof. Furthermore, the State has a justifiable interest in protecting the rights of those who wish to exercise their freedom of religion over the interest of those individuals who intend to infringe these First Amendment rights. The language of the challenged statute, given its normal meaning, is not so broad that its sanctions might apply to conduct that is constitutionally protected.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Standing to Raise Overbreadth Claim Defendants charged with disruption, or disturbance of a religious service (Penal Law § 240.21) have standing to raise an overbreadth claim even though their conduct allegedly occurred inside a church and, therefore, falls squarely within the hard core of the statute's proscriptions. Under the overbreadth doctrine, a person may be permitted to litigate the rights of third parties, even though that individual's alleged actions do not necessarily fall under the scope of these arguments. A person has standing to make an overbreadth challenge even though it might be constitutionally permissible to regulate that person's conduct under a more narrowly drawn and specified statute.

Crimes - Aggravated Disorderly Conduct - Disruption or Disturbance of Religious Service - Dismissal in Furtherance of Justice Defendants' motion to dismiss a charge of disruption, or disturbance of a religious service (Penal Law § 240.21) in the interest of justice, pursuant to CPL 170.40, is denied, where defendants allegedly chanted during the service and physically approached the priest and others participating in the Mass, as the defendants have failed to sustain the burden of showing factors which would compel the dismissal. The court may dismiss in the interest of justice to allow justice to prevail over the strict letter of the law so as to prevent a miscarriage of justice, but the motion should not be granted unless the facts and circumstances are such that to deny relief would shock the conscience of the court. Here, the actual harm that results from defendants' alleged actions is both tangible and intangible: tangible harm results from the halting or interruption of church services; and consequent harm, the disturbance of peaceful exercise of freedom of religion, is a serious disturbance of the rights of the worshippers. Therefore, a balance of the equities simply does not render unjust the continuance of this prosecution.

 

835 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Village of Hempstead v. SRA Realty Corp.


Index No. 5631/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


160 Misc. 2d 819; 611 N.Y.S.2d 441; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 133



March 9, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant property owner filed a motion to dismiss the complaint of plaintiff village for failure to state a cause of action on the grounds that the village's ordinance was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The village enacted an ordinance that prohibited the use of metal sheets on the exterior of a premises in order to prevent or impede access into said premises. The property owner had erected steel gates before the enactment of the ordinance and in response to criminal activity on the property. The village filed suit to enforce the ordinance. The property owner filed a motion to dismiss, which the court granted. The court held that while the ordinance was designed to enhance the aesthetic character of the area, a permissible goal, it was unconstitutional because the village failed to show that the property owner's gate was a substantial offense to the eye or how the benefit of a proposed substituted security system would outweigh the monetary loss of property and business of the property owner.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the complaint of the village against the property owner for removal of the property owner's gate.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Police Power - Constitutionality of Aesthetics-Based Use Restriction as Applied to Existing Structure

A Village Code, which prohibits metal sheets on the exterior of premises to prevent or impede access into the premises, and which is designed to improve the aesthetics of storefronts under the guise of promoting the health, safety and welfare of Village residents, is unconstitutional as applied to defendant owner of a commercial building who, prior to enactment of the Code, erected steel security gates on the extension of its building in response to repeated incidents of vandalism and burglary. Notwithstanding that aesthetics, in itself, constitutes a valid basis for the exercise of a municipality's police power just as safety does, such regulation which is enacted merely to enhance the aesthetics of a community, which is the obvious case here, generally does not provide the compelling reasons for implementation with respect to existing structures or uses. A property owner has the right to use his property in a certain fashion and exercise reasonable means to protect and secure that property. A denial of that right solely on aesthetic grounds should be based upon a showing that the offense to the eye is substantial and has a material effect on the community or district pattern. The Village has not met its burden in this regard.

 

836 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Vanguard Meter Serv.


Indictment No. 11938/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


160 Misc. 2d 685; 611 N.Y.S.2d 430; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 118



March 4, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, a company that was awarded city contracts and various persons associated with the company, filed a motion in a trial court (New York) for discovery and inspection of the grand jury minutes that supported the indictments against them, and for dismissal of the indictment. The defendants were indicted for violations of the penal code regarding the wages paid and professional supervision required in performing certain city contracts.


OVERVIEW: The city awarded contracts to defendants that required a certain wage rate to be paid and professional supervision of the work. The indictment generally alleged that the defendants never intended to comply with the wage and supervision requirements. The defendants sought dismissal of the indictment. The court held that evidence presented to the grand jury was: (1) sufficient to show a scheme to defraud or a pattern of behavior calculated to deceive persons of ordinary prudence and comprehension; (2) insufficient regarding larceny and conspiracy; (3) sufficient regarding the filing of false wage and professional supervision certifications; (4) sufficient regarding the perjury charge; and (5) sufficient to establish that the wage certifications were materially false and intended to deceive the city. The court held that the city was not required to show pecuniary loss, that the prevailing wage rate statutes were not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative power, that the state's labor laws did not provide the exclusive criminal penalties for conduct within their ambit, and that the prosecution had adequately responded to the defendants' discovery requests.


OUTCOME: The court granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion to dismiss the indictment. The court denied the motion to discover and inspect the grand jury minutes.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Scheme to Defraud - Municipal Contractor's Failure to Pay Workers Prevailing Hourly Wage

1. Defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts requiring the contractor to pay its workers the prevailing hourly wage in accordance with Labor Law § 220, may properly be prosecuted for the crime of scheme to defraud in the first degree (Penal Law § 190.65) for having allegedly cheated their meter installers by advertising a high hourly wage and then paying them at the lower piecework rate. The definition of property for purposes of the crime of scheme to defraud is broad enough to encompass the services provided by the installers. Furthermore, sufficient evidence was presented to the Grand Jury to demonstrate that the installers were deceived by defendants' words and conduct, including alleged misleading advertisements, and misstatements to trainees and installers. The sum total of defendants' conduct constitutes a pattern of behavior calculated to deceive persons of ordinary prudence and comprehension.

Crimes - Larceny - Larceny by False Promise - Theft of Municipal Contract

2. Defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts, cannot be prosecuted under Penal Law § 155.05 (2) (d) for having stolen the government contracts they entered into because of allegedly false promises made during the contract formation process concerning the company's intention to comply with the contracts' prevailing wage and preplumbing master plumber requirements since the contracts herein cannot be deemed property capable of being stolen within the meaning of the larceny statute (see, Penal Law § 155.00 [1]). The parties to a contract exist in a commercial form of symbiotic relationship. The "contract" does not exist independent of that relationship. Viewed in this context, a party to a contract, or in the case of a corporate entity, as here, its contracting officers, cannot steal that contract.

Crimes - Larceny - Larceny by False Pretense - No Criminal Liability for Municipal Contractor's Contractual Misrepresentations

3. Defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts, cannot be prosecuted for larceny by false pretense (Penal Law § 155.05 [2] [a]) for having accepted full payment under the contracts despite having made misrepresentations that the company had paid its meter installers the prevailing hourly wage and that preplumbing work had been performed under the supervision of a licensed master plumber as required by the contracts. Charging a contractor with stealing the entire contract price when the contractor did not perform strictly in accordance with the methodology agreed upon but delivered the essence of the performance at a price which is in no way inflated would constitute a dangerous expansion of the larceny statute.

Crimes - Offering False Instrument for Filing - False Certifications Regarding Compliance with Prevailing Wage and Master Plumber Requirements in Municipal Contract - Showing of Municipality's Pecuniary Loss Not Required

4. Defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts, may be prosecuted for multiple counts of offering a false instrument for filing in the first degree for having submitted false certifications that the company had complied with the contracts' prevailing hourly wage requirement (Labor Law §§ 220, 220-a) and the requirement that all preplumbing work would be supervised by a licensed master plumber since sufficient testimony of installers and team leaders was presented to the Grand Jury to demonstrate that employees were not paid the prevailing wage and that the master plumber simply lent the use of his seal while having no other involvement, directly or indirectly, in the preplumbing work. Furthermore, the statute only requires that legitimate government interests and processes were frustrated by defendants' false filings and does not require proof that the City suffered any pecuniary loss. The City's reason for requiring such filings was to ensure its interest in having the prevailing wage paid and proper plumbing supervision, and the filings frustrated such government interests.

Crimes - Perjury - False Sworn Certificates Regarding Compliance with Prevailing Wage Requirement in Municipal Contract - No Requirement That Notary Public Testify before Grand Jury

5. Defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts, may be prosecuted for perjury for having submitted false sworn certificates that the company had complied with the contracts' prevailing hourly wage requirement (Labor Law §§ 220, 220-a) since the evidence before the Grand Jury established that the piecework payments made to the meter installers were substantially less than the prevailing hourly wages defendants were required to pay. Furthermore, it was not necessary that the notary public before whom the certificates were sworn has testified before the Grand Jury since a jurat and signature of the notary are prima facie evidence that the oath was administered. Lastly, the evidence before the Grand Jury was sufficient to establish that the certificates were materially false and were intended to deceive the City of New York.

Crimes - Scheme to Defraud - Municipal Contractor's Failure to Pay Workers Prevailing Hourly Wage - Exclusivity of Labor Law Provisions

6. Defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts requiring the contractor to pay its workers the prevailing hourly wage in accordance with Labor Law § 220, may properly be prosecuted for the crime of scheme to defraud in the first degree (Penal Law § 190.65) for having allegedly cheated their meter installers by advertising a high hourly wage and then paying them at the lower piecework rate. The criminal penalties available under the prevailing wage statute are not the exclusive remedy available for failure to pay the prevailing wage in the absence of any specific evidence of legislative intent to have the Labor Law provide the exclusive criminal penalties for conduct within its ambit.

Statutes - Federal Preemption - Criminal Prosecution Predicated upon Municipal Contractor's Failure to Pay Workers Prevailing Hourly Wage Not Preempted by ERISA

7. The criminal prosecution of defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts, for Penal Law violations predicated upon the failure to pay workers the prevailing hourly wage in accordance with Labor Law § 220 as required by the contracts is not preempted by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) (29 USC § 1001 et seq.). ERISA only preempts those State laws in the area in which it legislates and, moreover, preemption does not apply, as here, to "any generally applicable criminal law of a State" (29 USC § 1144 [b] [4]). The fact that misrepresentations as to compliance with Labor Law § 220 may form part of the predicate for Penal Law violations cannot convert those criminal statutes into prohibited laws aimed specifically at employee benefit plans.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Prevailing Wage Statute - Criminal Prosecution Predicated upon Municipal Contractor's Failure to Pay Workers Prevailing Hourly Wage Not Barred

8. The criminal prosecution of defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation contracts, predicated upon the failure to pay workers the prevailing hourly wage in accordance with Labor Law § 220 as required by the contracts, is not barred because of the alleged unconstitutionality of the prevailing wage statute. The prevailing wage statute does not unconstitutionally delegate the legislative process to private parties by requiring the Comptroller, without discretion, to select prevailing wages from collective bargaining agreements. Rather, the statute grants the Comptroller discretion to select the rates and, in this case, the Comptroller did make findings and set the rates. Moreover, there is no allegation of collusive negotiation of collective bargaining agreements. Lastly, the statute's definition of "locality" is not impermissibly vague.

Grand Jury - Defective Proceeding - Failure to Present Exculpatory Evidence - Fair Presentation

9. In the criminal prosecution of defendants, the contracting officers in a company awarded municipal water meter installation, contracts, predicated upon the failure to pay workers the prevailing hourly wage in accordance with Labor Law § 220 as required by the contracts, the People were not obligated to present allegedly exculpatory evidence to the Grand Jury that certain employees received payment in excess of the prevailing wage. The People do not have the same obligations at the Grand Jury phase as they have at the trial phase. In this case, a reading of the Grand Jury minutes indicates that the presentation was fair and proper and that there was sufficient evidence to establish a prima facie case. Defendants have presented nothing but speculation to support their claims of irregularities.

 

837 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Battaglia v. New York City Transit Auth.


Index No. 25523/90


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 183



March 4, 1994, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to the collective bargaining agreement between petitioner employee's union and respondent employer, the employee challenged his dismissal for testing positive for a prescription medication to the arbitration board (board). The board upheld the termination because the employee failed to inform his employer about the prescription and it was his second offense. The employee sought vacatur of the arbitration award under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7511.


OVERVIEW: The employee argued that the employer, a city transit authority, was guilty of misconduct and that the award violated public policy. The employer claimed the employee lacked standing to challenge the award and that he waived his objections to the first drug test by not timely challenging it. The court held that the test results could not be considered by the board because the first test was not based upon individualized suspicion and was an unreasonable search in violation of the New York and Federal Constitutions, and the second drug test was fruit of the poisonous tree. The employee was a party for the purposes of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 7511 and had standing to challenge the award because the agreement provided that he could represent himself through all the grievance steps and personally appeal to the next step and to arbitration. The union did not waive the employee's constitutional rights when it agreed to random drug testing because the unconstitutional testing violated the state's strong public policy. The court held that, without the first blood test, dismissal was excessively harsh by the board's own standards, and the award was both contrary to public policy and irrational.


OUTCOME: The court granted the employee's petition and vacated the arbitration award on the grounds that it was irrational and violative of a strong public policy. The court ordered reinstatement of the employee to the position he held prior to termination and back pay from the date of termination until reinstatement minus any unemployment benefits and earnings accrued during that period.

 

838 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Resnick v. New York City Health & Hosps. Corp.


INDEX NO. SCR 2303/92


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


161 Misc. 2d 156; 612 N.Y.S.2d 315; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 175



January 22, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city health corporation filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff driver's personal injury action on the grounds that it did not receive proper notice of his claim as required by N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 50-e.


OVERVIEW: The driver was operating his vehicle when he was struck by an ambulance owned by the city health corporation. Pursuant to § 50-e, the driver submitted a claim notice to the city's comptroller. The city's comptroller notified the driver that the matter was under investigation. The city comptroller failed to act on the claim. The driver initiated a personal injury action against the city health corporation. The city health corporation the matter for seven months. The city health corporation then filed a motion to dismiss claiming that the driver gave the claim notice to the wrong agency. The court found that the city health corporation was estopped from arguing that it did not receive proper notice. The city comptroller lulled the driver into believing that he had sued the right party by claiming that it was investigating the driver's claim. In addition, the city health corporation adjourned the case several times and never raised the notice issue.


OUTCOME: The court denied the city health corporation's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Notice of Claim - Service upon Wrong Party in Small Claims Action - Estoppel Defendant New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation's (HHC) motion to dismiss a small claims negligence action timely commenced against it, on the ground that the pro se plaintiff failed to serve a notice of claim upon the proper party as required by General Municipal Law § 50-e is denied, where plaintiff incorrectly served the Comptroller rather than HHC within three weeks of the collision between the defendant's ambulance and the plaintiff's automobile and, less than one week after the service, the Comptroller's office provided a written acknowledgment of the claim noting that the claim "is currently under investigation". Procedural requirements such as the notice of claim provisions of General Municipal Law § 50-e need not be strictly applied in the Small Claims Court. In addition, since the defendant repeatedly adjourned this case for seven months, which was approximately 14 months after the accident, the defendant should be estopped from asserting the lack of a timely notice of claim upon it because its own acts delayed the proceeding to such an extent that the plaintiff was beyond the statutory time within which to move to extend the time to file a late notice of claim. Moreover, the action which was timely served upon HHC was sufficient notice in this matter to protect the rights of the defendant against stale claims.

 

839 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Giampino v. Leonard Ricci, M.D., P.C.


Index No. 551/85


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, PUTNAM COUNTY


160 Misc. 2d 326; 609 N.Y.S.2d 134; 1994 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 61



January 19, 1994, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Following a jury verdict in favor of plaintiff administrator, he challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 50-B and sought to strike it down on the ground that its application was tantamount to limiting recovery in a wrongful death action and violated N.Y. Const. art. I, § 16. The administrator had filed a malpractice action against defendant hospital and physician for the death of a patient occurring while the patient was giving birth.


OVERVIEW: A patient died while giving birth, and her administrator filed a medical malpractice action against the hospital and the attending physician. The jury returned a verdict in favor of the administrator in finding that the hospital was 30 percent responsible and that the physician was 70 percent responsible, and the award was later reduced by the court. Then, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 50-B, the court was required to process a judgment by returning an itemized verdict specifying the amount awarded for each item of special and general damages and by itemizing the amounts intended to compensate the administrator for damages incurred. The administrator then asserted that article 50-B was unconstitutional and sought to strike it down. The court held that: (1) article 50-B was constitutional, and its application did not violate N.Y. Const. art. I, § 16 because it did not have the effect of limiting recoveries; (2) article 50-B did not lower the verdict as much as it brought the amount awarded to a plaintiff within the context of what the parties might well have experienced economically had death not intervened; and (3) the Legislature was within its power in enacting the statute.


OUTCOME: The court denied the administrator's motion to strike down the applicable statute, in the administrator's medical malpractice action against the hospital and the physician.


HEADNOTES

Death - Wrongful Death - Constitutionality of Periodic Installments under CPLR Article 50-B for Wrongful Death Award

 CPLR article 50-B, which requires that a jury verdict be itemized specifying the amount awarded for each item of special and general damages, and, with regard to future damages in excess of $ 250,000, that a judgment be entered for the amount of the present value of an annuity contract that will provide for the payment of the remaining amounts of future damages in periodic installments, is not unconstitutional on the ground that applying the provisions of article 50-B would be tantamount to limiting recovery in a wrongful death action and therefore violative of article I, § 16 of the New York Constitution. Section 16 was adopted not to preempt the Legislature from an ability to legislate further in this area, but rather to remove an onerous monetary limitation. Moreover, article 50-B does not lower the verdict as much as it brings the amount awarded within the context of what the parties might well have experienced economically had death not intervened.

 

840 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Curtis


IND # 145/92


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


160 Misc. 2d 508; 610 N.Y.S.2d 441; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 594



December 29, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Prior to being sentenced upon his conviction for misdemeanor third degree assault, defendant asked court to declare N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §720.20 to be unconstitutional as a violation of equal protection clauses of U.S. Const. amend. XIV and N.Y. Const. art. I, § 11, because sentencing judge in superior court had authority to deny him youthful offender status, while a local criminal court judge would not have had that power.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was accused of felony assault and robbery. Defendant was convicted of third degree assault. Before sentencing, he moved to be mandatorily accorded youthful offender (Y.O.) status and asked court to find N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 720.20 to be unconstitutional. He alleged law was a violation of equal protection because he was eligible for Y.O. treatment but court could deny him that status because it had discretion to grant or deny youthful offender treatment, whereas a local criminal court would be required to treat him as a youthful offender. Court denied motion and found § 720.20 to be constitutional because broader discretion afforded to superior court to deny youthful offender status was based on gravity of crime originally charged, and there was a rational basis to distinguish between a youth charged with a felony and one accused of a misdemeanor. It was rational to allow superior court judges, being aware of evidence, to weigh all reasonable sentencing options. Finally, the discretion did not grant prosecutors unlimited power to prevent mandatory adjudication of defendants as a Y.O. simply by deciding to level charges in a superior, rather than lower court.


OUTCOME: Statute was deemed constitutional, and defendant's motion to be mandatorily adjudicated as a youthful offender (Y.O.) was denied because superior court could deny Y.O. treatment based upon gravity of crimes defendant was originally charged with, and there was a rational basis for making distinctions between youths charged with felonies and those charged with misdemeanors.


HEADNOTES

Infants - Youthful Offenders - Mandatory Treatment

 CPL 720.20 (1) does not violate defendant's equal protection guarantees by vesting only a superior court with discretion to grant or deny youthful offender treatment where defendant, an eligible youth charged with a felony, and convicted by a County Court jury of a misdemeanor, was not given mandatorily accorded youthful offender status. CPL 720.20 (1) mandates that an eligible defendant must receive youthful offender treatment for a maiden misdemeanor conviction secured in a local criminal court. Yet, if a conviction is obtained in a County Court, a Judge there is vested with discretion to deny youthful offender status. This difference in treatment has a rational basis in that the statutory classification, which gives superior courts broader discretion than lower courts to deny youthful offender status, is based on the gravity of the crime originally charged. This is especially evident here where the original evidence supported multiple felony charges, charges properly heard in a superior court only.

 

841 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Plumb v. Plumb


Index No. 34634/72


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 880; 606 N.Y.S.2d 859; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 545



December 15, 1993, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended February 18, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff wife and defendant husband executed a separation agreement which was incorporated into a judgment of divorce but was not merged into it. In a writing acknowledged by both parties, they agreed to modify the agreement in certain regards including maintenance and child support. The wife moved to have the modification agreement incorporated in the judgment.


OVERVIEW: The wife argued that to deny her the requested relief would permit her to enforce the original divorce judgment, including those portions which were modified, according to their original form. The court found that the result did not follow. The modification agreement was a contract by which the wife explicitly agreed to limit her rights with respect to the matters dealt with; thus, by the terms of the new contract, the modification agreement, the wife is barred from enforcing the original judgment to the extent it was modified. The court held that the wife's remedy, to proceed on the modified terms as though this were a contract action, could deprive her of certain procedural benefits while also offering the husband fewer defenses to enforcement. The court concluded that the benefits to be obtained by either party were items to be negotiated when the parties entered into the modification agreement. At the insistence of one side, the court would not alter the modification agreement more than seven years after it was signed.


OUTCOME: The court denied the wife's motion to have the modification agreement incorporated in the divorce judgment.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife - Separation Agreement - Modification of Agreement - Incorporation of Modification into Judgment of Divorce

Where plaintiff wife and defendant husband executed a separation agreement which was incorporated but not merged into a judgment of divorce and the parties modified the agreement in certain regards including maintenance and child support, the plaintiff's motion to have the modification agreement incorporated into the divorce judgment is denied. A separation agreement that is incorporated but not merged with the divorce degree remains an independent contract and absent compelling circumstances, the court must give controlling effect to a separation agreement. Here, the language of the parties did not agree to a modification of the judgment. Moreover, terms of the separation agreement cannot be added or deleted under the guise of construction. Further, no modification of a judgment incorporating the terms of a separation agreement shall be made as to maintenance without a showing of extreme hardship (Domestic Relations Law § 236 [B] [9] [b]) and plaintiff failed to offer any facts which would lead to a finding of extreme hardship. Finally, the standard for modifying a child support judgment is whether in the interests of the child, changed circumstances exist which warrant an increase. That standard has not been met.

 

842 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Anyakora


Ind. No.: 794/93


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


162 Misc. 2d 47; 616 N.Y.S.2d 149; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 612



December 14, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: [Portions of opinion omitted for purposes of publication.]


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with refusing to treat a person in need of emergency medical treatment under N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2805-b(2)(b), falsifying business records in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 175.10, and tampering with physical evidence under N.Y. Penal Law § 215.40, sought dismissal of the Public Health Law charge on various constitutional grounds.


OVERVIEW: The state charged defendant with refusing to treat a person in need of emergency medical treatment under N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2805-b (2)(b), falsifying business records in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 175.10, and tampering with physical evidence under N.Y. Penal Law § 215.40. Defendant sought dismissal of the Public Health Law charge on various constitutional grounds. The court denied the motion, holding N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2805-b (2)(b) was not unconstitutional. The court found that that the legislature intended by the statute in question, to impose strict liability on licensed medical practitioners with respect to the element of whether the person seeking emergency treatment was actually in need of such treatment. The court found that the statute met the Penal Law's minimum requirements for imposing criminal liability on individuals because it required the performance by a person of conduct which included a voluntary act or the omission to perform an act which he is physically capable of performing under N.Y. Penal Law § 15.10.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for dismissal of a charge against him under a public health law as the law in question was constitutional. The legislature intended to impose strict liability on licensed medical practitioners with respect to the element of whether the person seeking emergency treatment was actually in need of such treatment.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Strict Liability Offenses - Refusal of Medical Practitioner to Treat Emergency Patient Public Health Law § 2805-b (2) (b), which provides that any licensed medical practitioner who refuses to treat a person arriving at a general hospital to receive emergency medical treatment who is in need of such treatment shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, imposes strict liability on licensed medical practitioners to the extent that they may be culpable without having actual knowledge that the person they refused to treat was in need of emergency medical treatment at the time they refused to treat them.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Public Health Law § 2805-b (2) (b) - Vagueness Public Health Law § 2805-b (2) (b), which provides that any licensed medical practitioner who refuses to treat a person arriving at a general hospital to receive emergency medical treatment who is in need of such treatment shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, is not unconstitutionally vague on the ground that the statute does not define the terms "treat" and "emergency medical treatment" or enunciate criteria as to how and by whom such concepts are to be developed. "Treat" and "emergency" give sufficient notice because each is a term of general import and has a definite and ascertainable meaning intelligible to the average licensed medical practitioner without definition by the Legislature. That licensed medical practitioners do not always agree on a proper course of treatment has no constitutional import, since the question the statute raises is whether or not a licensed medical practitioner refused to treat a person. Moreover, the statute is reasonably read to require licensed medical practitioners to examine and diagnose persons seeking treatment. While licensed medical practitioners sometimes differ on whether certain cases present "emergency" situations, when, as here, the general class of offenses to which the statute is directed is plainly within its terms, the statute will not be struck down as vague, even though marginal cases could be put where doubts may arise.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Public Health Law § 2805-b (2) (b) - Vagueness - Malum In Se Conduct Public Health Law § 2805-b (2) (b), which provides that any licensed medical practitioner who refuses to treat a person arriving at a general hospital to receive emergency medical treatment who is in need of such treatment shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, does not punish otherwise innocent conduct so as to require that the elements of the offense be spelled out in words even more explicitly in order to withstand a constitutional challenge for vagueness. The conduct proscibed may accurately be characterized as malum in se with regard to medical professionals since guilt does not consist entirely in violation of a legislative fiat, but rather a legislative determination to criminalize professionally improper conduct. Moreover, there is a reasonable relationship between preventing unnecessary deaths or disabilities among persons seeking and in need of emergency medical treatment and prohibiting those directly responsible for rendering such care from refusing to treat them.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Public Health Law § 2805-b (2) (b) - Overbreadth Public Health Law § 2805-b (2) (b), which provides that any licensed medical practitioner who refuses to treat a person arriving at a general hospital to receive emergency medical treatment who is in need of such treatment shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, is not unconstitutionally overbroad or irrational. The language regarding the breadth of paragraph (b)'s coverage could not be clearer. A plain reading of the statute reveals that it applies to general hospitals, both private and public, and has no limitation based on where, at such hospital, a person arrives to seek treatment, whether it be at a designated "emergency room" or not. Further, the proscriptions of paragraph (b) are rationally related to its purpose of preventing unnecessary deaths or disabilities among persons seeking and in need of emergency medical treatment and prohibiting licensed medical practitioners at general hospitals from refusing to treat them, whether or not such persons arrive at designated "emergency" rooms.

 

843 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nieves


13399/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 720; 606 N.Y.S.2d 563; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 519



December 9, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended January 27, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The People sought to have defendant sentenced as a second felony offender following her guilty plea to the reduced charge of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree on the ground that defendant had one prior felony drug conviction under indictment for which she had received an unconditional discharge.


OVERVIEW: Defendant pled guilty to a reduced charge of criminal sale of a controlled substance in the first degree. She had one prior felony drug conviction under a 1991 indictment for which she had received an unconditional discharge. The unconditional discharge was vacated because no reason had been set forth in the record, and defendant was resentenced to a probationary term. The People asked the court to sentence defendant as a second felony offender. Although they did not dispute the fact that the sentence under the 1991 indictment was illegal, they argued that the vacatur of the original sentence did not alter the fact that the first sentence resulted in a final conviction and that the resentence was deemed nunc pro tunc to the original sentencing date. Defendant asserted that the vacated sentence was a legal nullity and that she was not, in effect, sentenced on the 1991 indictment prior to the commission of this offense. The court held that because no valid legal sentence was imposed on defendant under the 1991 indictment before she committed the instant offense, N.Y. Penal Law § 70.06 dictated that she did not qualify as a second felony offender.


OUTCOME: The court ruled defendant's felony sentence would not be enhanced.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Sentence - Second Felony Offender - Effect of Vacatur of Prior Sentence - Cruel and Unusual Punishment

Defendant may not be sentenced as a second felony offender where the sentence of unconditional discharge on her one prior felony drug conviction was vacated as illegal and she was resentenced to a probationary term subsequent to the second felony conviction. A defendant can be adjudicated a second felony offender only if the prior felony sentence was imposed before the commission of the subsequent felony (Penal Law § 70.06 [1] [b] [ii]). A sentence which was illegally imposed and subsequently vacated is a nullity and can be given no legal effect. Since no valid legal sentence had been imposed on defendant before she committed the instant offense, she does not qualify as a second felony offender. Moreover, even if the prior conviction does constitute a predicate felony notwithstanding the resentence, treating defendant as a second felony offender would constitute cruel and unusual punishment and would be contrary to the legislative purpose of the predicate felony statutes under the facts and circumstances of his case in view of defendant's untreated drug addiction underlying her criminal acts and her late involvement with the criminal justice system.

 

844 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Smith


94-246


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF RED HOOK, DUTCHESS COUNTY


160 Misc. 2d 1070; 612 N.Y.S.2d 306; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 600



December 4, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended June 6, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought dismissal of the charges against him on the grounds that the local law prohibiting the use of skateboards was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with violation of a local law that prohibited the use of skateboards. Defendant argued that the local law was unconstitutional. The court held that the local law was unconstitutional and found that: 1) the first paragraph of the local law discriminated against children without parents; 2) the confiscation or taking of any property without provision of a hearing was illegal; and 3) no fine could be levied on the mere issuance of a ticket and such action violated defendant's constitutional right to due process.


OUTCOME: The court held that the local law prohibiting the use of skateboards was unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Local Law Prohibiting Use of Skateboards

Local Laws, 1990, No. 1 of the Village of Red Hook, which prohibits the use of skateboards and provides that a fine will be assessed for every time a ticket is issued and that the fine shall be doubled upon the repetitious issuing of a ticket is unconstitutional. Fines must be based on convictions and not on the number of arrests. Moreover, it is the exclusive responsibility of the court to impose sentences and levy fines. Furthermore, while the spirit and intent of the statute was to have someone of parental authority request the return of the skateboard after it was confiscated for violation of the statute, the statute does not imply this, stating that "a parent of the child ... shall come to the Village"; therefore, this discriminates against children without parents. Additionally, the confiscation or taking of any property without provision of a hearing is illegal unless the seized property is the object or instrumentality alleged to have been used in some sort of criminal activity, which does not fit here since it may be returned, after a period of time, and upon request with a warning.

 

845 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cantarella


Ind. 5877/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


160 Misc. 2d 8; 606 N.Y.S.2d 942; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 541



December 2, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended February 22, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Seven defendants challenged their joint indictment for enterprise corruption in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 460.20(1)(a).


OVERVIEW: Thirteen individuals and one corporation were jointly indicted for enterprise corruption in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 460.20(1)(a). Four individuals and the corporation pleaded guilty. Defendants, seven individuals, challenged the indictment contending that the statute was vague and the prosecution was unconstitutional, that the evidence was insufficient to establish the existence of a criminal enterprise and that the evidence failed to establish reasonable cause to believe that defendants committed the offense of enterprise corruption. The court found that the statute and prosecution were constitutional and that the evidence was sufficient to establish the existence of a criminal enterprise. As to one defendant, the court found the evidence established reasonable cause to believe that he committed the offense of enterprise corruption and it sustained the indictment against him. As to the other six defendants, the court dismissed the indictment finding insufficient evidence to establish their participation in the offense.


OUTCOME: As to six defendants, the court dismissed their joint indictment for enterprise corruption finding the evidence insufficient to establish reasonable cause to believe that they committed the offense. As to one defendant, the court upheld his indictment for enterprise corruption finding sufficient evidence to establish reasonable cause.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - Constitutionality of Statute 

1. New York's enterprise corruption statute (Penal Law § 460.00 et seq.), which proscribes intentionally participating in the affairs of a criminal enterprise by participating in a "pattern of criminal activity" (Penal Law § 460.20 [1] [a]), is not unconstitutionally vague in light of the definition sections of the statute, which render the statute significantly more definite in its scope than the comparable Federal RICO statute (18 USC § 1961 et seq.) which has been upheld as constitutional.

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - "Pattern of Criminal Activity" - Participation in Three or More "Pattern" Crimes

2. New York's enterprise corruption statute, which renders a person guilty of enterprise corruption when, having knowledge of the existence of a criminal enterprise and the nature of its activities, and being employed by or associated with such enterprise, such person intentionally conducts or participates in the affairs of an enterprise by participating in a "pattern of criminal activity" (Penal Law § 460.20 [1] [a]), and which defines a "pattern of criminal activity" (Penal Law § 460.10 [4] [b]) to be "conduct engaged in by persons charged in an enterprise corruption count constituting three or more criminal acts that", inter alia, "are neither isolated incidents, nor so closely related and connected in point of time or circumstance of commission as to constitute a criminal offense or criminal transaction", does not require proof that each of the defendants jointly indicted herein for enterprise corruption and related crimes have participated in three separate criminal conspiracies. Section 460.10 (4) was intended to establish that three criminal acts constitute a pattern only where they evince the requisite elements of continuity and relatedness. The criminal enterprise must be proven to exist apart from the pattern of its criminal activity. Acts which are part of a common criminal scheme or plan are included within the "pattern of criminal activity" where there are other unrelated acts sufficient to establish the required continuity of criminality. Therefore, a defendant associated with the enterprise, acting with the necessary knowledge and intent, who engages in three criminal acts which are part of a single criminal transaction may nonetheless be guilty of enterprise corruption where the transaction is itself part of the "pattern of criminal activity".

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - "Pattern of Criminal Activity" - Participation in Three or More "Pattern" Crimes

3. Defendant may not be prosecuted for enterprise corruption (Penal Law § 460.20 [1] [a]) for his involvement in a criminal enterprise that engaged in a "pattern of criminal activity" designed to control a newspaper's circulation department by means of extortion, coercion, falsification of business records, bribery and other crimes for financial gain, where the evidence presented to the Grand Jury failed to establish that defendant, a member of a crime organization, committed or is otherwise liable for at least the requisite three "pattern" criminal acts in furtherance net of the affairs of the criminal enterprise (Penal Law § 460.10 [4]). Defendant's illegal possession of a firearm at his residence cannot properly be alleged as a criminal act of participation in the "pattern of criminal activity" encompassed by the enterprise. In addition, defendant's involvement in a no-show job scheme, whereby he collected a weekly paycheck from the newspaper over a three-year period, only constitutes a single continuous larceny for purposes of the enterprise corruption statute, thereby leaving only two criminal acts having the necessary connection to the criminal enterprise.

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - "Pattern of Criminal Activity" - Participation in Three or More "Pattern" Crimes

4. Defendant may not be prosecuted for enterprise corruption (Penal Law § 460.20 [1] [a]) for his involvement in a criminal enterprise that engaged in a "pattern of criminal activity" designed to control a newspaper's circulation department by means of extortion, coercion, falsification of business records, bribery and other crimes for financial gain, where the evidence presented to the Grand Jury failed to establish that defendant, a driver responsible for the delivery of papers, committed or is otherwise liable for at least the requisite three "pattern" criminal acts in furtherance of the affairs of the criminal enterprise (Penal Law § 460.10 [4]). Defendant's possession of loaded firearms on the newspaper's premises cannot constitute "pattern" crimes in the absence of any evidence that such possession was in any way related to the criminal enterprise. In addition, the evidence only establishes that defendant aided in the theft from the newspaper of at most $ 660 in the larcenous scheme involving falsified "returns" of nonredeemable papers, and petit larceny is not among the criminal acts designated in the enterprise corruption statute (Penal Law § 460.10 [1]). Similarly, the evidence is insufficient to support the crimes relating to the circulation scheme in the absence of any evidence that defendant was aware of the alleged conspiracy to inflate circulation figures by the creation of false delivery routes.

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - "Pattern of Criminal Activity" - Participation in Three or More "Pattern" Crimes

5. Defendant, the director of circulation at a newspaper which was the target of a criminal enterprise that engaged in a "pattern of criminal activity" designed to control its circulation department by means of extortion, coercion, falsification of business records, bribery and other crimes for financial gain, may not be prosecuted for enterprise corruption (Penal Law § 460.20 [1] [a]) for his involvement in an alleged conspiracy to inflate circulation figures since there is no evidence that defendant committed the alleged crimes of scheme to defraud and falsifying business records in order to further the criminal enterprise (Penal Law § 460.10 [2]). Rather, the evidence only supports the inference that defendant conceived and committed these crimes independently of the criminal enterprise, using some of the members of the criminal enterprise, to further the newspaper's interests by fraudulent means unrelated to the purposes of the criminal enterprise.

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - "Pattern of Criminal Activity" - Participation in Three or More "Pattern" Crimes

6. Defendant, a member of a criminal enterprise designed to control a newspaper's circulation department by means of extortion, coercion, falsification of business records, bribery and other crimes for financial gain, may properly be prosecuted for enterprise corruption (Penal Law § 460.20 [1] [a]) based upon his commission of 20 acts of forgery in the second degree in connection with his endorsement of payroll checks issued to a deceased employee and upon his participation in the conspiracy to commit grand larceny (Penal Law § 460.10 [1] [a]). The evidence before the Grand Jury justified the inference that the larceny benefited various members of the criminal enterprise and that defendant committed the forgeries with the intent to participate in and to advance the affairs of the criminal enterprise. Defendant's commission of three or more criminal acts as part of a common scheme or plan constitutes participation in the "pattern of criminal activity", where the transaction is part of a larger pattern established by evidence of other unrelated criminal transactions.

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - "Pattern of Criminal Activity" - Participation in Three or More "Pattern" Crimes - Improper Charge on Forgery Counts

7. Defendants, foremen at a newspaper which was the target of a criminal enterprise that engaged in a "pattern of criminal activity" designed to control its circulation department by means of extortion, coercion, falsification of business records, bribery and other crimes for financial gain, may not be prosecuted for enterprise corruption (Penal Law § 460.20 [1] [a]) based upon their commission of the crime of conspiracy to commit grand larceny pursuant to a payroll scheme, whereby they each endorsed payroll checks issued to a deceased employee, and upon the "pattern" crimes of forgery, possession of a forged instrument and falsifying business records since the prosecutor did not adequately instruct the Grand Jury as to the elements constituting the alleged "pattern" criminal acts. Defendants signed the payroll checks in their own names in a representative capacity as foremen. Under such circumstances, the instruments could only have been forgeries if defendants knew that the payee was nonexistent (Penal Law § 170.00 [5]), but the Grand Jury was not instructed as to this legal principle. Therefore, the prosecution may not rely on the alleged "pattern" crimes of forgery or of criminal possession of a forged instrument as to those defendants who signed their names to the payroll checks in the absence of any other evidence of intent to defraud. Furthermore, although the evidence was sufficient as to the defendant foreman who deposited a payroll check into his own account, the single criminal act does not establish that this defendant committed the requisite three criminal acts included within the "pattern of criminal activity" (Penal Law § 460.10 [4]; § 460.20 [2]).

 

846 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Doe v. Rosa


Index No. 22487/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 694; 606 N.Y.S.2d 522; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 512



November 17, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended March 4, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner homosexual law student filed a petition for review of an order of respondent Commissioner of the Division of Human Rights, which dismissed appellant's complaint and reversed a determination of the Division of Human Rights that respondent law school engaged in an improper discriminatory action when it permitted the use of law school placement services by an employer which discriminated upon the basis of sexual orientation.


OVERVIEW: Respondent law school allowed military recruiters to use its placement services and facilities. Petitioner homosexual law student filed a complaint claiming respondent law school violated Governor's Exec. Order No. 28.1, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 4.28, which prohibited discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, because the military engaged in such discrimination. The Division of Human Rights found that respondent law school engaged in an improper discriminatory action, but respondent Commissioner of the Division of Human Rights (commissioner) reversed, finding that state and federal law required respondent law school to provide access to the military for recruitment. The court granted the petition for review. A plain reading of state law permitted application of a uniform anti-discrimination policy by an educational institution. Further, respondent commissioner's findings, that the executive order could not prohibit lawful discrimination and that the military policy of exclusion based upon sexual orientation was lawful under federal law, was error as it ignored the direct violation of the executive order by respondent law school, a part of the executive branch.


OUTCOME: The court reversed an order of respondent Commissioner of the Division of Human Rights, which had reversed a determination that respondent law school improperly allowed an employer that discriminated upon the basis of sexual orientation to use its facilities. Respondent law school violated the state's prohibition against discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.


HEADNOTES

Colleges and Universities - Military Recruitment - Denying Access to Military Recruiters at State Institutions Due to Sexual Orientation Discrimination in Employment Practices - No Federal Preemption

The law school at a State University engaged in an improper discriminatory action in violation of Governor's Executive Order No. 28, which prohibits sexual orientation discrimination by any State agency or department (9 NYCRR 4.28), by allowing military recruiters the use of its placement services and university facilities since the military currently engages in sexual orientation discrimination in its employment practices. State law, which mandates on-campus military recruitment access "on the same basis" as other employers (Education Law § 2-a), permits application of a uniform antidiscrimination policy by an educational institution to which the statute applies and does not grant any preferential treatment to military recruiters so as to require the law school to provide access to the military for recruitment. The statute is not violated by applying to military recruiters the same antidiscrimination policies applicable to other potential employers. Furthermore, the fact that the military's practice of discriminating on the basis of sexual orientation is permissible under Federal law does not deprive the State, on preemption grounds, of power of prohibit discriminatory employment practices and limit recruitment speech.

 

847 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Marigliano v. Krumholtz


INDEX NO. 10992/87


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, CIVIL TERM, QUEENS COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 596; 603 N.Y.S.2d 1020; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 503



November 10, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended January 11, 1994.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant tortfeasors, a husband and wife, sought to protect transcripts and memoranda relating to surveillance tapes taken of plaintiff injured party as attorney's work product as privileged under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3101(c), or as privileged matter under rule 3101(b).


OVERVIEW: The tortfeasors admitted liability for negligence after their vehicle struck the injured party. Prior to commencement of the damages portion of the trial, the tortfeasors turned over, for examination to the other side, videotapes taken of the injured party unbeknownst to him. The injured party asserted that he was entitled to see any existing notes or memos relating to the tapes pursuant to N.Y. C.P.LR. 3101(i). The tortfeasors took the position that any such material was privileged and violated the attorney-client relationship. The court held that fairness required any memoranda to be disclosed because a hidden manipulation could become apparent from the contents of the documents. In addition, there was no basis to raise a constitutional issue since the parties were on an equal footing and the only remaining issue was the amount of damages. The court declined to extend, in a civil case, the protection guaranteed in criminal prosecutions under the Fifth Amendment. The underlying policy of the privilege was designed to protect individuals from oppression at the hands of a state exercising its awesome powers of investigation and could not be used in this civil matter.


OUTCOME: The court held that transcripts or memoranda relating to surveillance tapes were discoverable.


HEADNOTES

Disclosure - Material Exempt from Disclosure - Material Prepared for Litigation - Surveillance Tapes and Memoranda of Surveillance Tapes of Personal Injury Plaintiff

1. Plaintiffs are entitled to disclosure of memoranda of videotapes taken by defendants' investigators to refute plaintiff's claim of alleged serious injuries because the memoranda are discoverable material pursuant to CPLR 3101 (i). Videotapes and memoranda regarding videotapes are easily manipulated. Thus, they must be disclosed so that an adversary will be able to discover whether the tape has been distorted or manipulated. A sense of fairness requires any memoranda be disclosed as part of discovery prior to trial. A court may, however, authorize redaction of any information in the memoranda that constitutes attorney's work product.

Disclosure - Material Exempt from Disclosure - Material Prepared for Litigation - Surveillance Tapes and Memoranda of Surveillance Tapes of Personal Injury Plaintiff

2. Plaintiffs are entitled to disclosure of memoranda of videotapes taken by defendants' investigators to refute plaintiff's claim of alleged serious injuries because the memoranda are discoverable material, pursuant to CPLR 3101 (i), and discovery of the tapes is not excessive and unconstitutional. New York law favors an open disclosure policy and liberal interpretation of CPLR 3101 has been the hallmark of this policy. A mere allegation of infirmity is insufficient to raise an issue under CPLR 3101 (i) where no specific facts are offered to support the claim. In addition, because parties to a civil action are on an equal footing, the Court of Appeals has declined to extend to civil cases the protection guaranteed in criminal prosecutions under the Fifth Amendment. Thus, the defendants have no basis to raise a constitutional issue.

 

848 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Simeonov v. Tiegs


INDEX NO. 122589/90, INDEX NO. 122590/90, INDEX NO. 122591/90


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, TRIAL TERM, NEW YORK COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 54; 602 N.Y.S.2d 1014; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 406



September 30, 1993, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended November 18, 1993. Second Amendment.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants, tenant, landlord, and apartment building managing agent, filed a motion in limine seeking to limit plaintiff sculptor's evidence as to damages in a negligence action for damages resulting from the destruction of sculptor's personal property which was inside tenant's apartment.


OVERVIEW: Tenant was a fashion model who posed for an alginate impression of her face by sculptor. Sculptor, without tenant's consent, subsequently modified the impression to make a casting of tenant's head sleeping on a pillow. He took the cast to tenant's apartment so that she could view it where it remained for two months until it was accidentally broken by apartment maintenance workers. Sculptor filed suit seeking damages for copies of the cast which he had planned to reproduce and sell. Tenant, landlord, and apartment building managing agent contended that because sculptor made the cast without tenant's consent and planned to sell copies thereof, his actions constituted trade under N.Y. Civ. Rights Law §§ 50 and 51 and because tenant could have obtained injunctive relief and damages thereunder, they could not be liable to sculptor for damages because he was not entitled to sell copies of the cast in light of §§ 50 and 51. The court held that an artist could make a work of art that included a recognizable likeness of a person without the person's consent and sell limited copies thereof without violating §§ 50 and 51. The court denied the motion in limine.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion in limine.


HEADNOTES

Civil Rights - Right of Privacy - Plaster Casting of Individual Made without Consent - Defensive Use of Civil Rights Law § 51

In an action by plaintiff sculptor to recover damages allegedly arising from the corporate and individual defendants' negligent destruction of a plaster casting made of the individual defendant, and modified by plaintiff without the individual defendant's consent, which plaintiff intended to use to make a limited edition of 10 copies thereof for sale, plaintiff is not barred from introducing evidence as to his claim for damages for the 10 copies on the ground that his actual and intended actions constituted "trade" for which the individual defendant could have obtained injunctive relief and damages under Civil Rights Law §§ 50 and 51. Although generally these statutes are utilized to obtain affirmative relief, the concept that underlies them can be used defensively as defendants do here. However, because Civil Rights Law § 50 is a penal provision, it does not apply to the civil act here; additionally, just because plaintiff incidentally intended to sell a limited number of copies of his creation, that does not mean that he was acting "for the purpose of trade", which is barred by Civil Rights Law § 51. While a person's right of privacy as protected by sections 50 and 51 is a very significant right, it must fall to the constitutionally protected right of freedom of speech. An artist may make a work of art that includes a recognizable likeness of a person without his or her consent and sell a limited number of copies thereof without violating Civil Rights Law §§ 50 and 51.

 

849 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Roth v. Cuevas


Index No. 115602/93


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 238; 603 N.Y.S.2d 962; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 443



September 22, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Therefore, the petition, as amended, is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner secretary of a term limits group filed an action against respondent city clerk to have an initiative petition regarding term limits declared valid, proper, and legally effective, to order the city clerk to deliver a certificate to the city counsel stating the petition complied with all legal requirements, and to deliver the initiative to the city board of elections.


OVERVIEW: The secretary filed a petition with the city clerk, which sought to place on the next election ballot the issue of term limits for certain public offices. The city clerk certified that the petition did not comply with all legal requirements because there was no statutory authority for a local law limiting terms, and that if enacted, it would be unconstitutional by infringing on voters' rights to choose candidates and incumbents' rights to be elected. The secretary then filed an action under N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 37(5). The court found that the city was authorized to enact term limits, that the state law's silence on allowing term limits did not mean that term limits were illegal, and that voters' right to choose the candidate of their choice was not absolute and a candidate's right to seek public office was not fundamental.


OUTCOME: The court granted the secretary's petition.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers - Term of Office - Validity of Term Limits for Certain Municipal Officials

1. Initiative petitions containing the requisite number of valid voter signatures filed with respondent City Clerk, which seek to amend the New York City Charter to establish a limit on the number of consecutive terms of office that various elected officials can serve, are valid and must be placed on the ballot for public referendum. New York City is authorized to enact the term limit legislation proposed in the voter initiative petitions under its home rule powers since such legislation relates to the City's "affairs" and/or "government" as well as to the "terms of office" of its "officers" (Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [i], [ii] [a] [1]; NY Const, art IX, § 2 [c]). The State has no paramount interest in term limits placed on New York City public officers and the proposed term limit law is thus not substantially a matter of State-wide concern.

Local Laws - Term Limits for Certain Municipal Officials - Proposed Voter Initiative Not Inconsistent with State Law

2. Initiative petitions containing the requisite number of valid voter signatures filed with respondent City Clerk, which seek to amend the New York City Charter to establish a limit on the number of consecutive terms of office that various elected officials can serve, are valid and must be placed on the ballot for public referendum. The proposed term limit law is a proper subject of local legislation under the City's home rule powers (Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [i], [ii] [a] [1]; NY Const, art IX, § 2 [c]) and is not inconsistent with State law but is rather a permissible supplement to existing State law with respect to a topic on which State law is silent. Respondents have failed to establish that the term limit law prohibits what is specifically permitted by the State Constitution or State law or that the term limit law permits what is specifically forbidden by the Constitution or State law. Respondents have similarly failed to demonstrate that the State has preempted the field of setting qualifications for holding office or terms of office, either expressly or impliedly. In addition, the proposed local law is also a permissible "amendment" subject to public referendum pursuant to Municipal Home Rule Law § 37 since it clearly relates to and affects existing provisions of the New York City Charter regarding public offices and the terms of office.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Term Limits for Certain Municipal Officials Not Arbitrary Exclusion from Office

3. Initiative petitions containing the requisite number of valid voter signatures filed with respondent City Clerk, which seek to amend the New York City Charter to establish a limit on the number of consecutive terms of office that various elected officials can serve, are valid and must be placed on the ballot for public referendum. The limitation of the number of consecutive terms of certain City officials is not an arbitrary exclusion from office, but rather is a rational decision that would have a neutral application toward all candidates and would not discriminate on the basis of race, creed, color or sex. Furthermore, the proposed term limit legislation has rational bases, viz., to broaden opportunities for political and public participation, reduce the opportunities for corruption, and increase citizens' confidence in the integrity of their government.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Term Limits for Certain Municipal Officials - Right to Choose Candidates of Choice

4. Initiative petitions containing the requisite number of valid voter signatures filed with respondent City Clerk, which seek to amend the New York City Charter to establish a limit on the number of consecutive terms of office that various elected officials can serve, are valid and must be placed on the ballot for public referendum. The proposed term limit law would not disenfranchise citizens or impair fundamental rights. All voters will still be able to find, on the ballot, a candidate who most nearly reflects his or her policy preferences on contemporary issues. The proposed local law would be neutrally applied to all political parties, so as not to burden the right to vote by restricting the individual voter's choice to only major-party candidates. The proposed local law would in no way violate the constitutional rule of "one voter, one vote" nor would the constitutional right of association be infringed since associational rights do not require that any particular individual serve as a candidate.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Term Limits for Certain Municipal Officials - Right of Elected Officials to Seek Office - Equal Protection of Laws - Due Process of Law

5. Initiative petitions containing the requisite number of valid voter signatures filed with respondent City Clerk, which seek to amend the New York City Charter to establish a limit on the number of consecutive terms of office that various elected officials can serve, are valid and must be placed on the ballot for public referendum. The proposed term limit law would not unconstitutionally infringe on the equal protection or due process rights of elected officials to seek or hold office since there is no "fundamental right" to be a candidate. Term limits can be sustained as being rationally related to such legitimate governmental purposes as broadening opportunities for political and public participation, reducing the opportunities for corruption, and increasing citizens' confidence in the integrity of their government. Respondents have otherwise failed to demonstrate that term limits of public officers of New York City are of sufficient importance to the State, generally, to render term limits an improper subject of local legislation. Rather, the proposed law is a proper subject of local legislation under the City's home rule powers (Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [1] [i], [ii] [a] [1]; NY Const, art IX, § 2 [c]) since it clearly implicates substantial matters of local concern.

 

850 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Caruso v. Civilian Complaint Review Bd.


Index No. 93/117222


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 909; 602 N.Y.S.2d 487; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 382



August 20, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner police officers filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding seeking to enjoin respondent Civilian Complaint Review Board (Board) from enforcing N.Y. City Charter § 440, which allowed the Board to compel officers to appear before and respond to inquiries of the Board and its civilian investigators.


OVERVIEW: Police officers sought to enjoin the Board from enforcing § 440, which allowed the Board to compel officers to appear before and respond to inquiries of the Board and its civilian investigators, arguing that § 440 violated their constitutional right against self-incrimination. The court found that the officers failed to demonstrate any likelihood of ultimate success on the merits of their claims, and therefore denied injunctive relief. The court rejected the officers' argument regarding self-incrimination because it found that the officers' responses were automatically cloaked with immunity and could not be used against them in a subsequent criminal prosecution, even though § 440 did not expressly authorize the Board to grant use immunity. The court held that when a public employee was compelled to give testimony under the threat of job loss, the responses were cloaked with use immunity. Accordingly, in this case, because the officers were required to respond to questions by the Board, the court found that their responses were protected. The court also rejected the officers' argument that § 440 impaired their contractual rights.


OUTCOME: The court denied the police officers' claim for injunctive relief and dismissed their petition. The officers' rights against self-incrimination were not violated when they responded to questions by the Board because their responses were cloaked with use immunity because they were compelled to respond.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Privilege against Self-Incrimination - Establishment of Civilian Complaint Review Board - Automatic Grant of Use Immunity

1. Section 440 of the New York City Charter, which establishes a new Civilian Complaint Review Board comprised entirely of non-police-department personnel, is not unconstitutional for failing to expressly protect the constitutional privilege against self-incrimination of police officers called to testify before the Board since use immunity requires no specific statutory authorization. An officer responding to a Board inquiry and threatened with suspension or discharge from the force if the officer refuses to respond to any questions is automatically cloaked with use immunity in any future criminal proceedings. Where a public employee is compelled to testify under threat of dismissal, use immunity attaches automatically by operation of law and flows directly from the Constitution.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Impairment of Contract - Establishment of Civilian Complaint Review Board - Interrogation of Police Officers

2. Section 440 of the New York City Charter, which establishes a new Civilian Complaint Review Board comprised entirely of non-police-department personnel, is not unconstitutional for impairing police officers' contractual rights by allowing non-police-department employees to interrogate police officers in violation of the confidentiality provisions of the police officers' collective bargaining agreement, since the agreement permits the "Guidelines for Interrogation of members of the Department" to be altered, as here, "to reflect subsequent changes in the law" and there is thus no impairment of contractual rights.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Void for Vagueness - Establishment of Civilian Complaint Review Board - Automatic Grant of Use Immunity

3. Section 440 of the New York City Charter, which establishes a new Civilian Complaint Review Board comprised entirely of non-police-department personnel, is not unconstitutionally vague for not expressly conferring use immunity on police being questioned by the Board since use immunity requires no specific statutory authorization. Use immunity is an inherent constitutional right that inures to any public employee who is compelled to testify under threat of dismissal. There is no affirmative obligation to inform officers of the automatic attachment of immunity.

 

851 of 992 DOCUMENTS
