Cacace v. Crosson


93-415


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 595; 601 N.Y.S.2d 557; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 334



August 9, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, judges of the city court of Yonkers, sought salary parity with the district court judges of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, as well as ancillary relief. The city judges filed a motion for summary judgment, and defendants, the state and its comptroller, filed a cross-motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The city judges filed a declaratory judgment action seeking salary parity and ancillary relief. The court concluded that the statutory provisions establishing disparate salaries for the city judges and the district court county judges could not be justified rationally by reasons of disparities in population, case load and/or cost of living. The statutory provisions that established and perpetuated the disparity in salaries had to be declared unconstitutional as denying the city judges equal protection of the laws.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city judge's motion for summary judgement and declared the statutory provision unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Judges - Judicial Salaries - Salary Parity between Yonkers City Court Judges and District Court Judges of Nassau and Suffolk Counties

Plantiffs, past or present Yonkers City Court Judges, are entitled to salary parity with the District Court Judges of Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The statutory provisions establishing disparate salaries for plaintiffs and the District Court Judges are unconstitutional as denying plaintiffs equal protection of the laws since the disparity in salaries cannot be justified by reasons of disparities in population, case load and/or cost of living, especially in view of the fact that the cost of living in Westchester County is the highest in any county in the State. Even if the cost of living in the City of Yonkers constitutes the relevant data, plaintiffs have shown that Yonkers and the judicial district of Babylon in Suffolk County have very similar economic profiles.

 

852 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Doe v. State


Claim No. 82265.


COURT OF CLAIMS OF NEW YORK


159 Misc. 2d 83; 602 N.Y.S.2d 990; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 414



August 6, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was the motion of claimant judgment creditor for an order requiring that all the outstanding payments under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 50-B structured judgment be accelerated in a lump sum without reduction to present value and be immediately due and payable.


OVERVIEW: The judgment creditor had made a motion pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 5044 for an order requiring that all the outstanding payments under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 50-B structured judgment be accelerated in a lump sum without reduction to present value and be immediately due and payable. The court denied the motion. The judgment creditor argued that full payment was required because the judgment debtor tendered payment of its first installment of $ 43,471 due under the second amended judgment on July 7 rather than July 1, 1993. However, article 5044 did not define what constituted a failure to make a payment in a timely fashion. The court found the judgment creditor did not establish that the judgment debtor had failed to make a payment in a timely fashion within the meaning of article 5044 on this record. Further, in the context presented and where the second amended judgment in no way indicated time was of the essence, the court found that the payment under the second amended judgment was made in a timely fashion within the meaning of article 5044.


OUTCOME: The court denied the judgment creditor's motion for an order requiring that all the outstanding payments under the structured judgment be accelerated in a lump sum without reduction to present value and be immediately due and payable.


HEADNOTES

Judgments - Acceleration of Structured Judgment - Failure to Make Payment

Claimants' motion pursuant to CPLR 5044 for an order requiring that all the outstanding payments under the CPLR article 50-B structured judgment be accelerated in a lump sum without reduction to present value and be immediately due and payable because the defendant tendered payment of its first installment on July 7 rather than July 1, 1993 is denied where the judgment does not indicate that time is of the essence, and it is undisputed that the signed bank agreements from claimants requesting payment to an account at the bank was received on or about June 17 and 18, 1993, but since the bank zip code was omitted, data entry was delayed until July 2 and, with July 5 a holiday, the check was not issued until July 6. The court is vested with some discretion in determining whether a judgment debtor's conduct has actually amounted to a failure to make a payment in a timely fashion in the context presented. Here, claimants have not established that the defendant failed to make a payment in a "timely fashion" within the meaning of CPLR 5044.

 

853 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Colonial Life Ins. Co. of Am. v. Curiale


Index No. 1537-93, RJI No. 0193ST4096


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SPECIAL TERM, ALBANY COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 221; 603 N.Y.S.2d 263; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 418



July 30, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended November 22, 1993.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner insurer brought suit under N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 to challenge two regulations promulgated by respondent state insurance agency.


OVERVIEW: The insurer challenged two regulations promulgated by the state insurance agency, asserting that they were beyond the scope of authority delegated to the agency by the legislature. The court determined that the pool contributions mandated by Regulation 146, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 11, § 361.1, for insurers with a lower share of high risk insureds, were not a tax and were within the state's power to regulate the industry. The regulation was a rational interpretation of the statute under which it was promulgated. Regulation 145, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 11, § 360.4(c), however, was contrary to the mandatory directive of N.Y. Ins. Law § 3231(a), which defined "small group" as 3 to 50 employees. N.Y. Ins. Law § 3233(a) did not provide authority for requiring insurers of small groups to extend coverage to individual proprietors and groups of two. N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 11, § 360.3(a)(1)(ii), improperly amended N.Y. Ins. Law § 4235(c) by stating that if 50 percent of the employees of a group elected to participate in the small group policy, or in a policy offered by a health maintenance organization, the insurer had to offer the group policy.


OUTCOME: The court determined that one of the two regulations challenged by the insurer was within the state's power to regulate the insurance industry, but that the other regulation exceeded the scope of authority delegated to the state insurance agency.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Standing of Commercial Health Insurer to Challenge Mandatory Pooling Mechanism

1. Petitioner, a commercial health insurer, has standing to challenge an Insurance Department regulation (11 NYCRR part 361) which, pursuant to the statutory mandate of chapter 501 of the Laws of 1992 that commercial health insurers doing business in New York employ community rating and offer open enrollment for any insurance market in which they participate, requires it to make payment to an insurance pool, even though petitioner has not clearly demonstrated its claim of injury in fact. The merits of the claim should be reached in this case in view of the important purpose of the enabling statute of broadening the availability and affordability of health insurance in New York by precluding commercial insurers from offering coverage only to low-risk individuals and in view of the Legislature's strongly expressed interest in encouraging insurers to remain in the individual and small group markets to assure greater availability of health insurance in the State. While standing principles require something more than the interest of the public at large to entitle a person to seek judicial review, proof of special damage or injury in fact is not required in every instance.

Insurance - Health and Accident Insurance - Individual and Small Group Health Insurance - Validity of Mandatory Pool Contributions by Insurers Having Lower Share of High-Risk Insureds

2. An Insurance Department regulation which establishes a pooling mechanism whereby commercial health insurers who have a lower share of high-risk insureds must contribute to the pool while insurers who have a higher share of high-risk insureds may withdraw from the pool, is authorized by the enabling statute (L 1992, ch 501) and is in all respects valid. The mandatory pool contributions do not constitute an unconstitutional tax and are within the State's power to regulate the industry. Nor do such contributions constitute a taking by regulation without just compensation since any insurer required to contribute to the pool may include the contribution amount in its rate increase application. Moreover, any property interest an insurer has in its business arises from, and may be altered by, State law, especially in view of the State's constitutional authority to protect its citizens against sickness, by insurance or otherwise (NY Const. art VII, § 8 [2]). Furthermore, nothing in the enabling statute limits application of the pooling mechanism to only future policies written after the statute's effective date. In addition, the regulation represents a rational interpretation of the enabling statute, which was intended to extend the burden of insuring high-risk customers to commercial insurers; it is reasonable to interpret the pooling mechanism as a device which was intended to benefit Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield, the only insurer in the State which was obligated to provide coverage for high-risk insureds. Lastly, the Legislature must be deemed to have intended that contributions to the pooling mechanism be mandatory since a pool dependent on voluntary contributions would likely be wholly ineffective.

Insurance - Health and Accident Insurance - Individual and Small Group Health Insurance - Validity of Regulation Requiring Insurers of "Small Groups" to Extend Health Coverage to Individual Proprietors and Groups of Two

3. An Insurance Department regulation which, pursuant to the statutory mandate of chapter 501 of the Laws of 1992 that Commercial health insurers doing business in New York employ community rating and offer open enrollment for any insurance market in which they participate in order to precluded commercial insurers from offering coverage only to low-risk individuals, requires insurers of "small groups" to also extend coverage to individual proprietors and groups of two (11 NYCRR 360.4 [c]), is contrary to the unambiguous statutory directive defining "small group" as groups of 3 to 50 (Insurance Law § 3233 [a]) and is thus invalid for exceeding the scope of the delegated authority. Insurance Law § 3231 (b), which provides that "[i]ndividual proprietors and groups of two must be classified in the individual or small group rating category by the insurer", applies only to the rating of policies, requiring insurers who offer insurance to individual proprietors and groups of two to rate them in either the individual or small group category, and does not provide authority for requiring insurers of small groups to extend coverage to individual proprietors and groups of two.

Insurance - Health and Accident Insurance - Individual and Small Group Health Insurance - Validity of Regulation Changing Minimum Participation Levels among Employees in Order to Qualify for Small Group Health Coverage

4. An Insurance Department regulation which, pursuant to the statutory mandate of chapter 501 of the Laws of 1992 that commercial health insurers doing business in New York employ community rating and offer open enrollment for any insurance market in which they participate in order to preclude commercial insurers from offering coverage only to low-risk individuals, amends existing law establishing minimum participation levels among employees in order to qualify for small group coverage (Insurance Law § 4235 [c]) by requiring the insurer to offer a group policy if 50% of the employees elect to participate in the small group policy or in a policy offered by a health maintenance organization (11 NYCRR 360.3 [a][1][ii]), is null and void as exceeding the limit of authority delegated to the Department. While the regulation is not inconsistent with the Legislature's goal of making coverage more widely available, it conflicts with the express statement that commercial insurers should be encouraged to remain in the small group market in pursuit of that goal. General statements of legislative intent do not provide unlimited authorization to the Insurance Department to effect substantive changes in existing law.

 

854 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Brown


Indictment No. 11142/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, CRIMINAL TERM, KINGS COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 11; 603 N.Y.S.2d 256; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 404



July 29, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss an indictment against him that stated counts of criminal usury in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 190.42 and grand larceny under N.Y. Penal Law § 155.40[2].


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved to dismiss an indictment against him that stated two counts, one for criminal usury in the first degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 190.42, and the other for grand larceny under N.Y. Penal Law § 155.40[2]. The Bill of Particulars did not give specific dates of instances of the crime being committed and instead stated that the crime was for an unspecified period lasting sixteen months. The court concluded that both criminal usury and grand larceny fell into the category of crimes that were sometimes continuous and sometimes not continuous. As the Bill of Particulars alleged a single loan to a single individual with a single purpose that constituted a common scheme or plan for personal gain, the court found that each of payment of interest was part of a single continuous course of conduct. As such, the motion to dismiss Count 1 of the Indictment was denied as the period specified in the indictment complied with constitutional mandates and was not duplicitous. The motion also was denied as to Count 2, since the allegations pertaining to it were also sufficient. The prosecutor was however, directed to particularize the approximate month in which the crime commenced.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the usury and grand larceny counts of the indictment, because both acts could be found as a continuous crime and the period specified in the indictment complied with constitutional mandates and was thus sufficient, and was not duplicitous. However, the prosecutor was directed to particularize the approximate month in which the crime commenced.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Indictment - Usury - Continuous Crime

Defendant's motion to dismiss count one of the indictment charging criminal usury in the first degree (Penal Law § 190.42) on the ground that the indictment is vague and duplicitous is denied, where the People allege a single loan, to a single individual, with a single purpose, constituting a single common scheme or plan, for personal gain. Given the legislative intent and purposes, and the nature of the crime, criminal usury falls into a hybrid category of crimes, which have an element that sometimes can be committed by a single act or omission or by several different acts or omissions over a period of time; here, the People's allegations militate toward the conclusion that each payment of interest be deemed part of a single continuous course of conduct. Additionally, the prosecution is directed to particularize the approximate month in which the crime commenced, absent which the "16-month" period stated in the bill of particulars is too nonspecific.

 

855 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schulz v. State


RJI No. 0193 034403


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 169; 601 N.Y.S.2d 239; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 284



July 27, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1]  

EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: In view of the foregoing, there being no triable issues of fact, plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment is denied. Defendants' motions for summary judgment are, for all of the foregoing reasons, granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff citizens filed an action against defendants, state, thruway authority, and transportation authority, seeking a declaratory judgment that sections of 1993 N.Y. Laws ch. 56 were unconstitutional. All parties filed motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Citizens challenged chapter 56's mechanism for financing a bond plan authorized for the transportation authority and the thruway authority. They alleged that using state taxes for debt service on bonds without voter approval violated due process. The court granted the state and the authorities summary judgment and held that the funding mechanisms were constitutionally permissible. A previous case upheld basically the same funding mechanisms. The doctrine of stare decisis required the court to follow precedent. The citizens failed to prove that chapter 56 was unconstitutional beyond a reasonable doubt. The legislature had the authority to dedicate proceeds of particular taxes to the use of a public corporation. The citizens' failure to challenge the 1991 funding mechanisms in highway and bridge programs until 1993 barred them from challenging the financing of those programs.


OUTCOME: The court denied the citizens' motion for summary judgment in their action seeking a declaration that a statute was unconstitutional and granted the state, thruway authority, and transportation authority's motions for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Taxpayers' Action Challenging Constitutionality of Debt-Incurring Legislation - Statutory Bond Authorization for Funding Local Highway and Bridge Improvement Programs

1. Plaintiffs have standing as citizen taxpayers to challenge, as an alleged violation of the constitutional referendum requirement for incurring State debt (NY Const, art VII, § 11), the statutory financing mechanisms, whereby two public benefit corporations, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Thruway Authority, are authorized to issue special "appropriation-risk" bonds, which expressly are not to be debts of the State, for the financing of mass transportation, bridge, and highway projects from dedicated funds, backed by revenue from monies collected from State-wide taxes and fees, and subject to an annual appropriation by the Legislature (L 1993, ch 56). However, the scope of plaintiffs' standing will not be broadened to include their other constitutional challenges to the statutory bond authorization.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statutory Bond Authorization for Funding Local Highway and Bridge Improvement Programs

2. The statutory financing mechanisms, whereby two public benefit corporations, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Thruway Authority, are authorized to issue special "appropriation-risk" bonds, which are not to be debts of the State, for the financing of mass transportation, bridge, and highway projects from dedicated funds, backed by revenue from monies collected from State-wide taxes and fees, and subject to an annual appropriation by the Legislature (L 1993, ch 56), are not violative of the constitutional referendum requirement for incurring State debt (NY Const, art VII, § 11) under established precedent since the State is not legally liable for any obligations issued pursuant to the bond authorization for funding capital improvements. The bonds are payable solely out of annual appropriations that the State is under no duty to make. Plaintiffs have failed to meet their heavy burden in challenging the constitutionality of the legislative enactment.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statutory Bond Authorization for Funding Local Highway and Bridge Improvement Programs

3. The statutory financing mechanisms, whereby two public benefit corporations, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Thruway Authority, are authorized to issue special "appropriation-risk" bonds, which are expressly not to be debts of the State, for the financing of mass transportation, bridge, and highway projects from dedicated funds, backed by revenue from monies collected from State-wide taxes and fees, and subject to annual appropriation by the Legislature (L 1993, ch 56), are not violative of plaintiffs' due process rights as citizen-taxpayers. The Legislature has the authority to appropriate funds to a public benefit corporation for a public purpose and to dedicate the proceeds of particular taxes to the use of such a corporation.

Equity - Laches - Taxpayers' Action Challenging Constitutionality of Debt-Incurring Legislation - Statutory Bond Authorization for Funding Local Highway and Bridge Improvement Programs

4. A taxpayers' action, commenced in May 1993, challenging the constitutionality of the authorization of additional bonding for local highway and bridge improvement programs pursuant to the 1991 statutory financing mechanisms, whereby two public benefit corporations, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Thruway Authority, are authorized to issue special "appropriation-risk" bonds, which are expressly not to be debts of the State, for the financing of mass transportation, bridge, and highway projects from dedicated funds, backed by revenue from monies collected from State-wide taxes and fees, and subject to annual appropriation by the Legislature (L 1993, ch 56), is barred by laches where the localities, in reliance on these programs, have expended funds and committed themselves to programs with the expectation that they will be reimbursed. Time must be of the essence in light of the great prejudice certain to be inflicted on the State and its citizens when financial transactions of such magnitude and destabilizing impact are at stake and may be upset.

 

856 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Natoli v. Sullivan


INDEX NO. 92-1452, RJI NO. 37-92-0509


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, OSWEGO COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 681; 606 N.Y.S.2d 504; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 505; 21 Media L. Rep. 2097



July 14, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs asserted a civil claim against defendants, publications company and newspapers, under the Wiretap Act, 18 U.S.C.S. § 2510 et seq. Defendant publications company filed a pre-answer motion for dismissal of the complaint on the basis that it did not state a claim against it upon which relief can be granted under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3211(a)(7). Defendant newspaper then filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The complaint alleged that defendants eavesdropped and illegally intercepted and recorded private telephonic communications of plaintiffs. The complaint alleged that defendants intentionally and maliciously used electronic, mechanical, and other devices to intercept plaintiffs' telephonic communications in order to obtain political, economic, personal and other advantage at plaintiffs' expense. It was alleged that a certain illegally recorded tape of a private communication between plaintiffs was distributed by defendants to the media defendants. It was further alleged that the student college newspaper and its editors intentionally published, disclosed to the public, and used the contents of the illegally recorded oral wire and electronic communications in an article. The local daily newspaper allegedly intentionally published, disclosed, and used the contents of the same illegally intercepted and recorded tape in an article. The court stated that the governmental interest in protecting the privacy of telephonic communications from unauthorized intrusion was sufficiently substantial to permit the punishment of the publication of truthful information lawfully obtained.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss the third and fourth causes of action.


HEADNOTES

Newspapers - Liability for Publication of Illegally Recorded Conversations - Information Lawfully Obtained by Newspaper

Defendant newspapers' motion to dismiss a complaint asserting a civil claim pursuant to 18 USC § 2510 et seq., and alleging that they intentionally published, disclosed to the public and used in newspaper articles the contents of illegally recorded private telephonic conversations relating to matters of public interest procured by private parties in the first instance is denied. Defendants are not protected by a blanket rule, based upon the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, prohibiting an award of damages against the media for publication of true information lawfully acquired. 18 USC § 2511 prohibits knowing disclosure by third parties without regard to participation in the illegal interception, and no exception is made for the media. The rule prohibiting the publication of the contents of illegal wiretapes or other electronic surveillance with knowledge of the illegality has sufficiently defined parameters to be readily understood and applied, and the civil sanctions of 18 USC § 2520 are narrowly tailored to a Federal constitutional interest of the highest order. While there is a weighty fundamental interest in the free dissemination of information under the First Amendment, the conversations intercepted were purely private and no public interest is served by their revelation. The governmental interest in protecting the privacy of telephone communications from unauthorized intrusion is sufficiently substantial to permit the punishment of the publication of truthful information lawfully obtained in this case.

 

857 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Thompson


Indictment No. 2416/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 397; 601 N.Y.S.2d 418; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 274



July 1, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted of multiple kidnapping, sexual assault, and other offenses. At his jury trial, the trial judge had become incapacitated after evidence had begun and was replaced by another judge without defendant's consent. Defendant then appealed and sought to have the guilty verdicts set aside.


OVERVIEW: The issue of whether a judge, who became incapacitated after evidence had begun at a criminal jury trial, could be replaced by another judge to complete the trial over defendant's objection was one of first impression in New York. Defendant's trial had already begun when the sitting judge was admitted to the hospital for cardiac surgery. The judge that ultimately heard the case was approached about the consequences of a possible substitution in an "academic discussion." The judge then was assigned the case, upon which defendant sought recusal. The court refused to set aside the guilty verdicts and held that recusal was not required. There was no suggestion of actual or apparent bias, and no prejudice was claimed by defendant. The judge thoroughly read the trial transcript for the earlier portion of the trial. Neither federal nor New York law precluded a midtrial substitution for an incapacitated judge without defendant's consent. The case was tried to a jury, thereby removing the possibility of unfairness to defendant. Because New York adhered to a strict separation between the responsibilities of the judge and jury, substitution in the instant case was proper.


OUTCOME: The court held that the substitution of trial judges was proper and that it would have been entirely unwarranted to set aside the jury verdict and require a retrial. Defendant's motion was denied in all respects.


HEADNOTES

Judges - Recusal - Midtrial Substitution for Incapacitated Judge in Criminal Jury Trial

1. The Judge who replaced an incapacitated Judge to complete a criminal jury trial over defendant's objection to the midtrial substitution need not recuse himself on defendant's motion to have the guilty verdicts set aside on the ground that continuation of the trial was improper, in the absence of any actual or apparent bias arising from some personal interest in the outcome of the case or some connection with it that would require disqualification as a matter of law. The fact that the substituted Judge, in casual conversation with defendant's attorney prior to the actual substitution, expressed a preliminary view that midtrial substitution would be permissible provided that the new Judge adhered to all rulings made by the original Judge and was furnished with the record of prior proceedings to become familiar with the evidence in the case, does not disqualify the substituted Judge from now deciding defendant's postverdict motion.

Crimes - Trial - Propriety of Midtrial Substitution for Incapacitated Judge in Jury Trial

2. In the absence of a showing of prejudice, substitution for an incapacitated Trial Judge after evidence has begun in a criminal jury trial by a Judge of coordinate jurisdiction who has reviewed and become thoroughly familiar with the trial record and who is bound by the rulings of the original Judge, is permissible even without defendant's consent. Since New York law establishes and adheres to a strict separation between the responsibility of the Judge to decide questions of law and the jury to find the facts, neither Judiciary Law § 21, which provides that a lower court Judge cannot decide any question argued during his or her absence, nor any other statutory provision prevents a substituted Judge from completing a jury trial in which the Judge will not be called upon to render a decision based upon an evaluation of unheard testimony. The fact that a substituted Judge has not personally heard the witnesses who testified before the substitution does not, in and of itself, impair that Judge's ability to perform the judicial functions and responsibilities necessary for the completion of a jury trial in conformance with New York law. Accordingly, midtrial substitution herein was proper after the original Judge became incapacitated due to cardiac surgery and defendant's motion to set aside the guilty verdicts because of the substitution is therefore denied.

 

858 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Villatoro


Summons & Case No. 67012


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF WESTBURY, NASSAU COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 557; 601 N.Y.S.2d 410; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 328



June 29, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with violating Village and Town of North Hempstead, N.Y., Ordinance § 26A-3(A) (ordinance), which criminalized the possession of an open container of any alcoholic beverage in any public area. After defendant's arraignment, the court requested a memorandum of law from the prosecutor regarding the legality of the ordinance.


OVERVIEW: Specifically, the ordinance made unlawful the possession of an open container containing any alcoholic beverage in any public place within the village. The court ruled that the ordinance impermissibly offended the Fifth Amendment of the United States Constitution. The court reasoned that because the ordinance rendered unlawful the mere possession of an open container without specifically requiring the intent to consume the alcoholic beverage in the container to support a conviction under the ordinance, and because there was no legislative findings or any other demonstration that there existed a reasonable relation between mere possession of an open container of an alcoholic beverage and the public good, the ordinance was unconstitutional. The court directed the village clerk to remove the ordinance from the village code.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the ordinance was unconstitutional and dismissed the case against defendant.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Possession of Open Container of Alcoholic Beverage - Village "Open Container" Law Unconstitutional in Absence of Intent to Consume Requirement

A Village "open container" law, which proscribes the mere possession of an open container containing any alcoholic beverage in any public place within the Village without specifically requiring the intent to consume such beverage, is unconstitutional in the absence of any legislative findings or any other demonstration that there exists a reasonable relation between mere possession of an open container of an alcoholic beverage and the public good.

 

859 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Dieppa


INDICTMENT NO. 6410/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 584; 601 N.Y.S.2d 786; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 330



June 25, 1993, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] This court finds the defendant's described interference with the exercise of Mr. Mohibi's civil rights to be criminal within the intendment of Civil Rights Law § 40-c (2) and legally constitutes the crime of discrimination as defined by that statute. Accordingly, the motion to set aside the convictions upon the two counts of discrimination is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was convicted by a jury of two counts of discrimination as defined in N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 40-c(2) and one count of aggravated harassment in the second degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(3). Defendant filed a motion under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.30(1) to set aside the verdict on the two discrimination counts.


OVERVIEW: A private citizen tormented a native of Afghanistan by shouting racial and religious slurs on a constant basis in a public place, a store. At the close of evidence, defendant moved pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 290.10 to dismiss the discrimination charges. The court reserved decision and submitted the case to the jury. The court found, upon defendant's renewed motion under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 330.30(1) that the convictions on two counts of discrimination under N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 40-c were justified. The court held that § 40-c applied to both state actors and private citizens. In denying the motion, the court found that defendant's described interference with the Afghanistan native's civil rights was criminal within § 40-c.


OUTCOME: The court denied the defendant's motion to set aside the convictions on the two counts of discrimination.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Discrimination - Intentional Interference with "Civil Right" to Pursue Employment Because of Complainant's Perceived Race or Creed

Defendant was properly convicted of discrimination as defined in Civil Rights Law § 40-c (2) for having engaged in repeated assaultive and threatening behavior against a fast food store clerk motivated by religious and ethnic bias. The statute on its face protects all persons from harassment or discrimination in the exercise of their civil rights by any other person or institution because of race, creed, color, national origin, sex, marital status or disability. The harassing conduct of defendant in repeatedly threatening and physically abusing the complainant at his place of employment because of complainant's perceived race or creed provided a factual basis for the jury's verdict that defendant intentionally interfered with complainant's "civil right" to pursue employment and to engage in the use and occupancy of the food store, in contravention of the statute.

 

860 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Jamaica Water Supply Co.


Index No. 04675/88


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 378; 600 N.Y.S.2d 914; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 255



June 21, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended September 20, 1993.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The petitioner city condemnor filed an application to condemn under the provisions of N.Y. Gen. City Law § 20(2) (1986), in which it sought an order to ascertain the amount of compensation to be paid to the respondent condemnee, the method of valuing the property, and the value of the subject property.


OVERVIEW: After the city condemnor filed its condemnation application under § 20(2), the parties, in response to the court's inquiry concerning the justiciability of the application, stipulated that § 20(2) was constitutional and that it did not call for an advisory opinion. The court held that the application presented a dispute which was not justiciable because it called for an advisory opinion, it presented a question which was not ripe for determination, and it presented a contingent question. In so holding, the court found: (1) because there was no de facto taking or acquisition of the property under § 20(2), it did not have jurisdiction over the proceeding pursuant to Article 5 of the Eminent Domain Procedure; (2) the relief sought was advisory because it sought a decision declaring what method of valuation the court would use and did not concern the legal rights and obligations of the parties; (3) the question presented and relief sought was contingent and not ripe for determination because the § 20(2) provision that permitted the condemnor to withdraw the proceeding if not satisfied with the method of valuation or the actual valuation would render any decision void.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition and the proceeding.


HEADNOTES

Eminent Domain - New York City Water Supply - Improper Advisory Opinion as to Method of Valuation and Amount of Compensation

A proceeding brought by the City of New York pursuant to General City Law § 20 (2) to have the court determine in advance, prior to any valuation trial, the appropriate method of valuation and the value of the property that the City proposes to acquire for its water distribution system must be dismissed since the petition presents a dispute which is not justiciable in that it calls for an advisory opinion, presents a question which is not ripe for judicial review, and presents a question which is contingent upon the happening of a future event that may or may not come to pass. A declaration of the method of valuation and a declaration of the value of the property the City proposes to acquire does not present a cognizable claim for declaratory judgment relief pursuant to CPLR 3001 since the petition seeks a determination of wholly factual matters and does not concern the legal rights, obligations, or relations of the parties. Furthermore, although General City Law § 20 (2) clearly provides a basis for the relief sought, the statute is unconstitutional to the extent that it directs the court to render an advisory opinion regarding valuation only, prior to any taking of any property or any legal commitment by the City to acquire the property, and prior to the condemnee suffering any actual damages. The Legislature is without power to direct the court to act as an appraiser of damages and advise the City regarding the appropriate method of valuation and to estimate the value of the property the City proposes to acquire, before the City makes any legal commitment to acquire the property.

 

861 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Radio Common Carriers v. State


Index No. 18674/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 695; 601 N.Y.S.2d 513; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 306



June 9, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended September 23, 1993.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff radio common carriers sought a declaratory judgment that N.Y. Tax Law § 1150 was unconstitutional on its face and as applied, and that defendants, the State of New York (state) and others be made to pay attorneys' fees pursuant to the Civil Rights Attorneys' Fees Award Act of 1976, 42 U.S.C.S. §§ 1983, 1988. The radio common carriers challenged constitutionality of Laws of April, 1992, ch. 375, § 1150, 1992 N.Y. Tax Law ch. 55.


OVERVIEW: The radio common carriers sought a declaratory judgment that N.Y. Tax Law §1150, entitled "Special fee on paging devices," was unconstitutional on its face and as applied. They also requested that attorneys' fees be awarded pursuant to the Civil Rights Attorneys' Fees Awards Act of 1976, 42 U.S.C.S. §§ 1983, 1988. Contending that the fee was in reality a tax, the radio common carriers argued that it impermissibly discriminated against interstate commerce, unconstitutionally imposed an exaction upon out-of-state customers, and violated the due process and equal protection Clauses of the constitutions of the United States and the State of New York. Upon review, the court agreed and held for the radio common carriers on all counts. The court also found that the statute was impermissibly vague and violated the prohibition against double taxation. The court granted the radio carrier's request that attorneys' fees be paid by defendants.


OUTCOME: The court found in favor of the radio common carriers, that the statute was unconstitutional on its face and as applied. The statute that taxed radio paging devices was impermissibly vague and violated the commerce clause, due process, and the prohibition against double taxation. The request for attorneys' fees was granted and the question of attorneys' fees was severed and set down for a hearing on the question of reasonable fees.


HEADNOTES

Taxation - Sales and Use Taxes - Special "Fee" on Paging Devices Unconstitutional as Violative of Commerce Clause

1. New York's flat $ 1 monthly "fee" imposed on each radio "paging device used or authorized for use in conjunction with a paging service, where such service is provided for consideration" (Tax Law § 1150) is an unconstitutional tax violative of the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8, cl [3]) under the United States Supreme Court's four-part test, which requires findings that the tax is applied to an activity with a "substantial nexus" with the taxing State, is fairly apportioned, does not discriminate against interstate commerce, and is fairly related to services provided by the State. The "substantial nexus" component of the test is not satisfied merely because electronic signals pass through the State nor does the tax imposed by section 1150 insure that New York taxes only its fair share of an interstate transaction. Furthermore, the levy also places a disproportionate burden on transactions that cross State lines, in that out-of-State users who seldom, if ever, use their pagers in New York, are subjected to the same amount of tax as is paid by intrastate users. In addition, it cannot be said that section 1150 is fairly related to any services provided by the State to the class of out-of-State users involved in this case.

Taxation - Sales and Use Taxes - Special "Fee" on Paging Devices Unconstitutional as Violative of Due Process and Prohibition against Double Taxation

2. New York's flat $ 1 monthly "fee" imposed on each radio "paging device used or authorized for use in conjunction with a paging service, where such service is provided for consideration" (Tax Law § 1150), violates the Due Process Clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions since there is no link, definite or otherwise, between New York and the class of users who reside, work and use their pagers outside of New York. The mere "authorization" to use one's beeper in this State is an insufficient connection to satisfy due process requirements. Furthermore, the tax statute, by incorporating some other "provisions" of the sales tax article, "insofar as [they] can be made applicable" and by not defining the "modifications as may be necessary to adapt such other provisions to the fee so imposed", is also impermissibly vague. In addition, the statute also violates the prohibition against double taxation without specific legislative authorization by imposing a tax in addition to the sales tax on the sale or lease of a beeper. The statute's designation of the payment as a "fee" indicates that the Legislature did not intend to impose double taxation.

Civil Rights - Federal Civil Rights Claim - Counsel Fees - Action to Declare Tax Statute Unconstitutional 

3. Plaintiffs, who prevailed in having Tax Law § 1150 declared unconstitutional as violative of the Commerce Clause (US Const, art I, § 8, cl [3]) and due process in an action pursuant to 42 USC § 1983, are entitled to an award of attorneys' fees pursuant to 42 USC § 1988. The Commissioner of the State Department of Taxation and Finance qualifies as a State official who, acting under color of State law, has deprived plaintiffs of their Federally protected rights.

 

862 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Application of Harnischfeger


93-334


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 299; 600 N.Y.S.2d 894; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 256



May 26, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner police filed two applications for search warrants permitting seizure of one vehicle described as the instrumentality of a drug transaction, and four vehicles particularly described as the substituted proceeds of drug transactions.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner police submitted two search warrant applications, particularly in order to seize vehicles where no search was desired. Reviewing N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 690.10, seizure of the four vehicles purchased with the proceeds of drug transactions did not fit into any one of the four categories in that section. No warrant could be issued for them. The application to obtain the vehicle used in commission of the crimes alleged sufficient facts to justify issuing the warrant, by alleging that cocaine was unlawfully possessed in the vehicle and by alleging that cocaine was possessed in the vehicle for the purpose of unlawful sale. The search warrant did not permit the forfeiture of the vehicle; however, if the officers wished to obtain forfeiture there were other statutory provisions available for them to proceed.


OUTCOME: The application for the first search warrant to seize the suspect individual's motor vehicle as the instrumentality of a drug transaction was granted, and the application for the second search warrant to seize the suspect individual's four motor vehicles as the substituted proceeds of drug transactions was denied.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties - Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime - Seizure Warrants for Motor Vehicles Used as Instrumentality or Constituting Substituted Proceeds of Drug Transaction

Search warrants cannot be used for any purpose except as stated in the applicable criminal statutes. Thus, an application for a search warrant pursuant to CPL 690.10 to seize the suspect individual's motor vehicle as an instrumentality of a drug transaction is granted under the authority of Public Health Law § 3388, which authorizes the seizure and forfeiture of a vehicle used to facilitate illegal drug transactions, where the application seeks to seize the suspect individual's vehicle and not to search that vehicle and seize cocaine if it is located, as is provided for under CPL 690.10. Public Health Law § 3388 provides a procedure for the police to seize only the suspect individual's vehicle, and does not require judicial intervention; however, since the constitutionality of this section is doubtful, the safest course is for the police to comply by applying for a seizure warrant upon a showing of probable cause for forfeiture, as is the case here. Additionally, a second search warrant application to authorize the seizure of the suspect individual's four particularly described motor vehicles as the substituted proceeds of drug transactions is denied where the allegations do not fit into any of the categories in CPL 690.10 or Public Health Law § 3388. Forfeiture of all five vehicles would be available pursuant to Penal Law article 480 or CPLR article 13-A.

 

863 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Labbe v. Russi


Index No. 93-00311


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, WESTCHESTER COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 532; 601 N.Y.S.2d 643; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 297



May 3, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended September 15, 1993.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner inmate challenged the decision of the Appeals Unit of the Board of Parole (New York), which affirmed the decision of respondent New York State Board of Parole that denied the inmate's release.


OVERVIEW: An inmate, a native of Haiti who spoke French, appeared before the New York State Board of Parole (Board) for early release. The court vacated the decision of the Board that affirmed the denial of the inmate's release, holding that it was affected by an error of law. The court held that the Board's ability to determine whether the inmate could live without violating the law necessitated exploring various questions relating to her offense. However, the inmate's ability to understand the questions was reduced by the fact that they were posed to her in Spanish, a language she understood, but not very well. The substantial decrease in the inmate's capacity to be successfully interviewed caused by the absence of an adequate interpreter detrimentally affected her chances for parole release. The court held that, given that the record did not support the Board's decision to utilize a Spanish interpreter, the hearing was not fair, and was not an interview under N.Y. Exec. Law § 259-i(2)(a). Because the inmate was not afforded an interview, the appeals unit of the Board could not accede in a decision to deny her application for parole release.


OUTCOME: The court vacated and annulled the decision that affirmed the denial of the inmate's application for parole release.


HEADNOTES

Parole - Denial - Utilization of Foreign Language Interpreter at Parole "Interview"

Petitioner, a Haitian who speaks Creole and has difficulty making herself understood in English, was not accorded an appropriate and "fair" parole "interview" (Executive Law § 259-i [2] [a]; 9 NYCRR 8002.2) where petitioner, although stating a preference for a French interpreter and indicating that she only spoke "a little" Spanish and understood that language "not very well", was only provided with a Spanish interpreter. A parole hearing conducted entirely in English can be deemed to be "fair" only where the parole applicant demonstrably understood clearly the questions and comments made during the course of the hearing and where the applicant further demonstrably gave responses in English that adequately addressed the subject matter presented and were understood by the members of the Parole Board who conducted the interview. Unless interpreters in a language preferred by the parole applicant are demonstrably unavailable or nonexistent, a decision to utilize a non-English language other than that preferred by the applicant is irrational if, as here, as a result of the applicant's relative degrees of fluency and/or comprehension, the decision to utilize such third language could have affected the outcome of the proceeding to the detriment of the applicant. Furthermore, the fact that one panel member was able to understand petitioner's English does not meet the regulatory requirement of an "interview" conducted by two members of the Board of Parole where the second member never asserted his ability to understand petitioner's English.

 

864 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Smith v. Hudacs


INDEX NO. 5010-91, RJI No. 0191-ST3144


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 149; 599 N.Y.S.2d 902; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 231



April 29, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner state employee filed a petition seeking a judgment challenging the determination of respondent Commissioner of New York State Office of General Services (New York) to set off and recoup overpaid wages from petitioner's lump-sum separation from service entitlement.


OVERVIEW: Respondent comptroller found that petitioner state employee had been overpaid due to his submission of allegedly fraudulent time sheets. Respondent determined that the state was entitled to a set off and recoup from petitioner's lump-sum separation from service entitlement. Petitioner filed an application to declare respondent's determination null and void. The court reversed, granted the petition, and held that respondents' powers were exercised arbitrarily and capriciously. The court found that petitioner was never given timely notice of respondent's audit of his payroll account or its intent to offset the claim for overtime overpayment against his severance allowance. Petitioner was not afforded a meaningful opportunity to submit evidence or arguments in opposition to respondent's action. Thus, respondents' actions effectively deprived petitioner of any meaningful opportunity to contest the recoupment of overtime restitution from the petitioner's salary.


OUTCOME: The petition seeking a judgment declaring null and void respondent comptroller's determination to set off and recoup overpaid wages from petitioner state employee's lump-sum separation from service entitlement was granted. Respondent failed to provide petitioner with timely notice of respondent's audit of his payroll account and failed to provide petitioner with a meaningful opportunity to contest the recoupment of overtime restitution.


HEADNOTES

State - Comptroller - Power to Recoup Overpayment Made to Employee - Due Process Requirements

The determination of respondent State Comptroller to set off and recoup from petitioner's severance pay entitlement upon his retirement from State service, monies alleged to have been overpaid to petitioner due to his submission of allegedly fraudulent time sheets claiming unearned overtime pay, must be annulled, and the matter remanded for further proceedings, due to the failure to afford petitioner his fundamental due process rights to notice and a meaningful opportunity to be heard. The Comptroller has the inherent authority to recoup an overpayment made to a State employee from the employee's salary; however, where, as here, the alleged overpayment did not result from the State's "administrative error" (see, State Finance Law § 200 [3] [b] [iii]), a condition precedent to the right of recoupment is a quasi-judicial, due process determination by the Comptroller that there exists a valid claim subject to recoupment. The disciplinary proceeding instituted against petitioner was abandoned upon his retirement and never resulted in a due process determination of the validity of respondent's claim that petitioner owed the State money. Petitioner was never given notice of the Comptroller's audit of his payroll account or intent to offset the claim for overtime overpayment against his severance allowance prior to the Comptroller's action. Petitioner was therefore not afforded a meaningful opportunity to submit evidence or arguments in opposition to the Comptroller's action nor did he have a meaningful opportunity to be heard by the agency by which he was employed before that agency requested the offset from the Comptroller.

 

865 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Reyes


Docket No. 92X017348


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 476; 596 N.Y.S.2d 304; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 57



February 26, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to suppress a .38 caliber special revolver obtained during a search of his semi tractor cab. Defendant was charged with one count of criminal possession of a weapon in the fourth degree pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 265.01(1).


OVERVIEW: Defendant was pulled over after motor carrier safety unit officers observed that his tractor trailer lacked a valid Highway Use Tax sticker and observed him making an illegal left turn. Incident to the stop, the officers performed a safety inspection of the vehicle. Incident to a visual search of the cab, one officer found a gun and shells. The court conducted a hearing on defendant's motion to suppress the gun and ordered that the gun must be suppressed. The court held that N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 17, § 820.14, which authorized random searches for safety violations, was unconstitutional because it did not provide a meaningful limitation on the otherwise unlimited discretion afforded under N.Y. Transp. Law § 140(c)(2) or a satisfactory means to minimize the risk of arbitrary and/or abusive enforcement. Such finding was corroborated by one officer's testimony that the decision to perform such inspections was within each officer's discretion. The court then evaluated the search under a reasonableness standard, determining that the regulation did not provide safeguards to insure that individuals' reasonable expectation of privacy was not subjected to unregulated discretion.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that the gun found inside the tractor must be suppressed.


HEADNOTES

Searches and Seizures - Random Search Conducted without Reasonable Suspicion - Safety Inspection of Trucks

A gun seized from the rear of defendant's tractor trailer cab during the course of a police safety inspection of the truck following a lawful stop of the vehicle must be suppressed as the product of an unreasonable search, even if the gun was discovered in plain view, since the regulation which authorized the police officer's initial entry into the vehicle to perform the safety inspection (17 NYCRR 820.14 [a]) does not comply with constitutional search and seizure standards (NY Const, art I, § 12) to the extent that such regulation, adopted pursuant to Transportation Law § 140 (2) (c), on its face authorizes random searches of vehicles without particularized suspicion or advance judicial oversight. Searches conducted without particularized suspicion are governed by a three-pronged standard of reasonableness. Although the regulation herein satisfies the first two prongs, in that the government's interest in highway safety is substantial and the defendant has a diminished expectation of privacy in his vehicle, the absence of any safeguards on the otherwise unlimited discretion of police officers in conducting safety inspections renders the regulation unconstitutional.

 

866 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York City Off Track Betting Corp. v. State Racing & Wagering Bd.


Index No. 91-2547, CCN 46-1-91-1374


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SCHENECTADY COUNTY


157 Misc. 2d 524; 597 N.Y.S.2d 869; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 162



February 11, 1993, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs off-track betting corporations (OTB) filed a complaint against defendant, the New York State Racing and Wagering Board (board) and sought a declaratory judgment and injunctive relief to prevent implementation of a regulation, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 4204.15 (1983), which required the OTBs to restore to the betting public "missed pool" bets.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 4204.15 (1983) was adopted to require the off-track betting corporations (OTB) to restore to the betting public "missed pool" bets taken in by OTBs, which failed to be included in the pari-mutuel betting pool, and were thus not used to calculate payouts. The effect of the procedure was to reduce the amount that was payable to all winners had the wagers been included in the pool, and to permit the OTBs to pocket amounts that properly should have accrued to successful bettors. The court upheld the board's broad powers to regulate, and found that the manner in which the regulation was published and enacted was proper. However, the court found that the regulation was vague and not susceptible of precise meaning because the memorandum directive for implementation provided no guidance to effect the return of the accumulated "missed pool" gains or profits. The court granted a preliminary injunction to the OTBs until a proper implementing regulation was devised that showed that the profits and gains would be going into the proper betting pools for redistribution. The court denied a counterclaim to carry out the Board's directives.


OUTCOME: The court granted preliminary injunctive relief to the off-track betting corporations until a proper implementing regulation or implementing memorandum directive was devised that clearly showed that the profits and gains would be going into the proper betting pools for redistribution.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - When Cause of Action Accrues - Issuance of Memorandum Directive Implementing Regulation Requiring Return of "Missed Pool" Racing Bets to Betting Public

1. An "action" by plaintiffs, the State's six off-track betting corporations (OTBs), challenging a regulation of the State Racing and Wagering Board, promulgated in 1983, and a memorandum directive issued by the Board on October 8, 1991 first implementing the regulation, is not time barred regardless of whether the "action" is denominated an article 78 proceeding subject to a four-month limitations period ( CPLR 217) or a declaratory judgment action, since the "action" was commenced within four months of the date of the memorandum directive and any Statute of Limitations did not begin to run until that time, which was when the OTBs knew the full extent of how and when the regulation was to be implemented.

Horse Racing - Off-Track Pari-Mutuel Betting - Validity of Regulation Requiring Return of "Missed Pool" Bets to Betting Public

2. A regulation of the State Racing and Wagering Board (9 NYCRR 5204.15) and the implementing memorandum directive requiring plaintiffs, the State's six off-track betting corporations (OTBs), to restore to the betting public, in the form of "sweetened pools" for winning bettors on a designated special racing day, "missed pool" bets from 1983 through 1990 that were taken in by the OTBs but not included in the on-track pari-mutuel betting pool and thus not used to calculate the payouts, do not improperly fail to allow OTBs to make up for losses where payments to winning bettors off-track exceed the portion of the pari-mutuel pool attributable to such bettors (Racing, Pari-Mutuel Wagering and Breeding Law § 526 [5]), nor do they improperly deprive the OTBs of statutory commissions from the monies ordered to be returned to the bettors (Racing, Pari-Mutuel Wagering and Breeding Law § 527), or improperly place the burden of pooling bets solely on the OTBs (Racing, Pari-Mutuel Wagering and Breeding Law § 526 [2]). Furthermore, the payments directed by the regulation and memorandum directive do not constitute an improper and unauthorized penalty. The Board has the power to order that the profits or gains from "missed pool" bets be returned to bettors at a later date. However, the regulation and implementing directive are impermissibly vague and impossible of performance to the extent that there is no detailed plan for the infusion of the total amount of "missed pool" gains and profits back into specific races and specific bets.

Horse Racing - Off-Track Pari-Mutuel Betting - Validity of Regulation Requiring Return of "Missed Pool" Bets to Betting Public - No Violation of Constitutional Prohibition against Gifts of Public Funds to Individuals

3. A regulation of the State Racing and Wagering Board (9 NYCRR 5204.15) and implementing memorandum directive requiring plaintiffs, the State's six off-track betting corporations (OTBs), to restore to the betting public, in the form of "sweetened pools" for winning bettors on a designated special racing day, "missed pool" bets from 1983 through 1990 that were taken in by the OTBs but not included in the on-track pari-mutuel betting pool and thus not used to calculate the payouts, are not violative of the constitutional prohibition against gifts of public monies to individuals (NY Const, art VII, § 8 [1]) since the "missed pools" gains and profits originally belonged to the bettors and never became public funds. Even if the funds should be distributed to "participating counties" and not turned back to the bettors, there is no assurance in the record that the funds would actually reach the counties.

Horse Racing - Off-Track Pari-Mutuel Betting - Validity of Regulation Requiring Return of "Missed Pool" Bets to Betting Public - No Violation of Principles of Pari-Mutuel Betting

4. A regulation of the State Racing and Wagering Board (9 NYCRR 5204.15) and implementing memorandum directive requiring plaintiffs, the State's six off-track betting corporations (OTBs), to restore to the betting public, in the form of "sweetened pools" for winning bettors on a designated special racing day, "missed pool" bets from 1983 through 1990 that were taken in by the OTBs but not included in the on-track pari-mutuel betting pool and thus not used to calculate the payouts, are not violative of the principles of pari-mutuel betting. The Board's use of "sweetened" money is a rational way to try and solve the problem of "missed pool" bets.

Horse Racing - Off-Track Pari-Mutuel Betting - Validity of Regulation Requiring Return of "Missed Pool" Bets to Betting Public - Severance of Cause of Action against Track Operators for Failure to Have Included Timely Transmitted Bets into State-Wide Betting Pool

5. The State Racing and Wagering Board is authorized, by way of regulation (9 NYCRR 5204.15) and implementing memorandum directive, to require plaintiffs, the State's six off-track betting corporations (OTBs), to restore to the betting public, in the form of "sweetened pools" for winning bettors on a designated special racing day, "missed pool" bets from 1983 to 1990 that were taken in by the OTBs but not included in the on-track pari-mutuel betting pool and thus not used to calculate the payouts, but plaintiffs are granted preliminary injunctive relief against compliance until a proper implementing regulation or memorandum is devised which clearly shows that the "missing pools" profits and gains will be going into the proper betting pools for redistribution. Defendant New York Racing Association (NYRA) is not entitled to an order directing the OTBs to "carry out the Board's directives" so as to assure that the bank transfer clearance "mechanism" will work on the special racing day in the event there is an imbalance in a pool among successful wagers at various OTBs and the track since there are no grounds for such an order directing the OTBs to comply with any directives that have not as yet been formulated. Furthermore, plaintiffs state a valid cause of action under the regulation against intervenors NYRA and a track operator for their failure to have included timely transmitted bets into the State-wide pool, thereby resulting in the OTBs ending up with "missed pools" funds as to which they either made a profit or a loss depending on the number of winning tickets that they sold, but such cause of action is severed since the outcome of the main dispute is not dependent on any rights of recovery that the OTBs may have against the track operators.

Horse Racing - Off-Track Pari-Mutuel Betting - Validity of Regulation Requiring Return of "Missed Pool" Bets to Betting Public - Invalid Denial of Offset of Losses against Gains Involving "Missed Pool" Funds

6. The State Racing and Wagering Board has the authority, by way of regulation (9 NYCRR 5204.15) and implementing memorandum directive, to require plaintiffs, the State's six off-track betting corporations, to restore to the betting public, in the form of "sweetened pools" for winning bettors on a designated special racing day, "missed pool" bets from 1983 through 1990 that were taken in by the OTBs but not included in the on-track pari-mutuel betting pool and thus not used to calculate the payouts, but plaintiffs are granted preliminary injunctive relief against compliance until a proper implementing regulation or memorandum is devised which clearly shows that the profits and gains will be going into the proper betting pools for redistribution. Furthermore, the regulation is invalid as to Nassau and Suffolk OTBs to the extent that it does not allow any offsetting of losses against gains involving the "missed pool" funds. While the Board has authority to mandate that gains or profits that are made on "missed pool" bets should be returned to the bettors, only net gains or profits should be so returned.

 

867 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Seavey v. Korte


Index No.: 9985/91, Index No.: 14010/91,


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 984; 595 N.Y.S.2d 628; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 68



February 5, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended May 5, 1993.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant car corporations filed a motion for summary judgment against plaintiffs on their amended complaint against the car corporations and defendant individual for damages which arose from an automobile accident.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs originally filed a complaint against the individual in order to recover damages for injuries that resulted from an automobile accident. By a written stipulation between the attorney for plaintiffs and the individual, it was agreed that plaintiffs could file an amended complaint. In the amended complaint, plaintiffs added on the car corporations as defendants, and filed the amended complaint and a supplemental summons without first seeking the permission of the court. In their answer to the amended complaint, the car corporations alleged that the court lacked jurisdiction over them because of plaintiffs' failure to obtain court approval prior to adding them as parties as required by N.Y. C.P.L.R. 1003. The car corporations filed a cross-motion for summary judgment. The court denied the motion of the car corporations and held that service upon the car corporations gave the court jurisdiction, and that the service was not a nullity by reason of the failure to obtain prior court approval for the addition of the car corporations as defendants.


OUTCOME: The court denied the car corporations' motion for summary judgment on plaintiffs' amended complaint for damages which arose from an automobile accident.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Adding Additional Party - Valid Addition Absent Court Order

Where the parties to an action, by written stipulation, agreed that plaintiff may file a supplemental summons and amended complaint naming additional parties defendant and stating new causes of action against them, the service of the papers upon the additional defendants was not a nullity even though they were served without prior court approval. CPLR 1003 provides that parties may be added by the court at any stage of the action and CPLR 3025 (b) provides that a party may amend a pleading at any time by leave of court or by stipulation of all parties. CPLR 1003 does not contain a provision permitting joinder upon agreement of all parties. Nevertheless, the only objection to an addition of new parties may be made by an existing party over whom the court has jurisdiction. Normally, on an application to add parties, the defendant to be added is not present as jurisdiction over such prospective defendant is not a prerequisite to determining the motion. Thus, absent an objection, there would be no basis for a court to reject the existing parties' desire to have additional defendants added. In addition, parties by stipulation are free to chart their own course in the process of litigation. Also, no rights of the nonparty are in any way affected by its joinder as any defense it possesses may be raised after joinder. Finally, because of the unusual fact pattern presented, the parties sought to be added are already before the court.

 

868 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Doe v. Smith


93-118


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 942; 595 N.Y.S.2d 624; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 71



January 29, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, the maternal grandfather, sought an order compelling respondents, his two estranged daughters, to allow visitation with his grandchildren.


OVERVIEW: The daughters had chosen to avoid contact with the grandfather for intensely personal reasons, arising from the circumstances of his divorce from their mother. Both daughters had intact marriages with the fathers of the grandchildren. The court held that the grandfather had no standing to bring the petition, and dismissed. The court found it could not equitably intervene to force visitation when there was total estrangement between the grandfather and the daughters, no pre-existing relationship between the grandfather and the grandchildren, and all four parents in the two intact families objected to visitation.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the petition of the maternal grandfather to compel his estranged daughters to allow visitation with his grandchildren for lack of equitable standing.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child - Visitation Rights of Grandparents - Lack of Standing - No Circumstances Establishing Equitable Intervention

Petitioner maternal grandfather's petition seeking visitation with his grandchildren is denied for lack of standing where respondents, the parents of the grandchildren, are alive and object to the visitation and no equitable circumstances exist to permit the court to entertain the petition. Because the parents are alive, and the families are intact, the grandfather does not have an absolute right to standing; thus, the petition may be entertained if the grandfather can establish circumstances in which equity would see fit to intervene. Equitable circumstances include whether the family is intact, the nature and basis of the parents' objection and the nature and extent of the grandparent-grandchild relationship. Here, due to petitioner's divorce from his wife, petitioner had very little personal contact with his daughters from 1984 until he discovered that they had children in 1991. In addition, petitioner was very critical of his daughters as children, all four parents are opposed to visitation emanating from the total estrangement of petitioner and his daughters, and no preexisting grandparent-grandchild relationship exists.

 

869 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Commissioner of Social Servs. on behalf of Foreman v. Milien


Docket No. F-1-92, X-2835-92, FU-4485


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, ROCKLAND COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 527; 593 N.Y.S.2d 747; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 15



January 19, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: This matter is remanded back to the Hearing Examiner to amend her order of support in accordance with this decision.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner Commissioner of Social Services appealed the decision and order of support filed by the Hearing Examiner, which found that N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 449 was unconstitutional as violative of both the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Federal and New York State Constitutions. Hence, the examiner found that no support was to be awarded prior to the filing of the petition.


OVERVIEW: N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act. § 449 required the payment of child support from the earlier of the date of the filing of the petition, or, if the child for whom support is sought was on public assistance, the date from which the eligibility for public assistance was effective. As a preliminary matter, the court found that the Hearing Examiner did have the power to determine the constitutionality of the legislation, although generally not the practice of courts of first instance and limited jurisdiction such as the Family Court. However, the court agreed with petitioner Commissioner of Social Services that because the question of the constitutionality of the statute was raised by the court, without the urging of the respondent father, his consent or knowledge, the Hearing Examiner committed reversible error. Before the statute could be challenged, there must have been an "injury-in-fact" or aggrieved party before the court could properly determine if the subject statute was or was not constitutional.


OUTCOME: The matter was remanded back to the Hearing Examiner to amend her order of support in accordance with the decision.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Hearing Examiners - Powers - Determination of Constitutionality of Statute 

1. In a support proceeding involving the Child Support Standards Act, a Family Court Hearing Examiner possesses the power to determine the constitutionality of the Act as it relates to issues of support. A Hearing Examiner is empowered to hear, determine and grant any relief within the powers of the Family Court in support or maintenance proceedings (Family Ct Act § 439 [a]). Family Court, a court of first instance and limited jurisdiction, should not ordinarily set aside a statute as unconstitutional unless such a conclusion is inescapable. A Hearing Examiner is not precluded from determining the invalidity of a statute where he or she believes that the invalidity of the statute is apparent on its face. In addition, the constitutionality of a statute can properly be raised before a Hearing Examiner or Family Court without resort to a declaratory judgment action since a declaratory judgment action is not the sole avenue to test a statute's constitutionality in Family Court.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - No Determination of Validity Absent Aggrieved Party

2. In a support proceeding involving Family Court Act § 449, where respondent failed to appear for the hearing, the support order was entered on default and respondent did not move to vacate the default nor file a rebuttal to petitioner's objections, respondent waived his right to raise the constitutionality of the statute; thus, the Family Court Hearing Examiner improperly raised, sua sponte, and determined, the constitutionality of the statute. The constitutionality of statutes and ordinances can be determined only in an action where the question is raised by a party aggrieved. The void-statute exception to the party aggrieved requirement for standing, available if the statute can be found unconstitutional as to others not before the court and the constitutional and unconstitutional features cannot be meaningfully severed thus rendering the entire statute invalid, is not applicable in this case.

 

870 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Rice v. Perales


Index No. 91/14215


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 631; 594 N.Y.S.2d 962; 1993 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 34



January 15, 1993, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff beneficiaries sought to invalidate a change in the way New York State Home Relief (HR) benefits were calculated for mixed households in which one member received Supplemental Security Income. The beneficiaries' motion for a preliminary injunction was converted into a motion for summary judgment and defendant social services commissioner's (commissioner) answer treated as a cross motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: All of the beneficiaries were members of households in which one person received Supplemental Security Income (SSI) and the other was dependent on HR under the N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law §158 et seq., a general assistance program for those whose financial needs were not met by other programs. Benefits were based on defined income requirements, and SSI benefits were deemed "invisible" for HR purposes. Then, the commissioner was authorized to amend 18 N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. § 352.2(b) so that SSI income was no longer invisible for recipients of HR.
