In granting the commissioner's motion, the court held that the beneficiaries failed to establish that Federal law required the invisibility or disregard of SSI benefits for any purpose but Aid to Families with Dependent Children calculations. The court also found that no matter what policy was adopted concerning the special needs of the disabled, it could not be argued that mixed households were entitled to more assistance than those composed entirely of SSI recipients. The court concluded that under the new rule the beneficiaries would continue to receive benefits at a level equal to the needs of others generally.


OUTCOME: The beneficiaries' motion for summary judgment was denied, and the commissioner's cross motion for summary judgment was granted. The complaint was dismissed.


HEADNOTES

Social Services - Home Relief - Validity of Including Supplemental Security Income in Determining Household's Home Relief Benefits

The State's inclusion of Supplemental Security Income (SSI) received by a member of a "mixed household" in determining the household's Home Relief benefits pursuant to a rule change (18 NYCRR 352.2 [b]) is not invalid for being in conflict with the Social Security Act since plaintiffs have failed to establish that Federal law requires the invisibility or disregard of SSI benefits for any purpose other than the Aid to Families with Dependent Children program (42 USC § 602 [a] [24]). Nor is such inclusion violative of the State's affirmative duty to aid the needy (NY Const, art XVII, § 1) on the ground that it deprives plaintiffs of a constitutionally mandated level of support by forcing them to devote a portion of their income to their spouse's needs, since all constitutional requirements are met by the maintenance of plaintiffs' benefits at a level equal to those of the able-bodied supported by Home Relief. There is no constitutional mandate for a higher level of support for the aged, blind and disabled. Furthermore, the rule change was lawfully promulgated pursuant to the authorization granted the Commissioner of Social Services in the 1991 Aid to Localities Budget to contain welfare costs by revising "budget methodology for mixed households". That legislative authorization was directly related to the function of a budget--the allocation of funds--and thus did not violate the constitutional prohibition against the inclusion of "general legislation" in appropriation bills (NY Const, art VII, § 6).

 

871 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Rodriguez


RJI 19-92-3684


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, GREENE COUNTY


159 Misc. 2d 929; 607 N.Y.S.2d 567; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 675



December 22, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenor, an advocacy corporation for disabled individuals, sought a declaration that N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law art. 78 was unconstitutional. The Attorney General opposed the declaration. The proceeding concerned the application of the president of a medical center for the appointment of a committee of the person of an alleged incompetent person.


OVERVIEW: The intervenor sought a declaration that N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law art. 78 was unconstitutional because of its failure to provide for the appointment of counsel for indigent subjects of committeeship proceedings. The Attorney General opposed the application primarily on procedural grounds. The court found that the intervenor had standing, and that the issue was ripe for judicial review. The fact that the challenged provision of the Mental Hygiene Law would be repealed and replaced with a new statute that did provide for appointment of counsel did not render the issue moot. The guardian ad litem provided pursuant to the statute did not fulfill the alleged incompetent's right. The guardian asserted what he or she believed was in the alleged incompetent's best interests rather than his or her subjective interests. The court found merit in the intervenor's request.


OUTCOME: The court granted the intervenor's application to the extent that it was determined and declared that the pertinent article of the Mental Hygiene Law was constitutional upon condition that it be construed to require the assignment of counsel at public expense to represent the subjective wishes of an indigent alleged incompetent.


HEADNOTES

Courts - Justiciable Questions - Mootness - Repeal of Challenged Statutory Provision

1. An application for a declaration that article 78 of the Mental Hygiene Law is unconstitutional because of its failure to provide for the appointment of counsel for indigent subjects of committeeship proceedings presents a justiciable controversy ripe for review and has not been rendered moot by the appointment of counsel for the alleged incompetent herein since the issue is one likely to evade judicial review. Moreover, even though the challenged provision will be repealed and replaced with a new statute, which does not provide for appointment of counsel, it is likely that numerous committeeship proceedings will be conducted prior to the effective date of the change of the law.

Insane and Other Incompetent Persons - Appointment of Committee - Constitutional Right to Appointment of Counsel for Indigent Incompetent

2. The intervenor's application for a declaration that Mental Hygiene Law article 78 is unconstitutional due to its failure to provide for the appointment of counsel for indigent subjects of committeeship proceedings is granted to the extent that it is determined that article 78 is constitutional upon condition that it be construed to require the assignment of counsel at public expense to represent the subjective wishes of an indigent alleged incompetent. Because a proceeding to declare a person incompetent effectively results in a complete loss of personal liberty and property, an indigent alleged incompetent is entitled to assignment of counsel as a matter of constitutional right. However, the guardian ad litem provided pursuant to article 78 of the Mental Hygiene Law does not fulfill this right as the guardian asserts what he or she believes is in the alleged incompetent's best interest rather than his or her subjective interests. Thus, since nothing in article 78 prohibits such assignment, the statute will be rehabilitated by supplying the missing constitutional safeguard.

 

872 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Coopersmith v. Gold


INDEX NO. 2431/86


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ROCKLAND COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 594; 594 N.Y.S.2d 521; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 614



December 7, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The motion by Gannett Suburban Newspapers for an order vacating the sealing orders of the court is granted and the other witnesses' names, to the extent they may be identifiable in the submissions to the court, are to be redacted as agreed to by Gannett in Mr. Walsh's affidavit.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Intervenor newspaper filed a motion in plaintiff patient's action against defendant psychiatrist for medical malpractice to unseal the records of other patients' alleged claims of sexual contact with defendant. Plaintiff joined in intervenor's motion.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff patient brought a medical malpractice action against defendant psychiatrist for alleged illegal sexual contact. The court granted defendant's motion to seal the record concerning other patients' alleged claims of sexual contact with defendant. Intervenor newspaper filed a motion to unseal the records. The court granted intervenor's motion. The court found that defendant had not met his burden of proof to maintain secrecy and failed to prove that good cause existed under N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 216.1 to continue the sealing of the record. The court concluded that a presumption of openness applied to its records and decisions. Defendant practiced in a highly regulated profession and female patients needed to be aware of the serious allegations made so that they could make an intelligent decision to become or continue as a patient.


OUTCOME: The court granted intervenor newspaper's motion to unseal the records of other patients' alleged claims of sexual contact with defendant psychiatrist. Defendant failed to prove that good cause existed to continue the sealing of the record in plaintiff patient's action.


HEADNOTES

Records - Sealing of Records - Intervention by News Media

1. Movant, a nonparty newspaper which was denied an opportunity to be heard prior to the issuance of sealing orders in a medical malpractice action against a psychiatrist based upon his alleged improper sexual relations with a patient, may not intervene at the conclusion of the trial, which resulted in a jury verdict in favor of defendant, to have the records unsealed. Intervention pursuant to CPLR 1013 is not the proper mechanism whereby the news media are accorded an opportunity to be heard on the questions of closure or sealing of records. Rather, the news media are accorded standing to be heard, on request, prior to a ruling on closure or sealing, without the necessity of formal intervention. Since the sealing orders have already been made in this case, the appropriate remedy is a motion to vacate the sealing orders pursuant to CPLR 5015 (a) and since no prejudice has been claimed, the defect in procedure will be ignored ( CPLR 2001) and the motion converted from intervention to vacatur.

Records - Sealing of Records - Unsealing Records in Medical Malpractice Action Involving Alleged Sexual Misconduct by Physician

2. The records in a medical malpractice action against a psychiatrist based upon his alleged improper sexual relations with a patient, which were ordered sealed prior to trial upon a showing of good cause (22 NYCRR 216.1) in view of the highly prejudicial nature of the proposed testimony on collateral matters and in order to avoid the possible taint of the juror pool if the allegations of sexual misconduct involving other female patients were extensively publicized, are ordered to be unsealed at the conclusion of the trial, which resulted in a jury verdict in favor of defendant. Defendant has not met the burden of proving that good cause exists to maintain secrecy and continue the sealing. Since the matter is finally concluded at the trial court level, the reasons underlying the sealing orders no longer obtain. The presumption of openness of court proceedings must be given effect particularly where, as here, defendant practices in a highly regulated profession and female patients ought to be aware of the serious allegations made so that they may make an intelligent decision to become or continue as patients. Accordingly, the motion by the nonparty newspaper for an order vacating the sealing orders is granted and the other witnesses' names, to the extent they may be identifiable in the submissions to the court, are to be redacted.

 

873 of 992 DOCUMENTS


American Tel. & Tel. Co. v. New York State Dep't of Taxation & Fin.


INDEX NO. 34/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 806; 592 N.Y.S.2d 553; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 576



November 30, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [**1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff long distance telephone carrier sought summary judgment declaring that N.Y. Tax Law § was unconstitutional because the benefit of the deduction provided therein was directly related to the percentage of the carrier's property located in the state of New York. Defendant State Department of taxation and finance filed a cross motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The gross receipts of long distance carriers having operations outside New York were allocated, in determining New York State taxable receipts, pursuant to N.Y. Tax Law § 184(4)(c) on the basis of the proportion of the carrier's property located in New York. Local access fees were included in gross receipts, but a deduction therefor was allowed to the carrier, prior, however, to apportionment. As a result, an intrastate carrier could deduct the fee dollar for dollar, while interstate enterprises could deduct only a proportionate amount. The court first held that the carrier did not have to exhaust its administrative remedies, because the action was a declaratory action challenging the constitutionality of a taxing statute. However, the tax at issue did not violate the commerce clause, because the relative tax liabilities of carriers was not affected by their status as interstate or intrastate carriers. Because a lesser percentage of the carrier's receipts was allocated to New York, its benefit from the deduction was properly less than that of a carrier having a greater percentage of its property in-state and paying a greater percentage of its receipts to New York as a tax.


OUTCOME: The court denied the carrier's motion for summary judgment and granted the state's cross motion for summary judgment, and declared the challenged statute to be constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - "Access Fee" Tax Deduction for Long-Distance Carriers

Tax Law § 186-a (2-a), which provides an "access fee" deduction for long-distance carriers to be allowed against "interstate and international revenues prior to apportionment to New York" in order to determine their New York tax base, is not in violation of the Equal Protection, Due Process or Commerce Clauses as unjustifiably discriminatory, even though the result is that the statute provides a lower deduction to long-distance carriers having a higher proportion of property (and therefore business) outside of New York because of the reduced tax base. Therefore, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is denied and Tax Law § 186-a (2-a) is declared constitutional. Since plaintiff only allocated 5% of its receipts to New York business, its benefit from the deduction is appropriately less than that of a company which has a greater percentage of its property in the State, and thus pays a greater percentage of its receipts to New York as a tax.

 

874 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Tansey


Ind. Nos.: 13222/91 and 13223/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 233; 593 N.Y.S.2d 426; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 569



November 16, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended March 19, 1993.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved to dismiss counts of a criminal indictment for possession of stolen property, N.Y. Penal Law §§ 165.45, 155.25-155.30, and the divulgence of an eavesdropping warrant pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 250.20.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with possession of stolen property and the criminal divulgence of eavesdropping warrants. The charges arose from their alleged possession of stolen telephone authorization codes. Defendants moved to dismiss the indictment, contending that N.Y. Penal Law § 250.20 regarding the divulgence of eavesdropping warrants was overbroad, and also asserting that the allegations of possession of stolen property were inappropriate because the larceny statutes, N.Y. Penal Law §§ 165.45, 155.25-155.30, were not applicable to intangible authorization codes. The court agreed that the larceny statutes could not be applied. The statutes' definition of "property" was conditioned upon the statutes' application to "tangible" property. Counts related to the divulgence of eavesdropping warrants pursuant to N.Y. Penal Law § 250.20 were found not to be overbroad. The state pursued a valid government interest and had not restricted protected speech.


OUTCOME: Counts of a criminal indictment related to the possession of stolen property under larceny statutes were invalidated because the definition of "property" under the statutes could not be applied to intangible authorization codes, while a first amendment challenge to the criminal statute related to the divulgence of eavesdropping warrants was rejected.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Possession of Stolen Property - Stolen Telephone Calling Card Number

1. The mere knowing "possession" of a stolen telephone calling card number without "possession" of the actual telephone calling card cannot constitute the crime of criminal possession of stolen property in the fourth degree (Penal Law § 165.45) since the card number itself is not "tangible property" that can be "possessed" within the meaning of the criminal possession statute. The unambiguous wording of Penal Law § 165.45, which proscribes the possession of "stolen property", read in conjunction with Penal Law § 10.00 (8), which defines "possess" to mean having physical possession or otherwise exercising dominion or control over "tangible property", clearly indicates that the possession of intangible telephone authorization codes or calling card numbers has not yet been designated a crime. Accordingly, defendants cannot be charged with criminal possession of stolen property in the fourth degree in connection with their alleged unauthorized use of telephone credit card authorization codes for the New York State Office of General Services telephone calling card system issued to members of the State Police for business-related phone calls.

Crimes - Larceny - Defrauding Government - Use of Stolen Telephone Calling Card Number to Obtain Telephone Services

2. The use of a stolen telephone calling card number to obtain telephone services constitutes theft of services (Penal Law § 165.15 [4]) but cannot constitute the theft of "property" under the larceny statutes (Penal Law §§ 155.25, 155.30 [1]). While certain designated commodities supplied through a service constitute property which is subject to the larceny statutes, the supplying of the particular commodity, i.e., the service, is not property that can be the subject of a larceny. However, although defendant, a member of the State Police, cannot be charged with larceny for his alleged unauthorized use of telephone access codes for the New York State Office of General Services telephone calling card system, he may be charged with defrauding the government for his conduct (Penal Law § 195.20) since the telephone services obtained by defendant constitute the type of "property" that can be fraudulently obtained by a public servant within the meaning of Penal Law § 195.20. The property/services distinction applicable to theft-related offenses is not applicable to the crime of defrauding the government, since such a distinction would serve to frustrate the purpose of the statute of punishing those who abuse their public office for personal gain or benefit, at the expense of the government and its citizenry.

Crimes - Eavesdropping Warrants - Divulging Eavesdropping Warrant

3. Defendant, a former high ranking member of the State Police, may be prosecuted for divulging the existence of an eavesdropping warrant to the target of the eavesdropping order (Penal Law § 250.20), but may not be similarly prosecuted for disclosing such information to a confidential informant in response to the informant's statement that the target's office and phone were "bugged". The evidence before the Grand Jury establishes that it was the informant who first brought the matter to defendant's attention and, therefore, defendant's response was not a "disclosure" within the meaning of the statute.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Statute Proscribing Disclosure of Eavesdropping Warrant

4. Penal Law § 250.20, which proscribes disclosing "information concerning the existence or content of an eavesdropping warrant ... to another person", is not facially unconstitutional as vague or overbroad. Moreover, the statute, as it is applied against defendant, is directed not towards the expression of ideas, but rather towards the purposeful attempt to obstruct a lawful governmental eavesdropping operation. Defendant's interest in such expression is exceedingly minimal, when compared to the public interest in preserving the effectiveness and integrity of the court-authorized eavesdropping. In addition, the statute must be narrowly read so that the phrase "discloses such information" targets only disclosures made in order to obstruct, impede or prevent such interception. By proscribing only those disclosures that are made for the express purpose of obstructing court-authorized eavesdropping whether by a public employee or a private citizen, the State interest is sufficiently compelling to override any First Amendment concerns.

 

875 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Tops Mkts., Inc. v. County of Erie


Index No. 2473/92, Index No. 2478/92, Index No. 5169/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ERIE COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 49; 591 N.Y.S.2d 694; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 536



November 13, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, various food stores, filed a declaratory judgement action against defendant, the county, and sought a declaration that the County Law, which pertained to item pricing and required individual food items to be individually marked with a price, was unconstitutional under the Due Process and Equal Protection Clauses. The stores filed motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The state enacted the Unit Pricing Law, N.Y. Agric. & Mkts. Law § 214-h to allow consumers to compare retail product prices by instituting unit pricing of certain consumer commodities. It also enacted the Item Pricing Law, which later expired, requiring individual food items to be individually marked with a price. After its expiration, the county adopted an item pricing law, the County Law. The stores sought a declaration that the County Law was unconstitutional. The court granted the stores' summary judgment motion in part, denied it in part, and held that: (1) the county had jurisdiction under the Municipal Home Rule Law to enact the County Law, which was not preempted because expiration of the state Item Pricing Law removed preemption and conflict; (2) no inconsistencies existed between an item pricing law and a unit pricing law; (3) equal protection was not violated because the County Law exception of Mom and Pop stores from its application was reasonable; (4) the County Law was justified and rationally-related to the need for item pricing; and (5) its penalty provisions violated due process by not providing the stores with an ability to measure the risk of violation.


OUTCOME: The court granted the stores' summary judgment motions in part and denied in part against the county and declared that the County Law was constitutional excepting the penalty provisions, which the court held to be unconstitutional and to be stricken from the remainder of the County Law.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - County Item Pricing Law - Adequacy of Notice of Public Hearing

1. The Erie County Item Pricing Law, which requires supermarkets and certain other retail establishments which use laser scanning equipment to affix price tags to individual items, was validly enacted after adequate notice of public hearing was given. The notice of public hearing published in various local papers, stating that the proposed law was "in relation to item pricing in retail food establishments", adequately warned the general public as well as food stores that item pricing legislation was being considered. The notice also gave sufficient opportunity to any establishment which sold retail foodstuffs to easily determine if such establishment would be affected.

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Validity of County Item Pricing Law - No State Preemption

2. The Erie County Item Pricing Law, which requires item pricing in supermarkets and certain other retail establishments which use laser scanning equipment, is not preempted or in conflict with State law and was thus validly enacted. There was no blanket prohibition of local legislation regarding item pricing under the expired State Item Pricing Law (Agriculture and Markets Law former § 214-i [8]) and the expiration of the State law in 1991 cannot be deemed to have created a greater preemption than existed under the law prior to expiration. Furthermore, there are no inconsistencies between the County Item Pricing Law, which deals with affixing of price tags to individual items, and the separate State Unit Pricing Law (Agriculture and Markets Law § 214-h), which deals with the display of price per measure. There is nothing inherently inconsistent between a unit pricing law and an item pricing law.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - County Item Pricing Law - Equal Protection

3. The Erie County Item Pricing Law, which requires supermarkets and certain other retail establishments which use laser scanning equipment to affix price tags to individual items, is not violative of equal protection for exempting "Mom and Pop" stores and unaffiliated convenience stores from the law since the different treatment of supermarkets and affiliated convenience stores is rationally based upon an economic finding that the need for item pricing is greatest in those stores. In addition, the exceptions to the law's application are reasonably based upon the need to minimize the burden of item pricing to small operations which cannot absorb the cost of compliance.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - County Item Pricing Law - Due Process

4. The Erie County Item Pricing Law, which requires supermarkets and certain other retail establishments which use laser scanning equipment to affix price tags to individual items, does not violate plaintiffs' due process rights. The County has demonstrated the need for item pricing and the County Law is logically related to this purpose. Furthermore, the failure of the County Law to make any exception for sale items or to allow a general percentage exception does not render the law violative of due process since such exceptions, although reasonable, are not constitutionally mandated. In addition, the list of excepted items is likewise not a violation of due process since each of the exceptions is rationally based upon a weighing of the need for item pricing, the difficulty in pricing certain food items, and health and welfare considerations.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - County Item Pricing Law - Vagueness

5. The Erie County Item Pricing Law, which requires supermarkets and certain other retail establishments which use laser scanning equipment to affix price tags to individual items, is not unconstitutionally vague since the term "food stores" as used in the law is sufficiently precise to define the application of the entire item pricing scheme. Furthermore, an error in drafting resulting in the use of words "stock keeping unit" in several places within the law when the words "stock keeping item" were meant, does not render the law invalid since the court in this case, in order to carry out the purpose and intent of the statutory scheme, should look beyond the statutory and industry definition of "stock keeping unit", which would render much of the law meaningless, and instead give the word "unit" a more common dictionary meaning as "item".

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - County Item Pricing Law - Severance of Unconstitutional Penalty Provision

6. The penalty provisions of the otherwise valid Erie County Item Pricing Law are invalid as violative of plaintiffs' rights to due process since such penalty provisions as written could result in excessive and disproportionate fines of millions of dollars, particularly if there are daily inspections. Since the penalty provisions are merely a method of enforcing the statutory purpose of requiring certain "food stores" to affix price labels to individual items, they can be severed from the rest of the legislation without affecting its purpose and the County Law may thus stand without the unconstitutional penalty provisions.

 

876 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Andres A. v. Judith N.


Docket No's. P4264-67/92


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


156 Misc. 2d 65; 591 N.Y.S.2d 946; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 551



November 13, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner husband and petitioner wife initiated an action against respondent surrogate mother to have themselves declared the biological father and biological mother of twins conceived through an in vitro fertilization procedure.


OVERVIEW: The husband and wife were unable to conceive a child. The wife underwent a surgical procedure whereby several of her eggs were removed from her body and were fertilized by her husband's semen. The fertilized eggs were then implanted in the uterus of the surrogate mother. The surrogate mother had twins and gave the children to the husband and wife. Pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 5, the husband and the wife filed petitions to have themselves declared the biological father and biological mother of the children. The court granted the husband's petition, but denied the wife's petition. The court did not have jurisdiction to determine the wife's maternity action. Section 511 of the Act provided the court with exclusive jurisdiction to establish paternity. The statute made no provision for declarations of maternity. The court held that it was not its role to legislate judicially what is not there in the original text. The court found that it was up to the legislature to address technological advances such as in vitro fertilization.


OUTCOME: The court granted the husband's petition and declared him the biological father of the twins. The court denied the wife's petition.


HEADNOTES

Children Born out of Wedlock - Paternity Proceeding - In Vitro Fertilization

1. Whether a pregnancy occurs by virtue of sexual relations, artificial insemination in utero or in vitro fertilization, a paternity proceeding pursuant to article 5 of the Family Court Act may be commenced to rebut the presumption that any child born to a married woman is presumptively the legitimate issue of the husband and that he is the legal father. Accordingly, in a paternity proceeding involving two children conceived through in vitro fertilization, the presumption of legitimacy has been rebutted with respect to respondents, the woman who gave birth to the children and her husband, where credible evidence consisting of the parties' testimony that petitioners, a wife and husband, underwent an in vitro fertilization procedure resulting in the implantation of six ova into respondent birth mother, blood test results indicating a high probability of petitioner husband's paternity, and respondents' testimony as to nonaccess during the critical period, clearly and convincingly establish that petitioner husband is the father of the subject children; thus, petitioner husband is entitled to a declaration of paternity with respect to the subject children.

Children Born out of Wedlock - Maternity Proceeding - In Vitro Fertilization - Surrogate Birth Mother

2. Inasmuch as the Family Court is a court of limited jurisdiction which must adhere to its statutorily enunciated powers, and Family Court Act article 5, the only provision for declaration of parenthood, does not provide for declarations of maternity, Family Court lacks subject matter jurisdiction to determine a proceeding by petitioner genetic mother seeking a declaration of maternity with respect to two children conceived through in vitro fertilization and born to a surrogate mother. Moreover, article 5 is not unconstitutional.

 

877 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bozer v. Higgins


Index No. 10166/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ERIE COUNTY


157 Misc. 2d 160; 596 N.Y.S.2d 634; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 651



November 5, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner attorney filed an action, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, to have declared unconstitutional the use of magnetometer searches at a state courthouse by respondents, the local sheriff's department and court administrators, to restrain and enjoin respondents from limiting, restricting, or prohibiting free attendance of the public sittings of the court, and to recover costs, expenses, and reasonable attorney's fees in prosecuting the action.


OVERVIEW: The attorney claimed that the court's use of metal detector's on all persons entering the courthouse was unconstitutional. The court ruled that the use of magnetometers at the court buildings were reasonable searches to which entrants gave their implied consent. The court: (1) rejected the attorney's claim that neither the sheriff nor the Office of Court Administration had no authority to promulgate the security policy, ruling that N.Y. Const. art. VI, § 28 and N.Y. Jud. Law § 212(1) authorized the promulgation of necessary security measures to ensure the administration of justice; (2) rejected the attorney's claim that the security measures violated mandates that the courts were to be public and to be held in public buildings, and; (3) observed that the attorney ignored the state and federal decisions on the issue and thereby rejected the attorney's claim that use of the metal detectors was an unreasonable search and seizure under the state and federal constitutions. The court found, pursuant to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 22, § 1301.1, that the attorney's suit was completely without merit in law or fact and was frivolous and sanctioned the attorney and his law firm.


OUTCOME: The court ruled that the attorney's claims were meritless and frivolous, ordered sanctions against the attorney and his law firm, and awarded the sheriff and the Office of Court Administration reasonable costs and attorneys' fees.


HEADNOTES

Searches and Seizures - Validity of Courthouse Magnetometer Searches

1. Respondent Office of Court Administration has the constitutional and statutory authority (NY Const, art VI, § 28; Judiciary Law § 212 [1]) to promulgate the security policy requiring the use of magnetometer searches at court buildings without obtaining legislative approval. Respondent's broad constitutional authority cannot be overturned or undermined by a narrow interpretation of the statute governing warrantless arrests ( CPL 140.50). In addition, the use of magnetometers is not contrary to Judiciary Law § 4, which requires that court sittings be public. Furthermore, warrantless magnetometer searches at court buildings are constitutionally reasonable searches to which entrants give their implied consent to the extent that such searches are uniformly applied to prospective entrants, are minimally intrusive and may be terminated at will by the entrant. The need to protect courts from the very real potential for violent incidents more than justifies the use of magnetometers.

Courts - Sanctions - Frivolous Proceeding Challenging Courthouse Magnetometer Searches

2. Petitioner attorney and his law firm are sanctioned pursuant to 22 NYCRR 130-1.1 for bringing a frivolous proceeding challenging the use of magnetometers at court buildings almost four years after the magnetometers were installed. Courthouse magnetometer searches are constitutionally reasonable searches to which entrants give their implied consent. Such procedures protect not only the judiciary and court personnel, but members of the Bar and the general public alike. There was no bar to the courtroom and petitioner and his law firm did not comment upon any of the many Federal and New York cases regarding magnetometer searches in courtrooms and buildings. Accordingly, sanctions are ordered in the amount of $ 500 against petitioner and $ 1,000 against his law firm to be paid to the Clients' Security Fund.

 

878 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Miccio


Dockets: 92K014055, 92K014056, 92K014057


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 697; 589 N.Y.S.2d 762; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 472



October 20, 1992, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants stood accused of several crimes, including aggravated harassment in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(3) and the N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 40-c(2) following defendants' attack on two complainants. The case went before the court on defendants' motions to dismiss on free speech grounds.


OVERVIEW: Defendants allegedly approached the complainants, one defendant stated that they did not want any spics or niggers in the neighborhood, and defendants physically attacked the complainants. After defendants were formally accused of violating N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30(3) and N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 40-c(2), defendants filed motions to dismiss the charges on the ground that the statutes violated defendants' First Amendment right to free speech. The court denied the motions on the ground that the challenged statutes did not violate the First Amendment and were a valid exercise of police power. The court held that the First Amendment's prohibition of the regulation of individual speech was not absolute. Speech could be regulated or prohibited if it served no useful purpose, and there was a compelling societal interest to prohibit it. The challenged statutes did not proscribe bias-related fighting words; rather, the statutes targeted defendants' physical actions. The proscribed behavior was distinguished from simple harassment, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.25(1), due to the added factor that the acts were committed because of bias toward the victims of the harassment.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions to dismiss because the challenged statutes regarding aggravated harassment dealt with defendants' actions based on bias toward the victims and were a valid exercise of the state's police power. The court noted that First Amendment free speech rights were not absolute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Aggravated Harassment - Punishment of Bias-Related Activity

The aggravated harassment and antidiscrimination statutes (Penal Law § 240.30 [3]; Civil Rights Law § 40-c), which both make it illegal to strike, shove, kick or otherwise subject another person to physical contact or attempt or threaten to do the same because of the "race, color, religion or national origin of such person", do not violate the First Amendment and are a valid exercise of police power. Prosecution under the statutes is based on physical conduct and not on the mere use of bias- related "fighting words". The statutes do not make certain acts punishable because of the motive of the defendant but merely enhance the punishment for those acts because of the motive. The State has a legitimate interest in protecting the rights of victims and discouraging bias-related crimes. Accordingly, defendants may lawfully be prosecuted under both statutes for punching and kicking complainants for bias-related reasons.

 

879 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Jones v. Trane


92-126


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ONONDAGA COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 822; 591 N.Y.S.2d 927; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 547



October 19, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, an infant and his parents (infant), sued defendants, a priest and the church that employed him, for the priest's alleged sexual molestation of the infant. Plaintiffs asserted claims of respondeat superior and negligent hiring against the church and "clergy malpractice," in a variety of forms, against the priest. The priest and the church moved to dismiss the causes of action.


OVERVIEW: The infant sued the priest and the church that employed the priest (defendants) after the infant was allegedly sexually molested. In particular, the infant sued on the theories of, among others, clergy malpractice and negligence, outrageous conduct causing severe emotional distress to the infant, respondeat superior, negligent hiring, failure to evaluate periodically the priest's activities, and breach of trust. On defendants' motions to dismiss, the court: (1) dismissed the respondeat superior claim because there was no allegation or proof that the priest sexually molested the infant in furtherance of the church's interests; (2) dismissed the clergy malpractice and negligence claims because the priest's wrongful conduct constituted the intentional torts of assault and battery and therefore were not cognizable as claims in negligence; (3) sustained the breach of trust claim, rejecting defendants' contention that such a cause of action was barred by the First Amendment; (4) sustained the claim for negligent hiring and supervision because such a cause of action was valid if the infant could show that the church knew or should have known of the priest's sexual proclivities.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the infant's causes of action for clergy malpractice and negligence because the priest's misconduct amounted to the intentional torts of assault and battery. Because there was no allegation or proof that the priest was acting at the behest or in furtherance of the church's objective, the claim under respondeat superior was dismissed. The church could be held liable for negligent hiring, breach of trust, and outrageous conduct.


HEADNOTES

Negligence - Clergy Malpractice - Sexual Misconduct by Clergyman - Breach of Trust - Excessive Entanglement in Religious Matters

1. Causes of action for clergy malpractice and negligence, predicated upon alleged sexual misconduct of defendant clergyman regarding the infant plaintiff, must be dismissed since defendant's wrongful conduct constituted the intentional torts of assault and battery and, thus, falls outside the ambit of actionable negligence. However, plaintiffs state valid causes of action for breach or violation of trust. There is no constitutional impediment to such causes of action on the ground of excessive entanglement in religious matters since there is no evidence of any counseling relationship between defendant and the infant plaintiff, of which the sexual misconduct alleged was a part, such as might preclude an inquiry into the propriety of defendant's conduct as an excessive involvement in the philosophy of his religious community. Since it is conduct, not creed, that underlies plaintiffs' actions, the First Amendment does not preclude such claims. Furthermore, even if defendant's conduct had been within a counseling setting, the actions would not be dismissed on the ground of excessive entanglement where the misconduct charged is the sexual abuse of an infant.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Religion - Liability of Religious Institutions for Sexual Misconduct of Clergyman

2. The institutional religious defendants in this case involving the alleged sexual misconduct of a clergyman regarding the infant plaintiff can be held liable for negligent hiring and failing periodically to evaluate the clergyman's activities and are not cloaked with any immunity under the First Amendment. If plaintiffs establish that defendants placed the clergyman in contact with boys despite actual or constructive notice of the priest's perverted proclivities, the fact that the placement occurred in the course of internal administration of the religious units does not, on constitutional grounds, preclude holding the institutions accountable for their negligence in administration. Likewise, causes of action against defendants based upon the outrageous conduct of the priest causing severe emotional distress should not be dismissed at this stage. However, defendants may not be held vicariously liable for the alleged intentional sexual misconduct of the priest under the principle of respondeat superior in the absence of any evidence that the priest was acting in furtherance of his employers' interests.

 

880 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Jackson v. Triborough Bridge & Tunnel Auth.


INDEX NO. 1639/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 715; 589 N.Y.S.2d 748; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 481



October 2, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant employer sought dismissal of an action brought by plaintiff employee, who sought review of a determination by the employer that, when the employee transferred from another civil service position, he was still on probation, and could therefore be terminated without a formal hearing pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 75.


OVERVIEW: The employee originally worked for the New York City Department of Sanitation. He was dismissed for misconduct, but after filing a grievance, was reinstated with a one year probationary period. While still on probation, the employee transferred to the employer, but the employer was unaware of the employee's probationary status. After the employee committed disciplinary violations in his new position, the employer issued a letter informing him of his right to a formal hearing. The employer then realized that it had erred in issuing the letter, because a formal hearing was not required for probationary employees. The employer issued a superseding letter two days later, informing the employee of his termination. The employee brought this action seeking a formal hearing and reinstatement. The employer filed a motion to dismiss, which the trial court granted. The court held that, pursuant to N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 554, the employee's probationary status followed him to other civil servant positions within New York City agencies.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion to dismiss filed by the employer.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - Four-Month Statute of Limitations - When Cause of Action Accrues - Notification of Agency Determination

1. The four-month Statute of Limitations for a CPLR article 78 proceeding to review an agency determination ( CPLR 217) begins to run when the determination becomes final and binding--i.e., when petitioner is notified of the determination. Accordingly, a claim in the amended petition in an article 78 proceeding challenging a "Certificate of Approval" issued by the New York City Personnel Director on April 22, 1991, which conditioned petitioner civil service employee's job transfer from the Department of Sanitation to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority (TBTA) upon the completion of his probationary period, was timely asserted on April 17, 1992 where petitioner, who was terminated without a hearing on the basis of his probationary status, was not "notified" of the determination of the City Personnel Director until March 30, 1992, when he received a motion by TBTA to dismiss the petition challenging his termination.

Civil Service - Termination of Employment - Effect of Transfer on Probationary Status

2. Respondent Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority (TBTA) properly terminated petitioner's employment for disciplinary reasons without a formal hearing since petitioner's former permanent civil service status was lawfully altered by virtue of a stipulation signed by petitioner prior to his transfer from the New York City Department of Sanitation to the TBTA wherein he agreed to serve a one-year probationary period and to forgo other rights and privileges of a permanent civil servant as a condition to being reinstated to his former position following disciplinary proceedings. Petitioner retained his probationary status upon his transfer since civil servants who are transferred from a New York City agency to the TBTA "have the same status ... after transfer ... as they had under their original appointment" (Public Authorities Law § 554). Furthermore, petitioner was notified that his transfer would be subject to the City Personnel Director's rules governing transfers, which provide that where, as here, a probationary employee voluntarily agrees to a transfer to avoid a layoff, the transfer is subject to the employee completing any probationary period then being served (13 RCNY, tit 59, Appendix A, rule 6.1.6).

Civil Service - Termination of Employment - Estoppel to Treat Employee as Probationary

3. Where petitioner, an employee of the New York City Department of Sanitation who was on disciplinary probation, was transferred to the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority (TBTA) during the pendency of that probation, the fact that TBTA officials mistakenly told petitioner and his union representative that petitioner would have permanent civil service status at TBTA does not estop TBTA from treating petitioner as a probationary employee. The doctrine of equitable estoppel is unavailable to petitioner due to the absence of any detrimental reliance by petitioner on any of the mistaken assurances by TBTA. In addition, petitioner had no right to be treated as a permanent civil servant until the expiration of the one-year probation and the doctrine of equitable estoppel cannot be used to create a right or place petitioner in a better position.

 

881 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Iffland v. Iffland


3024


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 661; 589 N.Y.S.2d 249; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 433



September 11, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff former husband filed a motion requesting a downward modification of maintenance, pursuant to N.Y. Dom. Rel. Law § 236(B)(9)(b), which awarded to former wife under a separation agreement. The husband asserted extreme hardship and that the statute was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The husband and wife entered into a separation agreement during their divorce proceeding but pursuant to the terms of the agreement it did not merge into the judgment of divorce. The husband filed a motion requesting that the amount of his monthly maintenance payments to the wife be reduced based on his premature retirement alleging the current amount of $ 1,000 per month would be an extreme hardship after his retirement, and that the Domestic Relations Law was in violation of the parties' constitutional right to contract. The court denied the husband's application for relief and ruled that the statute was unconstitutional as it pertained to the separation agreement surviving the parties' divorce decree because the statute substantially impaired the long-standing rights of parties to enter into private contracts, the law had a questionable public purpose because there was no significant and legitimate social purpose pertaining to the health, safety or welfare of its citizens which could be found to outweigh the parties' individual right to contract, and the law was not reasonably and narrowly tailored because it lacked any subjective guidelines for the term extreme hardship.


OUTCOME: The court denied the husbands' motion for a downward modification of the monthly maintenance payments to the wife, and ruled the Domestic Relations Law unconstitutional as it pertained to separation agreements that survived a divorce decree.


HEADNOTES

Husband and Wife - Separation Agreement - Modification - Unconstitutional Impairment of Private Contractual Rights

Domestic Relations Law § 236 (B) (9) (b), which permits modification of maintenance contained in a separation agreement that survives the divorce decree upon a showing of "extreme prejudice", is unconstitutional as violative of the Contract Clause (US Const, art I, § 10, cl [1]) since it operates as a substantial impairment of the rights and obligations in private contracts without furthering a significant and legitimate social purpose beyond saving a party from having entered into a bad deal. The law furthers no legitimate health, safety or welfare concerns which outweigh the parties' individual rights of contract. In addition, the law is not reasonably and narrowly tailored since it lacks any subjective guidelines for "extreme hardship" as that term would relate to any legitimate and significant public purpose and it further fails to provide a framework limiting it to the public purpose which would permit such intrusion into private contracts. Accordingly, plaintiff husband's claimed "extreme hardship" due to early retirement cannot serve as grounds for a downward modification of the monthly maintenance he is required to pay defendant pursuant to the terms of a separation agreement incorporated, but not merged, into the judgment of divorce.

 

882 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mulqueen


Index No. 17204/90


DISTRICT COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY, FIRST DISTRICT


155 Misc. 2d 632; 589 N.Y.S.2d 246; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 468



September 10, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant individual filed a motion to set aside the verdict finding defendant guilty of violating N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 40-c (2) and acquitting defendant of two counts of aggravated harassment in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.30.


OVERVIEW: Defendant individual was acquitted of two counts of aggravated harassment, but was found guilty of the violation of N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 40-c (2). Defendant argued that the jury's verdict of guilt was against the weight of the evidence, that the conviction under § 40-c (2) was in violation of his first amendment rights under the constitution, and that the People failed to comply with the notification requirements under N.Y. Civ. Rights Law § 40-d, requiring dismissal of count 3 of the information. The court found that the evidence adduced at trial was legally sufficient to establish defendant's guilt beyond a reasonable doubt. In addition, the court found that § 40-c (2) withstood the constitutional scrutiny because violation of the statute was determined by defendant's conduct towards another. Defendant failed to support his contention that § 40-c (2) was unconstitutionally overbroad.


OUTCOME: Court denied motion to set aside defendant's conviction on constitutional grounds because defendant failed to support his contention that statute at issue was unconstitutionally overbroad, and to set aside verdict based upon credibility of evidence introduced at trial because evidence was legally sufficient to establish defendant's guilt beyond reasonable doubt.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Verdict - Setting Verdict Aside - Verdict against Weight of Evidence

1. Defendant may not have the jury verdict finding him guilty of making harassing telephone calls in violation of Civil Rights Law § 40-c (2) set aside pursuant to CPL 330.30 on the ground that the guilty verdict is against the weight of the credible evidence adduced at trial since a trial court is not authorized to set aside a verdict on that ground. Unlike an appellate court, a trial court may set aside a verdict pursuant to CPL 330.30 only in instances where the evidence is legally insufficient to support the verdict. In this case, there was nothing so inherently contradictory or unbelievable in the People's proof as to require a finding of insufficiency as a matter of law.

Civil Rights - Discrimination in Public Accommodation - Harassing Telephone Calls Not Constitutionally Protected

2. Defendant was lawfully convicted of making harassing telephone calls to a specific individual in violation of Civil Rights Law § 40-c (2), since his conduct was not constitutionally protected under the First Amendment. The statute withstands constitutional scrutiny since it does not on its face prohibit speech or impermissibly target conduct based upon its expressive content. Rather, violation of the statute is determined not by the content of the person's speech, but by his or her conduct towards another. ln addition, defendant has failed to establish that the statute is unconstitutionally overbroad. Furthermore, the People's failure to notify the Attorney-General of the commencement of the criminal proceeding against defendant does not require dismissal under Civil Rights Law § 40-d since the notification requirement only applies when the person aggrieved commences a civil action to recover a penalty from the defendant.

 

883 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York Coalition of Recycling Enters. v. City of New York


Index No. 24957/90


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


158 Misc. 2d 1; 598 N.Y.S.2d 649; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 662



September 1, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended July 17, 1993.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner recycling trade association challenged respondent city's law which regulated the waste transfer industry and sought a preliminary injunction blocking the law. The city sought a declaratory judgment that the law was constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The court found that (1) the association did not have standing to sue under the State Environmental Quality Review Act, (2) the enactment of the law was an emergency action exempt from the requirements under environmental review statutes, (3) the city fulfilled notice and hearing requirements, (4) the "as applied" challenges were not ripe where regulations had not been developed or implemented, (5) substantive due process was not violated as the law was reasonably related to a legitimate governmental objective, (6) equal protection was not violated although the city only addressed the environmental concerns of the waste transfer industry and not other industries, (7) the city did not "take" the association member's property as the law did not deprive the association members of the right to continue business, (8) the law did not improperly delegate responsibility to the Department of Sanitation (DOS) as the legislature enunciated a standard to guide DOS conduct and the standards were not void for vagueness, (9) the association's privacy rights would not be violated by requiring them to disclose information to the DOS, and (10) the statute did not impose cruel and unusual punishment.


OUTCOME: The court granted a declaratory judgment to the city that the law was constitutional and did not violate constitutional rights and denied the recycling trade association's petition for a preliminary injunction and other relief.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Environmental Review of Law Regulating Waste Transfer Industry - No Standing for Economic Concerns

1. Petitioners, an industrial trade association made up of the owners and operators of solid waste management and recycling facilities, and the individual operators, lack standing to challenge, on environmental grounds, the enactment of a New York City local law (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.) regulating waste transfer stations for recyclable materials. The perceived environmental harms claimed are not different in kind or degree from those affecting the general community. Petitioners' concerns as to the increase in their costs of doing business are economic, not environmental, and such concerns do not create standing to raise claims under State and City environmental review statutes. Furthermore, the enactment of the law was a health emergency action exempt from environmental review requirements. The lead agencies took the required "hard look" at the environmental consequences to support the issuance of a negative declaration of any adverse environmental impact.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - Proper Exercise of Police Power

2. A law enacted by the City of New York regulating waste transfer stations for recyclable materials (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.) represents a proper exercise of the City's police power to regulate for reasons of health and public safety and is facially constitutional. Petitioners, an industrial trade association made up of the owners and operators of solid waste management and recycling facilities, and the individual operators, have failed to establish that the notice and hearing procedures employed to enact the law were arbitrary, capricious or contrary to law. Petitioners were in fact present and participated at the hearings.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - "As Applied" Challenge - No Violation of Substantive Due Process

3. A law enacted by the City of New York, placing administrative jurisdiction over all waste transfer stations for recyclable materials with the Department of Sanitation (DOS) and enhancing DOS's regulatory authority, including the right to promulgate regulations with regard to siting specifications (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.), is not unconstitutional "as applied" to petitioners, an industrial trade association made up of the owners and operators of solid waste management and recycling facilities, and the individual operators, since the "as applied" challenge, which is dependent upon the regulations, is not ripe for determination and presents no justiciable controversy for a declaratory adjudication at this time prior to the adoption of any regulations. In addition, the law, on its face, does not violate substantive due process since it is reasonably related to the legitimate governmental objective of improving the health, safety and general welfare of the public by shifting administrative responsibility. The law is a reasonable exercise of police power in an area that has long been subject to regulation.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - No Violation of Operators' Equal Protection Rights

4. A law enacted by the City of New York, placing administrative jurisdiction over all waste transfer stations for recyclable materials with the Department of Sanitation (DOS) and enhancing DOS's regulatory authority, including the right to promulgate regulations with regard to siting specifications (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.), does not deny equal protection to petitioners, an industrial trade association made up of the owners and operators of solid waste management and recycling facilities, and the individual operators, since the City, in lawfully exercising its police power, may validly address the environmental concerns of the waste transfer industry separate from other industries that may impact upon the environment. Such disparate treatment of other classes does not give rise to complaint for a deprivation of equal protection. The placement of the entire waste transfer industry under one coherent scheme of regulation should, if anything, promote equal protection.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - No Unconstitutional Taking

5. A law enacted by the City of New York, placing administrative jurisdiction over all waste transfer stations for recyclable materials with the Department of Sanitation (DOS) and enhancing DOS's regulatory authority, including the right to promulgate regulations with regard to siting specifications (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.), does not unconstitutionally deprive owners of transfer stations of the right to continue to operate their businesses and use their properties in an economically viable manner. The law, on its face, does not prohibit transfer station operations in certain zones where such operations are now permitted but merely authorizes DOS to adopt siting regulations. A "possible taking" which might occur in the future when the regulations are adopted is not equivalent to a taking at this time. Moreover, petitioners do not have immunity against the valid exercise of the City's police power merely because their businesses were originally established in full compliance with then existing laws. While the new regulatory scheme may eventually increase the cost of doing business, that does not render it invalid. Furthermore, since petitioners have not provided any proof that previously issued permits were prematurely retired by the new legislation, they have not demonstrated a taking on this ground.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - No Improper Delegation of Authority to Administrative Agency

6. A law enacted by the City of New York placing administrative jurisdiction over all waste treatment stations for recyclable materials with the Department of Sanitation (DOS) and enhancing DOS's regulatory authority (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.), does not improperly delegate responsibility to DOS without providing statutory standards for the exercise of its discretion. The law's requirements that applicants produce such information as DOS determines "to be necessary for the department to fulfill its duties", including "financial statements" and "any annual or quarterly report" required to be filed, provides a sufficient framework and standard for DOS to follow. The statutory provision empowering DOS to rescind an order sealing, securing or closing premises or equipment when the operator provides DOS with "assurances that the conditions which caused the issuance of such order have been corrected and will not reoccur", likewise provides DOS with a specific standard to follow. Moreover, clear limits are set on the conduct of DOS in issuing exemptions regarding enclosure of putrescible waste transfer stations. Furthermore, the law does not constitute an improper delegation of authority as to enforcement and penalties since fines and penalties are imposed by adjudicatory bodies, not DOS. In the area of enforcement, it is customary and usual for the legislative body, as here, to leave to the adjudicatory body discretion in imposing penalties as the circumstances warrant within a particular range of choices.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - Void for Vagueness Analysis

7. A law enacted by the City of New York placing administrative jurisdiction over all waste transfer stations for recyclable materials with the Department of Sanitation (DOS) and enhancing DOS's regulatory authority (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.), is not void for vagueness since the broad and flexible standards and policies set forth in the law provide sufficient guidelines for the exercise of agency discretion.

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - No Violation of Due Process Right to Privacy for Having to Provide Administrative Agency with Business Records - Trade Secrets

8. A law enacted by the City of New York placing all administrative jurisdiction over waste transfer stations for recyclable material with the Department of Sanitation (DOS) and enhancing DOS's regulatory authority (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.), does not violate any due process right to privacy by requiring station operators to provide DOS with their business records, which may then be disclosed in response to a Freedom of Information Law request, since there is little or no expectation of privacy in business records in such an extensively regulated industry, especially for documents prepared in compliance with regulatory requirements. Moreover, trade secrets obtained in the course of regulatory compliance are exempt from disclosure to the public in any event (Public Officers Law § 87 [2] [d]).

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Regulation of Waste Transfer Industry - Valid Criminal Sanctions

9. The criminal sanctions imposed for illegal waste transfer station operations in the City of New York, making a violation of the statute (Local Laws, 1990, No. 40 of City of New York, amending Administrative Code of City of NY § 16-130 et seq.) a misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment of up to one year, a fine not to exceed $ 25,000 and impoundment and forfeiture of property and equipment used in the commission of a crime, are not grossly disproportionate to the nature of the offense so as to constitute cruel and unusual punishment. The penalties are all within the limits of comparable regulatory structures on the State and Federal levels for conduct detrimental to the public health and safety. In addition, the impoundment procedures provide for a timely postdeprivation hearing within three business days and are thus not violative of due process.

 

884 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cash v. State Dep't of Taxation & Finance


Index No. 1300-92, RJI 0192 030167


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 425; 1992-2 Trade Cas. (CCH) P69,955



August 24, 1992, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff cigarette wholesaler sought summary judgment in its action seeking a declaration that the Cigarette Marketing Standards Act (CMSA) was unconstitutional and violated the Sherman Anti-Trust Act. Defendants, the state department of taxation and its commissioner, sought summary judgment by cross-action, seeking a declaration that the CMSA did not constitute a resale price-fixing scheme contrary to federal law.


OVERVIEW: The wholesaler had unsuccessfully sought administrative relief in an attempt to establish that its cost of doing business was in fact lower than the statutorily presumed rate provided for in the CMSA. In the declaratory action, the wholesaler alleged that the CMSA was in conflict with the Sherman Anti-Trust Act, and therefore, unconstitutional pursuant to the Supremacy Clause. Defendants argued that the CMSA was immune from federal anti-trust provisions under the state action doctrine set forth in Parker. The court agreed with defendants and found that the CMSA satisfied both prongs of the state action exemption requirement. First, the court found that the enabling provision of the CMSA, which provided that regulation of the sales prices of cigarettes was required for the purpose of stabilizing the industry within the state, satisfied the first prong that required that the economic restraint was part of a state policy. The court next found that the second prong was satisfied in that the state department of taxation actively supervised the CMSA. Accordingly, the court found that the CMSA was exempt from the Sherman Anti-Trust Act.


OUTCOME: The court denied the wholesaler's motion for summary judgment and granted defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment to the extent that they were entitled to a declaration that the CMSA did not constitute a resale price fixing scheme contrary to federal law. The court ordered defendants' counsel to submit an order and judgment in conformance therewith.

 

885 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Borriello


Indictment No. 12556/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 261; 588 N.Y.S.2d 991; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 405



August 20, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Counts 1, 2, and 3 are dismissed as preempted by Federal statute.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss all counts against him charging advertisement of sale of unauthorized recordings in the first and second degree, failure to disclose the origin of a recording in the second degree, and criminal possession of a forged instrument in the third degree on the grounds that N.Y. Penal Law §§ 275.25, 275.30, 275.35, and 170.20 were preempted by federal copyright law.


OVERVIEW: Defendant owned video stores and possessed unauthorized recordings of videocassettes. Defendant was charged under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 275.25, 275.30, 275.35, and 170.20 for advertisement of sale of unauthorized recordings, failure to disclose the origin of a recording and criminal possession of a forged instrument. Defendant moved to dismiss all of the counts on the ground that those sections of the N.Y. Penal Law were preempted by federal copyright law. The court dismissed three counts that were charged under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 275.25 and 275.30 because those statutes were under the purview of 17 U.S.C.S. § 301 and, thus, were preempted by explicit congressional enactment because copyright protection provided by those statutes was the equivalent of that provided in the federal copyright statute, 17 U.S.C.S. § 301. However, the remaining four counts that were charged under N.Y. Penal Law §§ 275.35 and 170.20 were not dismissed because they dealt with misleading packaging for recordings and possession of a forged instrument; therefore, they did not conflict with federal copyright law, and they were not preempted by federal law.


OUTCOME: Three counts were dismissed because the copyright protection provided by the state statutes was equivalent of that provided in the federal copyright statute; thus, the state statutes were preempted by federal law. The remaining four counts were not dismissed because the statutes dealt with misleading packaging for recordings and possession of a forged instrument, so they did not conflict with and were not preempted by federal copyright law.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Offenses Relating to Unauthorized Recording - Preemption by Federal Copyright Law

Defendant, the owner of three video stores, may not be prosecuted under State law for advertisement or sale of unauthorized recordings in the first and second degrees (Penal Law §§ 275.25, 275.30) based upon his having rented to the public unauthorized recordings of videocassettes without the copyright owner's consent since the State statutes as applied in this case have been preempted by Federal copyright law. A State regulation or statute is preempted if the rights covered are "equivalent" to any of those exclusive rights "within the general scope of copyright ... in works of authorship that ... come within the subject matter of copyright" (17 USC § 301 [a]). Sections 275.25 and 275.30 deal exclusively with matters related to distribution and thus contain "equivalent" rights covered exclusively by Federal copyright law. Furthermore, the videocassettes at issue come within the Federal subject matter of copyright (17 USC § 102 [a] [6]). However, defendant may properly be prosecuted for failure to disclose the origin of a recording in the second degree (Penal Law § 275.35) and criminal possession of a forged instrument in the third degree (Penal Law § 170.20). The rights being affected by those consumer protection statutes are not "equivalent" rights "within the general scope of copyright"; moreover, those statutes are not copyright infringement statutes by nature and have no effect on the congressional objective of national uniformity of copyright law.

 

886 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Wakefield Fin. Corp.


Indictment No. 289-91, Indictment No. 288-91, Indictment No. 286-91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 775; 590 N.Y.S.2d 382; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 494



August 12, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants moved to dismiss the indictments charging them with manipulating the over-the-counter stock market and with enterprise corruption under New York's enterprise corruption statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 460.1, et seq.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were indicted for enterprise corruption under New York's enterprise corruption statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 460.1 et seq., similar to federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, in connection with manipulating the over-the-counter stock market. Defendants moved to dismiss the indictments on numerous grounds. The court denied the motion finding the warrants for electronic eavesdropping were supported by probable cause since the prosecution adequately met its burden of demonstrating that wiretapping was an appropriate method of investigation. The court further found that New York's enterprise corruption statute was constitutional, and that the indictment sufficiently charged a continuing enterprise.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion since prosecution adequately met its burden of demonstrating that wiretapping was an appropriate method of investigation, thus there was probable cause supporting the warrant. The court further held the indictment and presentation to the grand jury sufficiently charged a continuing enterprise to satisfy statutory requirement.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Eavesdropping Warrants - Standing to Challenge Warrant

1. In the prosecution of defendants for engaging in a criminal enterprise to secretly manipulate the over-the-counter stock market in which evidence was obtained by wiretapping, only those defendants whose conversations were overheard and intercepted have standing to challenge the initial warrant and subsequent extensions.

Crimes - Eavesdropping Warrants - Necessity for Electronic Eavesdropping

2. In the prosecution of defendants for engaging in a criminal enterprise to secretly manipulate the over-the-counter stock market, the People have adequately demonstrated that electronic eavesdropping was an appropriate method of investigation as provided in CPL 700.15 (4) and 700.20 (2) (d). There is no statutory requirement that wiretapping be only the last resort or that all other imaginable means of investigation have been absolutely and completely exhausted.

Crimes - Eavesdropping Warrants - Amendment of Warrants - Enterprise Corruption

3. In the criminal prosecution of defendants for engaging in a criminal enterprise to secretly manipulate the over-the-counter stock market in which evidence was obtained by wiretapping pursuant to warrants seeking evidence of securities fraud and related crimes, the failure of the People to amend the warrants to specify enterprise corruption (Penal Law § 460.10 [3]) as a target crime does not preclude the use of the intercepted conversations to prove that crime. Although the crime of enterprise corruption is not an approved designated offense for purposes of obtaining an eavesdropping warrant (CPL 700.30 [4]; 700.05 [8]), such offense is within the ambit of the crimes sought to be discovered in the surveillance. Accordingly, the crime of enterprise corruption was "otherwise sought" in the eavesdropping warrants within the meaning of the retrospective amendment procedure of CPL 700.65 (4) and amendment was thus not required.

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - Constitutionality of Enterprise Corruption Statute 

4. New York's enterprise corruption statute, which proscribes acting with intent to participate in or advance the affairs of a "criminal enterprise" having a "structure and criminal purpose beyond the scope of individual criminal incidents" (Penal Law § 460.10 [3]), is not unconstitutionally vague.

Crimes - Enterprise Corruption - What Constitutes Criminal Enterprise

5. Defendants, independent securities firms and individuals, were properly charged with enterprise corruption for allegedly engaging in a "criminal enterprise" to secretly manipulate the over-the-counter stock market, where the evidence presented to the Grand Jury established: that the otherwise discrete and independent defendants acted together to manipulate securities on an ongoing basis; that defendants' unlawful purpose was to profit from their manipulative market tactics; that while not all defendants were involved in every deal, there was a continuing structure and purpose; and that there existed an enterprise with an ascertainable structure distinct from a pattern of criminal conduct, including a system of authority beyond what is minimally necessary to effectuate individual substantive criminal offenses. Moreover, the enterprise corruption statute was not intended to apply only to the "Mafia" but, rather, was also intended to cover the type of "ordinary white collar crimes" involved in this case.

 

887 of 992 DOCUMENTS


McDermott v. Regan


Index No. 4984-90, Index No. 2166-92, Index No. 4985-90, RJI No. 0190-24651


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 137; 587 N.Y.S.2d 533; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 378; 15 Employee Benefits Cas. (BNA) 2326



August 10, 1992, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:
