PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the union officers and others, filed suit against defendants, the comptroller and others, seeking a declaration that 1990 N.Y. Laws 210 was unconstitutional for violating N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7. The parties filed cross motions for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The Common Retirement Fund (CRF) held the assets and income of certain retirement systems. Previously, comptrollers used the aggregate cost method as the actuarial funding method to determine annual contributions to be made by public employers to the CRF. Thereafter, the legislature enacted 1990 N.Y. Laws 210 which mandated changing the actuarial funding method from the aggregate cost method to the projected unit credit method. Studies projected that the amount required to be contributed to the CRF by public employers would increase dramatically. The union officers and others then commenced the instant action seeking a declaration that 1990 N.Y. Laws 210 was unconstitutional. The court found that one of the contract benefits public employees acquired as a result of N.Y. Const. art. V, § 7 was the right to an independent trustee imbued with the discretion to protect their retirement funds. 1990 N.Y. Laws 210 was an unconstitutional attempt to divest public employees of that contract right.


OUTCOME: The court granted the union officers and others' motions for summary judgment and denied the cross motions for summary judgment filed by the comptroller and others.


HEADNOTES

Civil Service - Retirement and Pension Benefits - Unconstitutional Impairment of Retirement Benefits - Change in Actuarial Funding Method Used to Calculate Employer Contributions

Chapter 210 of the Laws of 1990, which requires the State Comptroller, as trustee of the Common Retirement Fund (CRF), to change the actuarial funding method for determining the annual contributions to be made by public employers to the CRF from the fiscally conservative aggregate cost method, which has been employed since 1921 and has resulted in a surplus in the CRF in excess of $ 7 billion, to the projected unit credit method, which would reduce or eliminate public employer contributions to the CRF for a 10-year period by expending the surplus in the CRF, is unconstitutional as violative of the constitutional amendment, effective after July 1, 1940, which makes membership in any pension or retirement system of the State a contractual relationship, "the benefits of which shall not be diminished or impaired" (NY Const, art V, § 7). A contract benefit acquired by public employees as a result of the constitutional amendment was the right to an independent trustee imbued with the discretion to protect their retirement funds. Chapter 210 is an unconstitutional attempt to divest public employees of that contract right. The diversion of accumulated pension funds of public employees to meet a present fiscal crisis by reducing the contributions of public employers in order to avoid raising taxes or cutting other programs is precisely the type of conduct the constitutional amendment was designed to prevent.

 

888 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re New York Agency etc.


Index No. 43170/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 122; 587 N.Y.S.2d 524; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 375



August 3, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 9, 1992.



DISPOSITION: The application is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Superintendent of Banks of the State of New York seized the state agency of a foreign bank, pursuant to N.Y. Banking Law § 606. Petitioner international bank, who had paid its end of a currency swap with the foreign bank but had not been paid in return, filed an application for an order directing the Superintendent to turn over a portion of the funds that were being held for liquidation.


OVERVIEW: The international bank paid its end of the currency swap to the foreign bank's office in London. The international bank never received what it was owed by the foreign bank. The international bank argued that § 606 was unconstitutional. First, the international bank argued that § 606 unfairly favored creditors of the state agency of the foreign bank by giving them preferred access to the foreign bank's assets. In denying the application, the court held that § 606 did not give preference to in-state creditors over residents elsewhere; instead, the statute prioritized between creditors whose claims arose out of business done with the foreign bank's state agency, whether the creditor resided in the state or not. The international bank also argued that § 606 unlawfully discriminated among creditors by creating a preferred group of creditors, those of the foreign bank's state agency, and a disfavored group, those of the foreign bank. The court held that the statutory scheme was not arbitrary or irrational because the state was balancing the need to attract foreign banks for business purposes and the desire to protect those that dealt with foreign banks in the state.


OUTCOME: The court denied the international bank's application for an ordering directing the Superintendent to disburse the liquidated funds.


HEADNOTES

Banks and Banking - Liquidation - Constitutionality of Liquidation Procedures Regarding New York Agency of Foreign Bank

The liquidation procedures of Banking Law § 606 are not unconstitutional to the extent that they give a preference to claims of creditors of a New York Agency of a failed foreign bank over claims of creditors against other out-of-State branches of the foreign bank. The statutory scheme is a rational and balanced system for the regulation of foreign banking that does not directly or indirectly unconstitutionally give preference to New York creditors over out-of-State creditors. The distinction drawn by the statute between creditors whose claims arise out of business done with the foreign bank's New York Agency, whether they reside in New York or not, and those whose claims arise out of dealings with the bank or its branches elsewhere, is not arbitrary or irrational but, rather, furthers the legitimate State interest of insuring that those who deal with foreign banks in this State, whatever their citizenship, are protected.

 

889 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Toth


DOCKET NO.: 92K012185


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 1006; 586 N.Y.S.2d 737; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 355



July 20, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: As there is no longer any property to be suppressed, that portion of defendant's motion requesting a Mapp hearing is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion for an order dismissing the accusatory instrument, which charged him with the crimes of attempting to not have a dismantler registration in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(1) and failure to produce a record of motor vehicle or motor vehicle parts in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5), on the ground that the criminal court information was facially insufficient.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged in an information with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(1) and N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5). Defendant filed a motion for an order dismissing the accusatory instrument. The court dismissed the portion of the information charging defendant with violating § 415-a(5) and denied the portion of defendant's motion inasmuch as the information charged him with violating N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(1). The court found that the provisions in N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5)(a) for warrantless, suspicionless searches of business premises were unconstitutional because the authorized searches were undertaken solely to uncover evidence of criminality and failed to delineate rules to guarantee the certainty and regularity of application necessary to provide a constitutionally adequate substitute for a warrant. The court held that defendant, as vehicle dismantler, was not required, under New York law, to produce his records upon request of a police officer, and could not be charged with criminal activity for his failure to do so. The court held that the provisions of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a fell within the legitimate licensing powers of the state.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the portion of the information charging defendant with the crime of failure to produce a record of motor vehicle or motor vehicle parts. The court denied the portion of defendant's motion inasmuch as he requested the court to dismiss the information, which charged him with the crime of attempting to not have a dismantler registration.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles - Junkyards - Vehicle Dismantlers - Prosecution for Failure to Produce Records and Registration

Defendant, who is in the vehicle dismantling business, cannot be prosecuted for failure to produce his records of motor vehicles and motor vehicle parts coming in and going out of the business ( Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a [5] [a]) since, in view of the decision of the Court of Appeals in People v Keta (79 NY2d 474) "that Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a (5) (a)'s provisions for warrantless, suspicionless searches of business premises cannot withstand challenge" under the State Constitution, a vehicle dismantler is not required to produce his records upon request of a police officer and cannot be charged with criminal activity for his failure to do so. However, the provisions of Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a (1) requiring a vehicle dismantler to be registered and the specifications as to how the registration must be displayed fall within the legitimate licensing powers of the State. Such provisions are neither onerous nor invasive. Accordingly, the information in this case clearly sets forth facts tending to support defendant's alleged failure to have such registration.

 

890 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Kelly v. Kaladjian


Index No. 40298/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 652; 589 N.Y.S.2d 730; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 474



July 14, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff applicants requested Emergency Home Relief (EHR) grants to pay amounts due so they could retain their homes. Defendant, the acting commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services (DSS), denied the applications because the applicants' income exceeded 125 percent of the Federal income poverty line, a ceiling prescribed by a recent amendment to the regulations governing the EHR program. The applicants appealed.


OVERVIEW: The EHR program provided assistance to New York residents with emergency needs who were ineligible for assistance under any other state program. Under EHR, applicants could receive one-time emergency assistance payments if they were facing eviction for nonpayment of rent and they did not qualify for Federal assistance. In order to contain costs, DSS adopted a monetary guideline capping eligibility for EHR at 125 percent of the Federal poverty level on the theory that families that had income above that level should be able to plan for emergencies. The applicants sought to have the amendment declared invalid on the grounds that it was irrational and unconstitutional, and that, as an emergency regulation, it was illegally promulgated. On appeal, the court held that the amendment was unconstitutional and enjoined its enforcement. The court held that the amendment was arbitrary because it was not based on any empirical study, analysis, or report, and denied assistance to residents in need. The court deferred ruling on the applicants' request to certify the action as a class action.


OUTCOME: The court invalidated the DSS amendment that capped eligibility for Emergency Home Relief at 125 percent of the Federal poverty level and enjoined its enforcement. The court remanded the matter to the DSS to consider the applications.


HEADNOTES

Social Services - Emergency Assistance - Invalidity of Income Test for Eligibility for Emergency Home Relief

An amendment to the regulations governing the Emergency Home Relief program (EHR), which limits eligibility for one-time assistance payments to persons otherwise ineligible for welfare whose household incomes do not exceed 125% of the current Federal income official poverty line (18 NYCRR 370.3 [b] [2]), is invalidated and its enforcement is enjoined. The determination by defendant Department of Social Services that its bright-line income test meaningfully distinguishes between worthy and unworthy EHR recipients lacks any empirical basis and is thus impermissibly arbitrary. In addition to the absence of any factual underpinning, defendant's theory that EHR applicants with incomes exceeding the monetary guideline should have been able to pay rent arrears and other emergency needs is irrational on its face.

 

891 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Manocherian v. Lenox Hill Hosp.


Index No. 24431/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 982; 586 N.Y.S.2d 726; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 358



July 6, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, plaintiffs' motions for summary judgment are denied and defendants' cross motions are granted. Lenox Hill's cross motion seeking leave to amend is denied. As to plaintiffs' first and second causes of action in each of the complaints, defendants are entitled to a declaration that chapter 940 of the Laws of 1984 is constitutional and a declaration that Lenox Hill is the primary resident of the apartments in issue and is entitled to renewal leases. All the remaining causes of action in this consolidated action are dismissed. Lenox Hill is not entitled to recover attorneys' fees as sought in its counterclaims (see, Peck v Wolf, 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landlords sought summary judgment in its suit for a declaration that the enforcement of rent stabilization laws, § 5(a)(11) of the Emergency Tenant Protection Act and N.Y. City Admin. Code § 26-504(a)(1)(f), was an unconstitutional taking. Defendant tenant filed a cross-motion for summary judgment and a motion to amend its answer to plead estoppel.


OVERVIEW: The landlords leased apartments to the tenant, a not-for-profit hospital, for the use of the tenant's employees. The landlords sent notices of nonrenewal. A new law did not require a landlord to offer renewal to a tenant who was not using the apartment as his primary residence. To protect entities such as the tenant, the statutes in question were amended to state that the tenant would be the primary tenant. The primary tenant then had the right to sublet without the landlord's consent. The trial court denied the motion to amend because the amendment was without merit since estoppel was not a bar to the landlords' action. The enforcement of the new rules was not an unconstitutional physical or regulatory taking under the Fifth Amendment since the landlords voluntarily agreed to open their premises. The landlords were not compelled to become landlords, and they could sell the premises if they desired to be free of any tenancies. The public policy of curbing rent profiteering by landlords and providing housing provided a legitimate state interest favoring enforcement. The landlords also failed to establish that they were denied the economic viable use of the property.


OUTCOME: Leave to amend was denied. Otherwise, summary judgment was granted to the tenant. The enforcement of rent stabilization laws was neither a physical nor or a regulatory taking of the landlords' property.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Renewal Lease - Constitutionality of Statute Mandating Renewal Leases to Not-For-Profit Hospitals Which Sublet Apartments to Employees - Physical or Regulatory Taking

Plaintiffs, the owners of the subject apartment building, must offer renewal leases to defendant hospital for six rent-stabilized apartments occupied by hospital employees. Chapter 940 of the Laws of 1984, which amended the Rent Stabilization Law so as to require landlords to provide renewal leases to not-for-profit hospitals based on the primary residency status of the hospital's employee-subtenant, rather than on the primary residency status of the tenant of record (Administrative Code of City of NY § 26-504 [a] [1] [f]; § 26-511 [c] [12]), does not constitute an unconstitutional physical taking of property without just compensation. Plaintiffs have failed to show the loss in perpetuity of their reversionary interest in their property or that the statute requires them to refrain in perpetuity from terminating a tenancy. Since plaintiffs voluntarily opened their property to occupancy by others, they cannot assert a per se right to compensation based on their inability to exclude particular individuals. Furthermore, plaintiffs have not demonstrated that any of the avenues of changing the use of their property have been closed to them or that they are not in fact free to change the use of their land. In addition, the statute does not effect a regulatory taking, since it promotes the purposes of the Rent Stabilization Law, and does not deny them the full use of their property or a reasonable return on their investment.

 

892 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Dawson v. Higgins


Index No. 14558/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 811; 588 N.Y.S.2d 93; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 319



June 23, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended August 25, 1992.



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, after review of all the authorities and papers, I find as a matter of law that on each of their causes of action plaintiffs have failed to state a claim upon which relief may be granted, their complaint is dismissed and their motion for summary judgment is denied. Defendants' cross motion for summary judgment is granted to the extent of dismissing plaintiffs' complaint for failure to state a claim and to the extent that this court declares the New York City Rent and Rehabilitation Law (Administrative Code of City of NY) § 26-408 (b) (1), and New York City Rent and Eviction Regulations (9 NYCRR) § 2204.5 (a) constitutional under both the Federal and State Constitutions, and not violative of any of plaintiffs' rights herein brought in issue.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, property owner and her children, sought a judgment declaring that § 26-408(b)(1) of the Rent and Rehabilitation Law, New York, N.Y. Admin. Code, tit. 26, ch. 3, and § 2204.5(a) of the New York City Rent and Eviction Regulations, N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, parts 2200-2210, were unconstitutional. Plaintiffs and defendants, Commissioner of the New York State Division of Housing and Community and city, sought summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs owned and occupied different parts of a building which at the time of purchase contained units subject to rent control. Plaintiffs challenged the laws which prevented them from evicting, for family use of the property, two unrelated tenants each of whom had a rent-controlled unit which each had occupied for more than 20 years. The court held that nothing that the plaintiffs alleged rose to a violation of the Involuntary Servitude Clause of the Thirteenth Amendment. The indefinite tenancies did not amount to a physical taking of property. The protection for tenants of 20 years or more against removal to meet a landlord's desires for personal use did not amount to an impermissible over-regulation or "regulatory taking." The court found plaintiffs' arguments that the challenged provisions did not advance legitimate state interests because they were either superfluous, vague or too broad, to be entirely without merit. Inasmuch as the court found that there was no physical taking of plaintiffs' property, and the challenged provisions substantially advanced legitimate state interests, it found that there had been no violation of plaintiffs' due process rights.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed plaintiffs' complaint and denied their motion for summary judgment. Defendants' cross motion for summary judgment was granted to the extent of dismissing plaintiffs' complaint for failure to state a claim and to the extent that the court declared the New York City Rent and Rehabilitation Law and the New York City Rent and Eviction Regulations constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Recovery of Rent-Controlled Unit for Landlord's Personal Use - Protection of Long-Term Tenants from Eviction

New York City's tenant protection provisions, which prohibit an owner from recovering possession of a rent-controlled housing accommodation for personal or family use from a long-term tenant who has occupied the unit for more than 20 years (Administrative Code of City of New York § 26-408 [b] [1]; New York City Rent and Eviction Regulations [9 NYCRR] § 2204.5 [a]), substantially advance legitimate State interests in protecting long-term tenants who have roots in the community from the devastating impact of evictions and do not constitute an unconstitutional physical taking of private property without just compensation. The challenged provisions do not constitute an involuntary servitude by forcing owners to continue in the rental business. The owners are not being forced to subject their properties to a use not otherwise planned or intended in the first instance. Furthermore, the protection of long-term tenants against removal to meet a landlord's desires for personal use does not constitute an impermissible over-regulation or "regulatory taking" since owners are not deprived of the economically viable use of their properties.

 

893 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gertz


Indictment Nos. 1986/89 and 2965/90


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 762; 586 N.Y.S.2d 463; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 313



June 19, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Defendant's motion is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to set aside his plea agreement and sentence on the grounds that the statute that lead to a search of his business that discovered illegal drugs had been declared unconstitutional subsequent to his plea and sentencing. The state argued that defendant had entered into a binding plea agreement and had waived his right to appeal with full knowledge of the then pending constitutional challenge to the statute.


OVERVIEW: Defendant's business was searched under N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 415-a(5)(a), which authorized police inspection of junkyards and related businesses as part of their licensing requirements; during the search illegal drugs were found. Defendant's challenge to §415-a(5)(a)'s constitutionality was denied and the evidence was not suppressed. Defendant then entered a plea agreement on the drug charges and expressly waived his right to appeal with full knowledge that statute was being challenged in other cases. When the statute was ruled unconstitutional, defendant sought to set aside his plea and sentence. The court held that the plea was binding, especially as defendant was convicted on a statute other than the one declared unconstitutional. The court held that the fact that constitutional rights were implicated did not preclude enforcement of a waiver of the right to appeal or was a jurisdictional defect that barred a lawful waiver of appellate rights. To permit a plea to be withdrawn after the very uncertainty which served as the basis for the bargain was ultimately resolved in defendant's favor would render plea bargains, so vital to the criminal justice system, useless.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to set aside his plea agreement and sentence was denied.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Plea Bargaining - Enforcement of Agreement - Waiver of Right to Appeal

1. Where defendant, whose arrest was predicated on an administrative search of his business premises pursuant to Vehicle and Traffic Law § 415-a and the recovery of numerous stolen automobile parts, agreed to waive his right to appeal as part of a negotiated plea bargain at a time when defense counsel knew that the Court of Appeals was considering the constitutionality of section 415-a, defendant's intelligent and voluntary waiver must be enforced even though the statute was subsequently held unconstitutional, and his convictions will not be set aside. Only those jurisdictional issues which actually concern a defendant's actual guilt of the crimes charged or those which go to the very right of the State to hold a trial act as a bar to waiver. No such jurisdictional impediment exists in this case where the subdivision of the statute found unconstitutional (§ 415-a [5] [a]) served merely as the predicate to obtain the evidence against defendant but was not the section under which defendant was actually charged. Furthermore, defendant's convictions should not be vacated in the interests of justice since the unconstitutionality of the statute dealt solely with the right to search defendant's premises and did not address defendant's actual guilt of the crimes charged.

Crimes - Plea Bargaining - Enforcement of Agreement - Modification of Agreed upon Sentence

2. In a criminal proceeding in which defendant negotiated a plea bargain, the imposition of a lesser sentence than the one originally agreed upon resulting from the modification of defendant's sentence from consecutive to concurrent terms of probation as required by statute (Penal Law § 65.15 [1]), did not serve to breach the plea agreement so as to require vacatur of his conviction.

 

894 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Foy


DOCKET Nos. 91X090196, 91X041201


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


155 Misc. 2d 81; 587 N.Y.S.2d 111; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 365



June 18, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state moved to reduce the charge against defendant of criminal contempt in the second degree to attempted criminal contempt in the second degree in one docket, and to reduce the charge against defendant of aggravated harassment in the second degree to attempted aggravated harassment in the second degree in another docket. Defendant opposed the motion, and demanded a jury trial on all charges pending against him.


OVERVIEW: In two dockets, defendant was charged with various crimes including: criminal mischief, aggravated harassment, assault, and criminal contempt. With respect to the state's motion to reduce the charges of criminal contempt and aggravated harassment to attempts, the court ruled that the reduction was acceptable. In so ruling, the court rejected defendant's argument that attempted criminal contempt and attempted aggravated harassment were hypothetical crimes which could not be committed. The court explained that both criminal contempt and aggravated harassment were intentional crimes, and that both could be unsuccessfully attempted. The court also ruled that defendant's request for a jury trial was premature because the two dockets had not yet been consolidated, and no single charge carried a penalty of more than six months in prison. Consequently, defendant was not entitled to a jury trial pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 340.40(2). In reaching this conclusion, the court relied on a line of cases that found that a defendant charged with multiple petty offenses was not entitled to a jury trial where, as here, the charges stemmed from unrelated incidents.


OUTCOME: The court granted the state's motion to reduce the charge against defendant of criminal contempt to attempted criminal contempt, and to reduce the charge of aggravated harassment in the second degree to attempted aggravated harassment in the second degree. The court also denied defendant's request for a jury trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Aggravated Harassment - Criminal Contempt - Attempt

1. The charges of criminal contempt in the second degree (Penal Law § 215.50 [3]) and aggravated harassment in the second degree (Penal Law § 240.30 [1]) can properly be reduced to attempts to commit said crimes in a domestic violence prosecution pursuant to Penal Law § 110.10, which provides that it is no defense "that the crime charged to have been attempted was, under the attendant circumstances, factually or legally impossible of commission, if such crime could have been committed had the attendant circumstances been as [the defendant] believed them to be." The reduced charges do not constitute "hypothetical" crimes that are legally impossible of commission such as an attempt to commit a crime which does not include culpable intent as an element or where the proscribed result is unintended. In order to constitute an attempt, it must first be established that the defendant acted with a specific intent (Penal Law § 110.00). Both of the crimes which the People seek to reduce to attempts in this case are intentional crimes and neither crime can be committed by the mere attempt to do the proscribed act or bring about the proscribed result.

Crimes - Right to Jury Trial - Consolidation of Multiple Petty Offenses

2. The defendant in a domestic violence prosecution facing multiple petty offenses under two dockets arising from separate incidents which occurred on different dates is not entitled to a jury trial ( CPL 340.40 [2]) in the event that both dockets are consolidated for trial pursuant to CPL 200.20. Defendant is not facing more than six months in jail on either docket. It is only where the multiple offenses arise from a single act, transaction or occurrence that a jury trial might be required.

 

895 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Schenck


Docket No. 92V-1003


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, BUFFALO


154 Misc. 2d 937; 588 N.Y.S.2d 519; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 341



June 16, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended October 28, 1992.



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the court dismisses the accusatory instrument charging the defendant with violating Penal Law § 240.20 (7) on the basis that the statute is unconstitutionally vague.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged for disorderly conduct under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(7). He filed a motion to dismiss the accusatory instrument.


OVERVIEW: Defendant asserted the accusatory instrument was (1) facially insufficient; (2) violated his right to free speech and assembly under the U.S. Const. amend. I: and (3) violated his right to equal protection. He also asserted that N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(7) was unconstitutional on its face as being overly vague. The court determined (1) that the information containing references to affidavits of persons with knowledge of the acts was adequate to satisfy the requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 100.15 and 100.40; (2) that N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(7) was not unconstitutionally applied to the defendant because a regulation of expressive conduct was proper when it was not an attempt to suppress the communication; and (3) that the defendant was treated unequally as compared to others because they were limiting their action to speech and defendant was involved in demonstrative acts. The court dismissed the information because it determined that N.Y. Penal Law §240.20(7) was unconstitutionally vague because the statute did not sufficiently define the prohibited conduct of creating a physically offensive condition so as to give notice as to what was proscribed by the statute.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the accusatory instrument.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Disorderly Conduct - Thrusting Aborted Fetus in Faces of Bystanders - Constitutionality of Statute Proscribing Creation of "Physically Offensive Condition"

An information charging defendant with disorderly conduct (Penal Law § 240.20 [7]) for "holding up an apparent aborted fetus" at a public demonstration and the supporting deposition stating that defendant placed what "he said to be a live fetus" "close" to the faces of bystanders satisfy the pleading requirements of CPL 100.15 and 100.40 as to facial sufficiency. The disorderly conduct charge is not unconstitutionally applied in this case as to abridge defendant's rights of free speech and assembly since the statute does attempt to restrict the substance of the speech, but instead attempts to protect the health, safety or well-being of the public from a form of communication that may violate those interests; nor was defendant unconstitutionally singled out and denied equal protection of the law since other persons who were not arrested used methods protected by the First Amendment in merely voicing their opinions and distributing literature. However, the disorderly conduct charge must be dismissed since Penal Law § 240.20 (7), which proscribes creating "a hazardous or physically offensive condition by any act which serves no legitimate purpose" with "intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm", is unconstitutionally vague on its face; the statute does not sufficiently define the prohibited conduct of creating a "physically offensive condition" so as to give notice to ordinary intelligent people as to what is proscribed by the statute.

 

896 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Mancuso v. Levitt


Index No. 31515/87


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 252; 585 N.Y.S.2d 164; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 254



May 15, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended January 27, 1993.
Appeal dismissed by, Subsequent appeal at, Decision reached on appeal by Mancuso v. Levitt, 201 A.D.2d 386, 607 N.Y.S.2d 353, 1994 N.Y. App. Div. LEXIS 1359 (N.Y. App. Div. 1st Dep't, 1994)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, firefighters and their association, sought a declaration that N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law §§50-a and 50(7) were unconstitutional and moved for summary judgment. Sections 50-a and 50(7) set up a review procedure for challenging answers to civil service examinations and limited court review to issues of whether procedures were followed. Defendants, the city and its department of personnel's director, cross-moved for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs' action was commenced after two firefighters failed a civil service exam. They alleged that they could not challenge the test answers due to the operation of §§ 50(7) and 50-a. Plaintiffs argued that §§50-a and 50(7) were unconstitutional because they violated the constitutional guarantee of competitive examination under N.Y. Const. art. V, § 6, and denied civil service employees equal protection and due process. Defendants argued that the action was time-barred. The court held that because an article 78 proceeding was not the appropriate method to challenge the constitutionality of a legislative enactment, plaintiffs' attempt to strike §§ 50(7) and 50-a as being unconstitutional was not subject to the four-month time bar established for the proceedings. The court held that the procedures set forth in § 50-a did not meet the merit and fitness requirement of the New York Constitution because it failed to give candidates, who under the proposed answer key correctly answered a question, notice that the answer was being changed. The court directed that plaintiffs be permitted to show that their test answers were as good or better than the answer key ultimately chosen.


OUTCOME: The court held that one of the challenged sections of the law was unconstitutional and directed that a referee be appointed to give plaintiffs the opportunity to show that the answers they selected on the civil service exam were as good or better than the answer key ultimately used to grade their exams.


HEADNOTES

Limitation of Actions - Four-Month Statute of Limitations - Review Procedures for Challenging Key Answers to New York City Civil Service Examinations

1. The action by plaintiffs, commenced December 22, 1987, challenging the constitutionality of the review procedures for protesting key answers to New York City civil service examinations (Civil Service Law §§ 50-a, 50 [7]), in connection with the 1986 civil service examination for the position of fire department lieutenant and the resulting final eligible list promulgated on August 5, 1987, is not subject to the four-month time bar established for CPLR article 78 proceedings ( CPLR 217). While this action arises out of specific actions taken by the Test Validation Board (TVB) in rejecting answers which had initially been designated as correct, the underlying challenge is to the constitutionality of the review procedures and an article 78 proceeding is not the appropriate method to challenge the constitutionality of a legislative enactment. However, plaintiffs' request for the creation of a special eligible list in the event they can establish that their answers were equally correct to ones chosen by the TVB is governed by the four-month limitations period, running from date subsequent to the promulgation of the eligible list when they learned of the changes made by the TVB. Under the circumstances, there is an issue of fact that must be decided by a Referee as to the date upon which plaintiffs were permitted to review the final key answers and thereby became aggrieved by the actions of the TVB.

Civil Service - Examinations - Constitutionality of Review Procedures for Challenging Key Answers to New York City Civil Service Examinations - Laches - Necessary Parties

2. The action by plaintiffs, commenced December 22, 1987, challenging the constitutionality of the review procedures for protesting key answers to New York City civil service examinations, in connection with the 1986 civil service examination for the position of fire department lieutenant, should not be dismissed on the ground of laches in the absence of any showing of prejudice by the City, which, if it believed that passage of time was affecting the reliability of the examination, could have moved for summary judgment or served a demand on plaintiffs to prosecute the action. In addition, the action should not be dismissed for failure to join necessary parties in view of the limited relief requested by plaintiffs in seeking the creation of a special eligible list if they can establish that their answers were equally correct as the key answers.

Civil Service - Examinations - Constitutionality of Review Procedures for Challenging Key Answers to New York City Civil Service Examinations

3. Civil Service Law § 50-a, which establishes the review procedures for challenging key answers to New York City civil service examinations, is unconstitutional as violative of the merit and fitness requirement (NY Const, art V, § 6) since the review procedures fail to give candidates who, under the proposed answer key correctly answered a question, notice that the Test Validation Board (TVB) is changing an answer. The failure to give notice deprives aggrieved candidates of an opportunity to contest the changes before a final answer key is established. The inability to contest the changes at the administrative level coupled with the circumscribed judicial review under Civil Service Law § 50 (7), pursuant to which review is limited to whether established procedures have been followed and aggrieved candidates are precluded from challenging the correctness of the final answers, renders section 50-a unconstitutional since the procedures can result in civil service determinations that are not made in accordance with merit and fitness. Furthermore, since plaintiffs were not given an opportunity to show why the answers they selected on the 1986 civil service examination for fire department lieutenant were as good or better than the answer key ultimately chosen by the TVB, Civil Service Law § 50 (7) must be deemed unconstitutional as applied to the facts of this case.

 

897 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Triphammer Dev. Co. v. Bd. of Trs.


Tompkins County Index No. 92-251; Tompkins County RJI No. 92-0161M


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, TOMPKINS COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 369; 585 N.Y.S.2d 160; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 265



May 7, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended Spetember 17, 1992.



DISPOSITION: The petitioner is entitled to a judgment directing the village to issue the permit and declaring the provisions of section 504.01 ultra vires and void which require the satisfaction of extraneous debts as a condition precedent to the issuance of a building permit.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner development company sought a judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 that respondent village unlawfully refused to issue a building permit and asserted that the section of the zoning law relied on by the village was void as beyond the delegated zoning powers of the municipality, unconstitutional on its face, and arbitrary and capricious.


OVERVIEW: The company's application for a building permit was denied under a local zoning law that refused permits to any owner who had not paid in full certain debts or charges related to the property involved in the application. The village and the company had a longstanding dispute over charges the village claimed were due for work it had done in the area of the company's property. The permit was denied because of these charges. The company filed a petition asserting that the village had exceeded the powers delegated to it under state law when it enacted the zoning law. The court agreed and held that the law was ultra vires and void. The court first found that the denial of the permit was motivated by the desire of the village to obtain payment on the claim arising out of the unrelated transaction and that this debt had no connection with the use of the property or with any zoning function delegated to the village under N.Y. Village Law §§ 7-700, 7-704. The court concluded that the zoning law, to the extent it required the denial of permits based on an extraneous quarrel with the company, was inconsistent with state law because it invoked powers not delegated by the Village Law.


OUTCOME: The court granted the company a judgment directing the village to issue a permit and declaring the provisions of the ordinance at issue ultra vires and void.


HEADNOTES

Administrative Law - Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies

1. In a CPLR article 78 proceeding to annul a determination of respondent village denying petitioner a building permit to renovate space within petitioner's existing shopping mall, petitioner is not required to exhaust administrative remedies under the local zoning law before pursuing its claim that respondent lacks any power to condition the issuance of a building permit upon prior payment of a claim which is unrelated to accepted zoning factors and criteria affecting the use of such property. Petitioner should not be compelled to seek administrative relief from a determination which, if petitioner's claim is correct, is void ab initio. 

Municipal Corporations - Zoning - Authority of Village to Condition Grant of Permit upon Payment of Extraneous Debt

2. A village zoning law provision which requires a property owner to satisfy extraneous debts as a condition precedent to the issuance of a building permit is ultra vires and void. Accordingly, petitioner, whose application for a building permit to renovate space in its existing shopping mall was denied pursuant to that zoning law provision, based upon petitioner's failure to satisfy respondent village's pending claim for reimbursement of construction costs incurred to improve roadways located on petitioner's property, is entitled to judgment directing respondent to issue the permit. The Village Law contains no express or implied grant of power to impose zoning conditions which are based upon extraneous disputes with owners of property, and imposition of such conditions by the village zoning law is inconsistent with the scheme of general State law because it invokes powers not delegated by the Village Law. Moreover, the village zoning law provision does not lawfully supersede the Village Law insofar as the latter omits any express or implied power to so condition the granting of permits, since respondent did not invoke its power of supersession under Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 (1) (ii) (e) (3) and did not comply with Municipal Home Rule Law § 22 (1).

 

898 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Board of Educ. v. Ramapo Teachers' Ass'n


INDEX NO. 931/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ROCKLAND COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 834; 586 N.Y.S.2d 852; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 273



May 1, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the motion to stay arbitration is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent teachers' association demanded arbitration over whether petitioner board of education could be compelled to reinstate its practice of paying salaries in which the first check of the beginning of the school year included a sum for services not yet performed. Board of education filed a request to stay arbitration and asserted that the former practice violated N.Y. Const. art. VIII, § 1 and N.Y. Educ. Law § 3015.


OVERVIEW: Change in practice by board of education did not affect the total salary paid to teachers, but only the timing of payments. The court rejected board of education's argument that the practice would necessarily violate the constitutional prohibition against gifts of public monies or the loaning of any money in aid of any individual. The court held that because the teachers were legally obligated under their employment contracts to perform their services in the future and would have performed part of the expected service at the time of receiving their first check, the prepayment of a fraction of their salary did not constitute a gift and that the teachers' good-faith obligation to perform the contract was sufficient consideration to support the prepayment of the part of the salary. However, the court found that the matter could not be subjected to arbitration because § 3015 prohibited the practice and represented a strong public policy that was not arbitrable. The court stated that the underlying purpose of the law was to avoid the problems that may arise on the death, retirement, resignation, or dismissal of a teacher during a period when the teacher has been prepaid.


OUTCOME: The court granted the board of education's petition for a stay of arbitration over the issue of discontinuing the practice of prepaying a portion of teachers' salary.


HEADNOTES

Arbitration - Matters Arbitrable - Prepayment of Teacher Salaries - No Arbitration on Public Policy Grounds

Public policy forbids arbitration of the question whether petitioner school district should be compelled to reinstate its prior practice of prepaying teacher salaries for services not yet rendered in the teachers' first paychecks in September. Even though an award by an arbitrator directing prepayment for services not yet rendered would not necessarily violate the constitutional prohibition against gifts of public moneys (NY Const, art VIII, § 1), inasmuch as the implicit obligation to perform coupled with the contractual promise to be in attendance over the life span of the agreement provides sufficient consideration to support the prepayment of part of a teacher's salary, any arbitration award directing prepayment of teacher salaries would violate the explicit statutory prohibition against such practice (Education Law § 3015 [3]). The controversy involves a matter of substance, not mere procedural safeguards, and public policy considerations, embodied in the statute, prohibit, "in an absolute sense", the particular matter posed for arbitration from being decided against petitioner. Accordingly, petitioner's motion to stay arbitration is granted.

 

899 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Alfonso v. Fernandez


Index No. 8785/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


151 Misc. 2d 899; 584 N.Y.S.2d 406; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 163



April 23, 1992, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner parents brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78 proceeding in which they challenged, on statutory and constitutional grounds, respondent board of education's program to distribute condoms to students in the public high schools. The parents sought declaratory and injunctive relief.


OVERVIEW: The parents, whose children were unemancipated minors attending New York City public high schools, objected on religious grounds to the distribution of condoms in the schools as part of an AIDS education program. The court held that the program was not a "health service" under N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2504 and, therefore, was not prohibited by that statute without parental consent. The court found no violation of First Amendment, U.S. Const. amend. I, rights because the school program was voluntary, was neutral on its face, and was supported by a compelling state interest. Because students were not compelled to accept the condoms, there was no interference with their free exercise of religion. The court found only an incidental effect on their ability to practice religion because the program had no tendency to coerce individuals to act contrary to their religious beliefs.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the proceeding, finding the challenged policy to be lawful.

 

900 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Fallon v. New York State Div. of Housing & Community Renewal


INDEX NO. 3236/88


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 340; 585 N.Y.S.2d 293; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 248



April 16, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: In accordance with the foregoing, the motion by plaintiffs is denied. The cross motion by defendants Jose Diaz, Teddy Giatis and Eleni Giatis and cross motion of DHCR for summary judgment dismissing the complaint are granted and it is declared that section 26-511 (c) (9) (b) of the Rent Stabilization Law as applied to the plaintiffs, rent-stabilized tenants occupying garden apartments converted into individual houses, is constitutional.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs sought, before the Supreme Court of New York, Queens County, to have § 26-511(c)(9)(b) of the New York Rent Stabilization Law ruled violative of the equal protection and due process clauses of the state constitution and more particularly, N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 6 and 11.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, tenants of certain garden apartments, sought summary judgment declaring that § 26-511(c)(9) (b) of the New York Rent Stabilization Law was violative of the equal protection and due process clauses of the state constitution and more particularly, N.Y. Const. art. I, §§ 6 and 11. Defendants, owners of the individual units, and the Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR), cross-moved for summary judgment dismissing the complaint and for judgment declaring § 26-511(c)(9)(b) to be constitutional. The court held that motion by plaintiffs was denied. The cross motion by defendants and DHCR for summary judgment dismissing the complaint were granted and it was declared that § 26-511 (c) (9) (b) of the Rent Stabilization Law as applied to plaintiffs was constitutional. Had the legislature wished to expand the exemption from owner-occupancy evictions to rent-stabilized tenants occupying garden apartments converted into individual houses, it could easily have done so. It instead chose not to do so, and the court could not usurp the responsibility and obligation, which reposes solely with the legislature.


OUTCOME: The court denied plaintiffs' motion to have the New York Rent Stabilization Law ruled violative of the equal protection and due process clauses of the state constitution because the legislature had declined to expand exemption from owner-occupancy evictions to rent-stabilized tenants occupying garden apartments converted into individual houses.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant - Rent Regulation - Garden Apartment Complexes Converted to Individual Houses - Constitutionality of Statute Permitting Nonrenewal of Lease on Owner Occupancy Grounds

Rent Stabilization Law § 26-511 (c) (9) (b) (Administrative Code of City of New York, tit 26, ch 4) which permits the nonrenewal of leases of rent-stabilized tenants in a garden apartment complex on the ground of personal use occupancy where the complex is converted into individual units, each as a one, two or four-family house, and then sold to individuals, does not deprive the tenants of equal protection of the laws on the ground that General Business Law § 352-eeee (2) (c) (ii) and Rent Stabilization Code (9 NYCRR) § 2524.4 (a) (1) prohibit the eviction on owner occupancy grounds of rent-stabilized tenants of buildings that have been converted pursuant to noneviction plans into cooperative or condominium ownership. In view of the magnitude of the potential displacement of rent-stabilized tenants from buildings converted to cooperative or condominium ownership during the 1980's the Legislature could have rationally concluded that the possibility of undue harm to that class of rent-stabilized tenants was greater than for all other rent-stabilized tenants and that it warranted a special exemption from the owner-occupancy provisions of section 26-511 (c) (9) (b). In contrast, it is conceivable that the Legislature could have reasonably concluded that the physical alteration of garden apartments into individual houses did not pose a threat to the public interest and general welfare in the same magnitude as the threat posed to stabilized tenancies by the steady increase of cooperative and condominium conversions. Accordingly, section 26-511 (c) (9) (b), as applied to plaintiffs, rent-stabilized tenants occupying garden apartments converted into individual houses, is constitutional.

 

901 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bachchan v. India Abroad Publications, Inc.


Index No. 28692/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 228; 585 N.Y.S.2d 661; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 231; 20 Media L. Rep. 1051



April 13, 1992, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended September 30, 1992



DISPOSITION: For the above-stated reasons, the motion for summary judgment in lieu of complaint is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff private figure sought to enforce its English judgment against defendant operator for libel by filing a motion for summary judgment in lieu of a complaint.


OVERVIEW: A Swedish daily newspaper reported that Swiss authorities had frozen a private figure's account into which an arms company had deposited commissions. A New York operator of a news service transmitted the wire service story to India and printed and distributed the story in England and New York. The private figure was awarded damages and attorney's fees in his libel action against the operator. The private figure sought to enforce the judgment in New York by motion for summary judgment in lieu of a complaint. The court held that enforcement of the English judgment violated U.S. Const. amend. I. The court held that the English court unconstitutionally and with chilling effect placed the burden of proving truth upon the media defendants who published speech of public concern. The court found that the English courts did not require the private figure to prove falsity or that the operator was at fault in any degree in disseminating another news company's press report.


OUTCOME: The court denied the private figure's motion for summary judgment and refused to enforce the foreign judgment against the operator.


HEADNOTES

Judgments - Foreign Judgment - Enforcement of English Libel Judgment

An English libel judgment obtained by plaintiff, an Indian national, based upon a wire service story transmitted by defendant regarding plaintiff's involvement in an international scandal which touched major players in Indian politics, is not entitled to enforcement in New York pursuant to CPLR 5304 on constitutional grounds because English libel law, contrary to constitutional requirements in this country, places the burden of proving truth upon media defendants which publish speech of public concern. Plaintiff's failure to prove falsity in the English libel action renders the judgment unenforceable in this State. In addition, enforcement of the English judgment would also violate the First Amendment since plaintiff was not required to and did not meet the "less forbidding" constitutional requirement that a private figure show that a media defendant, which published a matter arguably within the sphere of legitimate public concern, acted in a grossly irresponsible manner without due consideration for the standards of information gathering and dissemination ordinarily followed by responsible parties.

 

902 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Medical Soc'y of State v. Sobol


(RJI No. 01-91-ST-2970)


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 815; 583 N.Y.S.2d 145; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 121



April 10, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:   [**1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is granted. Defendant's cross motion for summary judgment is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, a medical society and others, sought summary judgment and compensation in their declaratory judgment action against defendants, Commissioner of the Department of Education of the State of New York and others, in which plaintiffs' contended that N.Y. Educ. Law § 6524, as amended by 1990 N.Y. Laws ch. 190, § 280, was unconstitutional. Defendants also sought summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs filed a declaratory judgment action in which they sought to have the amendment to § 6524 declared unconstitutional. Both parties filed motions for summary judgment. In granting plaintiff's motion and denying defendant's, the court found that the physicians had a constitutionally protected property interest in their registrations. The court determined that defendant's elimination of the third year of registration effectively rendered the licensed physicians unable to practice without paying and registering again, which was a taking without just compensation. The court declared 1990 N.Y. Laws ch. 190, § 280 void and unconstitutional to the extent it affected a taking of the physicians' property without compensation and concluded that it changed the physicians' terms of registration by reducing the state's obligation by a year, which substantially impaired the purpose of registration certificates. The court stated the process would be meaningless if the state could invalidate registration certificates at will. The court found that the state did not have a reasonable and appropriate reason to revoke the registrations. The court directed defendants to refund the renewal fees.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied defendants' cross motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Due Process of Law - Retroactive Change in Registration Period for Licensed Physicians

1. Laws of 1990 (ch 190, § 280), which changed the registration fee periods for licensed physicians from a triennial to a biennial basis, is unconstitutional and void as retroactively applied to the 1989 triennial registration ending on December 31, 1991 since the State's elimination of the third prepaid year in 1991, thereby rendering licensed physicians unable to practice in 1991 unless they paid and registered again for that year, constituted a taking of property without due process and just compensation. Where the Department of Education issues registration certificates for a fee which are supposed to be valid until the end of a set registration period (Education Law §§ 6524, 6502 [1]), the State creates a constitutionally protected interest in the term of the registration. A physician has a legitimate claim of entitlement in the validity of the registration until the stated expiration. Physicians had a right to practice according to their registrations in 1991, and this right cannot be arbitrarily taken away, regardless of whether physicians could ransom their right to practice by paying additional registration fees.

Constitutional Law - Contract Clause - Retroactive Change in Registration Period for Licensed Physicians

2. Laws of 1990 (ch 190, § 280), which changed the registration fee periods for licensed physicians from a triennial to a biennial basis, is unconstitutional under the Contract Clause (US Const, art I, § 10, cl [1]) as retroactively applied to the 1989 triennial registration ending on December 31, 1989 since the reduction of the 1989 registration period by one year, thereby rendering licensed physicians unable to practice in 1991 unless they paid and registered again for that year, substantially impaired the rights of valid registration holders granted by the registration contract with the State. The statutory registration process (Education Law §§ 6524, 6502 [1]) gives rise to a contractual relation between the State and licensed physicians. In this case, the measures taken by the State are not so reasonable and so appropriate to advance the State's legitimate interest in investigating and policing medical misconduct as to warrant the impairment of the State's contractual obligation to physicians.

 

903 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. DiLorenzo


DOCKET Nos. 91X004015, 91X004016


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 1021; 585 N.Y.S.2d 670; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 165



March 31, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, this court finds that the defendants failed to establish selective prosecution.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants charged with multiple petty offenses moved for a jury trial pursuant to U.S. Const., amend. VI, for severance, for court-ordered discovery, for an order disqualifying the City of New York from prosecuting the matter, and for an evidentiary hearing on a claim of selective prosecution.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charged with multiple petty offenses, each separately carrying a penalty of less than six months' incarceration, but in the aggregate punishable by a potential penalty in excess of six months. They moved for a jury trial pursuant to U.S. Const., amend. VI. Denying their motion, the court held that defendants were entitled a non-jury trial, but that the maximum aggregate sentence was limited to six months. The court denied defendants' motion for severance, but it granted their motion for court-ordered discovery. The court further denied defendants' request for an order disqualifying the City of New York from prosecuting the matter because of a potential shared civil liability between the parties. The court held that the issue in the civil action was substantially dissimilar from the issues presented in the criminal matter. Finally, the court denied defendants' motion for an evidentiary hearing on the issue of selective prosecution.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motions for a jury trial, for severance, for an order disqualifying the City of New York from prosecuting them for multiple petty offenses, and for an evidentiary hearing on a claim of selective prosecution. The court granted defendants' motion for court-ordered discovery.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Right to Jury Trial - Multiple Petty Offenses Punishable by Aggregate Sentence Exceeding Six Months - Violations of Administrative Code of City of New York

1. Where defendant is charged with multiple offenses under the Administrative Code of the City of New York, each carrying a penalty of less than six months' incarceration but in the aggregate punishable by a potential penalty in excess of six months, the defendant's trial must be a nonjury trial, and the maximum aggregate sentence shall not exceed six months. CPL 340.40, which requires, in New York City, a single-Judge nonjury trial where an information charges a misdemeanor for which the authorized term of imprisonment is not more than six months, must be interpreted to require a single-Judge trial for multiple offenses each of which carries a penalty of not more than six months' incarceration. Moreover, in multiple petty count cases, the right to a jury trial requires a trial by jury only where a sentence of more than six months is imposed; it is the exercise of the court's discretion to impose sentences in the aggregate exceeding six months, and not the fact that such discretion exists, which triggers a right to a jury trial. Accordingly, since imposition of a sentence in the aggregate exceeding six months would trigger the right to a jury trial, but CPL 340.40 requires a nonjury trial for multiple petty offenses, defendant here must receive a nonjury trial and the maximum aggregate sentence imposed cannot exceed six months.

Crimes - Right to Jury Trial - What Constitutes "Serious" Offense

2. Defendant, who is charged with multiple offenses under the Administrative Code of the City of New York, is not entitled to a jury trial on the ground that his exposure to a potential fine of $ 5,000 together with a six-month potential prison sentence renders the offenses charged "serious" for purposes of attachment of the constitutional right to trial by jury. Where the maximum authorized prison term does not exceed six months, a presumption exists that the Legislature viewed the offense as petty. Where the additional penalty is a fine, so long as it is below the $ 5,000 level, the statutory penalties are not so severe as to deem the offense "serious" for Sixth Amendment purposes.

Crimes - Selective Prosecution

3. Defendants charged with four counts of violations of the Administrative Code of the City of New York have failed to establish that they are being selectively prosecuted since they have not demonstrated a reasonable probability of success in proving that the law was not applied to others similarly situated and that selective application of the law was deliberately based upon an impermissible standard such as race, religion or some other arbitrary classification.

 

904 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Vatore v. Commissioner of Consumer Affairs


INDEX NO. 3438/92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


154 Misc. 2d 149; 584 N.Y.S.2d 728; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 186



March 30, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the court grants defendant's cross motion to dismiss the complaint for failure to state a cause of action.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant city filed a motion to dismiss plaintiff cigarette machine vendors' declaratory judgment action to invalidate New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 17-177, which restricted the distribution of certain tobacco products through the location of cigarette vending machines, on that ground that it failed to state a cause of action.


OVERVIEW: The cigarette machine vendors contended that § 17-177 seriously interfered with their business activities because it limited the sale of cigarettes from vending machines to taverns. In support of their claim that § 17-177 was unconstitutional, the vendors claimed that it was preempted by state law and was void for vagueness. The city, on the other hand, contended that § 17-177 was a valid exercise of police power to protect the health of children and adolescents. The court granted the city's motion to dismiss the vendor's action. The court disagreed with the vendors' claim that, by the enactment of four state statutes, the state enacted a comprehensive scheme to regulate tobacco products. In so ruling, the court stated that the mere fact that § 17-177 concerned the same area of regulation as the state statutes did not render the city ordinance invalid. Further, court stated that any argument that § 17-177 was preempted by state law because it prohibited what state law permitted was without merit. The court also held that § 17-177 was not void for vagueness. Indeed, the definition of "tavern" was clear and unambiguous.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's motion to dismiss the cigarette machine vendors' declaratory judgment action to invalidate a city ordinance that restricted the distribution of certain tobacco products through the location of cigarette vending machines.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Cigarette Vending Machines

A local law of the City of New York which prohibits the sale and distribution of tobacco products through vending machines except in a tavern (Administrative Code of City of New York § 17-177) is a valid exercise of the police power designed to protect the City's minor citizens from the documented health hazards of smoking. The mere existence of State statutes relating to cigarette sales and smoking (Tax Law § 480-a; General Business Law § 399-e; Penal Law § 260.20; Public Health Law § 1399-n et seq.) does not render the local law invalid under the preemption doctrine as being inconsistent with a comprehensive State scheme of regulation since the local law is separate and dramatically different from the purposes of the State statutes. Nor does the local law either prohibit conduct which the State law expressly or impliedly permits or impose additional restrictions on rights granted by State law. Furthermore, the portions of the ordinance which are applicable solely to taverns does not preempt the Alcoholic Beverage Control Law since the local law does not in any way regulate the sale, distribution or consumption of alcoholic beverages. Moreover, the local law is precise and detailed and is thus not void for vagueness. Lastly, plaintiffs lack standing to challenge the law on the grounds that its enforcement will result in decreased fees and State tax revenue from cigarette vending machines.

 

905 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schulz v. State


Index No. 866-92


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


151 Misc. 2d 594; 582 N.Y.S.2d 355; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 77



March 12, 1992, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, taxpayers, and defendants, State of New York and officials, both sought summary judgment in a constitutional challenge to N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law §§ 3231-3249, N.Y. Tax Law § 1148, N.Y. Finance Law § 92-r, which established a public corporation to provide assistance to local governments through the issuance and sale of bonds, under N.Y. Const. art. VII, §§ 11, 8, art. X, § 5, and to N.Y. Finance Law § 123-b(1).


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers sought a declaratory judgment declaring a statutory scheme to create the New York Local Government Assistance Corporation (LGAC), which would have provided assistance payments to local governments through the issuance and sale of public bonds, unconstitutional and further declaring unconstitutional the portion of N.Y. Finance Law art. 7A, § 123-b(1) which denied standing to a citizen-taxpayer to challenge revenue measures. The court granted summary judgment in favor of defendants, holding the scheme constitutional, upholding § 123-b(1), and dismissing the taxpayers' action. The court held that the taxpayers lacked standing because the exception contained in § 123-b(1) was a valid expression of legislative policy. The court further held that the statutory structure and modus operandi establishing LGAC was constitutional because it did not create a debt of the state in violation of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 11, nor give or lend credit of the state in violation of art. VII, § 8, nor require acceptance of liability in violation of art. X, § 5. Finally, the court held that the action was barred by laches because the bonds had already been issued and sold.


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment for the defendants, denied summary judgment to the taxpayers, and dismissed the complaint, holding that both the scheme to create a public corporation to issue and sell bonds for the purpose of providing assistance to local governments and the law denying standing to taxpayers challenging revenue measures were constitutional.

 

906 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. O'Leary


2711


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, OSWEGO


153 Misc. 2d 641; 583 N.Y.S.2d 881; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 114



February 28, 1992, Decided  
February 28, 1992, Entered



DISPOSITION:  [**1] The motions of the defendant therefore are denied and the matter is set for trial on the 5th day of May 1992.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Criminal defendant, charged with committing disorderly conduct, moved to dismiss charges on the grounds that disorderly conduct statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20, violated N.Y. Const. art. I § 8 and U.S. Const. amend. I.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff filed a complaint charging criminal defendant with disorderly conduct, a violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20. Plaintiff alleged that defendant had yelled a profanity outside a public place and then kicked a police car. Defendant, prior to trial, filed a motion to dismiss the charges on the grounds that § 240.20 was unconstitutional as applied, it being violative of N.Y. Const. art. I § 8 and U.S. Const. amend. I. Defendant cited in support the state's highest court's ruling that the similarly worded harassment statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 240.25, was unconstitutional. Trial court denied defendant's motion, noting that protected speech may still be regulated in terms of time, place, and manner, and that in defendant's case it was alleged that he had yelled while in a public place and kicked a police car. Under those circumstances, he could be tried for his conduct.


OUTCOME: Motion to dismiss denied; § 240.20 is not unconstitutional on its face or as applied, since it regulates how and when speech may be presented, not the content of that speech.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Disorderly Conduct - Constitutionality of Proscription of Abusive or Obscene Language or Gesture

1. Penal Law § 240.20 (3), which provides that a person is guilty of disorderly conduct when, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoy- ance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, in a public place he uses abusive or obscene language, or makes an obscene gesture, is not unconstitutional on its face. Implicit in the statute is a limiting or saving construction that a breach of the peace must be intended to occur or likely to occur as a result of the actions of the defendant, which comports with constitutional guidelines and logically applies only to fighting words or words that would evoke a breach of the peace; thus, the statute passes constitutional muster.

Crimes - Disorderly Conduct - Constitutionality of Statutory Proscription of Creation of Hazardous or Physically Offensive Condition

2. Penal Law § 240.20 (7), which provides that a person is guilty of disorderly conduct when, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoy- ance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof, he creates a hazardous or physically offensive condition by any act which serves no legitimate purpose, is constitutional on its face.

 

907 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Livery Owners Coalition v. State Ins. Fund


2686, INDEX NUMBER 33528/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 905; 581 N.Y.S.2d 577; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 90



February 28, 1992, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, livery owners coalition and independent livery owners, filed a motion for an order enjoining defendants, state insurance fund (fund) and workers compensation board (board), from enforcing Laws of 1986, ch. 903, 1986 N.Y. Laws (statute), and declaring it unconstitutional. The fund and the board sought an order dismissing the complaint and declaring the statute constitutional.


OVERVIEW: The fund and the board interpreted the ch. 903 as defining an employer-employee relationship between the livery car base owners and the livery car owner operators for the purposes of workers' compensation coverage. The livery owners coalition and the individual livery owners claimed that the statute, which provided that the livery car base owners had to pay workers' compensation premiums on behalf of the independent owner-operators, was unconstitutional. The coalition and owners sought injunctive relief. The fund and the board sought an order dismissing their complaint and declaring the statute constitutional. The court denied the coalition and owners injunctive relief, dismissed their complaint, and declared the statute constitutional on its face. The court found that the fund and board's interpretation of the statute furthered the goal of expanding workers' compensation coverage and made the assessment and collection of premiums more efficient. According to the court, the statute and the fund and board's interpretation of the statute had a rational basis.


OUTCOME: The court denied the coalition and owners' motion for injunctive relief and granted the application of the fund and board for an order dismissing the complaint and declaring the statute constitutional on its face.

 

908 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bianco


Indictment No. 3237


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, CAYUGA COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 509; 582 N.Y.S.2d 622; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 93



February 21, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: By reason of the foregoing, the motion brought on behalf of the defendant under date of March 28, 1991 to vacate the judgment of conviction entered against him in this court on May 6, 1986 will be granted, that judgment of conviction will be vacated, and a new trial will be ordered ( CPL 440.10 [4]).


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion with the court to vacate a judgment that convicted him of a crime.


OVERVIEW: Following his conviction, defendant filed a motion with the court seeking to have his conviction vacated on the ground that the prosecution deprived him of discoverable impeachment material that could have been used during his criminal trial. The court granted the motion to vacate the conviction and ordered a new trial. The court found that defendant was not required under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.10 (1)(f) to demonstrate an actual prejudice occurred by soliciting testimony from jurors because prejudice could be readily ascertained by the court. The court held that the proper standard of review was whether there was a reasonable possibility that such a failure to disclose the material contributed to the verdict. The court concluded that there was little doubt as to whether the undisclosed material in question contributed to defendant's conviction where the undisclosed material could have been used by defendant to impeach a witness who testified that defendant had admitted that he had committed the crime. The court also noted the undisclosed material could have been used by defendant to impeach witnesses who identified defendant as the perpetrator of the crime.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to vacate a judgment that convicted him of a crime. The court ordered a new trial.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Vacatur of Judgment of Conviction - Rosario Claim - "Harmless Error" Analysis

The rule of People v Jackson (78 NY2d 638), which, in a postconviction CPL article 440 motion based upon the deprivation of Rosario material at trial, requires "harmless error" analysis to determine whether there is a "reasonable possibility" that the failure to disclose the Rosario material contributed to the guilty verdict, does not require the application of a subjective test for actual prejudice, whereby former jurors would be asked what they would have done had they known of the undisclosed evidence. The nature of the evidence from an "inquiry" of the actual jurors would be patently unseemly, unreliable, often unavailable, and would be inconsistent with the strong public policy favoring the confidentiality and sanctity of jury deliberations in criminal matters.
