Rather, the court must make a detached and reasoned assessment of the cumulative effect of any Rosario violations on the verdict based on the reasonable reaction to the absent evidence from the viewpoint of the hypothetical fair-minded "deliberative" juror. Accordingly, in this case, the undisclosed evidence that the witness who testified as to an incriminating statement made by defendant had said nothing of defendant's admission during prior police/prosecutor interviews, combined with the undisclosed evidence of the identifying witness's prior inconsistent description, so severely prejudiced defendant as to require a new trial ( CPL 440.10 [4]).

 

909 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Orzechowski v. Perales


Index No. 18528/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 464; 582 N.Y.S.2d 341; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 72



February 14, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Since the Orzechowskis fail to make such an allegation, the Foundling's motion to dismiss the claim for negligent infliction of emotional distress is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff Roman Catholic adoptive parents filed an action for declaratory and injunctive relief and damages against defendant adoption agency, New York State Department of Social Services, and its Commissioner, alleging violation of their constitutional rights. Plaintiffs argued that defendants' administration of the religious preference provisions of the adoption laws was unconstitutional. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiff Roman Catholic adoptive parents were in the process of adopting a handicapped child when defendant adoption agency terminated the adoption in accordance with the religious matching provisions of the adoption law because the birth mother preferred that the child be placed in a Jewish home. When their request for a hearing was denied by defendant New York State Department of Social Services, plaintiffs filed an action alleging violation of their constitutional rights. Defendants filed motions to dismiss. The court held that although plaintiffs did not have standing to bring the action as taxpayers under the Finance Law, they did have standing predicated on the breach of constitutional rights because they were directly injured by defendants' application of the religious matching provisions. The court denied defendants' motion as to the claim that defendants used the religious preference provision as the sole factor in deciding placement of the child, because if the averments were true, that was a cognizable claim. The court granted defendants' motion to dismiss the claim that the religious preference provision violated plaintiffs' right to freely exercise their religion.


OUTCOME: The court declined to dismiss plaintiff Roman Catholic adoptive parents' action alleging that defendant New York State Department of Social Services and its Commissioner used religious preference as the sole factor in deciding a child's placement in an adoptive home. The court dismissed plaintiffs' claim alleging that application of the religious matching provisions of the adoption laws violated their right to freely exercise their religion.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Challenge to Administration of Religious Matching Provisions of Adoption Laws

1. Plaintiffs, who were allegedly disqualified as adoptive parents of a physically disabled child solely because of the biological parents' stated religious preference for placement, lack standing as taxpayers, pursuant to State Finance Law § 123-b, to enjoin defendants' administration of the religious matching provisions of the adoption laws (Family Ct Act § 116 [e]) as an unconstitutional disbursement of State funds since, even if New York has an improper institutional policy to place children "solely or predominantly" on the basis of religion, moneys expended on housing and clothing foster children cannot be characterized as a wrongful expenditure or misapplication of State funds, especially in light of the discretion granted to officials to make placement determinations based on the best interest of the child. However, plaintiffs do have standing to challenge defendants' religious placement policy based on the claim that their constitutional rights have been violated by defendants' application of the statutory religious matching provisions.

Constitutional Law - Freedom of Religion - Religious Matching Provisions of Adoption Laws

2. Plaintiffs, who were allegedly disqualified as adoptive parents of a physically disabled child solely because of the biological parents' stated religious preference for placement, state a cause of action for declaratory and injunctive relief in regard to defendants' administration of the religious matching provisions of the adoption laws (Family Ct Act § 116 [e]) since, if plaintiffs' central claim is proven, religion would be the controlling factor in determining whether a placement is in the best interest of a child in violation of the Establishment Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions. However, even if religion is the sole or predominant factor upon which placement decisions are made, plaintiffs fail to state a cause of action based on interference with their fundamental constitutional right of free exercise of religion since plaintiffs are free to adopt a child whose natural parents were "indifferent" to the religious placement of their child and, thus, it cannot be said that there is substantial pressure on plaintiffs to modify their religious beliefs. Similarly, since the religious matching provisions have a valid legitimate secular purpose sufficient to withstand rational basis scrutiny, plaintiffs' equal protection claims must be dismissed. Furthermore, plaintiffs' substantive and procedural due process claims must likewise be dismissed since plaintiffs failed to show a protected interest within the Due Process Clauses of the Federal and State Constitutions.

Adoption - Statutory Religious Matching Provisions - Right to Hearing upon Disqualification as Adoptive Parents

3. Plaintiffs, who were allegedly disqualified as adoptive parents of a physically disabled child solely because of the biological parents' stated religious preference for placement (Family Ct Act § 116 [e]) after their application to become adoptive parents had already been approved, are not entitled to a hearing pursuant to Social Services Law § 372-e (4) since the statutory fair hearing requirement relating to applications received from persons who are seeking to become adoptive parents only applies where an "application has been denied" or "has not been acted upon by an authorized agency within six months of its submission". In addition, the regulation which permits only foster parents and certain blood relatives who are unsuccessful in adopting a child to contest the determination at a hearing (18 NYCRR 421.18 [n] [1]) is not inconsistent with State law. There is no statutory requirement that plaintiffs be provided with a hearing.

Torts - Intentional Infliction of Emotional Distress - Disqualification as Adoptive Parents on Religious Grounds

4. Plaintiffs, who were allegedly disqualified as adoptive parents of a physically disabled child solely because of the biological parents' stated religious preference for placement (Family Ct Act § 116 [e]) after their application to become adoptive parents had already been approved, do not state a cause of action for intentional infliction of emotional distress since defendants' conduct in attempting to comply with the religious wishes of the child's biological parents pursuant to statutory authority, was not sufficiently outrageous or extreme. Furthermore, plaintiffs do not state a cause of action for negligent infliction of emotional distress since defendants did not owe plaintiffs a duty, arising from special circumstances, as would permit recovery for pure emotional harm, nor was there any allegation of "contemporaneous or consequential physical harm".

 

910 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Stephen


Docket No. 91N101578


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 382; 581 N.Y.S.2d 981; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 69



February 10, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, defendant's motions to dismiss the charges of Penal Law § 240.20 (1) and § 205.30 are granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss the charges of disorderly conduct under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(1) and resisting arrest under N.Y. Penal Law § 205.30, contending the information was facially insufficient since it unconstitutionally charged conduct that was a protected form of expression under U.S. Const. amend. I.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest resulting from an incident where he made a crude outburst directed at police officers. After making the outburst he was arrested, and during that time resisted arrest. Defendant moved to dismiss the charges, contending the information was facially insufficient since it unconstitutionally charged conduct that was a protected form of expression. The court granted the motion and dismissed the charges since defendant's threatening comments and gestures did not present a clear and present danger of immediate harm, and amounted to pure, protected speech. The court further found that since the officer was not authorized to arrest defendant, an essential element of resisting arrest was lacking.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion and dismissed the charges. Defendant's comments and gestures did not present a clear and present danger of immediate harm, but amounted to pure, protected speech. Since the officer was not authorized to arrest defendant, an essential element of resisting arrest was lacking.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Disorderly Conduct

Defendant, who is charged with disorderly conduct for repeatedly clutching his genitals and yelling offensive epithets at a police officer while a crowd gathered and joined defendant's chants, has failed to meet his burden of establishing beyond a reasonable doubt that the statute (Penal Law § 240.20 [1]), which proscribes engaging "in fighting or in violent, tumultuous or threatening behavior" with "intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof", on its face, impinges upon constitutionally protected speech. The statute punishes conduct and there is thus no reasonable possibility that the statute presents a significant risk of prosecution for the mere exercise of free speech. However, since defendant's threatening comments and gestures in the absence of "violent" or "tumultuous" behavior did not present a clear and present danger of inciting those listening to lawless action, or constitute "fighting words" likely to provoke a retaliatory response from the police officer, and amounted to pure, constitutionally protected speech, defendant's prosecution in this case impermissibly infringes upon his State constitutional rights of free expression. Furthermore, since the officer lacked authority to arrest defendant for disorderly conduct at the time defendant struggled with the officer, an essential element of resisting arrest is lacking (Penal Law § 205.30) and that charge must thus be dismissed for facial insufficiency.

 

911 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Morabito


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, GENEVA, ONTARIO COUNTY


151 Misc. 2d 259; 580 N.Y.S.2d 843; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 22



January 29, 1992, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended February 19, 1992.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant moved to dismiss charges of criminal possession of a controlled substance in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 220.03 and endangering the welfare of a child in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10 arising out defendant's ingestion of cocaine during pregnancy.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with criminal possession of a controlled substance and endangering the welfare of a child arising out of her ingestion of cocaine during pregnancy. Defendant moved to dismiss both charges. The court denied the motion to dismiss the charges of possession of a controlled substance. The court granted the motion to dismiss the child endangerment charge since the word "child" in the statute did not include "fetus," and the duty under the criminal statute did not arise until a live child was born of the pregnancy.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to dismiss the charges of possession of a controlled substance, but it granted the motion to dismiss the child endangerment charge. The word "child" in the statute did not include "fetus," and the duty under the criminal statute did not arise until a live child was born of the pregnancy.

 

912 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Beecher


Docket No. 5119, 5313/91 Motion No. 104/91


JUSTICE COURT OF NEW YORK, VILLAGE OF VALLEY STREAM, NASSAU COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 247; 580 N.Y.S.2d 980; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 49



January 29, 1992, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the motion of the defendant to dismiss the summons and information is denied. In rendering this decision the court has considered the notice of motion, defense counsel's affirmation in support and exhibits attached thereto, the prosecution's affirmation in opposition, defense counsel's reply affirmation and letter dated January 10, 1992 including short form order of the Supreme Court, Nassau County, dated January 8, 1992. ( CPLR 2219 [a].)


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a), 170.35(1)(c), defendant property owner filed a motion to dismiss the summons and information. Plaintiff state charged the property owner with violations of Valley Stream, N.Y., Code §§ 64(4), 64(5), and 50(12), related to the property owner's failure to maintain the property free of litter and debris and the property owner's failure to maintain the premises in good repair.


OVERVIEW: The property owner obtained village permits to renovate a facility on the property owner's premises. The state then charged the property owner with violations of §§ 64(4), 64(5), and 50(12), related to the property owner's failure to maintain the property free of litter and debris and the property owner's failure to maintain the premises in good repair. The property owner filed a motion to dismiss the summons and information under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a), 170.35(1)(c). The court denied the property owner's motion to dismiss the summons and information. The court held (1) that Valley Stream, N.Y., Code §§ 64(4), 64(5), and 50(12), were constitutional, as they were based on sound governmental objectives and were not vague; (2) the information was sufficient, as it alleged specific violations and referred to the proper statutory sections to fairly apprise the property owner of the charges against him; (3) and that under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 170.40, the circumstances did not warrant a dismissal of the charges against the property owner.


OUTCOME: The court denied the property owner's motion to dismiss the summons and information, which were filed by the state against the property owner.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Validity of Statute - Village Ordinance Requiring Property Owner to Maintain Premises in "Good Repair"

1. A village ordinance requiring a property owner to maintain the premises "in good repair" and keep structures painted or covered in a protective coating in order to "foster the health, safety and welfare" and "maintain the neighborhood and property values" is based on valid governmental objectives and is not unconstitutionally vague or overbroad. The statutory term "in good repair" is not incapable of definition and is not a phrase which the common sense of a reasonable person would not comprehend. Furthermore, a person of ordinary intelligence would be capable of recognizing if a structure needed painting or a protective coating.

Crimes - Information - Violations of Village Ordinance - Dismissal in Interests of Justice

2. Informations charging defendant with violating a village ordinance requiring a property owner to maintain the premises "in good repair" and keep the property free of litter and debris fairly apprise defendant of the charges against him and contain sufficient nonhearsay allegations to establish every element of the violations charged ( CPL 100.15, 100.40). The allegations are based upon an inspector's personal observations and even detail the types of debris and garbage found on defendant's property. Furthermore, the failure to allege intent does not warrant dismissal since building and zoning code violations are based upon strict liability and, thus, intent is not an element of the violations charged. In addition, defendant is not entitled to a dismissal in the interests of justice ( CPL 170.30 [1] [g]) on the ground that the village's delays in granting renovation permits caused the charged violations since the normal expense to defendant of painting his building, boarding up the windows and keeping the property free from litter results in little financial burden and defendant could thus have maintained the premises regardless of the eventual granting or denial of future building permits.

 

913 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grumet v. New York State Educ. Dep't


RJI 0190 021649, Index No. 1054-90


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


151 Misc. 2d 60; 579 N.Y.S.2d 1004; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 5



January 22, 1992, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, the state school boards association and its officials, filed a motion for summary judgment in its declaratory judgment action against defendants, the state department of education, its officials, and the attorney general, seeking a declaration that Laws of 1989, ch. 748 was unconstitutional. Defendants filed a cross-motion for summary judgment seeking a declaration of the law's constitutionality.


OVERVIEW: A village comprised of Hasidic Jews practiced separation from the outside community and separation of the sexes. Yiddish was the principle language of the village; television, radio, and English publications were not in general use. The dress and appearance of the village residents were also distinctive. In an attempt to compromise an ongoing dispute regarding whether special services to the village's handicapped children were required to have been provided in the public schools or religiously affiliated private schools, Laws of 1989, ch. 748 was enacted, which created a separate school district for the village. Plaintiffs brought an action challenging the statute's constitutionality. The court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment, finding that Laws of 1989, ch. 748 violated the Establishment Clause of the First Amendment and its state counterpart, N.Y. Const. art. XI, § 3. The court found that the statute had a sectarian purpose rather than a secular purpose, its purpose was to meet exclusive religious need, it was impermissibly entangled with religion, and it gave the appearance of symbolic benefit to religion.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motion for summary judgment and denied defendants' cross-motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Parties - Standing - Constitutionality of Law Creating Village School District to Meet Religious Needs

1. Plaintiffs, the New York State Boards Association and its executive director and president, have standing to challenge the constitutionality of a law creating a village school district for a village of Hasidic Jews in an effort to provide public funding for special educational services for the nonpublic school handicapped children of the village (L 1989, ch 748).

Constitutional Law - Establishment of Religion - Constitutionality of Law Creating Village School District to Meet Religious Needs

2. A law creating a village school district for a village of Hasidic Jews in an effort to provide public funding for special educational services for the village's nonpublic school handicapped children (L 1989, ch 748) is unconstitutional as violative of the Establishment of Religion Clause of the State and Federal Constitutions (NY Const, art XI, § 3; US Const 1st Amend). The school district was created solely and exclusively to meet religious needs, the village residents having rejected any attempts to provide for the education of nonpublic school handicapped pupils at a neutral site, and has the effect of advancing, protecting and fostering the religious beliefs of the inhabitants of the school district. The law also fosters excessive entanglements with religion in view of the special steps the State Education Department must take to monitor the newly created school district to ensure that public funds are not expended to further religious purposes.

 

914 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Maloney v. Rincon


Index Nos. 41921/91, 42772/91, Cal. Nos. 15P, 16P & 17P of 12/3/91


CIVIL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 162; 581 N.Y.S.2d 120; 1992 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 29



January 22, 1992, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, this court hereby orders that all further proceedings herein shall be stayed, pursuant to CPLR 326 (a) and 2201, until further order of this court or the Supreme Court, in order to permit petitioner to make proper application in the Supreme Court, for both removal of this proceeding under CPLR 325 and appropriate injunctive relief.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 2201, petitioner car owner moved for an order from the court to stay the sale of an automobile and, by a special proceeding simultaneously commenced, also moved to cancel respondent garage owner's lien on the automobile.


OVERVIEW: The car owner moved for an order staying the sale of his car and simultaneously sought to cancel the garage owner's lien. The car owner claimed that the garage owner agreed to store his vehicle without charge and then performed various repairs without consent. The car owner asserted that he was served him with a notice of foreclosure sale without a demand for payment or any other notice. The garage owner denied the allegations, including ownership, and asserted that he surrendered the vehicle to a third party who had allegedly exhibited a certificate of title. The court found that while City Civ. Ct. Act 209 (a) statutorily granted the court subject matter jurisdiction over proceedings under to N.Y. Lien Law § 207 the court was granted no injunctive jurisdiction in connection with such proceeding. The court held that the jurisdictional provision of N.Y. Lien Law § 201-a, which permitted proceeding to be brought in any court having monetary jurisdiction, could not grant injunctive jurisdiction to a court that did not have it. The court, however, stayed further proceedings to permit the car owner to apply to the proper forum for both removal and injunctive relief.


OUTCOME: While finding that it lacked the subject matter jurisdiction to enjoin a lien sale, the court held that if it denied the motion for a stay and proceeded to adjudicate the underlying special proceeding the car might well be sold before the rights of the parties were determined. The court therefore stayed all further proceedings in order to permit car owner to apply to the proper forum.


HEADNOTES

Courts - New York City Civil Court - No Subject Matter Jurisdiction to Enjoin Lien Sale

The New York City Civil Court, which possesses no equitable power other than that specifically bestowed by Constitution or statute, lacks subject matter jurisdiction to order injunctive relief staying a lien sale within a special proceeding challenging the validity of the lien over which it has subject matter jurisdiction (CCA 202). CPLR 2201, which codifies a court's inherent power to stay its own proceedings in a pending case, is inapplicable since a lien sale is not a function of the court's own process and, thus, at the time the injunctive relief was requested, there was no action pending in which the court's proceedings could have been stayed. CPLR 2201 is not a substitute for, nor an alternative to, a proper application for injunctive relief under CPLR article 63. In addition, Lien Law § 201-a, which sets forth the power of the court and the procedure to be followed in a special proceeding to determine a lien's validity, grants no injunctive jurisdiction to a court not already vested with it. Accordingly, in order to prevent any injustice, all further proceedings will be stayed pursuant to CPLR 326 (a) and 2201 in order to permit petitioner to make proper application in the Supreme Court for both removal of the proceedings under CPLR 325 and appropriate injunctive relief.

 

915 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Balsam Lake Anglers Club v. Department of Envtl. Conservation


2707, RJI 55-90-01116


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ULSTER COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 606; 583 N.Y.S.2d 119; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 801



December 30, 1991, Decided


NOTICE:   [**1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: The petition shall be granted to the extent that it is determined that respondents failed to comply with the provisions of SEQRA in adopting the UMP. The matter shall be remitted to respondent Department of Environmental Conservation for further proceedings consistent herewith. It shall further be declared that the UMP does not violate the provisions of the New York State Constitution or any of petitioner's property rights in certain lands.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner lake club commenced a hybrid proceeding that challenged a unit management plan (UMP) for a forest area adopted by respondents, Department of Environmental Conservation and others. Petitioner sought a prohibition of UMP's application, a declaratory judgment that the UMP violated N.Y. Const. art. XIV and violated certain easements, and violations of the provisions of the State Environmental Quality Review Act.


OVERVIEW: Respondents adopted a UMP for a forest area. Respondents intended to construct a number of small parking areas, which provided access to trails and primitive campsites, to relocate certain trails to avoid private lands, and to construct new trails. Petitioner argued that the UMP violated the New York Constitution because it required the cutting of a number of trees. The court found that the great majority of the cutting would be completely decomposed within a few years leaving no trace of their existence but providing increased growth opportunity for the remaining trees in the forest. Thus it was not constitutional prohibited. The court found that respondents' negative declaration did not consider the increased usage of the recreational facility and failed to consider the aesthetics of new trails in currently totally wild areas or the camping impact. The court granted the portion of the petition that challenged the UMP on the ground that respondents failed to comply with the provisions of the State Environmental Quality Review Act because the UMP may have had an adverse impact on the environment, which required an environmental impact statement.


OUTCOME: The court granted the petition to the extent that it was determined that respondents failed to comply with the provisions of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) and remitted for further proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - State Forest Preserve - Lawful Cutting of Trees to Facilitate Use of Forest Preserve

1. The cutting of as many as 2,000 "trees", most of which are less than three inches diameter, in a State-owned forest preserve as part of respondents' plan to construct a number of small parking areas providing access to trails and primitive campsites, to relocate certain trails to avoid private lands and to construct new trails, does not violate the constitutional prohibition against the removal or destruction of "timber" within State-owned forest lands (NY Const, art XIV, § 1). Insubstantial and immaterial cutting of trees is constitutionally authorized in order to facilitate public use of the forest preserve where such use is consistent with wild forest lands. Here, the amount of vegetation, seedlings, saplings and timber-sized trees destroyed in the construction of the relocated trails, is not constitutionally prohibited nor is the number of trees planned to be removed to complete such relocation. Furthermore, the construction of new trails, thereby increasing human activity, does not violate the further constitutional requirement that the forest preserve lands "be forever kept as wild forest lands" since such requirement is intended not to prevent or hinder public use of the forest, but to allow forest areas to revert to their natural or wild state without human interference. There is no indication of any intent to maintain the forest in an "absolutely" wild state with no organized human alteration or intervention at all.

Environmental Conservation - Environmental Quality Review - Plan to Relocate and Construct Trails in State Forest Preserve

2. Respondents violated the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8) by failing to take the requisite "hard look" at any relevant area of environmental concern before adopting a plan to construct small parking areas providing access to trails and primitive campsites, to relocate certain trails to avoid private lands and to construct new trails all within a State- owned forest preserve. The negative declaration issued by respondents fails to contain a reasoned elaboration of the basis for the determination supported by empirical and scientific authority. It is clear that respondents' plan may have an adverse impact on the environment requiring preparation of an environmental impact statement in view of the almost certain substantial increase in the legal use of the forest preserve resulting from implementation of respondents' plan.

Easements - Scope of Easement - Designation of Cross-Country Ski Trail in State Forest Preserve

3. Respondents' designation of a cross-country ski trail as part of a plan to relocate and construct new trails within a State-owned forest preserve does not violate the terms of an easement granted by petitioner's predecessors in title to respondents' predecessors in title allowing logging and hunting, since the uses allowed by the easement have the potential for substantially greater impact upon petitioner's lands than cross-country skiing. Moreover, the easement refers to the existence of certain public trails, which have been in public use for decades, and implicitly allows the continuation of such public trails. Accordingly, respondents' plan does not violate any of petitioner's property rights in and to the proposed cross-country ski trail.

 

916 of 992 DOCUMENTS


North Hempstead v. Westbury


Index No. 5271/91, Chambers No. G-3634, Index No. 12593/91, Chambers No. G-3755


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 225; 581 N.Y.S.2d 536; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 789



December 20, 1991, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended June 3, 1992.



DISPOSITION: For all the reasons set forth above, the Town's motions for summary judgment in action Nos. 1 and 2 are denied. Defendant Westbury's cross motion is granted to the extent that chapter 544 and the Town's Flow Control Law, Sanitation Code chapter 46 are declared invalid and unconstitutional and the Town's complaint is dismissed. The counterclaims of Westbury and Mineola are severed and shall continue. In light of this decision, Great Neck Plaza's cross motion has been rendered academic and is accordingly denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County, reviewed motions and cross-motions for summary judgment filed by plaintiff town and defendant town, defendant first and second villages, and plaintiff third village from two actions concerning solid waste disposal.


OVERVIEW: The villages were in the town. With authority granted by the state specifically to the town by 1983 N.Y. Laws ch. 544, the town adopted a law for the disposal of solid waste. Town's waste management authority bought land for a landfill. Under N.Y. Envtl. Conserv. Law § 27-0704, landfills were to close by a certain date. The town therefore chose alternate locations for waste. Aware of the deadline, the first and second villages made an agreement with a facility for waste disposal. The town filed an action against the first and second villages seeking a permanent injunction, and the third village filed an action against the town seeking declaratory and injunctive relief. The parties filed motions and cross-motions for summary judgment. The court denied the town's motion and the third village's cross-motion, granted the second villages cross motion, and dismissed the town's complaint. Under N.Y. Const. art. IX, § 2(d), and N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 10(5), the town lacked the power to adopt its law because N.Y. Mun. Home Rule Law § 11(3) stipulated that town laws did not apply to villages. 1983 N.Y. Laws ch. 544 was unconstitutional because solid waste disposal was a local matter.


OUTCOME: The court denied the town's motions for summary judgment. The court granted the second village's cross-motion for summary judgment to the extent that certain state and local laws were declared unconstitutional and invalid. The court dismissed the town's complaint and severed the first and second villages' counterclaims. The court denied the third village's cross-motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Necessary Parties

1. In an action brought by the Town of North Hempstead (Town) against defendant incorporated villages to enforce the Town's Flow Control Law, which requires that all solid waste generated in the Town, including the incorporated villages, be delivered to a solid waste management facility designated by the Town, it is not necessary that other villages within the Town be joined as parties pursuant to CPLR 1001 (a). Three villages directly affected by the outcome of this litigation have been actively participating in these lawsuits. The likelihood that the remaining villages are united in interest is great. Under such circumstances, dismissal or joinder is not necessary.

Municipal Corporations - Home Rule Powers - Solid Waste Management

2. State enabling legislation, passed without a home rule message or certificate of necessity, which authorizes plaintiff Town of North Hempstead (Town) to adopt a local law to, inter alia, "exclusively control all solid waste ... including without limitation the collection, transportation and delivery of solid waste to a designated resource recovery facility or facilities within the town" and to collect fees for said services (L 1983, ch 544), unconstitutionally infringes on the constituent villages' home rule powers (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [b]) and is invalid. In the absence of a home rule message, the State must demonstrate a State concern when enacting special laws in areas relating to a local government's property, affairs or government. In this case, although the enabling legislation contains a pro forma recitation of its purported State concern, i.e., the protection of the environment by controlling air, water and land pollution, and to promote solid waste management, the true purpose of the law is to provide the Town with a funding mechanism to finance a resource recovery facility, a matter that is not a State concern. Furthermore, the Town's Flow Control Law, passed pursuant to the enabling legislation and the powers subsequently vested in the Town of North Hempstead Solid Waste Management Authority (Public Authorities Law § 2049-a et seq.), is likewise unconstitutional for impairing the incorporated villages' home rule powers to control their waste disposal (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [d]; Municipal Home Rule Law § 10 [5]; § 11 [3]).

 

917 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Reform Educ. Fin. Inequities Today v. Cuomo


INDEX: #2500/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NASSAU COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 714; 578 N.Y.S.2d 969; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 725



December 12, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, not for profit organization on behalf of itself, taxpayers, parents, students, and school districts, sought to declare defendant New York State's system of funding public education unconstitutional and to obtain appropriate injunctive relief. Plaintiffs claimed that huge disparities existed as a result of the inadequacy and unfairness of the formulas by which state aid was distributed among the state's school districts.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs, not for profit organization on behalf of itself, taxpayers, parents, students, and school districts, initiated an action against defendant New York seeking declaratory and injunctive relief on the grounds that the state's system of funding public education was unconstitutional. Plaintiffs claimed that the state's financial scheme for education based on property tax valuation failed to satisfy the education article, N. Y. Const. art XI, § 1, and violated the Equal Protection Clause of U.S. Const. amend. XIV, § 1 and of N.Y. Const. art I, § 11. Plaintiffs claimed that huge disparities existed as a result of the inadequacy and unfairness of the formulas by which state aid was distributed among the state's 700 school districts. The state maintained that this showing was insufficient absent a showing of "gross and glaring inadequacy" in the quality of education provided. The court held that plaintiffs had vividly demonstrated the disparities in expenditures per pupil between property-wealthy and poor districts, but that the primary responsibility for the provision of fair and equitable educational opportunity rested with the Legislature. The court dismissed the complaint.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant New York State's motion to dismiss the complaint of plaintiffs, not for profit organization on behalf of itself, taxpayers, parents, students, and school districts, which sought a declaration that the state's system of funding public education was unconstitutional. The court held that it was not the court's role, but rather the Legislature's role to address equitable educational opportunity within the state.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law - Equal Protection of Laws - Public Schools Financing System

New York State's system for financing public schools (Education Law §§ 2022, 3602) by which funds raised by locally imposed taxes are augmented by allocations of State moneys in accordance with a variety of formulas and grants, although resulting in huge disparities between property-wealthy and property-poor districts, is not violative of the Equal Protection Clauses of the State and Federal Constitutions and the education article of the State Constitution (NY Const, art XI, § 1). Any deviation from the prior holding in Board of Educ. v Nyquist (57 NY2d 27) that expenditure disparities alone do not establish a violation of the Federal or State Constitutions must come from the Court of Appeals or by legislative action.

 

918 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Schultz v. State


RJI 0191-ST3105


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 589; 578 N.Y.S.2d 822; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 697



December 5, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers brought a declaratory action against defendant state challenging the constitutionality of the state budget. The state sought to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayers brought an action challenging the state budget, and the state sought to dismiss the complaint. The court held that the taxpayers had standing to challenge the governor's alleged failure to include in his proposed budget "without revision" an itemized estimate of the financial needs of the judiciary. The court held that the taxpayers had standing to challenge the contracts, which the state was to enter into with the Thruway Authority. The court held that the claims were ripe for judicial review. The court held that the action was not barred by laches in the absence of any showing of prejudice to the state from the asserted delay. The motion to dismiss was denied.


OUTCOME: The court denied the state's motion to dismiss the taxpayers' complaint challenging the constitutionality of the state budget.


HEADNOTES

Parties - Standing - Citizen-Taxpayer Action to Challenge Constitutionality of Budget Legislation - Laches

1. Plaintiffs have standing as citizen-taxpayers to maintain a declaratory judgment action challenging the constitutionality of the 1991-1992 State budget on the ground that the Governor failed to include in his proposed budget "without revision" the itemized estimates of the financial needs of the judiciary certified by the Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, allegedly in violation of NY Constitution, article VII, §§ 1, 2. If the budget process was flawed to the point that the 1991-1992 budget is unconstitutional, then plaintiffs' action falls squarely within State Finance Law § 123-b (1), which permits a citizen-taxpayer to seek such declaratory relief "whether or not such person is or may be affected or specially aggrieved". In addition, defendants have not demonstrated any prejudice from any delay on the part of plaintiffs sufficient to invoke the defense of laches.

Parties - Standing - Citizen-Taxpayer Action Challenging Constitutionality of Bonding Legislation 

2. Plaintiffs have standing as citizen-taxpayers to challenge the constitutionality of legislation which authorizes the State Comptroller and the State Department of Transportation to enter into "debt service contracts" and "cooperative highway contractual agreements" with the State Thruway Authority as part of a plan to effectuate the transfer of $ 80 million from the Thruway Authority to the State, allegedly in violation of NY Constitution articles VII and X relating to bonding, and need not await the actual implementation of the legislation before mounting a challenge. State Finance Law § 123-b (1) permits a challenge against State officials who are about to cause a wrongful expenditure or any other illegal or unconstitutional disbursement of State funds.

Courts - Justiciable Questions

3. A justiciable controversy is raised by plaintiff citizen-taxpayers in their causes of action challenging the constitutionality of New York State's 1991-1992 budget on the ground that the Governor failed to include in his proposed budget "without revision" the itemized estimates of the judiciary, and the constitutionality of legislation authorizing the State Comptroller and the State Department of Transportation to enter into "debt service contracts" and "cooperative highway contractual agreements" with the Thruway Authority as part of a plan to effectuate the transfer of certain moneys from the Authority to the State.

 

919 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Ananias


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, TROY


152 Misc. 2d 660; 578 N.Y.S.2d 371; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 683



December 4, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charge against him for violating N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(3), which was the disorderly conduct statute. The state filed an affirmation in opposition to his motion.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that § 240.20(3), under which he was charged with disorderly conduct, was overbroad and impermissibly vague and that there was a legal impediment to conviction. He filed a motion to dismiss. The court stated that the statute proscribed using "abusive or obscene language" for making an "obscene gesture" in a public place with the intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly create a risk thereof and held that such language was unconstitutionally overbroad because on its face it prohibited a substantial amount of constitutionally protected expression and because its continued existence presented a significant risk of prosecution for the mere exercise of free speech. The court granted the motion to dismiss, concluding that any proscription of pure speech had to be sharply limited to words which, by their utterance alone, inflicted injury or tended naturally to evoke immediate violence or other breach of the peace and holding that § 240.20(3) was unconstitutionally overbroad and invalid.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss and held that the disorderly conduct statute that he was charged with violating was unconstitutionally overbroad and invalid.

 

920 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Duke v. Huntington


INDEX No. 4717


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, SUFFOLK COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 521; 581 N.Y.S.2d 978; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 798



December 3, 1991, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Plaintiff's motion for summary judgment is granted; Local Laws, 1989, No. 3 and Local Laws, 1990, No. 2 of defendant Town of Huntington have expired by their own time limitation, but Local Laws, 1991, No. 3 is now held to be void and of no effect as to the lands of plaintiff, the subject of this action across which plaintiff has riparian rights of access; defendant is enjoined from prohibiting plaintiff from erecting a dock on or adjacent to his property as permitted by the State DEC; and defendant shall issue a permit to plaintiff for the construction of the proposed dock and his dockage of boats in connection therewith.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff landowner filed an action for a declaratory judgment that defendant town's Local Law No. 2 of 1990, which imposed a "temporary" restriction upon the construction of docks in town waterways until 60 days after the date of the adoption of a local waterfront revitalization plan, or May 20, 1991, whichever was earlier, was void. Relief was also sought to enjoin the town from prohibiting the landowner from erecting a dock on his property.


OVERVIEW: The landowner wanted to build a timber dock on his property. The Department of Environmental Conservation issued him a permit. Thereafter, the town imposed its first temporary restriction on construction of docks in town waterways for the purpose of developing a waterfront revitalization plan. The temporary restriction was extended numerous times. The landowner sought a declaration that the local laws enacting the moratorium were void, and were of no effect as to his property; he also sought an injunction enjoining the town from prohibiting his building of the dock or requiring him to secure a town permit. The landowner argued that the inordinate delay in the town's final development of its revitalization plan resulted in a violation of his constitutional rights. The court granted the landowner's motion for summary judgment. The court noted that the town had developed an embryonic plan for protecting its harbors in 1984, but had not come up with a definite plan. The court held that the town's legislative limitation on the landowner's right to use his property, halted for a period extending over three years by virtue of the moratoriums, was excessive and unconstitutionally void.


OUTCOME: The court granted the landowner's motion for summary judgment striking the town's answer on the ground that there was no defense to the cause of action alleged in the complaint. The court held that the town's law was void and of no effect as to the landowner's property. The court enjoined the town from prohibiting the landowner from erecting a dock on his property. Finally, the town was ordered to issue the landowner a construction permit.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Building Permits - Invalid Moratorium on Dock Construction

A local law of defendant town enacting a further moratorium on the construction of docks in town waterways until 60 days after the adoption of a local waterfront revitalization plan or February 21, 1992 is void and of no effect as to plaintiff's property due to defendant's unreasonable delay in enacting a definite plan for protecting its harbors. Such a plan was first proposed in 1984, but defendant has yet to enact a definite plan, and there is no expectation of one in the future. Moreover, no dire necessity, crisis condition or emergency situation has been demonstrated by defendant to justify the stop-gap legislation. Accordingly, defendant's legislative limitation on plaintiff's right to use his property, now halted for a period extending over three years by virtue of continued moratoriums, is excessive and constitutionally void. Defendant is enjoined from prohibiting plaintiff from erecting a dock on or adjacent to his property as permitted by the Department of Environmental Conservation and defendant shall issue a permit to plaintiff for the construction of the proposed dock.

 

921 of 992 DOCUMENTS


City of N.Y. v. 17 Vista Assoc.


Index No. 41208/90


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


153 Misc. 2d 194; 580 N.Y.S.2d 963; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 786



December 3, 1991, Decided


NOTICE:   [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff City of New York (city) filed an action against defendant real estate developer (developer) to enforce a contractual obligation of the developer to pay $ 500,000 to the city's trust for low- and moderate-income housing. The city subsequently filed a motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The developer negotiated to purchase a housing building for the purpose of demolishing it and erecting an office building. At the time of the negotiations, local laws placed an 18-month moratorium on the demolition of multiple dwelling units, and required a nonharassment certificate prior to the demolition. The local laws contained an exclusion for buildings whose occupancy was restricted to "institutional use." The developer obtained an institutional use exemption after signing a promissory note to place money in the city's trust for low-income housing, to expedite the process. When the city attempted to collect on the note, the developer refused, asserting duress and that the contract was void because the local laws were determined to be unconstitutional. The city filed an action to enforce and the court granted summary judgment in favor of the city. The developer failed to prove duress. The fact that the local laws were subsequently deemed unconstitutional did not relieve the developer's duties under the contract because it was aware of the laws when it signed the note. The contract was mutually beneficial and entered into in good faith by the city, creating a binding contract.


OUTCOME: The court granted the city's motion for summary judgment.


HEADNOTES

Contracts - Consideration - Voidable Contracts - Duress - Public Policy - Agreement to Expedite City's Grant of "Institutional Use" Exemption for SRO Building

An agreement executed in 1985 whereby defendant, a real estate developer, in connection with its plan to construct an office tower on the site of an existing building owned by a charitable trust for low- and moderate-income housing, agreed to pay $ 500,000 to the trust for such housing if it received a prompt determination from plaintiff City of New York that the building was exempt from the moratorium on the demolition of single room occupancy (SRO) buildings then in effect and was "timely" issued the necessary permits to begin lawful construction, is valid and enforceable even though the permit approval process was unnecessarily protracted, causing delays, increased costs and lost revenues. Since the sole reason for the agreement was the need for a prompt and favorable determination of the building's SRO status, the "timely" issuance of the permits must be interpreted to mean "without delay attributable to the existing building's possible SRO status", and not merely "without unnecessary delay"; thus, the City's grant of an "institutional use" exemption to the building on the same day the agreement was executed and the building sold to defendant constitutes valid consideration for the agreement. The agreement is not voidable on the ground of duress since defendant must accept the consequences of having moved headlong into a major real estate development project without checking all of the legal implications, nor should it be voided by the subsequent determination by the Court of Appeals that the City's SRO law was unconstitutional. Moreover, requiring a sophisticated business enterprise to honor a financial obligation made to the City in return for help in clearing reasonable hurdles applicable to the project does not violate public policy.

 

922 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Melton


Ind. No. 75


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 649; 578 N.Y.S.2d 377; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 693



November 26, 1991, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended February 26, 1992.



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the application of the defendant to suppress the cocaine seized from him and the statement made by him is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to suppress all evidence obtained from a consensual search.


OVERVIEW: Defendant made a motion to have all evidence suppressed on the grounds that the loitering statute in which the police officer was originally investigating was unconstitutional, all evidence obtained therefrom was required to be suppressed. The supreme court denied defendant's motion. The supreme court held that defendant correctly asserted that where defendant was arrested on the basis of a loitering statute which was unconstitutional, any search incident to such an arrest was improper and any items seized must be suppressed. The supreme court held, however, that the stop and search were proper because the officer possessed an articulable objective reason for approaching defendant and requesting information. According to the supreme court, it was immaterial that the officer predicated his approach upon his assumption that he was investigating a violation of a probably unconstitutional loitering statute. Because defendant's consent to search was voluntary, suppression was not warranted.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to suppress was denied because defendant's consent to the search was voluntary and because the officer had an articulable objective reason for approaching defendant and requesting information from him.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Unlawful Search and Seizure - Police Approach Premised on Probably Unconstitutional Loitering Statute 

Cocaine seized from defendant's pocket after a consensual pat-down search and defendant's written statement admitting possession of cocaine should not be suppressed where the arresting officer, responding to a report that several individuals were shooting dice in public at a designated address, initially approached defendant and the group he was with on the basis of the probably unconstitutional loitering for the purpose of gambling statute (Penal Law § 240.35 [2]), since a police approach for the purpose of requesting information premised on a probably unconstitutional statute can still be equated with a lawful approach premised on the requisite objective credible reason. In this case, the police officer was not precluded from responding to a radio dispatch that individuals were loitering and playing dice to investigate whether the crimes of promoting gambling (Penal Law § 225.05) or possession of a gambling device (Penal Law § 225.30 [2]) were being committed. The officer therefore possessed an articulable reason for approaching defendant and requesting information, and it is immaterial that the officer predicated his approach upon his assumption that he was investigating a violation of a probably unconstitutional loitering statute.

 

923 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. David


2817


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, MONROE COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 66; 585 N.Y.S.2d 149; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 809



November 8, 1991, Decided


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected June 2, 1992.



DISPOSITION: It is therefore the determination of this court that the verdicts of conviction are legally insufficient and against the weight of the evidence and are therefore reversed (CPL 470.20 [2], [5]). The informations are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants appealed their convictions from the lower court (New York) for public exposure under N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01.


OVERVIEW: Defendants' convictions for public exposure was reversed and the indictments dismissed pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 470.20 (2), (5). The appellate court found that the evidence was insufficient to support defendant's convictions. Defendants, females, were charged under N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01 for sunbathing topless. The appellate court found the statute unconstitutional as violating the equal protection clause because the gender-based classification did not serve a legitimate governmental interest better than a gender-neutral law would. According to the court, the test for determining constitutionality turned on whether the statute protected a legitimate government interest and whether the classification was a reasonable means of achieving substantial government ends and not merely the arbitrary classifying of people by sexual stereotype. The appellate court held that there was no physiologically difference between male and female breast except for lactation capability. Although the court found the statute unconstitutional, the court reversed the convictions based on insufficiency of the evidence.


OUTCOME: Defendants' convictions were reversed because the evidence was insufficient to support their conviction where the evidence showed that a change in community standard negated the notion that a woman's breast was a private or intimate part of a person's body.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Exposure of Person - Unconstitutional Gender-Based Classification

The exposure of a person statute (Penal Law § 245.01) is unconstitutional as violative of equal protection to the extent that it prohibits only a female from appearing at a public place with her breasts unclothed since the statute's gender-based classification does not serve the legitimate governmental interest in protecting the public's sensibilities better than would a gender-neutral law. The unconstitutionality of that part of the statute does not require reversal of defendants' convictions, however, since the statute can be construed as gender neutral. Nevertheless, in view of the testimony of defendants' expert witnesses that the change in community standards is such as to negate the notion that a woman's breast is a "private or intimate part" of a person's body, defendants' convictions are reversed as being legally insufficient and against the weight of the evidence (CPL 470.20 [2], [5]).

 

924 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Meredith


Ind. No. 11121/90


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 387; 578 N.Y.S.2d 79; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 652



October 30, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed an application for a stay of judgment pending his appeal.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was convicted upon his guilty plea. Defendant filed an application for a stay of judgment with a court of concurrent jurisdiction. State alleged that the more appropriate forum for the application was the judge who took defendant's plea. The court held that was required to entertain the application because N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 460.50 gave defendant the right to make the stay application to any judge in the appropriate judicial district. Further, the court would deny defendant's due process rights by failing to hear the application. Although the court determined that there was an arguable issue of merit to be reviewed upon appeal, the court did not rule upon the application. The information supplied in support of and in opposition to the application was insufficient for the court to make an assessment of the degree of control necessary to secure defendant's court attendance during the appeal, pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 510.30(2)(a) and (b). The court instructed the parties to supply this evidence to the court.


OUTCOME: Defendant's application for stay of judgment was held in abeyance until the court was supplied with sufficient information to allow the court to determine the degree of control required to secure defendant's appearance at the appeal.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Appeal - Stay of Judgment Pending Appeal

A Judge who is statutorily authorized to hear an application for a stay of judgment pending appeal pursuant to CPL 460.50 must entertain the defendant's stay application and may not transfer such application to the Judge who conducted the proceedings in the case. The statute clearly authorizes the defendant to choose among a broad number of trial and appellate Judges to hear the single stay application allowed and that decision by the defendant is not one that can be usurped by a Judge through the mechanism of transferring the application to the Judge who presided over the case. Defendant would be denied due process if the Judge chosen declined to hear the stay application.

 

925 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cruz


Docket No. 91N062810


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 436; 576 N.Y.S.2d 978; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 648



October 22, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss count three of the information is, in all respects, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant brought a motion to dismiss count three of the misdemeanor complaint filed by the people, which alleged the offense of endangering the welfare of a child (count three). Defendant contended that this count was facially insufficient under N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 170.40 and, alternatively, that dismissal was in the interest of justice pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law 170.30(1)(a),(g), 170.35.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was stopped by the police while driving in a state of intoxication when his vehicle contained two children. The police administered a test indicating a .18 percent blood alcohol content. The complaint alleged two counts of operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol or drugs in violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 1192(2),(3). The court declined to grant defendant's motion to dismiss count three. The court held that the facts alleged in the complaint and in the supporting deposition provided prima facie evidence of each element of N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10(1) including the likelihood of injury to the children passengers. The court decided that § 260.10(1) was constitutional and rejected defendant's cited authority. The court ruled that the risk of harm to the child covered under § 260.10(1) should be direct and was not limited to sexual and moral offenses. The court concluded that harm to the passengers was likely when defendant was using the accelerator and brake with unsteady feet when driving across the bridge at night. The court held that defendant's alternative motion for dismissal in the interest of justice was conclusory and lacked factual support.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss count three of the people's misdemeanor complaint as facially insufficient. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss count three in the interest of justice under the statute.


HEADNOTES

Crimes - Endangering Welfare of Child - Driving while Intoxicated with Child Passengers

The allegation that defendant was driving his automobile in an intoxicated condition while "two small children" were passengers in the car is sufficient to sustain a charge of endangering the welfare of a child under Penal Law § 260.10 (1), which proscribes "knowingly act[ing] in a manner likely to be injurious to the physical, mental or moral welfare of a child less than" 17 years old. The language of the child endangerment statute is not unconstitutionally vague. Nor does a cognizable wrong under the statute require that the potential of harm to which the child is subjected be actually realized or that the potential injury be the product of conduct focused directly upon the child. The potential impact of the injury anticipated by the statute need not be direct, rather it must only be "likely". Accordingly, the facts alleged in the misdemeanor complaint together with those in the supporting deposition establish, prima facie, each of the elements of the offense charged, including the likelihood of injury to the child passengers.

 

926 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Hamburg


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Surrogate's Court of New York, Bronx County


151 Misc. 2d 1034; 574 N.Y.S.2d 914; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 544



September 5, 1991 


NOTICE:  [***1] [EDITED FOR PUBLICATION]


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner administratrix sought to recover the sum of $ 280,000 plus interest that had initially belonged to the decedent and was deposited into accounts containing the names of the decedent and respondent relative. The relative had withdrawn the funds from the accounts prior to decedent's death and deposited the proceeds into accounts in his name.


OVERVIEW: The administratrix contended that the relative was liable for the total amount of the withdrawals because the accounts were convenience accounts rather than joint accounts. Alternatively, she sought to recover one-half of the amount on the ground that the relative had forfeited any survivorship interest by withdrawing the entire balance without obtaining decedent's consent. The relative contended that the accounts were joint accounts and that the decedent expressly or impliedly approved of the withdrawals. He also argued that the exclusion of his testimony under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 4519, the Dead Man's Statute, constituted an unconstitutional taking of property. The court found that, under the facts, the result was the same whether the accounts created a survivorship interest or a tenancy in common because the relative destroyed his rights of survivorship by withdrawing more than his interest without consent and because a tenancy in common interest only entitled the relative to one-half of the sum. The court expressed its dissatisfaction with the provisions of N.Y. C.P.L.R. 4519, but stated that, in the absence of any constitutional infirmity, the statute had to be enforced as enacted.


OUTCOME: The court held that the administratrix was entitled to recover from the relative the sum of $ 134,117.00, which was the $ 140,000.00 improperly withdrawn from the accounts minus $ 5,883.00 reimbursement for funeral expenses, plus interest at the statutory rate from the date of decedent's death.

 

927 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Home Builders Ass'n v. County of Onondaga


Index No. 91-343, RJI No. 33-91-134


Supreme Court of New York, Onondaga County


151 Misc. 2d 886; 573 N.Y.S.2d 863; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 460



August 21, 1991, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, builders association and builder, brought an action to vacate Onondaga County Resol. 482-90 of respondent Onondaga County, to enjoin the county and respondents, Onondaga County Sanitary District and Commissioner of the Onondaga County Department of Drainage & Sanitation, from imposing and collecting a sewer connection fee. Petitioners also sought a declaration that the sums collected as sewer collection fees were collected illegally.


OVERVIEW: Petitioners brought an action: 1) to vacate Resol. 482-90, which provided for a sewer connection fee to be charged, 2) to enjoin respondents from imposing and collecting the fee, 3) to obtain a declaration that sums collected by respondents as sewer collection fees were collected illegally, and 4) for judgment in favor of the builder be granted. The court annulled, vacated, and set aside Resol. 482-90, enjoined respondents from imposing and collecting the sewer connection fees, and ordered the return, to those who had paid the fee, of sums collected to the date of the court's judgment and retained by respondents pursuant to Resol. 482-90. The court found that N.Y. County Law § 5-A, which provided a comprehensive scheme for the establishment, administration, operation, and improvement of county sewer districts, manifested an attempt by the state legislature to preempt regulation to local sewer districts, and provided for financing of county sewer districts by allowing counties to impose a system of sewer rents. The court found that the sewer connection fee, a one-time charge, was not a sewer rent as provided for in N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 14-F and that it was ultra vires.


OUTCOME: The court annulled, vacated, and set aside Resol. 482-90. The court enjoined respondents from imposing and collecting the sewer connection fees set forth in Resol. 482-90. The court ordered the return, to those individuals or entities who paid the fee, of all sums collected to the date of the court's judgment and retained by respondents pursuant to Resol. 482-90.

 

928 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Burke v. Crosson


Index No: 91-2620, RJI No: 33-91-840


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ONONDAGA COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 158; 575 N.Y.S.2d 624; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 586



August 9, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff judges filed a motion for summary judgment after they filed a complaint alleging that the Equal Protection Clauses of the federal and state constitutions required that they be paid the same salary as county court judges serving in 13 other counties of the state. Defendants, comptroller and state, filed a cross-motion for summary judgment, seeking to dismiss the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The judges filed a motion for summary judgment on their claim against the comptroller and the state, alleging that the Equal Protection Clauses of the federal and state constitutions required that they be paid the same salary as county court judges serving in 13 other counties in the state. The judges also sought adjustment of their salaries and the comptroller and the state filed cross-motions for summary judgment, seeking dismissal of the complaint. The court granted the judges' motion for summary judgment, holding that the comptroller and the state offered no proof that the differences among the various counties was sufficient to support different salaries under constitutionally mandated equal protection standards. The court held that in order to satisfy equal protection, the judges' salaries should have been at least as high as those of county court judges in Erie and Monroe Counties. The court also held that it could discern no separate geographic considerations which differentiated the Syracuse metropolitan area from that of Albany and, thus, the judges' salaries should be equalized to the level of the Albany county court judges in order to satisfy equal protection.


OUTCOME: The court granted the judges' motion for summary judgment and ordered back pay on the judges' salaries, retroactive to October 1, 1978 or first date of judicial service if that service began after October 1, 1978. The court also granted the comptroller and the state's motion for summary judgment as to counts 6, 10, 13, and 17.


HEADNOTES

Judges - Judicial Salaries - Constitutionality of Salary Differentials Based on Geographic Factors

1. Plaintiffs, Onondaga County Court Judges seeking to have the salary disparities among County Court Judges based on geographic factors resulting from the unification of the court system in 1976 declared unconstitutional as a denial of equal protection, state a cause of action for declaratory and injunctive relief under 42 USC § 1983 against the State Comptroller and the Chief Administrator of the Courts since State officials acting in their representative capacities are deemed to be "persons" for purposes of the Federal statute. In addition, although the State may not be considered a "person" under section 1983, it is nonetheless a proper defendant inasmuch as the constitutionality of the statutory judicial salary schedule is at issue.

Limitation of Actions - Six-Year Statute of Limitations - Constitutionality of Judicial Salary Differentials Based on Geographic Factors

2. The action by plaintiffs, Onondaga County Court Judges, pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 to have the salary disparities among County Court Judges based on geographic factors resulting from the unification of the court system in 1976 declared unconstitutional as a denial of equal protection is not time barred under the six-year limitations period applicable for declaratory judgments since the Statute of Limitations for the continuing harm done by denying salary parity does not begin to run while plaintiffs are still employed and the disparity remains unremedied.

Judges - Judicial Salaries - Constitutionality of Salary Differentials Based on Geographic Factors - Monetary Award

3. The action by plaintiffs, Onondaga County Court Judges, pursuant to 42 USC § 1983 to have the salary disparities among County Court Judges based on geographic factors resulting from the unification of the court system in 1976 declared unconstitutional as a denial of equal protection need not be brought in the Court of Claims since the action is not primarily for monetary damages but is rather an action for declaratory and injunctive relief in which back pay is requested as an incident to the primary relief.

Judges - Judicial Salaries - Constitutionality of Salary Differentials Based on Geographic Factors

4. Plaintiffs, Onondaga County Court Judges who are being paid at the lowest rate for County Court Judges in the State, have prevailed on their salary disparity claim under 42 USC § 1983 and must be paid at the level of Albany County Court Judges in order to satisfy equal protection in view of the similarities in caseloads, populations and cost of living in the two counties. The Third and Fourth Departments may properly be treated as a unity of judicial interest for purposes of determining whether salary differentials based on geographic factors for Judges having the same responsibilities and powers violate the equal protection guarantees of the Federal and State Constitutions. Accordingly, plaintiffs are entitled to back pay based on the salary of the Albany County Court Judges retroactive to October 1, 1978 or the first date of judicial service if that service began after October 1, 1978.

 

929 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Ruotolo v. State


Claim No. 70726, Motion No. M-43672


Court of Claims of New York


151 Misc. 2d 820; 574 N.Y.S.2d 904; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 512



July 31, 1991, Decided  
August 8, 1991, Filed


NOTICE:  [***1] [EDITED FOR PUBLICATION]


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Claimants, estate of a deceased police officer and two injured police officers, filed a claim with the court against defendant state alleging negligence and violations of N.Y. Exec. Law § 259 i-(3) and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 8004.2. The court dismissed and the appellate division affirmed. Claimants brought a motion to renew their opposition to the state's successful motion for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The police officer was killed and the two others were seriously injured as they attempted to apprehend a parolee. The parolee reported to his parole office until he was arrested. Although the parole officers were notified of the parolee's arrest they failed to report the violations to the parole board. Claimants brought an action against the state based in negligence and violations of N.Y. Exec. Law § 259 i-(3), and N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 9, § 8004.2, arguing that had the parole board been notified, it would have revoked the parolee's parole, thereby preventing their injuries. The court awarded the state summary judgment. The court's decision was affirmed on appeal. Claimants brought a motion to renew their opposition to the state's prior successful motion for summary judgment after N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 205-e was amended to apply retroactively. The court denied the motion, holding that (1) the fireman's rule applied; and (2) because the statute and regulation allegedly violated were not ones which dealt with on-premise safety and maintenance, they did not come within § 205-e and the state owed claimants no duty of care.


OUTCOME: The court denied claimants' motion.

 

930 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Biltsted


Nos. 90N040231, 90N040243, 90N040263, 90N040322, 90N040274, 90N040244, 90N040307, 90N040440


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


150 Misc. 2d 872; 574 N.Y.S.2d 272; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 441



July 31, 1991 


NOTICE:  [***1] [EDITED FOR PUBLICATION]


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants had moved to dismiss the charges of unlawful assembly filed against each of them under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.10, stemming from incidents alleged to have occurred in a park. Defendants contended that the unlawful assembly statute was facially unconstitutional, as vague and overbroad.


OVERVIEW: Defendants moved to dismiss the unlawful assembly prosecution brought against them, contending that the statute impermissibly trammeled their free speech rights. The court denied the motion. In so ruling, it noted that it was indeed possible to construe the unlawful assembly in a fashion violative of free speech. However, the court adhered to the precept that statutes are to be interpreted as being constitutional if at all possible. In this case, the unlawful assembly could be so construed, provided that it be interpreted as implicitly including the requirement that, in order to be convicted under the statute, the defendants' actions must had constituted an incitement which was both directed towards and likely to produce imminent violent and tumultuous conduct. With that definition being applied, the statute survived constitutional scrutiny, and the prosecution could go forward. Accordingly, defendants' dismissal motion was denied.


OUTCOME: Defendants' motion to dismiss was denied. Although the statute could be construed as being unconstitutional, it was not if it was assumed that language setting forth the constitutional limitations on unlawful assembly statutes was in the statute. The jury was to be so instructed.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Unlawful Assembly -- Constitutionality of Statute

The unlawful assembly statute (Penal Law § 240.10) is not facially unconstitutional as vague and overbroad if constitutional protections are read into the statute to require that, before an individual may be charged with unlawful assembly, such individual's actions must constitute an incitement which is both directed towards and likely to produce imminent violent and tumultuous conduct. When the group activity out of which the alleged offense develops can be described as involving both legal and illegal purposes and conduct, and is within the shadow of the First Amendment, the factual issue as to the alleged criminal intent must be strictly judged. Specially meticulous inquiry into the sufficiency of proof is justified and required because of the real possibility in considering group activity, characteristic of political or social movements, that the intent or acts of some participants will unfairly be imputed to all others. In cases arising under the unlawful assembly statute, juries should be instructed regarding the mandated First Amendment tests as well as the standard of strict scrutiny to be applied in their evaluation of the facts.

 

931 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Benoit


Docket No. 91K008301


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 115; 575 N.Y.S.2d 750; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 581



July 25, 1991, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:
