PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant resisted the provisions of the N.Y. City Crim. Ct. Act § 50, under which defendant's landlord, after the district attorney's office declined to prosecute, pursued private prosecution for the misdemeanors of assault in the third degree, criminal mischief in the fourth degree, menacing, and harassment.


OVERVIEW: The crimes charged against defendant were all allegedly based on the same incident for which the landlord had been charged with felony assault, an altercation between the two at the landlord's house. The court found that the N.Y. City Crim. Ct. Act § 50, constituted a violation of defendant's rights to due process and equal protection. The court held that under the circumstances, all aspects of the landlord's felony prosecution constituted Brady material to which defendant was entitled. However, the court pointed out that neither the court nor the landlord, as a private individual, was entitled to access to the district attorney's file and, unless the landlord advised the court or defense counsel, no one would know if she filed a complaint with the police regarding the incident, and failure to turn over such a report to defendant constituted a Rosario violation, which would necessitate automatic reversal of any conviction. The court found that the complaint was a tactic to delay prosecution and to pressure defendant into withdrawing her charges of assault against the landlord. The court found the statute unconstitutional and granted the motion to dismiss.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss. The presumption that the state criminal statute was constitutional was overcome. It violated the due process and equal protection clauses of the federal constitution and violated the due process clause of the state constitution.


HEADNOTES

District and Prosecuting Attorneys - Private Prosecution - Denial of Equal Protection and Due Process

 New York City Criminal Court Act § 50, which allows a private citizen to commence a prosecution for a crime without involvement of the public prosecutor, is unconstitutional as violative of defendant's rights to equal protection and due process as applied to this assault case wherein complainant instituted this private prosecution pursuant to the statute after she had been arrested for assaulting defendant based on the same incident and after the District Attorney's office had declined to accept prosecution of defendant. At the time of defendant's arraignment, complainant had been indicted for assault and criminal possession of a weapon for allegedly assaulting defendant. Prosecution by a disinterested prosecutor is a fundamental aspect of due process that defendant would be deprived of if this private prosecution is allowed to continue. A prosecution for a crime by a private citizen pursuant to the statute, after the District Attorney has declined to prosecute, makes a mockery of the criminal justice system by attempting to utilize the court for private ends. Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss is granted.

 

932 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Martinez


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


151 Misc. 2d 641; 574 N.Y.S.2d 467; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 440



July 19, 1991 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected November 7, 1991.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: In criminal prosecution of defendant for narcotics offenses, pursuant to joint state and federal investigations of defendant, defendant's counsel sought an order prohibiting prosecution from seeking forfeiture of defendant's assets, under 21 U.S.C.S. § 881, and requiring prosecution to proceed under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 13-A, which exempted attorneys' fees from forfeiture.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested and indicted in state court for several narcotics related offenses. Pursuant to 21 U.S.C.S. § 881, prosecution seized defendant's, as well as defendant's ex-wife's, bank accounts in Puerto Rico. An account within the state, in the name of defendant's ex-wife, was also seized. From the latter account, defendant's ex-wife had issued a check for defendant's attorney's fees, but the funds were seized before the check could be deposited. Defendant's attorney moved for an order prohibiting prosecution from seeking forfeiture of defendant's assets, under § 881, and requiring prosecution to proceed under N.Y. C.P.L.R. 13-A. The court denied the motion, holding that because defendant's assets were outside state's control and constitutional protections, and because the sole asset within state was in defendant's ex-wife's name and defendant did not claim it, the state had no jurisdiction over the assets, thus prosecution could proceed under state or federal forfeiture laws.


OUTCOME: Order denied; because defendant's assets were outside the state's control and constitutional protections, and because the sole asset within the state was in defendant's ex-wife's name and defendant did not claim it, the state had no jurisdiction over the assets, thus prosecution could proceed under state or federal forfeiture laws.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime -- Election to Pursue Federal Forfeiture -- Duty of Prosecutor to Set Aside In-State Federally Seized Assets for Attorney's Fees

A State prosecutor who has investigated a defendant under joint Federal and State auspices, resulting in a New York State indictment for a violation of New York's narcotics laws, may elect to pursue Federal in rem Forfeiture proceedings (21 USC § 881), rather than State in personam forfeiture proceedings (CPLR art 13-A), in order to seize out-of-State assets or assets located within the State which do not fall within the purview of the State's forfeiture law, as long as the defendant's State constitutional right to counsel of choice is protected (NY Const, art I, § 6). Where a defendant's forfeited property is located within New York State, and subject to seizure under the State's forfeiture law, the People have a duty under the State Constitution to ensure that a portion of such in-State, Federally forfeited assets is made available for payment of reasonable attorney's fees for defendant's counsel of choice or risk the imposition of sanctions including dismissal of the State prosecution. In addition, the People have an obligation to ensure that the State is reimbursed for administrative expenses from any Federally seized assets. Accordingly, since, in this case, the State could not seize defendant's bank accounts located in Puerto Rico or the New York bank account in the name of his ex-wife under the State's forfeiture law, the prosecutor cannot be required to set aside those Federally forfeited funds so that defendant can retain counsel of choice.

 

933 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Council of Trade Waste Ass'n v. New York


Index No. 9689/91


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, NEW YORK COUNTY


152 Misc. 2d 43; 574 N.Y.S.2d 883; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 554



July 12, 1991, Decided



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, petitioners' application for a preliminary injunction is denied, the petition is dismissed and the TRO shall be deemed vacated on the 10th day following receipt of service of a copy of this order with notice of entry.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner carting companies (carters) brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding with a temporary restraining order (TRO), and sought a preliminary injunction to enjoin respondent, the Commissioner of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs (commissioner) from enforcing new lower maximum rates for the collection of commercial refuse, adopted under New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 20-335(b), and from a judgment vacating the rates.


OVERVIEW: The carters objected to the new rates for refuse removal, claiming that the rate-setting procedure had violated due process, that § 20-335(b) was an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority to the commissioner, and that the new rates were irrational. The court denied the carters' petition. First, the procedures in § 20-335(b) satisfied the due process test because they adequately safeguarded the carters' interests and minimized the risk of erroneous deprivation, while serving the substantial government interest in regulating the waste removal process. In addition, the commissioner had properly followed the § 20-335(b) procedures and the record showed that the carters had been given the opportunity to participate meaningfully in the rate-making process. Second, the court found that § 20-335(b) was not an unconstitutional delegation of legislative authority to the commissioner because the legislature was entitled to commit to an administrative board the power to determine rates, and the carters had not met their burden of proving § 20-335(b) unconstitutional beyond a reasonable doubt. Last, the court found that the commissioner's determination had a rational basis.


OUTCOME: The court denied the carters' application for a preliminary injunction, dismissed the carters' petition to vacate the new refuse removal rates, and vacated the TRO, thus allowing the new rates to go into effect.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Commercial Refuse Removal - Rate- Fixing Authority of New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs - Due Process of Law

1. Respondent New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs acted lawfully in adopting new lower maximum rates that refuse carters may charge for commercial refuse collection. Petitioners, private commercial carting companies, were given the opportunity to participate meaningfully in the rate-making process and were not denied due process by respondent's refusal to allow discovery and cross-examination. The statutory scheme does not require an adjudicatory hearing but only that the rates be fixed after "public hearings" at which "interested persons" have the right to appear and give evidence (Administrative Code of City of New York § 20-335 [b]). As such, the statutory procedures for fixing the maximum rates for the removal of commercial refuse satisfy due process standards. Furthermore, the authority to fix the maximum allowable rates has been lawfully delegated to the Commissioner.

Municipal Corporations - Regulation of Commercial Refuse Removal - Rate Determination - Rational Basis

2. A determination of respondent New York City Commissioner of Consumer Affairs adopting new lower maximum rates that refuse carters may charge for commercial refuse collection has a rational basis. Respondent considered the actual operating costs of the industry, tipping fees paid to landfill operators, profits and related increased expenses, and the methods of calculation appear to be directed toward achieving the dual goal of affording petitioner refuse carters a fair rate of return while protecting the economic interests of the consumer.

 

934 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Craig


Indictment No. 6622/90


Supreme Court of New York, Criminal Term, Queens County


151 Misc. 2d 561; 573 N.Y.S.2d 390; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 423



June 26, 1991 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with one count of criminal possession of stolen property in the fourth degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 165.45(1), and two counts of falsifying business records in the second degree, N.Y. Penal Law § 175.05(3). Before the court was defendant's motion to suppress physical evidence seized by police when they conducted a warrantless administrative search of his business premises pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code §§ 435, 436.


OVERVIEW: A detective testified that his unit made random inspections of auto repair shops. The unit stopped at the shop where defendant was employed as manager. Defendant admitted to using used parts to repair cars but stated that he did not sell used parts directly to the public. Defendant produced several valid licenses. A random inspection revealed that a 1989 nose assembly from a Mustang automobile appeared to be stolen. When no papers for the parts were produced, defendant was charged with stolen property in the fourth degree and falsifying business records in the second degree. Defendant brought a motion to suppress, which the court granted. The court held that § 436, which authorized the random inspection of defendant's place of work, was violative of the constitutional protections against unreasonable searches and seizures extended to the citizens of New York through N.Y. Const. art. 1, § 12. Thus, the statements allegedly made by defendant and the search conducted by the police department were a by-product of an illegal search and seizure and therefore had to be suppressed.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to suppress physical evidence, in his criminal prosecution for criminal possession of stolen property in the fourth degree and falsifying business records in the second degree.

 

935 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York State Bankers Ass'n v. Wetzler


Index No. 91-1257


Supreme Court of New York, Cayuga County


151 Misc. 2d 684; 573 N.Y.S.2d 816; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 451



June 17, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, bankers' association and bank, filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the first cause of action in their complaint, which alleged that a provision in the State Operations Budget Bill, 1990 N.Y. Laws 50, violated the state constitution, and sought to invalidate proposed regulations. Defendant Commissioner of the Department of Taxation and Finance of the State of New York also filed a motion for partial summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: Added to the appropriations bill was the Audit Fee Provision, which directed the State Tax Commissioner to raise revenues to cover the cost of conducting audits of bank taxpayers, by imposing fees for conducting the audits. The Audit Fee Provision authorized and provided for charging bank taxpayers for their own tax audits. Plaintiffs claimed that the provision was unconstitutional and the court agreed. The court stated that a plain reading of N.Y. Const. art. VII, § 4 indicated that the provision was unconstitutional because it clearly was not a strike out of an item, a reduction of an item, nor an addition of an item of appropriation and was not an part of the original budget bill submitted to the Governor. The court held that the Audit Fee Provision was a perfect example of the ills that were intended to have been cured by § 4. This was an instance of significant and substantial legislation of large economic impact on bank taxpayers, passed without recourse to the regular legislative process, contained in a 702-page budget bill, apparently without the knowledge of one or more legislators.


OUTCOME: The court granted plaintiffs' motion for partial summary judgment, declared the Audit Fee Provision null and void as unconstitutional, and permanently enjoined the commissioner from issuing further invoices or attempting to collect or enforce invoices previously issued under the provision.

 

936 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Long Island College Hosp. v. New York State Dep't of Health


Index No. 22264/90


Supreme Court of New York, Kings County


151 Misc. 2d 370; 573 N.Y.S.2d 560; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 406



June 3, 1991 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended December 16, 1991.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner hospital sought to recover the income earned on its sinking fund and on its depreciation construction funds that respondent state department of health (department) set off against Medicaid reimbursement due the hospital.


OVERVIEW: The hospital filed suit to recover the income earned on its sinking fund and on its depreciation construction funds that the department set off against Medicaid reimbursement due the hospital. The department contended that the hospital did not timely appeal the calculation of its 1985 capital cost reimbursement and did not follow the formal route for its 1985 appeal. The hospital's accountants sent a letter stating their intention to appeal. The court held that the fundamental issue was the constitutionality of the amendment to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, § 86-1.23(b), which provided that board-designated funds and the accrual of liabilities to the funded depreciation accounts should not be recognized as funding of depreciation. The court further held that the department did not comply with § 202 of the State Administration Procedure Act with respect to the contested amendment, and that the amendment to N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. tit. 10, § 86-1.23(b) was unconstitutional. Thus, the petition was sustained and the case was remanded to the department.


OUTCOME: The court sustained the hospital's petition to recover income that was set off against Medicaid reimbursements and remanded the case for hearing.

 

937 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Kollore


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


CITY COURT OF NEW YORK, MOUNT VERNON


151 Misc. 2d 384; 573 N.Y.S.2d 357; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 830



May 15, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: During trial on allegations that he violated N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511(1)(a), the defendant objected to the prosecutor's attempt to offer into evidence affidavits by employees of the Division of Motor Vehicles (DMV). The defendant argued that the statements that notice of his suspended license was mailed to the defendant were inadmissible because they were not based on personal knowledge of the affiants.


OVERVIEW: During trial for violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 511(1)(a), which prohibited operation of a motor vehicle with a suspended license, the defendant objected to admission in evidence of documents subpoenaed from the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles. The court overruled the objection and admitted the documents into evidence. The prosecutor offered into evidence affidavits regarding the procedures used by the DMV to notify drivers by mail of suspension of a driver's license in order to meet § 511(1)(a)'s requirement of proof that an operator knew that his license was suspended. . The defendant argued that the affiants lacked personal knowledge that the notices were issued and mailed. The court held that N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 214 provided that the affiants need not have had personal knowledge concerning the notices. The court rejected the argument that § 214 violated the defendant's right of confrontation because he was denied the opportunity to cross-examine the affiants. The court held that the legislature could create a statutory exception to the hearsay rule and that § 214 could provide a proper exception because the affiants were public officials with no motive to lie.


OUTCOME: The court overruled the defendant's objection and admitted the affidavits. The court held that by statute, personal knowledge was unnecessary for the DMV affidavits at issue and that the statute did not violate the defendant's constitutional rights because the right to confrontation was not impaired by the statutory exception to the hearsay rule.


HEADNOTES

 [***1] Motor Vehicles -- Revocation or Suspension of Operator's License -- Proof of Mailing of Notice of Revocation or Suspension

1. Vehicle and Traffic Law § 214, which provides that an affidavit of a designated employee of the Department of Motor Vehicles, "setting forth the procedure for the issuance and the mailing of [a] notice of suspension or revocation" is "presumptive evidence that such notice of suspension or revocation was produced and mailed in accordance with such procedures", thereby relieving the prosecution from providing personal knowledge of the mailing of the notice, does not violate a defendant's constitutional right of confrontation. Since the affidavits of regularity made by public officials in the furtherance of public duties with no motive to distort the truth, they are sufficiently reliable and trustworthy to form exceptions to the hearsay rule. Moreover, the statute does not violate due process or deprive a defendant of a fair trial since the statute only creates a presumption of mailing which may be rebutted by the defendant.

Motor Vehicles -- Revocation or Suspension of Operator's License -- Admissibility of Abstract of Driving Record

2. In a prosecution for operating a motor vehicle with a suspended license (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 511), the Department of Motor Vehicles abstract of defendant's driving record cannot be admitted under the business records exception to the hearsay rule (CPLR 4518) to establish that defendant's license was suspended on the dates in issue. However, the abstract is admissible under CPLR 4520 and the common-law public records exception to the hearsay rule. Where a public officer is required or authorized by statute (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 354) or the nature of his duty to keep records or to make reports of acts or transactions occurring in the course of his official duty, those records or reports are admissible in evidence. Similarly, the orders of suspension or revocation are likewise admissible.

 

938 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York v. Learning Annex, Inc.


Index No. 46727/89


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


150 Misc. 2d 791; 571 N.Y.S.2d 380; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 285



May 6, 1991 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Before the court was the motion for summary judgment of defendants, course offeror and publisher, on plaintiff city's action that sought to remove certain magazine bins of defendants on a sidewalk, and sought to permanently enjoin them from installing the devices for displaying such magazines.


OVERVIEW: The city of New York had promulgated § 2.5-a of the Highway Rules and Regulations that sought to prohibit the installation of magazine bins on sidewalks for the purpose of distributing materials that were deemed commercial speech. The city then instituted an action against the course offeror and the publisher pursuant to this regulation that sought to prohibit them from displaying their magazine on the sidewalk because it was commercial speech. In response, the course offeror and the publisher had made a motion for summary judgment, and the court granted the motion. The court found the magazine was not commercial speech because it could not be said that it did no more than propose a commercial transaction, although the primary purpose of the publication was to showcase the courses that were offered. Next, the court found the city's regulation was unconstitutional because it was clearly content-based. Further, the city had not demonstrated that its interest in cleanliness, aesthetics, health, and safety could not be achieved by a regulating scheme that rationally limited the number and location of the bins rather than totally banning them.


OUTCOME: The court granted the motion for summary judgment of the course offeror and the publisher on the city's action that sought to remove certain magazines on a sidewalk, and that sought to permanently enjoin them from installing the devices for displaying such magazines.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Distribution of Magazine Via Bins on Sidewalks

A regulation of the City of New York banning the distribution of materials constituting commercial speech through bins on sidewalks does not legally authorize the city to prohibit defendants from installing devices on sidewalks for the distribution and display of a magazine which advertises defendants' courses in a wide variety of academic and life experience subjects since the publication, although containing elements of commercial speech, also contains features and articles not related to defendants' courses, and is thus entitled to full constitutional noncommercial speech protection. In any event, the content-based regulation is unconstitutional since the city has failed to demonstrate that its interest in cleanliness, aesthetics, health and safety cannot be achieved by a regulating scheme which rationally limits the number and location of the receptacles for distributing commercial speech; nor has the city established interests of sufficient magnitude to override the countervailing interests established by the First Amendment and the public's right to be informed.

 

939 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Application of Suffolk County


Index No. 91-3624


Supreme Court of New York, Suffolk County


151 Misc. 2d 378; 573 N.Y.S.2d 348; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 404



April 26, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: At a hearing held under N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 72(1), the hearing officer ruled that defendant employer had acted properly in suspending plaintiff employee. The employee appealed pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 72(3) and served subpoenas to compel production of records and appearances of medical experts. The employer filed a motion to quash.


OVERVIEW: The employer claimed that the records were not reviewable because they were not part of the first hearing and that it was abusive to require the medical experts to re-testify regarding two-year old matters. The court found the language of N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law § 72(3) ambiguous, examined its history, and determined that the appeal it authorized was a review, rather than a de novo proceeding. The court concluded that the employee was not entitled to two due process hearings and that the reviewing tribunal should focus on the record generated in the first hearing. Thus, the court granted the employer's motion to quash because the documents were irrelevant to a § 72(3) appeal and no new witnesses could be introduced at the appellate level.


OUTCOME: The court granted the employer's motion to quash the subpoenas issued in the employee's action challenging the propriety of his suspension.

 

940 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Nassau/Suffolk Neighborhood Network, Inc.


Information No. 11/90


Justice Court of New York, Village of Roslyn Harbor


151 Misc. 2d 773; 574 N.Y.S.2d 243; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 462



April 24, 1991, Decided


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff People sought to enforce Roslyn Harbor, N.Y., Local Law 1, §§ 6,7,8 (1983), an ordinance that limited soliciting, against defendant organization that canvassed homeowners about environmental issues.


OVERVIEW: The ordinance required solicitors to have a license, banned soliciting of houses on a list, and banned soliciting after dark and on weekends. After the organization canvassed the homeowners about environmental issues, the People sought to enforce the ordinance. The court ordered the organization to appear for sentencing. It was guilty of violating the licensing provisions of § 6 by soliciting in the village without first receiving the license. The village had the power to institute reasonable licensing requirements as a condition to solicitation and canvassing there. The licensing provisions were enforceable, operative, and viable. The time restriction did not pass constitutional requirements. Protection of residents against crime did not justify the preclusion of canvassing or soliciting at any time on a Saturday or Sunday. Insufficient evidence supported a prevention of crime basis for sustaining the outright ban on soliciting on weekends. The hours restriction was severable. The ordinance as written proscribed soliciting at homes listed under § 7. The organization was not given a copy of the list, so it was not guilty of violating the list provision.


OUTCOME: The court ordered the organization to appear for sentencing under the ordinance after the organization canvassed the homeowners.

 

941 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. McLeod


Docket No. 90K062127


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


150 Misc. 2d 606; 570 N.Y.S.2d 431; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 210



April 18, 1991 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law §§ 170.30(1)(a) and 170.35(1)(c) to dismiss the charge of criminal contempt in the second degree on the ground that N.Y. Penal Law § 215.50(3) violated the First Amendment's free speech guarantees and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was arrested while picketing on a public street outside of a grocery store. Defendant argued that, even though N.Y. Penal Law § 215.50(3) did not directly seek to suppress certain speech, it was still violative of the First Amendment because it served as the basis for the prosecution of those who engage in nonlabor picketing but not for those engaged in labor picketing. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the charge of criminal contempt in the second degree. The court held that N.Y. Jud. Law § 751(1) contained no exemption for cases involving or growing out of a labor dispute. Section 215.50(3) did not violate defendant's right to equal protection. The disparate treatment of picketers satisfied the substantial state interest test. The practice of collective bargaining in the Labor Law was an exercise of the police power of the state for the protection of the public welfare. It was rational for the legislature to conclude that the sanctions of the Judiciary Law were sufficient to regulate labor picketers since labor picketers were generally organized, identifiable, and answerable to a union that was also subject to the court's authority.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Contempt -- Criminal Contempt -- Nonlabor Picketing

Penal Law § 215.50 (3), which exempts from prosecution for criminal contempt in the second degree some labor demonstrators whose conduct may be in violation of a court order, is not constitutionally infirm for providing preferential treatment to labor picketing over other forms of peaceful picketing since labor picketing is punishable under a complementary statute (Judiciary Law § 750), thereby resulting in equality of treatment. The fact that a person convicted for contempt under the Penal Law is subject to greater punishment than a labor picketer convicted of Judiciary Law contempt does not violate equal protection since the disparate punishment of labor and nonlabor picketers grows out of a statutory scheme to regulate labor in private industry, a substantial State interest. It is rational for the Legislature to conclude that the sanctions of the Judiciary Law are sufficient to regulate labor picketers since such picketers are generally organized, identifiable and answerable to a union, which is also subject to the court's authority. Accordingly, defendant may be prosecuted for violating a court order prohibiting all picketing within 50 feet of a grocery store being boycotted.

 

942 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Baker


Docket No. 4595-90


City Court of New York, Mount Vernon, Westchester County


150 Misc. 2d 713; 569 N.Y.S.2d 907; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 221



April 17, 1991 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [**1] As Amended June 17, 1991.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with committing the offense of disorderly conduct in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(3). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss on the grounds that § 240.20(3) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant, with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance and alarm, in a public place allegedly stated to the police officer in a loud voice, "I'll fuck you up, get lost, you don't know who I am," which caused a crowd to gather and which caused public inconvenience, annoyance, and alarm. Defendant was charged with committing the offense of disorderly conduct in violation of § 240.20(3). Defendant filed a motion to dismiss the charge, contending that § 240.20(3) was unconstitutional. The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss, holding that § 240.20(3) was constitutional because it applied only to language that the state was permitted to restrict. Section 240.20(3) prohibited the so-called "fighting words," which by their very utterance inflicted injury or tended to incite an immediate breach of the peace. Such "fighting words" fell outside the scope of the state and federal constitutional guarantees of free expression. Also, § 240.20(3) imposed an objective standard of public inconvenience, annoyance, and alarm as opposed to the subjective standard of private or individual annoyance.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to dismiss the disorderly conduct charge.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct -- Constitutionality of Proscribing Use of "Fighting Words"

The disorderly conduct statute, which prohibits the use of abusive or obscene language in a public place "with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof" (Penal Law § 240.20 [3]), is not unconstitutionally overbroad since the statute applies only to "fighting words" that the State is permitted to restrict. Unlike the proscriptions of the harassment statute involving the use of abusive or obscene language toward "another person" (Penal Law § 240.25 [2]) which impermissibly encompass constitutionally protected speech (see, People v Dietze, 75 NY2d 47), the disorderly conduct statute is based on an objective standard which requires some public disturbance or threat to the public peace recognized by the Court of Appeals as the type of speech which can be proscribed within constitutional limits.

 

943 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Daniel J. G. v. Michael M.


Index No. 14116/90


Supreme Court of New York, Westchester County


150 Misc. 2d 784; 571 N.Y.S.2d 372; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 278



April 16, 1991 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant alleged father (father) filed a motion to dismiss the declaratory action in which plaintiff mother sought a declaration regarding the paternity agreement between the mother and father. The mother filed a cross-motion questioning the validity of the N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. V, § 516.


OVERVIEW: The mother brought a paternity action in 1982. The parties reached a binding agreement under art. V, § 516 (Act). In 1989, the mother initiated an action to void the agreement and alleged that it was reached by coercion. The hearing examiner found that there was no physical or mental disability on the mother's part at the time of the agreement. The mother then initiated a declaratory action and questioned the constitutionality of the Act. The father filed a motion to dismiss. The court denied the motion on the basis that because it was a declaratory action, a declaration rather than dismissal, was appropriate. The court stated that the Act as it applied to the parties should be viewed in the scientific light of 1982, rather than in consideration of the scientific advances in DNA testing in 1989. The court found that the heightened scrutiny test applied to the review of the Act's constitutionality. The Act encouraged fathers to settle paternity claims while achieving a binding effect and protecting mothers and children by mandating review and approval of the agreements by a court. Therefore, the Act was constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied the father's motion to dismiss and granted the mother's cross-motion to the extend that the court would make a declaration with regard to the constitutionality of the Act. The court found that the Act, as it applied to the parties in 1982, was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Children Born out of Wedlock -- Paternity Proceeding -- Constitutionality of Statutory Paternity Agreement

Family Court Act § 516, as extant and applied between the parties with respect to court-approved paternity agreements executed in 1982, in which defendant admitted paternity and committed himself to pay support but which made no provision for future modification, is constitutional. Section 516, which provides that a paternity agreement for the support of an out-of-wedlock child and the mother is binding upon them when the court approves such agreement after determining that adequate provision has been made and after notice and opportunity to be heard is given to the local welfare official, is not unconstitutional on the ground that it deprives out-of-wedlock children of the equal protection of modifiable support based on increased needs that in-wedlock children enjoy. Any present day infirmity of the statute based on the recent and rapid evolution of the genetic sciences, which can now more easily and clearly establish paternity than was possible in 1982, must be left to the Legislature. Moreover, the court must heed the constitutional protection against interference with contractual rights, especially in view of the judicial imprimatur of the order reflecting these contractual rights.

 

944 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Hope v. Perales


Index No. 21073/90


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


150 Misc. 2d 985; 571 N.Y.S.2d 972; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 351



April 15, 1991 


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY: As Amended August 20, 1991.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff pregnant women, plaintiff doctors, plaintiff clinics, and plaintiff advocacy groups challenged the constitutionality of the Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP), N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2520 et seq., which failed to provide funding for medically necessary abortions.


OVERVIEW: PCAP was enacted to provide funding for prenatal and postpartum services to women with incomes up to 185 percent of the poverty level. When a pregnant woman, who was diagnosed with sickle cell anemia, sought a medically recommended abortion, she was denied reimbursement through PCAP even though she was otherwise eligible for services under PCAP. The pregnant woman and others similarly situated, along with doctors, clinics, and advocacy groups challenged the constitutionality of PCAP. The court held that PCAP was violative of the state constitution's Due Process Clause and Equal Protection Clause but refused to fashion a remedy believing that this was best left to the legislature. PCAP violated the Due Process Clause because it conditioned the availability of medical assistance on the state-preferred choice of childbirth, which precluded an eligible woman from any real choice in the fundamental, and constitutionally protected, decision of whether to bear or beget a child. PCAP violated the Equal Protection Clause because it did not provide for equal participation in state benefits once such benefits were extended.


OUTCOME: The court held that PCAP's failure to provide funding for medically necessary abortions violated the state constitution's Due Process Clause and Equal Protection Clause; however, it refused to fashion a remedy because it believed this was best left to the legislature.


HEADNOTES

Social Services -- Medical Assistance -- Constitutionality of Prenatal Care Assistance Program -- Due Process of Law

1. The Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP) (Public Health Law § 2520 et seq., as amended by L 1989, ch 584), which provides medical assistance to pregnant women with incomes up to 185% of the Federal poverty line for certain specifically enumerated prenatal and obstetric services (Public Health Law § 2522) but excludes funds for all abortions without exception, abridges an eligible woman's constitutional right of privacy under the State's Due Process Clause (NY Const, art I, § 6) to obtain an abortion free from governmental intrusion. In excluding funds for all abortions, PCAP is facially deficient since it cannot fulfill its stated objective to combat infant mortality and promote healthier babies. The selective, conduct-oriented financing scheme of PCAP impermissibly pressures an eligible indigent woman toward childbirth, thereby abridging a constitutionally protected right and possibly creating a serious risk to the woman's life and/or health. PCAP violates the due process rights of an eligible woman for whom an abortion is medically necessary by leaving her with no real choice in the decision of whether to "bear or beget a child".

Social Services -- Medical Assistance -- Constitutionality of Prenatal Care Assistance Program -- Aid to Needy

2. The Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP) (Public Health Law § 2520 et seq., as amended by L 1989, ch 584), which provides medical assistance to pregnant women with incomes up to 185% of the Federal poverty line for certain specifically enumerated prenatal and obstetric services (Public Health Law § 2522), but excludes funds for all abortions without exception, is unconstitutional since the impact of the unequal financing scheme of PCAP undermines the substantial interest of the State in the life, health and welfare of eligible women for whom an abortion is medically required, contrary to the State's affirmative constitutional obligation to aid its needy residents and promote the public health (NY Const, art XVII, §§ 1, 3).

Social Services -- Medical Assistance -- Constitutionality of Prenatal Care Assistance Program -- Equal Protection of Laws

3. The Prenatal Care Assistance Program (PCAP) (Public Health Law § 2520 et seq., as amended by L 1989, ch 584), which provides medical assistance to pregnant women with incomes up to 185% of the Federal poverty line for certain specifically enumerated prenatal and obstetric services (Public Health Law § 2522), but excludes funds for all abortions without exception, is constitutionally defective under the State's Equal Protection Clause (NY Const, art I, § 11) because of underinclusion to the extent that PCAP restricts funding for medically necessary abortions to pregnant women who require such treatment to preserve their lives and/or health.

 

945 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Fernandez


Ind. No. 1363/91


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


150 Misc. 2d 560; 569 N.Y.S.2d 569; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 174



April 11, 1991 



DISPOSITION:  [**1] Accordingly, the evidence before the Grand Jury was insufficient to make out the crime of arson in the first degree and count one is hereby dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant brought a motion to dismiss an indictment charging him with arson in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 150.20(1).


OVERVIEW: The indictment alleged that defendant broke the windows of an automobile for ventilation, doused the interior with gasoline, drove it into the lobby of the victim's building, and set it on fire with a match. Defendant asserted that the car was not an "incendiary device" within the meaning of N.Y. Penal Law § 150.20(2), thus, sought dismissal of the charge of first degree arson. The court granted defendant's motion. The court strictly construed the statute and found that "incendiary device" did not refer to any device capable of starting a fire, but was limited to what was commonly called a "Molotov cocktail": a breakable container designed to explode or produce uncontained combustion upon impact, containing a flammable liquid with a wick or similar device. The court held that an automobile did not fall within that definition.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendant's motion to dismiss the indictment charging him with arson in the first degree.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Arson -- Incendiary Device -- Automobile

The count of an indictment charging defendants with arson in the first degree for driving an automobile, the interior of which was doused with gasoline, into a building lobby, breaking its windows, and igniting the gasoline with a book of matches, is dismissed, since the automobile does not fit the statute's specific definition of an "incendiary device" in that the automobile was not a "breakable container designed to explode or produce uncontained combustion on impact" (Penal Law § 150.20 [2]). To expand the statutory definition to include an automobile as used here would inject uncertainty into Penal Law § 150.20 and deprive defendants of their constitutional right to notice.

 

946 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Dawson v. Spring Valley


Index No. 20701/90


Supreme Court of New York, Rockland County


151 Misc. 2d 128; 572 N.Y.S.2d 1000; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 361



March 20, 1991 Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner club owner filed an action with the court and sought a judgment annulling a determination by respondent revoking a music license and declaring Spring Valley, N.Y., Code §§ 10-15 and 10-16 invalid in a case involving respondent village.


OVERVIEW: The club owner operated a bar that had been licensed to offer live or mechanically reproduced music. The court found the provisions of the village ordinances unconstitutional and held that it was unable to conclude from the record that the predominant purpose of the ordinances was other than the suppression of musical expression that the village found undesirable. The village also failed to demonstrate that the regulation was narrowly tailored to achieve such objectives. There was no showing either that there was a significant relationship between the regulation of expression and the governmental interest, or that less restrictive alternatives were inadequate to protect the governmental interest. The court was unable to save the subject ordinances through judicial construction by construing them in accordance with constitutional requirements. Given the breadth of the ordinances and the lack of clear objectives, any attempt by the court would have been tantamount to wholesale revision of the legislature's enactment, rather than prudent judicial construction.


OUTCOME: The court found two local ordinances unconstitutional in the club owner's challenge of the village's determination to revoke a music license.

 

947 of 992 DOCUMENTS


County of Rensselaer v. Regan


Index No. 7973-90, RJI No. 0190 024762


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


151 Misc. 2d 552; 573 N.Y.S.2d 345; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 425



March 20, 1991 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, counties, an association, and its coordinator, filed an action against defendants, a state comptroller and an agency commissioner, for a judgment declaring that an appropriation contained in the 1990-1991 State Operations Budget was unconstitutional. The appropriation diverted Special Traffic Options Program for Driving While Intoxicated (STOP DWI) revenues to cover shortfalls in the budget of the department of motor vehicles.


OVERVIEW: Plaintiffs challenged the appropriation on constitutional grounds. Plaintiffs argued that the legislature was prohibited from assigning the comptroller administrative duties except those which could be incidental to the performance of his constitutional mandates. The appropriation provided, in pertinent part, that the comptroller was authorized to withhold up to two percent of the monies received in any court pursuant to the STOP DWI program for costs incurred by the department in carrying its responsibilities with respect to such programs. The wording of the legislation specifically invested the comptroller with the discretion to collect any amount he saw fit, from nothing, to a maximum of two percent of the revenues received in any court within participating counties. Viewed in an historical perspective, the challenged appropriations provision would be a step back to an era preceding a 1925 constitutional amendment, which added N.Y. Const. art. V, § 1, defining the limitations of the office of comptroller. Plaintiffs were entitled to a judgment declaring that the appropriations provision was unconstitutional as a violation of that provision of the New York State Constitution.


OUTCOME: The court held the challenged appropriation unconstitutional.

 

948 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Heard v. Cuomo


Index Nos. 26498/87, 26499/87


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


150 Misc. 2d 257; 567 N.Y.S.2d 594; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 87



February 26, 1991 


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, homeless, mentally ill individuals, brought two actions, one against defendant New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation (HHC) and one against defendant governor, seeking a judgment declaring that the HHC and the governor violated their duties owing to the homeless, mentally ill individuals in failing to provide each discharged patient with a written service plan in compliance with N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 29.15(f) and (g).


OVERVIEW: The complaints against the HHC and the governor were on behalf of the homeless, mentally ill individuals who were discharged or conditionally released from hospitals without a written service plan, an assurance of residence, or other after care services. The court found that the HHC and the city failed to see that discharges from psychiatric hospitals operated by the HHC obtained appropriate housing. The court also found that it did not have to reach the question of whether there was a rational basis for the difference in benefits between patients discharged from the HHC hospitals and those leaving state facilities because other statutory provisions demonstrated that the HHC patients were to receive services similar to those required by N.Y. Mental Hyg. Law § 29.15(h). The court concluded that the HHC and the city had an obligation to see that the residences in which its discharged patients were living were adequate and appropriate to their needs. The court determined that the city of New York and its Department of Social Services should be added as party defendants so that the judgment may also be directed against them.


OUTCOME: The court found that the HHC and the city of New York jointly had an obligation to see that discharged patients from psychiatric hospitals operated by the HHC obtained appropriate housing. The court urged counsel to consent to the addition of the HHC and the city as defendants so that the judgment could be directed against them. If the amendment was not agreed to, leave was granted to the homeless mentally ill individuals to move for such relief.


HEADNOTES

Mental Health -- Placement of Discharged Mental Patients -- Appropriate Housing

1. The New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation (HHC) and the City of New York jointly have an obligation to see that dischargees from psychiatric hospitals operated by HHC obtain appropriate housing, since the success of in-patient care and treatment given to mentally ill persons is in large part dependent on their being able after discharge to reside in stable housing with available supportive services, and a discharge to the street, a congregate public shelter or a "flop house" would not constitute effective "rehabilitation" required to be given to such persons pursuant to Mental Hygiene Law § 7.07 (c), as those places are not appropriate residences in light of the dangers involved in such living arrangements. Moreover, as a result of the implementation and monitoring requirements of Mental Hygiene Law § 29.15 (h), the State has an obligation to see that dischargees from psychiatric facilities operated by the State Office of Mental Health obtain "adequate and appropriate" housing.

Injunctions -- When Injunctive Relief Appropriate -- Housing for Mental Health  Dischargees

2. In light of the acknowledgement by the State that, as a result of the implementation and monitoring requirements of Mental Hygiene Law § 29.15 (h), it has an obligation to see that dischargees from psychiatric facilities operated by the State Office of Mental Health obtain "adequate and appropriate" housing, and that public shelters are not appropriate places to send patients, the court shall not issue an "obey the law" type of injunction against it where the proof showed that the number of instances where some of its patients did go to a shelter or other inappropriate residence was not great. Moreover, the improper discharges resulted when patients left without leave, were released upon presenting a 72-hour letter demanding discharge, were discharged by court order, or refused offered residential recommendations (see, Mental Hygiene Law § 9.13 [b]; § 9.31 [c]).

Mental Health -- Placement of Discharged Mental Patients -- Municipal Dischargees to Receive Services Similar to State Dischargees

3. Dischargees from psychiatric hospitals operated by the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation (HHC) are to receive services similar to those received pursuant to Mental Hygiene Law § 29.15 (h) by dischargees from State facilities, since HHC hospitals, being subject to licensure by the State Office of Mental Health, are governed by subdivisions (m) and (n) of Mental Hygiene Law § 29.15 and, consequently, are required "to cooperate" with the city Department of Social Services in the "preparation and implementation" of discharge plans required under Mental Hygiene Law § 29.15 (f). Accordingly, although subdivision (n) does not contain the specificity of subdivision (h), the mandate of the two provisions is similar and, hence, more than merely giving a patient a piece of paper is required of HHC: the City of New York and HHC have an obligation to see that the residences in which its discharged patients are living are adequate and appropriate to their needs.

Mental Health -- Placement of Discharged Mental Patients -- Injunction Directing Municipal Agency to Comply with Mental Hygiene Law

4. Inasmuch as the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation (HHC) has an obligation to see that dischargees from its psychiatric hospitals obtain "adequate and appropriate" housing, it is appropriate for the court to direct compliance with that mandate since HHC, as an agency of government, has not satisfied the nondiscretionary duty imposed upon it by Mental Hygiene Law § 29.15. Moreover, in light of the social emergency emanating from the homeless crisis in New York City, the court would, even if the statute were not interpreted as imposing said mandate, direct that similar relief be granted. Accordingly, judgment shall be settled declaring that HHC has violated its obligations with respect to discharge planning under Mental Hygiene Law § 29.15 (f), (g), (m) and (n), and requiring compliance; however, in view of the fact that there is not now in existence sufficient available housing to enable HHC to immediately fully comply, the judgment shall provide for implementation over a period of time.

 

949 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Kingston v. Vadala


Docket No. P-482-90


Family Court of New York, Onondaga County


150 Misc. 2d 52; 567 N.Y.S.2d 586; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 68



February 15, 1991 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, it is ordered that the respondent's motion to dismiss is hereby denied; and it is further ordered that respondent shall pay petitioner the sum of $ 50 per week as and for temporary support of the child, the payments to commence within seven days of service of this order upon his attorney; and it is further ordered that the matter is referred to the Hearing Examiner on the issue of permanent support; counsel are to appear before Hearing Examiner Robert Jenkins, Esq. on March 5, 1991 at 9:30 A.M. for further proceedings.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner mother filed a petition alleging that respondent father was the father of her child and sought an order of filiation and support. The father denied the allegations. The court made a preliminary determination that certain aspects of the case had raised questions about the constitutionality of N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 516.


OVERVIEW: The mother had filed a petition alleging that the father was the father of her son. A compromise agreement settling the claim of support had been consented to by the Commissioner of Social Services (DSS), the assignor of the mother, and the father. There was no record of any affidavit of service of the order upon the mother. The father filed a motion to dismiss the mother's petition pursuant to § 516, on the grounds that a previous order had approved a compromise agreement regarding support of the child. On the return date for argument on the motion to dismiss, the father voluntarily withdrew his denial of paternity and entered an admission, but argued that so much of the petition as sought an order of support should be dismissed. An order of filiation was issued and the court made a preliminary determination that certain aspects of the case had raised questions about the constitutionality of §516. The court denied the motion to dismiss the mother's petition for support. The court found that § 516 as applied to the facts of the case was unconstitutional, in that the mother had been denied due process of law when the earlier compromise agreement had been approved.


OUTCOME: The court denied the father's motion to dismiss; and ordered that the father pay the mother an amount per week for temporary support of the child.


HEADNOTES

Parent and Child -- Support -- Notice to Out-of-Wedlock Mother of Submission of Settlement Proposal Regarding Father's Support Obligations to Court for Approval

In a filiation and support proceeding by petitioner mother against respondent putative father, respondent's motion to dismiss the petition pursuant to Family Court Act § 516 (c) on grounds that a prior, court-approved compromise agreement entered into between respondent and the Department of Social Services (to whom petitioner assigned her support rights as a condition of receiving public assistance) regarding the support of this child precludes maintenance of the instant proceeding, is denied. Petitioner's assignment of her support rights to the Department of Social Services extends only to those rights during the period the child continues to receive public assistance; there is nothing in the applicable law which requires the assignor-mother to waive her right to support from the father, including the right to independent counsel during the pendency of the paternity proceeding and a de novo hearing on child support once the child ceases to receive public assistance. Retention and exercise of these rights is meaningless unless the assignor-mother is given notice of and an opportunity to be heard in any proceeding for judicial approval of a compromise agreement. While there is no statutory requirement in Family Court Act § 516 that the assignor-mother be given notice and an opportunity to be heard in any proceeding for judicial approval of a compromise agreement between the Department of Social Services and the putative father, such a requirement must be read into the statute in order to render it constitutionally sound and consistent with the tenets of due process.

 

950 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Capaldo


Ind. No. 7069/90


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


151 Misc. 2d 114; 572 N.Y.S.2d 989; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 363



February 13, 1991, Decided


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Eight defendants challenged their joint indictment by a grand jury (New York) for enterprise corruption in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 460.20.


OVERVIEW: Eight defendants were indicted on 153 counts arising out of an investigation into the activities of various union officials, painting contractors and alleged organized crime members. Defendants were jointly indicted in the first count with enterprise corruption, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 460.20. Defendants moved to dismiss the charge contending that the statute was unconstitutionally vague, and that the evidence presented to the grand jury was insufficient to support the charge. The appellate court denied the motion and upheld the indictment. It held that N.Y. Penal Law § 460.20 was neither vague nor overbroad. The court further found that the evidence was legally sufficient to sustain the indictment where it held that the right of a union official her position was property within the meaning of the larceny statute, N.Y. Penal Law § 155.00(1).


OUTCOME: The court denied defendants' motion to dismiss their joint indictment for enterprise corruption where it found that the criminal statute was neither vague nor overbroad, and where the court held that the evidence was legally sufficient to sustain the indictment.

 

951 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Richmond Hill Block Ass'n v. Dinkins


Index No. 22480/90


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


149 Misc. 2d 654; 567 N.Y.S.2d 584; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 91



February 11, 1991 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the petition is denied. The cross motion to dismiss is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, the community organizations, the residents, and the political representatives of an area in Queens, New York, filed a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding to vacate a determination by respondents, the Mayor of the City of New York, the Fire Department of the City of New York, and the Fire Department Commissioner, to close a fire station in an area of Queens.


OVERVIEW: The City of New York had a budget crisis, so the Mayor determined that budget reductions for all municipal services, including the Fire Department, were necessary. The Fire Department, by its Commissioner, elected to terminate a fire station in Queens based on its determination that surrounding fire companies could adequately protect the lives and property of the affected community. Petitioners filed an Article 78 proceeding to vacate respondents' determination, contending that it was arbitrary and capricious because nonessential municipal services should have been eliminated before essential services and that the affected community would not be afforded adequate protection. Respondents filed a cross motion to dismiss the petition. The court determined that the dispute was not justiciable, and even if it was justiciable, the court could not reverse respondents' determination because the court was not permitted to substitute its judgment for that of the body or officer empowered by statute to issue the determination, and the determination was based on objective data available to the Commissioner, sound fire protection principles, and was neither arbitrary nor capricious.


OUTCOME: The court denied the petition filed by the community organizations, the residents, and the political representatives and granted respondents' cross motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Justiciable Questions -- Municipal Services

A municipal government's decision to address a budget crisis by closing a firehouse is not justiciable, since the management and operation of municipal government, which require decisions regarding the quality and quantity of municipal services, should not be preempted by the judiciary but left in the control of duly elected officials. Accordingly, respondent city officials' motion to dismiss a CPLR article 78 petition to vacate their determination to close a firehouse is granted. Moreover, even if the issue under consideration were justiciable, the standard of review pursuant to article 78 would not require reversal of the determination, since the determination was based on objective data and sound fire protection principles and was neither arbitrary nor capricious.

 

952 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Quirk v. Regan


Index No. 6386/90


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


148 Misc. 2d 300; 565 N.Y.S.2d 422; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 11



January 15, 1991 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Pursuant to N.Y. Civ. Serv. Law art. 14, petitioners, the collective bargaining representatives to the state's court employees, sought to enjoin respondents from carrying out an alternative payment plan whereby certain court employees' wages were withheld. Petitioners sought a declaration that 1990 N.Y. Laws § 375, which directed the withholding of wages from nonjudicial employees, was a violation of the state's constitution and laws.


OVERVIEW: The employees who wages were being withheld pursuant to 1990 N.Y. Laws § 375 had had no opportunity to negotiate with respondents prior to their wages being lagged; other employees, under previous collective bargaining agreements, had been able to negotiate such withholding directives. Petitioners thus contended that the lag provisions, as passed, were in violation of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 17 and contrary to unfair labor practices and the right to bargain collectively under the state's Taylor Law. For an employer to withhold wages and use the employees' moneys for its own use conflicted with the basic concepts of labor law. The withholding of petitioners' wages for respondents' use compelled petitioners, who were public employees, to be respondents' financier. The court further noted that the lag provision was a tax designed and structured against the wage earner exclusively, to meet the needs of the general welfare. The financing by lag payments was simply a plan to deprive the workers from receiving their earned income. The court therefore declared 1990 N.Y. Laws § 375 to be unconstitutional, and determined that petitioners were entitled to recover the withheld payments.


OUTCOME: The court declared the challenged legislative provision to be unconstitutional, and concluded that petitioners were entitled to their respective payments in compliance with the former law.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Nonjudicial Personnel -- Constitutionality of Lag Payroll

Section 375 of Laws of 1990 (ch 190), which imposed a lag payroll without prior negotiation on certain nonjudicial employees of the Unified Court System who were subject to an existing collective bargaining agreement that did not provide for the lagged payment of such employees' wages, is unconstitutional.

 

953 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Debevoise & Plimpton v. New York State Dep't of Taxation & Finance


Index No. 5298/89


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


149 Misc. 2d 571; 565 N.Y.S.2d 973; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 7



January 8, 1991 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended March 26, 1991.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff tenant filed a declaratory judgment action against defendant State Department of Taxation and Finance, challenging the right of the department to impose and collect sales tax on payments by the tenant to its landlord for overtime heating, ventilation and air conditioning. The tenant moved and the department cross-moved for summary judgment.


OVERVIEW: The tenant sought an order declaring that the imposition of the New York State sales tax on heating, ventilation and air conditioning services provided by the landlord at the subject premises was invalid. The state sought dismissal of the complaint on the grounds that the tenant had failed to exhaust administrative remedies and because the action was not ripe for adjudication because there was a need to make a full record as to factual issue. The court held that: (1) the doctrine of exhaustion of administrative remedies was inapplicable; (2) a declaratory judgment action was not subject to dismissal merely because the tenant was not entitled to the declaration it sought; (3) there was a justiciable controversy between the parties as to their rights and duties; (4) the tenant had made a prima facie showing that the imposition of commercial occupancy rent tax and sales tax on its overtime heating, ventilation and air conditioning payments constituted double taxation; and (5) the provision of overtime heating, ventilation and air conditioning services incidental to the provision of rented premises was not subject to a sales tax under N.Y. Tax Law §1105 (b).


OUTCOME: The court granted summary judgment to the tenant and declared that the provision of overtime heating, ventilation and air conditioning services incidental to the provision of rented premises was not subject to a sales tax under N.Y. Tax Law § 1105(b).


HEADNOTES

Judgments -- Summary Judgment -- Opportunity to "Make Record"

1. In a declaratory judgment action by plaintiff, a commercial tenant, challenging the right of defendant State Department of Taxation and Finance to impose and collect sales tax on payments by plaintiff to its landlord for overtime heating, ventilation and air conditioning as being beyond defendant's statutory grant of power (Tax Law § 1105 [b]), defendant's argument that the action is not ripe for adjudication, because there is a need to make a full record, is inappropriate in the context of plaintiff's motion for summary judgment. Defendant has failed to demonstrate the existence of a genuine triable issue of fact in opposition to plaintiff's motion for summary judgment. Merely requesting an opportunity to "make a record" without identifying any particulars as to what defendant hopes to discover or why it thinks the facts may be other than as attested to by plaintiff's expert is insufficient, and is tantamount to an impermissible request for a "fishing expedition".

Administrative Law -- Failure to Exhaust Administrative Remedies -- Challenge to Power to Impose Sales Tax

2. An action by plaintiff, a commercial tenant, challenging the right of defendant State Department of Taxation and Finance to impose and collect sales tax on payments by plaintiff to its landlord for overtime heating, ventilation and air conditioning as being beyond defendant's statutory grant of power (Tax Law § 1105 [b]), will not be dismissed on the ground that plaintiff failed to exhaust administrative remedies. The doctrine of exhaustion of administrative remedies is inapplicable where, as here, an agency's action is challenged as wholly beyond the agency's grant of power.

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Overtime Heating, Ventilation and Air Conditioning

3. Defendant State Department of Taxation and Finance may not impose and collect a sales tax on payments by plaintiff, a commercial tenant, to its landlord for overtime heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) since overtime HVAC does not constitute a sale of gas, electricity, refrigeration or steam service as a matter of statutory construction. The legislative intent in imposing a sales tax on "electric, refrigeration and steam service of whatever nature" (Tax Law § 1105 [b]) was to tax all sales of utilities when sold as commodities or articles of commerce, not to tax the provision of heat and air conditioning to business premises but rather the products that are used to produce these results. In addition, since plaintiff has already been subjected to New York City commercial rent or occupancy tax for its overtime HVAC payments, plaintiff should not be subjected to double taxation on its HVAC payments by imposition of a sales tax pursuant to section 1105 (b) in the absence of any specific provisions or statements of legislative intent evidencing that such services were also intended to be subject to a sales tax.

 

954 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Craft


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


County Court of New York, Monroe County


149 Misc. 2d 223; 564 N.Y.S.2d 695; 1991 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 4



January 2, 1991 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] Leave to Appeal Granted June 17, 1991.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner State appealed the order of the City Court of Rochester (New York) dismissing criminal informations charging respondents with violations of N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01 governing exposure of a person.


OVERVIEW: Respondents were charged with violating N.Y. Penal Law § 245.01 governing exposure of a person. The lower court found the statute constitutional in general, but unconstitutional as applied to respondents. Petitioner State appealed. Respondents claimed that because the statute denied exercise of their First Amendment right of freedom of speech, it was unconstitutional. The court found that respondents' nudity, in the context in which it occurred, was sufficiently expressive to rise to the level of communication of an idea. It held, however, that § 245.01 could impinge on that chosen form of speech. The State was not foreclosed from regulating activity, provided that the statute furthered an important or substantial governmental interest unrelated to the suppression of free expression, and the incidental restriction on alleged First Amendment freedoms was no greater than essential to furtherance of that interest. The court upheld the statute in issue as a permissible state exercise in regulating a person's First Amendment right to express an opinion on the basis of time, place, and manner. It therefore reversed the lower court and remitted the matter for further proceedings.


OUTCOME: The decision of the lower court dismissing the informations against respondents was reversed because the penal statute in issue was not unconstitutional as applied to respondents.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Gender Based Bias -- Public Nudity

1. The State may treat males and females differently and not violate the Equal Protection Clauses of the United States and New York Constitutions provided the unequal treatment is substantially related to the achievement of an important governmental concern. Accordingly, since the State's objective in the passage of Penal Law § 245.01, which applies unequally to women on the basis of their gender by prohibiting exposure of their breasts in public while not prohibiting a similar display by men, is substantially related to the achievement of the important governmental concern of protecting the public from invasions of its sensibilities, the statute is constitutional as written.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Actions as Speech -- Public Nudity

2. Actions can be deemed sufficiently expressive as to rise to the level of communication of an idea, thus giving rise to constitutional free speech considerations. Accordingly, since the respondents' public removal of their shirts occurred in the context of a preannounced protest against the public nudity statute (Penal Law § 245.01) which treats males and females differently, it was sufficiently expressive as to rise to the level of communication of an idea and consideration must be given as to whether enforcement of that statute can constitutionally be permitted to impinge upon this chosen form of speech.

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Governmental Regulation of Actions Constituting Speech -- Public Nudity

3. Actions constituting speech may be regulated or even prohibited if such limitation furthers an important or substantial governmental interest, if the governmental interest is unrelated to the suppression of free expression, and if the incidental restriction on alleged First Amendment freedoms is no greater than is essential to the furtherance of that interest. Accordingly, since the prohibition of public nudity is within the State's police power and furthers an important governmental interest, and since the statute prohibiting public nudity (Penal Law § 245.01) is not directed toward suppressing the expression of public opinion concerning nudity, but instead neutrally prohibits all public displays of nudity regardless of the actor's purpose, the statute is constitutional as applied to the respondents, who violated the statute by removing their shirts to protest the statute's different treatment of males and females with respect to exposure of their breasts.

Crimes -- Public Exposure

4. It is the general purpose of a criminal statute to give fair warning of the nature of the conduct proscribed, while at the same time preventing arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement by demanding boundaries sufficiently distinct for police to fairly administer the law. Penal Law § 245.01, which prohibits exposure of private or intimate parts of the body in public, and provides that the private or intimate parts of a female include that portion of the breast which is below the top of the aureola, satisfies that standard.

 

955 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Mulcahy


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Mount Vernon, Westchester County


149 Misc. 2d 419; 564 N.Y.S.2d 974; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 657



December 21, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with a violation of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 401 in that he owned and operated a pickup truck over and along a public highway without first having registered the vehicle in accordance with the processes of article 14 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law.


OVERVIEW: Defendant contended that his vehicle was registered by the Commissioner of Motor Vehicles as a passenger vehicle, and that he was not in violation of article 14. The court rejected defendant's vagueness argument finding that it was clear from N.Y. Veh. & Traf. Law § 401 that he had notice that his vehicle was improperly registered. The court found that the pickup truck was not altered extensively, and that defendant testified that the vehicle did not come within the definition of "suburban," which was the classification under which it was registered under § 401(6). Defendant testified that he did not recall what information he provided the Department of Motor Vehicles at the time of registration nor did he recall whether or not he stated in his application that the vehicle in question was in fact a truck or a pickup. The court found that defendant was fully aware that his vehicle was improperly registered as a "suburban" vehicle, that it should have been registered as a commercial vehicle, and that the "suburban" registration issued to him was based on the representations made by him to the Department.


OUTCOME: The court found defendant guilty as charged of owning and operating a pickup truck over and along a public highway without first having registered the vehicle.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Registration -- Constitutionality of Registration Statute -- Registration of Pickup Truck

The fact that the Department of Motor Vehicles allowed defendant to register his pickup truck with passenger plates rather than commercial plates does not prevent his conviction for operating an improperly registered vehicle in violation of section 401 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law, since defendant was fully aware that the vehicle was improperly registered and the registration was issued on the basis of defendant's representations on the registration application forms (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 401 [1] [b]). Moreover, the statute is not unconstitutional on grounds of vagueness or failure to provide notice since defendant had clear notice from the statutory definition of both "truck" and "suburban" motor vehicle that his pickup truck was improperly registered as a "suburban" vehicle (Vehicle and Traffic Law § 401 [6]) when it should have been registered as a commercial vehicle.

 

956 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Estate of Cooper


File No. 1718/88


Surrogate's Court of New York, Kings County


149 Misc. 2d 282; 564 N.Y.S.2d 684; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 639



December 19, 1990 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner, decedent's mate, sought a judgment declaring him to have the rights of a surviving spouse, pursuant to N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1, against the decedent's will as the survivor of a homosexual relationship.


OVERVIEW: The decedent's mate alleged that he and the decedent had lived together in a spousal-type relationship in New York for approximately four years and that their relationship was identical to that of husband and wife. He further alleged that the only reason they were not legally married was that they could not obtain a marriage license. The court held that the decedent's mate did not have a right or standing to elect against the decedent's will under N.Y. Est. Powers & Trusts Law § 5-1.1. It also held that it was not unconstitutional to prohibit persons of the same sex from entering into marriage with each other. New York had a compelling interest in fostering the traditional institution of marriage for procreation and for providing status and stability to the environment in which children were raised. Also, there was no authority in any United States jurisdiction either authorizing same-sex marriages or elevating homosexual unions to the same level achieved by marriage.
