Further, the restriction on the right to marry people of the same sex had a rational basis and did not offend the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment or due process.


OUTCOME: The court declared that the decedent's mate did not have the rights of a surviving spouse against the decedent's will.


HEADNOTES

Wills -- Elective Share of Surviving Spouse -- Homosexual Relationship

The survivor of a homosexual relationship, alleged to be a "spousal relationship", cannot claim spousal rights against the decedent's will pursuant to, or similar to those granted by, EPTL 5-1.1. Persons of the same sex have no constitutional rights to enter into marriage with each other and neither due process nor equal protection of law provisions are violated by prohibiting such marriages. Further, to grant rights to the survivor of a homosexual "spousal relationship" similar to those granted to a surviving husband or wife by the Legislature would amount to impermissible judicial legislation and be contrary to the public policy expressed by the Legislature. Accordingly, notwithstanding the fact that decedent and petitioner, members of the same sex, allegedly lived in a spousal-type relationship, kept a common home, shared expenses, had a physical relationship and were recognized as spouses by their friends, those factors do not give rise to any right of election on the part of petitioner pursuant to EPTL 5-1.1 with respect to the decedent's will.

 

957 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Keith H.


Docket No. S-44-90, Family Unit No. 09949


Family Court of New York, Dutchess County


150 Misc. 2d 470; 569 N.Y.S.2d 555; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 726



December 14, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Respondent student filed a motion to dismiss the request filed by petitioner principal that the court find that the student was a person in need of supervision (PINS), as provided in N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act art. 7.


OVERVIEW: The principal alleged that the student was incorrigible and beyond the control of his parent and other lawful authority. The principal also alleged that the student was involved in a physical confrontation in the school hallway with another student, the student was involved in a number of other specific incidents at the school, and that he walked out of a PINS assessment and refused to return to complete the assessment. The entire factual basis for the petition was stated to be "upon information and belief," and the source of that belief was stated to be the school records. No supporting depositions or other documents were annexed or made a part of the petition. The student filed a motion to dismiss the petition on the ground that it did not contain any nonhearsay allegations that related to the misconduct charged. The court granted the motion. The court held that the distinction between the liberty interests at stake in a juvenile delinquency proceeding when compared to those at stake in a PINS proceeding, was not sufficiently great to permit the student to be prosecuted on a petition based purely on hearsay allegations of misconduct.


OUTCOME: The court granted the student's motion to dismiss the request filed by the principal that it find that the student was a PINS, as provided in the Act.


HEADNOTES

Infants -- Persons in Need of Supervision -- Sufficiency of Petition -- Nonhearsay Allegations

The distinction between the liberty interests at stake in a juvenile delinquency (JD) proceeding when compared to those at stake in a proceeding involving a person in need of supervision (PINS) is not sufficiently great to permit a juvenile alleged to be a PINS to be prosecuted on a petition based on allegations set forth in a less reliable form than that required by the New York statutory scheme established for a child alleged to be a JD. Thus, the failure of section 732 of the Family Court Act to require that the allegations of misconduct in a PINS petition be in nonhearsay form violates the respondent's equal protection rights, but does not compel that the statute be declared unconstitutional since the deficiency can be cured by reading the fundamental requirements of Family Court Act § 311.2 into article 7. Accordingly, the PINS petition, filed by petitioner school principal, which is based upon information and belief and refers to school records that are not attached, is jurisdictionally defective and, since the court lacks the power to authorize an amendment under such circumstances, the petition is dismissed without prejudice to further submissions in proper and sufficient form.

 

958 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Alexander


Docket No. 90K041731


Criminal Court of the City of New York, Kings County


149 Misc. 2d 361; 565 N.Y.S.2d 681; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 689



December 12, 1990 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Amended April 1, 1991.



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the defendant's motion to dismiss pursuant to CPL 170.30 and 170.35 must be denied and the matter is continued for trial.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant sought dismissal of criminal charges for endangering the welfare of a child under N.Y. Penal Law §260.10.


OVERVIEW: Defendant moved to dismiss, for legal insufficiency, charges brought under N.Y. Penal Law § 260.10 for endangering the welfare of a child. The charges stemmed from defendant's action in pointing a gun at the child's mother when the child was at her side. The court denied the request. It found that the State's allegations were sufficient to establish a prima facie charge of endangering the welfare of a child, based on the requirements of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law. §§100.15, 100.40. Providing further detail was the function of a bill of particulars. Accordingly, defendant's motion to dismiss was denied, and the matter was continued for trial.


OUTCOME: Defendant's motion to dismiss was denied because the accusatory instrument made out a prima facie case of acts endangering the welfare of a child.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Endangering Welfare of Child -- Sufficiency of Accusatory Instrument

An accusatory instrument, the factual portion of which alleges that defendant pointed a gun at and threatened the complaining witness while her 11-year-old daughter was standing next to her, is legally sufficient to establish a prima facie charge of endangering the welfare of a child (Penal Law § 260.10), thus necessitating denial of defendant's motion to dismiss. While certain cases have held that section 260.10 was designed only to protect children from persons exerting some influence or control over them and is not applicable to behavior directed towards others no matter how detrimental the ultimate effect, there is no such limitation in the statute. Indeed, the history of section 260.10 makes clear that it is intended to protect minors from more than just physical risk. The facts alleged sufficiently satisfy section 260.10's mental culpability requirement that defendant "knowingly act in a manner likely to be injurious to the physical, mental or moral welfare of a child." It takes little imagination, in this instance, to be aware that pointing a gun at a person with the threat of using it will also endanger, frighten and traumatize a child standing alongside.

 

959 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Payne


Docket Nos. 90N779778W, 90N778778W, 90N776473W


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


150 Misc. 2d 34; 565 N.Y.S.2d 389; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 670



December 10, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was charged with violating New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 27-4249, by unlawfully setting a fire in public when he burned a cloth flag outside a courthouse; he argued that the summons should be dismissed on the grounds of unconstitutionality.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with setting a fire in public in violation of New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 27-4249, after burning a cloth flag in front of a courthouse. He contended that the summons should be dismissed because its issuance impermissibly precluded him from exercising his constitutionally protected right to burn the flag as a form of protest, and further that § 27-4249 was impermissibly vague and overbroad. The court dismissed the summons. It held that as applied to defendant's conduct, the provision was unconstitutional because in the absence of any real threat to public safety, the police had no legitimate interest unrelated to the suppression of expression for issuing the summons. The court further held that the provision was not substantially broad, nor was it void for vagueness.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the summons charging defendant with setting a fire in public.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Freedom of Speech -- Flag Burning

Section 27-4249 (a) of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which makes it "unlawful for any person to kindle, build, maintain or use a fire upon any land * * * within the jurisdiction" of the city, although not facially invalid or impermissibly vague and overbroad, is nonetheless unconstitutional as applied to defendant's conduct in burning a flag as a form of protest in front of the criminal courthouse, in the absence of any proof of a compelling public safety reason for the issuance of summonses to defendant charging violations of section 27-4249 (a). The act of flag burning in order to convey a message is a form of political expression that is entitled to constitutional protection. The primary interest of the police in issuing the summonses to defendant was to suppress defendant's politically charged acts of burning the flag. Such a purpose is inconsistent with the First Amendment and cannot be used as a basis for a criminal prosecution. Although the police may have some right to regulate the time, place and manner of a flag burning, they may not prohibit it entirely merely because it occurs on public property.

 

960 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Empire State Bldg. Co. v. New York State Dep't of Taxation & Finance


Index No. 6788/90


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


150 Misc. 2d 747; 570 N.Y.S.2d 419; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 733



December 5, 1990 


NOTICE:  [***1] [EDITED FOR PUBLICATION]


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayer filed the motions for summary judgment and for a preliminary injunction tolling the period within which it could challenge the proposed statement of tax adjustment and the notice of determination. Defendant New York State Department of Taxation and Finance (department) filed the motion to dismiss the action for declaratory judgment regarding the taxation of electricity rent charges paid by the taxpayer's tenants.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer, a commercial landlord, brought the action for a declaratory judgment to determine whether the department was authorized to assess sales taxes for electricity rent charges paid by the taxpayer's tenants. Considering the taxpayer's motions for a preliminary injunction and summary judgment and the department's motion to dismiss the case, the court first held that the taxpayer was not required to exhaust administrative remedies before litigating the matter in court. The taxpayer was challenging the constitutionality of the tax and the department's authority to issue the tax. The court then noted that under state statutes, the sale of electricity and commercial rents were taxed separately. Construing the statutes liberally in favor of the taxpayer and to avoid double taxation, the court concluded that the department was not authorized to impose sale tax on the redistribution of electricity by the landlord to its tenants, who paid commercial occupancy tax as well. This would have amounted to double taxation. The court granted the taxpayer's motions for summary judgment and a preliminary injunction and denied the department's motion to dismiss the action.


OUTCOME: The court granted the taxpayer's motions for summary judgment and for a preliminary injunction tolling the period for challenging the notice of determination and the proposed statement of tax adjustment. The court also denied the department's motion to dismiss the action for a declaratory judgment to determine whether the department properly taxed redistributed electricity rent charges paid by the taxpayer's tenants.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Exhaustion of Administrative Remedies -- Statutory Exclusive Remedy Provisions

1. Plaintiff, the lessor of commercial office space, may maintain a declaratory judgment action challenging the imposition or amount of tax on rent inclusion charges paid by commercial tenants for nonmetered electricity without first exhausting administrative remedies and then bringing a CPLR article 78 proceeding, since plaintiff is not challenging the amount of the tax allegedly owed, but, rather, is challenging the right of the defendant taxing authorities to impose and collect the sales tax, an issue that is one of pure statutory analysis that can be decided as a matter of law. Similarly, since plaintiff is challenging the applicability or constitutionality of a taxing statute and is not challenging the correctness of the amount of defendants' determination of its tax liability, the exclusive remedy provisions of Tax Law § 1140 do not preclude a declaratory judgment action.

Taxation -- Sales and Use Taxes -- Nonmetered Electricity Rent Inclusion Charges

2. The State and municipal taxing authorities lack the statutory authority to impose and collect sales tax on the nonmetered electricity rent inclusion charges paid by plaintiff's commercial tenants since the imposition of sales tax on the redistribution of electricity by plaintiff to its tenants, who pay New York City's commercial occupancy rent tax as well, would amount to double taxation. Defendant taxing authorities have failed to overcome the presumption against such double taxation, particularly in the face of the undisputed practice over several decades of not having treated the redistribution of unmetered electricity by a landlord to commercial tenants as a "sale" or "resale" (Tax Law § 1105 [b]).

 

961 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lane v. Town of Oyster Bay


Index No. 20294/90


Supreme Court of New York, Nassau County


149 Misc. 2d 237; 564 N.Y.S.2d 655; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 628



November 27, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Based upon the foregoing opinion, the application for an annulment of the referendum and underlying proceedings is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner property owners sought to set aside the result of a referendum conducted in respondent Town of Oyster Bay, which was and approved by the voters, and which was held to determine whether voters supported an extension of a sanitation collection district of the Town to a circumscribed area.


OVERVIEW: The owners sought to set aside the result of a referendum conducted in a Town. The referendum was held to determine whether voters supported an extension of a sanitation collection district of the town to a circumscribed area. The referendum resulted in approval of the extension by a majority of those who voted. The owners argued that procedural irregularities caused a problem in identifying those who voted for the referendum. The court concluded that the statutory restriction of N.Y. Town Law § 209e(3) was applicable, and the votes cast by non-landowners contaminated the election result, making it impossible to determine whether a majority of those properly entitled to vote approved the proposition. The court held that ownership of taxable real property was a requirement for voting in the special election, and that resolution required annulment of the referendum.


OUTCOME: The court granted the owners' application for an annulment of the referendum and underlying proceedings.


HEADNOTES

Elections -- Special Election -- Qualifications for Voting -- Landowners -- Referendum on Extension of Sanitation Collection District

1. The requirement contained in Town Law § 209-e (3) that a voter in a special election or referendum concerning the extension of an improvement district subject to the provisions of Town Law article 12-A be an owner of real property situate in the proposed extended district passes constitutional muster since passage of the extension would have a disproportionate effect or special burden on such landowners, whose property alone would be subject to assessments and charges for the benefits conferred, and also to liens for delinquencies. Accordingly, a special election on extending a sanitation collection district was invalid where nonlandowners were permitted to vote, since those votes contaminated the election result, making it impossible to determine whether a majority of those properly entitled to vote approved the proposition.

Elections -- Special Election -- Qualifications for Voting -- Citizenship -- Referendum on  Extension of Sanitation Collection District

2. Restriction of the franchise in a special election to the owners of taxable real property in a proposed extended improvement district subject to the provisions of Town Law article 12-A does not operate to extend the franchise to noncitizens who own such real property, since noncitizens may not vote in contravention of Election Law § 5-102 (1), which provides that no person shall be qualified to vote at any election unless he is a citizen of the United States and 18 years of age or older; while other procedural requirements applicable to general elections are not strictly required for special town elections, no authority dispensing with age or citizenship requirements has been presented. Accordingly, in a special election to determine whether a sanitation collection district should be extended, noncitizens were properly excluded from voting, even though landowners (see, Town Law § 209-e [3]).

Elections -- Special Election -- Procedural Requirements

3. A special election held by a town to determine whether a sanitation collection district should be extended was not invalid on the ground that the town failed to follow a direction that a copy of the resolution/order directing a public hearing be posted and published with the notice of hearing, where no prejudice was claimed as a result of that minor deviation and it appears that the information contained in the resolution was made public by other means. Moreover, although strict compliance with the Election Law is not required for a local special election not held at the time of a general election (Election Law § 1-102), some method of properly identifying voters should be instituted where registration is not required and signatures cannot be matched to election "buff" cards; inasmuch as petitioners, who seek to invalidate the referendum, have not indicated any fraudulent practice in the election in question, the failure to obtain the signatures of several of the voters would not constitute grounds for annulling the referendum.

 

962 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Burton


Indictment No. 7009/89


Supreme Court of New York, Bronx County


150 Misc. 2d 214; 569 N.Y.S.2d 861; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 725



November 23, 1990 


NOTICE:  [**1] [Portions of opinion omitted for purposes of publication.]


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was arrested and indicted for the murder of his mother. Defendant proposed to post bail secured by real property and challenged the constitutionality of N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 500.10(17)(b), which required that the value of the real property used to secure the bond be at least twice the amount of the bail.


OVERVIEW: The value of the of the house that defendant proposed to use to secure the bond for his bail was greater than the amount of the bail but not twice the amount of the bail as required by N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 500.10(17)(b). Defendant argued that § 500.10(17)(b) was unconstitutional because it violated the Equal Protection Clauses of the United States and New York Constitutions and it was irrational as a matter of law. The court dismissed defendant's equal protection claim because the statute did not clearly make invidious distinctions between classes of citizens based on race and where there was no fundamental constitutional right involved, wealth was not a classification that warranted the strict scrutiny equal protection review. However, the court found that there was no rational basis for the heightened requirements of § 500.10(17)(b). The evils that the requirement sought to dispel when the requirement was enacted into law 50 years earlier, particularly unscrupulous bail bondsmen, no longer existed. Section 500.10(17)(b) also conflicted with the policy of in favor of granting a defendant pretrial liberty.


OUTCOME: The court ruled in favor of defendant in his constitutional attack on the requirement that property used to secure a bond posted for bail be valued at twice the amount of the bail.


HEADNOTES

Bail -- Bail Bonds -- Bond Secured by Real Property -- Irrationality of Double Equity Requirement

1. CPL 500.10 (17), which provides that a bail bond may be secured by personal property with a value over and above all liabilities and encumbrances equal to the amount of the undertaking, but requires real property securing a bond to be worth twice the amount of the undertaking, is irrational as a matter of law. The double equity requirement was enacted to deal with the "evil" of unscrupulous bail bondsmen who would secure bail bonds with "undesirable", i.e., already pledged, property, but no rational relationship exists between the gravity of those "evils" and the contextual purpose of the modern statute. The double equity requirement visits a heavy and irretrievable burden not upon offending professional bail bondsmen, but upon an accused possessed of little resource where a court, despite an inclination to release a "good risk" defendant, feels impelled to fix bail in an amount reflective of the factual matters that must be taken into account. In the case of the instant defendant, a teenager accused of murdering his mother, there is neither overreaching nor fraud.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Presumptions

2. A legislative enactment is cloaked with a strong presumption of constitutionality and while the presumption is rebuttable, its challengers bear the heavy burden of proving the questioned legislation unconstitutional beyond a reasonable doubt. Judicial review of a challenged statute revolves about an inquiry as to whether any state of facts known or to be assumed justifies the disputed measure, and where statutory language is clear and unambiguous, interpretation of the statute must give effect to the words used by a coequal branch of government, unless such application would cause an anachronistic or absurd result contrary to the contextual purpose of the enactment.

Bail -- Bail Bonds -- Bond Secured by Real Property -- Double Equity Requirement -- Equal Protection

3. CPL 500.10 (17), which provides that a bail bond may be secured by personal property with a value over and above all liabilities and encumbrances equal to the amount of the undertaking, but requires real property securing a bond to be worth twice the amount of the undertaking, does not violate the equal protection rights of African-Americans and Hispanic-Americans, who allegedly lack liquid assets and must rely on bonds secured by real property, since the mere conjecture of a denial of equal protection need not, in the absence of evidence of invidious distinctions between classes of citizens, be subject to the strict review scrutiny otherwise required where purposeful unequal treatment or resulting disproportionate harm is alleged. In the absence of a stark pattern that a statute bears more heavily on one race or ethnic group than upon another, impact alone is not determinative of whether there has been a violation of equal protection.

Bail -- Right to Bail -- Right to Have Bail Determined in Accordance with Law -- Equal Protection

4. There is no per se absolute right to bail; there is only a right to have bail determined in accordance with law, and bail is not considered to be excessive merely because a defendant cannot furnish it. Accordingly, for purposes of an equal protection challenge, the double equity provision of CPL 500.10 (17) (b), which requires that real property securing a bail bond be worth at least twice the amount of the undertaking, can hardly be classified as an implicit "fundamental right" or based upon a showing of suspect criteria, which must then be construed to be of constitutional dimension. The applicable measure, therefore, must be the "rational basis" standard of review.

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Judicial Oversight -- Changed Conditions

5. In reviewing the constitutionality of a statute, judicial oversight of the motives of a legislature is hazardous and courts are not free to invalidate a challenged statute because of disagreement over legislative wisdom, or to substitute their opinion for the judgment of the legislature. Moreover, the constitutionality of an act depends on its real character, its practical operation and effect, rather than on its professions of purpose, and in examining the question, reference must necessarily be had to subsequent developments which may have changed the validity of information before the legislature at the time of its enactment. Consequently, legislation valid when adopted will nevertheless fall as invalid when, at a later time, its operation under changed conditions proves unconstitutional.

Bail -- Bail Bonds -- Bond Secured by Real Property --  Double Equity Requirement -- Fluctuation in Value of Security

6. CPL 500.10 (17), which provides that a bail bond may be secured by personal property with a value over and above all liabilities and encumbrances equal to the amount of the undertaking, but requires real property securing a bond to be worth twice the amount of undertaking, anachronistically lacks a discernable connection to a commonsense interpretation of revised legislative intent, as well as not comporting with it. Although the Legislature wanted to safeguard the "adequacy" of a bond's security, given that its later wisdom afforded a defendant liberty merely by having him incur a legal obligation under the form of an unsecured bond, the double equity requirement, seen as an aid in the enforcement and collection of forfeitures, sweeps too broadly. Moreover, although it was feared that real property might fluctuate notoriously, today stocks and bonds, which are subject to far more wild fluctuations than real estate, may secure a bail bond at their equity value ( CPL 500.10 [17] [a]). Inasmuch as the record reveals no substantial State interest in the face of a requirement that more than incidentally interferes with defendant's personal liberty, the double equity requirement is facially invalid.

 

963 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Hyde Park Assoc. v. Higgins


Index No. 5576/90


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


149 Misc. 2d 682; 564 N.Y.S.2d 651; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 635



November 19, 1990 


NOTICE:  [***1] [Portions of Opinion Omitted for Purposes of Publication.]



DISPOSITION: Accordingly, the court finds that section 26-514 of the Rent Stabilization Law was constitutional as applied to the petitioners and that the rent refund ordered by the DHCR on March 9, 1990 was not "excessive" nor "wholly disproportionate" and therefore the petition is dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlords filed a petition to vacate an order from respondents, the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal and its Commissioner, which ordered a rent reduction and rent freeze pursuant to the Rent Stabilization Law, New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 26-514.


OVERVIEW: Respondents determined that the landlords had reduced essential services to their tenants, so respondents ordered a rent reduction and a rent freeze pursuant to § 26-514. The landlords claimed that the sanctions against them were excessive, so they filed a petition to vacate respondents' orders. But the court held that the imposition of the rent reduction and rent freeze was mandatory upon the finding of the reduction in essential services, so the landlords' assertion of their good faith effort to improve services to the tenants was irrelevant. The court further rejected the landlords' claim that the amount of the sanctions were excessive holding that the amount of the sanctions were high only because of the number of tenants who were entitled to individual compensation pursuant to § 26-514. The court also held that § 26-514 was not unconstitutional as applied to the landlords because the application of the statute was reasonably related to the statutory goal of compelling a landlord to restore services and affording tenants a measure of compensation for the period that those services were not provided.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the landlords' petition.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Validity of Statute -- Excessive or Disproportionate Sanction as Applied -- Sanctions for Reduction of Housing Services

The statutory sanctions in the form of retroactive rent reductions and rent freezes estimated at over $ 750,000 imposed on petitioner landlord by respondent State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for reduction of essential services pursuant to Rent Stabilization Law (Administrative Code of City of New York) § 26-514 are not excessive, or disproportionate to the wrong, are reasonably related to the statutory purpose, and are constitutional as applied. Although the monetary amount which petitioner must pay is very large, it is not excessive or disproportionate to the wrong; the reduction in essential services extended over a long period of time and affected a large number of tenants, resulting in each complaining tenant receiving an average refund of $ 43.55 per month for reduced services and each noncomplaining tenant receiving an average refund of $ 5.81 per month, and these refunds are clearly not excessive. The sanctions are reasonably related to the statutory goals of compelling a landlord to restore services, affording tenants a measure of compensation, and preservation and maintenance of the rental housing stock in New York City. Accordingly, the landlord's CPLR article 78 proceeding to vacate respondent's order on the ground that the sanctions imposed are excessive and so disproportionate to the offense as to render Rent Stabilization Law § 26-514 unconstitutional as applied is dismissed.

 

964 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Santangelo v. State


Claim Nos. 81400, 81401, Motion Nos. M-42937, M-42936, Cross-Motion Nos. CM-42980, CM-42981


Court of Claims of New York


149 Misc. 2d 171; 563 N.Y.S.2d 597; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 615



November 7, 1990 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Several years after the dismissal of their initial claims, plaintiff police officers filed claims to recover injuries sustained as the result of attempting to arrest a mental patient escapee. Defendant state filed a motion to dismiss the claims as res judicata. The police officers filed a cross-motion for summary judgment on the grounds that N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 205-e revived their previous claims.


OVERVIEW: The police officers claimed that N.Y. Gen. Mun. Law § 205-e, as amended, revived their initial claims, which had been dismissed, and created an absolute liability on the State for injuries they sustained due to the State's violation of its own regulations and its negligence resulting in the mental patient's escape. The State claimed that § 205-e could not constitutionally revive the police officers' claims. The trial court held that the police officers' initial claims came within the purview of § 205-e, as amended, which stated that the § 205-e applied retroactively to all cases dismissed on or after January 1, 1987. The trial court further held, however, that the legislature could not infringe upon the State's vested rights established by the final judgment entered on the police officers' initial claims. According to the trial court, the State had a vested right in the initial final judgment, which held that the State did not have to expend public funds to compensate the police officers for their injuries. The trial court held that, to the extent § 205-e provided for retroactive application where a final judgment had been obtained, it was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The motion to dismiss the claims was granted and the cross-motion for summary judgment was denied.


HEADNOTES

Courts -- Court of Claims -- Constitutionality of Statutory Cause of Action for Money Damages against State

1. In the absence of any prohibition, constitutional or otherwise, the Court of Claims, in a cause of action created by statutory legislation, for money damages against the State, has the authority to determine whether the cause of action, as stated, is sustainable when tested against constitutional limitations imposed upon the Legislature.

Statutes -- Retroactive Application of Statute -- Legislative Intent

2. Clear legislative intent is required in order to give retroactive application to an act of the Legislature when said act creates a cause of action where none previously existed, and said retroactive application of such statute is not unconstitutional because of the retroactive effect. Accordingly, where the history, as well as the literal words of a Session Law (L 1990, ch 762), clearly express that a statute creating a cause of action for police officers injured while on duty (see, General Municipal Law § 205-e) be retroactively applied, no court interpretation of legislative intent is required.

Civil Service -- Police -- Claim against  State for Injuries Sustained While on Duty -- Revival Statute

3. In a claim against the State asserted pursuant to General Municipal Law § 205-e to recover damages sustained by police officers who were injured while attempting to arrest an escaped mental patient, claimants' contention that their cases, which were dismissed by order of the Court of Claims in June 1985, were pending as of January 1, 1987, as appeals were not completed as of that date, and, thus, that they were revived pursuant to a provision of the revival statute (L 1990, ch 762) encompassing cases "which [were] pending on or after January 1, 1987", although metaphysically arguable and subject to logistical formulation, requires total obfuscation of existing facts, necessitating a "quantum leap" possible only in the make-believe world of television. Remedies may be modified even as to pending actions, but no action can be regarded as pending when it has expanded into a judgment and the time to appeal has expired, or the only appeal allowed by law has been taken and decided.

Limitation of Actions -- Revival of Time-Barred Claims -- Action by Police Officer to Recover Damages for Injuries Sustained While on Duty 

4. Claims asserted pursuant to General Municipal Law § 205-e by police officers who were injured while attempting to arrest an escaped mental patient were not revived by language in Laws of 1990 (ch 762) providing for the revival of claims "which would have been actionable on or after January 1, 1987 had [the statute] been effective", since the language of the statute waived the notice provision required by Court of Claims Act § 10 and prospectively extended the three-year time limitation for commencing an action, as required by CPLR article 2, only as to those cases which otherwise would have been actionable on or after January 1, 1989, and the instant claims do not fall within that category: they accrued on July 15, 1979, and the Statute of Limitations, which expired on July 15, 1982, would have acted as a bar to any action started in 1987, notwithstanding the existence of the effect of the cause of action created by the revival statute.

Statutes -- Retroactive Application of Statute -- Claim for Injuries Sustained by Police Officers While on Duty -- Revival Statute

5. Claims asserted pursuant to General Municipal Law § 205-e by police officers who were injured while attempting to arrest an escaped mental patient were revived by language in Laws of 1990 (ch 762) providing for the revival of claims "which [were] dismissed on or after January 1, 1987 because this section was not yet effective", where the Court of Claims initially dismissed the claims in June 1985 and said dismissal was not affirmed by the Court of Appeals until March 1988. The Legislature having clearly expressed its intent that the statute be applied retroactively to include all cases dismissed on or after January 1, 1987, and the prior claim having been finally determined in March 1988, said claim comes within the aforementioned provision of the statute.

Statutes -- Retroactive Application of Statute -- Infringement upon Vested Rights -- Revival Statute -- Claim against State for Injuries Sustained by Police Officers While on Duty

6. The Legislature does not have the right to infringe upon the vested rights established by a final judgment of the courts of New York. Accordingly, Laws of 1990 (ch 762), which amended Laws of 1989 (ch 346), which enacted General Municipal Law § 205-e providing a right of action to police officers injured while on duty as a result of a defendant's negligence in failing to observe any statute, ordinance, regulation, etc., is unconstitutional to the extent that it be retroactively applied to revive a claim against the State asserted by police officers injured while attempting to arrest an escaped mental patient, where the claim was dismissed by the Court of Claims in 1985, where Laws of 1990 (ch 762) revived claims "which [were] dismissed on or after January 1, 1987 because [section 205-e] was not yet effective", where Laws of 1989 (ch 346) was made effective July 12, 1989, and where final judgment dismissing the claims by the Court of Appeals was not rendered until March 1988, since public policy, which defines public interest, is not served by retroactively applying the legislation to the instant claims in light of the necessity to preserve and protect public funds from unwarranted and nonmeritorious claims.

Judgments -- Res Judicata -- Revival of Barred Claims -- Public Policy

7. Res judicata is not applicable to a claim against the State brought by police officers to recover damages sustained while attempting to arrest an escaped mental patient where the claim was initially dismissed, since the statutory rights of the parties have been altered in the intervening period between the conclusion of the first claim and the commencement of the present action owing to the enactment of legislation creating a cause of action in favor of police officers injured as a result of a defendant's negligence in failing to observe statutes, regulations, etc. (see, General Municipal Law § 205-e) and giving section 205-e retroactive effect (see, L 1990, ch 762). In the dismissal of the initial claim, the State acquired the vested right not to expend public funds to compensate claimants, and that vested right, which is inviolate, may not constitutionally be waived. Moreover, section 205-e, as amended, did not change the public policy as to common-law negligence, but simply places police officers on the same footing as firemen (see, General Municipal Law § 205-a); thus, in the absence of any change in public policy, which defines public interest, it cannot be said that the public interest is served by retroactively applying the legislation to the present claim.

 

965 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Gonzales


Indictment No. 89-01890-01


County Court of New York, Westchester County


148 Misc. 2d 973; 561 N.Y.S.2d 358; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 542



October 9, 1990  
October 10, 1990, Filed



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The court, therefore, declares Penal Law § 130.05 (3) (a) constitutional, for the reasons stated herein. Defendant's motion is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with statutory sodomy in the third degree under N.Y. Penal Law § 130.40(2) and statutory rape under § 130.25(2), filed a motion to have § 130.05(3) declared unconstitutional under the Due Process Clauses of the federal and state constitutions. He argued that the statute violated the privacy rights of the under-age victim, and that the statutory presumption unconstitutionally removed the element of consent from the crimes.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was charged with multiple counts of statutory sodomy in the third degree and statutory rape. He filed a motion seeking a declaratory judgment that § 130.05(3) unconstitutionally deprived him of his right to have the People prove each element of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt. The court denied the motion and ruled that the statute was constitutional. Although concluding that defendant did not have standing to assert the victim's privacy interests, the court chose to decide the privacy issue. It ruled that the State had a compelling interest in protecting its youth, particularly from sexual exploitation. The State also had the authority to regulate the sexual conduct of its minors by setting age limits. Accordingly, the statute was not unconstitutional on privacy grounds. Neither did the statute deprive defendant of his right to have the People prove each element. Lack of true consent of those under 17 was not an element of the substantive crimes but was a presumption. It was equivalent to a substantive rule of law and was expressed in terms of the rules of evidence. Once the victim's age was proven, the People had established the element of lack of consent.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion for a declaratory judgment, and it declared that the statutory consent statute was constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Trial -- Timeliness of Motion for Judgment Declaring Statute Unconstitutional

1. Defendant's motion subsequent to commencement of trial for judgment declaring unconstitutional Penal Law § 130.05 (3) (a), which creates a presumption that a person less than 17 years old is incapable of consent for purposes of sex offenses, will not be summarily denied on the ground that it is tardy (see, CPL 255.20) in view of the importance of the issues being raised and the absence of prejudice to the People. Further, the relief sought is not dismissal of the related charges, but a legal instruction that the presumption is rebuttable, and the issues raised can be disposed of without a hearing, thereby avoiding any unnecessary delay in the trial proceedings.

Declaratory Judgments -- When Remedy Appropriate -- Validity of Penal Statute

2. Although declaratory relief is not available to a person against whom a criminal action is pending, the court presiding over the underlying trial may properly entertain defendant's motion to have Penal Law § 130.05 (3) (a), which creates a presumption that a person less than 17 years old is incapable of consent for purposes of sex offenses, declared unconstitutional since he is being prosecuted under that statute.

Crimes -- Sodomy -- Standing to Challenge Constitutionality of Statutory Presumption of Lack of Consent Based on Age

3. Defendant, charged with statutory sodomy and statutory rape (Penal Law § 130.40 [2]; § 130.25 [2]), lacks standing to challenge the constitutionality of Penal Law § 130.05 (3) (a), which creates a presumption that a person less than 17 years old is incapable of consent for purposes of sex offenses, on the ground that such presumption interferes with the right to privacy of those under 17 years of age since a defendant-victim relationship, standing alone, is insufficient to grant standing on the basis of the privacy rights of the minor.

Crimes -- Sodomy -- Constitutionality of Statutory Presumption of Lack of Consent Based on Age -- Right to Privacy -- Due Process of Law

4. Penal Law § 130.05 (3), which creates a presumption that a person less than 17 years old is incapable of consent for purposes of sex offenses, is not unconstitutional on the ground that it interferes with the right to privacy of those under 17 years of age, since there is a compelling State interest in protecting its youth from sexual exploitation and abuse. In addition, while defendant, charged with statutory sodomy and statutory rape (Penal Law § 130.40 [2]; § 130.25 [2]), has standing to challenge the statute on due process grounds, he has failed to establish that the statutory presumption unconstitutionally removes the element of consent from the related crimes, thereby depriving him of his right to have the People prove each element of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt. Penal Law § 130.05 (3) (a) is a statutory legal definition; the lack of true consent of those under 17 years is not an element of the substantive crime. Once the People prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the victim's age was less than 17 at the time of the alleged offense, they have established lack of consent and the remaining "elements" of the crime must then be proved by the same degree of proof.

 

966 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Amalgamated Transit Union, Local 1202, etc. v. Greyhound Lines, Inc.


Index No. 5471/90


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


148 Misc. 2d 601; 561 N.Y.S.2d 118; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 485; 119 Lab. Cas. (CCH) P10,812



September 19, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Based upon the foregoing, the cross motion is granted, the complaint is dismissed, and the motion for a preliminary injunction is denied as moot.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff union brought an action to enjoin defendant employer from violating § 22-502 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York by hiring and transporting strikebreakers to replace striking employees. The matter was before the court on the union's motion for a temporary injunction and the employer's cross-motion to dismiss.


OVERVIEW: The union alleged that the employer violated § 22-502(a), which prohibited strikebreakers from being hired, and § 22-502(c), which prohibited strikebreakers from being transported to strike locations. The employer argued that the union's action was preempted by the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA), 29 U.S.C.S. § 151 et seq., because the local ordinance directly covered a labor-management question that fell under the ambit of the NLRA. The employer also contended that the local attempt to regulate the hiring of workers to replace striking employees violated the Supremacy Clause. The court held that the NLRA preempted the union's cause of action. The court reasoned that §§ 22-502(a) and (c) both directly interfered with the implementation of the explicitly recognized and factually applicable right of an interstate employer to hire replacement workers under federal labor law principles. In view of their direct impact on the employer, the anti-hiring provisions in § 22-502(a) could not be tangential to a labor dispute. In addition, there was no local interest sufficient to avoid preemption of the union's claim under the anti-transportation provisions in § 22-502(c).


OUTCOME: The court granted the employer's cross-motion to dismiss the union's action to enjoin its alleged violation of local laws regulating the hiring and transportation of strikebreakers. The court also denied the union's motion for a preliminary injunction against the employer for violating the local anti-strikebreaker laws as moot.


HEADNOTES

Labor -- "Antistrikebreaker" Law -- Federal Preemption

Defendant bus company, which is involved in a nationwide strike of its bus drivers, may not be subjected to a civil suit for allegedly violating New York City's "antistrikebreaker" penal statute by hiring "strikebreakers" "in the place of employees involved in [the] strike" or transporting or arranging for the transportation of "strikebreakers" to be replacement workers (Administrative Code of City of New York § 22-502 [a], [c]) since the local ordinance is preempted by the Federal National Labor Relations Act (29 USC § 157 et seq.). The hiring of workers to replace strikers is lawful under Federal law. There is no basis to hold that the impact of the "antistrikebreaker" law provisions directed against the employer is tangential to a labor dispute or that preemption may be otherwise avoided. In addition, no acceptable local interest is present that would support an exception to Federal preemption in the labor area.

 

967 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Caviano


Indictment No. 14097/89


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


148 Misc. 2d 426; 560 N.Y.S.2d 932; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 471



August 27, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the reasons set forth above, the defendant's motion to suppress evidence of his written and oral statements is, in all respects, denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant was indicted on charges of murder in the second degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 125.25, robbery in the first degree in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 160.15, and robbery in the second degree, in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 160.10. Before the court was defendant's motion to suppress evidence of his written and oral statements.


OVERVIEW: Defendant was located at a naval training base by two detectives and questioned regarding his involvement in two robberies and the murder of a taxicab driver. Two Navy officers were present during the questioning. At his trial on charges of robbery and murder, defendant sought to suppress the statements on the ground that such questioning violated his constitutional rights under the Posse Comitatus Act, 18 U.S.C.S. § 1385 (act). The court denied the motion because the nature of the Navy's assistance in the case could not be characterized as military. At most, the Navy played a passive role in the civilian law enforcement activity. Defendant was also fully advised of both of the offenses of which he was suspected and of his Miranda rights, and the military personnel did not aid or otherwise participate in the questioning. Further, the act was not designed to afford protection to the rights of individuals under the circumstances of the case. Finally, the actions of all parties were reasonable and under the circumstances where the wrong that defendant sought to remedy was a technical statutory violation, the extraordinary measure of suppression was not applicable.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to suppress evidence of his written and oral statements.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Confession -- Military Involvement in Civilian Law Enforcement

1. Defendant's incriminating statements made to New York police officers at an out-of-State naval base where he was stationed should not be suppressed since the actions of naval personnel in rendering assistance to the police officers by escorting defendant to an interrogation room does not constitute the type of active military involvement prohibited by the Posse Comitatus Act (18 USC § 1385), which proscribes the use of military personnel in civilian law enforcement. The military personnel simply extended the normal courtesies that they would be expected to extend to State law enforcement officials under the circumstances. Even if the conduct of the naval authorities did violate the Federal act, suppression is not warranted since the remedy for a violation of the act is limited to criminal penalties, a fine of not more than $ 10,000, imprisonment for not more than two years, or both. In addition, any violation of the act was merely technical and not willful so that the extraordinary remedy of suppression is unwarranted.

Crimes -- Right to Counsel

2. Defendant's uncounseled, but otherwise voluntary statements, made to New York police officers at an out-of-State naval base, should not be suppressed as the product of an illegal stratagem specifically designed to "circumvent" his right to counsel due to the failure of the police officers to secure an arrest warrant despite the existence of probable cause and despite their intention to secure an arrest warrant and arrest defendant regardless of whether he agreed to make a statement since defendant enjoys no constitutional right to be arrested and, thus, any deliberate attempt to "circumvent" his right to counsel cannot constitute grounds for suppression.

 

968 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cabon


Docket No. 90N024984


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


148 Misc. 2d 260; 560 N.Y.S.2d 370; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 438



August 14, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The application to quash is denied. The subpoenas withdrawn by defendants as noted herein are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state applied to quash subpoenas duces tecum issued ex parte to defendants' attorneys for routine police reports concerning the charges against defendants.


OVERVIEW: Defendants' attorneys were issued subpoenas duces tecum ex parte by the court for specific routine police reports prepared by the police department. The police reports were not confidential or privileged. They were sought by defendants in preparation for trial, for information regarding favorable witnesses who would not be called to testify at trial and to disclose other unspecified exculpatory material. The state applied to quash the subpoenas. The court denied the application to quash. It held that it was prudent to disclose the subpoenaed police reports to the defense without delay in order to avoid continuous monitoring on the issue of materiality and the risk of reversible error for nondisclosure. Because there was a reasonable possibility that the information contained in the police reports would be material, it was more prudent to deny the application to quash and to disclose the information.


OUTCOME: The court denied the state's application to quash subpoenas duces tecum that the court had issued ex parte to defendants' attorneys for specific and routine police reports that were not confidential or privileged and were requested in preparation for trial. In order to promote judicial efficiency and avoid costly reversible error, it was more prudent to deny the application to quash and to direct the disclosure of the subpoenaed materials.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Disclosure -- Subpoena Duces Tecum -- Routine Police Reports

A defendant in preparation for trial may subpoena (CPL art 610) specific and routine police reports that are not confidential or privileged since, as a matter of due process of law, the defense is entitled to know before trial any exculpatory evidence, including potential evidence or leads to evidence, contained in the reports if there is a "reasonable possibility" that the specifically subpoenaed police reports would make a difference in the outcome of the trial (see, People v Vilardi, 76 NY2d 67). To summarily quash subpoenas for specific police reports would unjustifiably ignore the fact that such reports by nature suggest a "reasonable possibility" that they will make a difference in the outcome of the trial. Since the police department regularly provides all police reports to the prosecution, there should be no significant burden in supplying an extra copy for the defense when subpoenaed. In addition, reversal of convictions and costly retrials resulting from failures by the prosecution to disclose exculpatory evidence are avoidable by giving the defense pretrial access to police reports by subpoena. Accordingly, subpoenaed police reports should not be delivered to the defense until the prosecution has had a reasonable opportunity to inspect them and to make any reasonably necessary redactions to protect the identity of endangered witnesses, or undercover officers, or investigations in progress, and the like. The court will intervene only as to any disputed redactions or representations of nonmateriality by the prosecution.

 

969 of 992 DOCUMENTS


All Peoples Congress v. Metropolitan Transp. Authority


Index No. 27538/89


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


147 Misc. 2d 1020; 559 N.Y.S.2d 462; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 349



July 12, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] In conclusion, plaintiffs' motion to amend their pleading is denied, and the application by defendants to dismiss the complaint, insofar as it seeks other than declaratory relief, is granted, and the court declares that Public Authorities Law § 1205 (6) (which is the only section specifically challenged in the complaint) as well as the similar sections applicable to MABSTOA and the MTA, are not violative of either the United States or New York State Constitution, and that the decisions to raise the fares on the facilities of the defendants were not unlawful.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff lobbyists brought a motion for leave to amend their complaint, which sought to annul the decisions of defendant transit authority that imposed fare increases and to declare N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1205(6) unconstitutional. The transit authority brought a motion to dismiss the lobbyists' complaint.


OVERVIEW: The transit authorities raised fares, which the lobbyists' asserted was unlawful due to the transit authority's failure to file an environmental impact statement (EIS) as required by the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA). The lobbyists' application for a temporary injunction was denied because N.Y. Pub. Auth. Law § 1205(6) provided that such increases did not require the filing of an EIS. The lobbyists filed a motion for leave to amend the complaint to challenge the constitutionality of § 1205(6), and the transit authority brought a motion to dismiss. The court denied the lobbyists' motion for leave to amend, granted the transit authority's motion to dismiss, and found § 1205(6) was constitutional. Under the rational basis test, where a statute passed the test of constitutionality if the governmental classification was based upon a legitimate state interest, § 1205(6) was lawful because the transit authority required adequate financing. Since the EIS process was subject to lengthy delays and often involved related litigation, the legislature fairly exempted fare increases from that process to avoid emergencies in financing transit facilities.


OUTCOME: The court denied the lobbyists' motion for leave to amend their complaint against the transit authority, granted the transit authority's motion to dismiss the lobbyists' complaint, declared that the challenged statutory section was constitutional, and held that the transit authority's decision to raise fares was not unlawful.


HEADNOTES

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Rational Basis Test

1. In an action challenging the constitutionality of exemptions from the necessity of filing environmental impact statements granted to several metropolitan area transit authorities regarding fare alterations (Public Authorities Law § 1205 [1], [6]; § 1203-a [10]; § 1266 [3]), the rational basis test is the proper standard for determining whether the exemptions are violative of equal protection under the Federal and State Constitutions. The challenged legislation does not result in intentional discrimination against a class of persons grouped togetherby reason of personal characteristics such as would require the more stringent "strict scrutiny" standard.

Constitutional Law -- Equal Protection of Laws -- Exemption of Certain Transit Authorities from Filing Environmental Impact Statement in Connection with Fare Alterations

2. The exemption of certain metropolitan area transit authorities from filing environmental impact statements in connection with fare alterations (Public Authorities Law § 1205 [1], [6]; § 1203-a [10]; § 1266 [3]) is not violative of equal protection under the Federal and State Constitutions. The Legislature had a rational basis for such exemptions since the Legislature declared an emergency that called for prompt financing to improve transit facilities, and can be presumed to know that the environmental impact statement procedure can be subject to lengthy delays, that the contemplated financing could require that fare revenues serve as security, and that the transit authorities are required to have balanced budgets.

Public Authorities -- New York City Transit Authority -- Applicability of State Environmental Quality Review Act to Fare Adjustments

3. By specifying that fare alterations effected bycertain metropolitan area transit authorities are not "actions" subject to the provisions of the State Environmental Quality Review Act (ECL art 8 [SEQRA]) (See, Public Authorities Law § 1205 [1], [6]; § 1203-a [10]; § 1266 [3]), the Legislature intended that the entire SEQRA be inapplicable to such activity. Accordingly, defendant transit authorities' failure to consider alternatives to fare increases that would minimize or avoid adverse environmental impacts, as required by ECL 8-0109 (1), does not render unlawful defendants' decisions to implement the increases.

 

970 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Commissioner of Social Services on behalf of Deneen C. v. William C.


Docket No. P 9697/89


Family Court of New York, New York County


147 Misc. 2d 974; 559 N.Y.S.2d 88; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 317



June 14, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner Commissioner of Social Services moved to amend the petition to substitute the estate administrator for respondent decedent, in a matter where the Commissioner, on behalf of petitioner mother, filed a paternity suit against the decedent and where the estate administrator cross-moved to dismiss pursuant to N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 519.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner mother claimed that she became pregnant when respondent decedent raped her at gunpoint. While N.Y. Fam. Ct. Act § 518 dealt with the situation of a mother's dying prior to the commencement of a proceeding, it was silent with respect to the death of a putative father prior to the commencement of a proceeding, irrespective of whether the putative father was the petitioner or the respondent. The only way to have the petition not be subject to abatement would be to hold the statute unconstitutional, which the mother and respondent Commissioner of Social Services did not attempt. The court found that a constitutional challenge would ultimately fail, as the biological reality justified the gender-based distinction in the Act that presumed the parentage of a mother, while requiring the relationship between a putative father and a child to be an established fact. The lack of knowledge about the subject was notably prejudicial to the decedent's family, since they would face insurmountable problems in preparing a defense since the claim implicates a highly unusual scenario for which apparently no independent corroboration exists.


OUTCOME: The court denied the motion to substitute and granted the cross-motion to dismiss.


HEADNOTES

Children Born out of Wedlock -- Paternity Proceeding -- Effect of Death of Putative Father

A gender-based enactment (Family Ct Act § 519), which permits the granting of an order of filiation in a paternity proceeding after the death of the putative father provided some tangible articulable nexus existed between the child and deceased putative father (i.e., the putative father was the petitioner in the paternity proceeding; or the putative father acknowledged paternity of the child in open court; or a blood genetic marker test had been administered to the putative father prior to his death; or the putative father had openly and notoriously acknowledged the child as his own) is constitutional since the proper purpose of the statute of foreclosing false paternity claims, while allowing legitimate claims to proceed where a concrete connection between the decedent and the child can be specified, can only be accomplished, given biological realities, in a gender-based statute. Accordingly, since petitioner Commissioner of Social Services, on behalf of the mother who claims to have become pregnant after being raped by the deceased putative father, a police officer, failed to establish the existence of any of the four specified circumstances, the paternity proceeding must be dismissed.

 

971 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Perkins


Index No. 22598/89


District Court of New York, First District, Nassau County


147 Misc. 2d 325; 558 N.Y.S.2d 459; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 337



June 13, 1990  
June 13, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant, charged with disorderly conduct under N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20 (3), filed a motion for dismissal of the information on the ground that § 240.20 (3) was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: Defendant became boisterous when cinema security prevented him from cutting in line for a movie, shouting "fuck you" and "eat this" to police while grabbing his genitals. Such acts were in front of approximately 100 people including the arresting officer. Dismissing the information charging defendant with disorderly conduct, the court held that § 240.20 (3) was unconstitutional. The court based such holding on a prior ruling striking down N.Y. Penal Law § 240.25(2), the "harassment" statute, which was very similar to the disorderly conduct statute. Both statutes were overbroad because they did not limit their proscription of speech to "fighting words." The court found that the variance between the statutes was a distinction without a difference.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the information against defendant and held the disorderly conduct statute unconstitutional.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct -- Use of Abusive or Obscene Language in Public Place

The disorderly conduct statute, which proscribes using "abusive or obscene language" or making an "obscene gesture" in a public place with "intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof" (Penal Law § 240.20 [3]), is unconstitutionally overbroad in view of the decision of the Court of Appeals striking down similar provisions of the harassment statute (Penal Law § 240.40 [3]) on the ground that speech may neither be forbidden nor penalized unless it presents a clear and present danger of some serious substantive evil (see, People v Dietze, 75 NY2d 47). Any proscription of pure speech must be sharply limited to words which, by their utterance alone, inflict injury or tend naturally to evoke immediate violence or other breach of the peace. Accordingly, defendant may not be prosecuted for disorderly conduct for using vulgar language and making an obscene gesture when he was asked by police to leave a movie theatre after he tried to "cut" to the front of a long ticket line.

 

972 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Marwyte Realty Assoc., Ltd. v. Valcarcel


Index No. 116628/89


Civil Court of the City of New York, Bronx County


147 Misc. 2d 910; 559 N.Y.S.2d 80; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 361



June 8, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landlord brought a holdover proceeding to evict respondents, tenant and tenant's children, on the ground that they were objectionable because they used or condoned the use of part of the premises, for the purpose of illegal activity. The landlord further sought possession against the tenant for harboring the two children. Finally, the landlord sought a restraining order or protective order.


OVERVIEW: The court held that a tenant was removable, pursuant to a proceeding seeking to recover possession, if the landlord, by competent evidence, established to the satisfaction of the court that the tenant was objectionable. After the tenant's children had been arrested and convicted for drug offenses, the tenant allowed the children to live in her apartment. The court determined that the tenant of record was an objectionable tenant by condoning the illegal trade of drugs engaged in by her two children, in a part of the premises in which she lived, in violation of the law; and by harboring the two children after being informed of their illegal trading in narcotics. The court restrained the children from appearing at the premises or within 1000 feet of the premises.


OUTCOME: In the landlord's holdover proceeding to evict the tenant and the tenant's children, the court granted a judgment of possession in favor of the landlord. The court order the restraining order against the tenant and the tenant's children.


HEADNOTES

Public Housing -- Eviction of Nondesirable Tenant -- Responsibility of Tenant for Sale of Drugs by Children

1. One who harbors a person in a premises or any part thereof in which an illegal drug is sold is punishable as a principal. Thus, respondent tenant who knew her children had been convicted of dealing drugs in or near her rented premises and continued to allow said children to reside with her is punishable as a principal in a proceeding pursuant to RPAPL 711 (1), (5) to remove respondent and her children from the premises as objectionable.

Public Housing -- Eviction of Nondesirable Tenant -- Condoning Drug Trade

2. Respondent, a tenant of public housing who condoned her children's trade in illegal drugs in part of the subject premises, and harbored the children after learning of their illegal drug trading, is objectionable within the meaning of RPAPL 711 (1), (5). Thus, respondent and her children are evicted from the subject premises.

Public Housing -- Eviction of Nondesirable Tenant -- Restraining Orders

3. In a proceeding pursuant to RPAPL 711 (1), (5), respondents, children evicted from public housing as objectionable for dealing illegal drugs from thepremises and their mother, similarly evicted for condoning their actions and harboring them in those premises, may properly be enjoined and restrained from appearing in, at, or near said premises, nearby schools, playgrounds, youth centers, public swimming pools or video arcades, pursuant to CCA 110 (c), Administrative Code of the City of New York § 27-2121 and 21 USC § 845a.

 

973 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Bollander


Ind. No. 826-90


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


147 Misc. 2d 897; 558 N.Y.S.2d 795; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 301



June 6, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Inasmuch as this court holds that the defendant's constitutional rights were violated under the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the US Constitution which this court believes is encompassed in the spirit of CPL 40.40, the discrimination charge must be dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The state filed a second indictment against defendant following reversal of defendant's conviction for riot in the second degree. The second indictment accused defendant of riot in the second degree and a new offense, discrimination. Defendant filed an omnibus motion seeking dismissal of the indictment.


OVERVIEW: Defendant argued that the discrimination allegation of the second indictment violated N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 40.40, which barred a subsequent separate prosecution of an offense where it was not charged in the first indictment and there was evidence available to charge the offense not charged. The state argued that the law did not apply to the case before the court because a trial of the existing accusatory indictment had not begun nor had the indictment disposed of by a guilty plea. The court rejected the state's argument and dismissed the discrimination count. The court pointed out that the legislature's intent in enacting § 40.40 was not to permit the state to add an additional offense once a trial had commenced on one offense involving the same conduct and the same evidence. The court also concluded that inclusion of the discrimination count at retrial was a violation of the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution because second prosecution in these circumstances raised the spectre of vindictiveness on the part of the state and would also have placed a chilling effect on defendant's right to appeal.


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the discrimination charge contained in the second indictment because it denied defendant's constitutional rights under the due process clause, which was encompassed in spirit of the state's legislation.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Former Jeopardy -- Retrial -- Prosecution of Additional Offense Arising out of Same Transaction and Using Same Evidence

In the criminal prosecution of a defendant who successfully appeals his conviction, once the original conviction is set aside and the prosecutor is granted leave to re-present the mater to a new Grand Jury, the prosecutor may not go into the Grand Jury and obtain an indictment which includes an additional offense based upon the same transaction and the same evidence that was in the People's possession prior to the finding of the first indictment, since the prosecution of the additional offense is barred by CPL 40.40 and the Fourteenth Amendment of the US Constitution; CPL 40.40 prohibits separate prosecutions for offenses arising out of the same criminal transaction if they had been joinable in one accusatory instrument, and the intent of the Legislature was not to permit a prosecutor to add an additional offense once a trial had commenced on one offense involving the same conduct and the same evidence. Moreover, by adding an additional charge, defendant is subjected to the possibility of increased punishment, and it is the fear of such greater punishment which may unconstitutionally deter defendant from exercising his right to appeal or to collaterally attack his first conviction.

 

974 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Cody


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Rochester


147 Misc. 2d 588; 558 N.Y.S.2d 793; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 319



May 31, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant filed a motion to dismiss an information that charged him with disorderly conduct in violation of N.Y. Penal Code § 240.20(3) on the ground that § 240.20(3) was unconstitutional, or, in the alternative, that the information was facially insufficient.


OVERVIEW: An information alleged that defendant committed disorderly conduct by making an obscene statement to a police officer. The court granted defendant's motion and dismissed the information based on the unconstitutional overbreadth § 240.20(3). The court held that § 240.20(3) was unconstitutionally overbroad. It was so ambiguous that it could not have advised defendant that his statement could be prosecuted as disorderly conduct. If § 240.20(3) were construed to include constitutionally permissible limits on the conduct that could be punished, its plain language would fail to inform a reasonable person of the conduct that was and was not prohibited. Therefore, it would fail to give fair warning of the nature of the conduct proscribed as required by N.Y. Penal Law § 1.05. If the court were able to construe N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(3) so as to establish constitutionally permissible limitations on its scope, the language complained of would necessarily fall outside of the scope of § 240.20(3).


OUTCOME: The court dismissed the information that charged defendant with disorderly conduct.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct -- Using Abusive or Obscene Language in Public Place

The disorderly conduct statute, which proscribes using "abusive or obscene language" or making an "obscene gesture" in a "public place" with "intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating a risk thereof" (Penal Law § 240.20 [3]) is unconstitutionally overbroad in view of the unconstitutionality of the similar harassment statute, which requires an even greater mental culpability to sustain a conviction (see, People v Dietze, 75 NY2d 47; Penal Law § 240.25 [2]). The fact that the harassment statute is designed to prevent alarm or annoyance to individuals, while the disorderly conduct statute protects against public disturbances or breaches of the peace does not require that the disorderly conduct statute be upheld for the greater public good since speech which is constitutionally protected may not be prohibited based on the number of listeners it reaches. Accordingly, defendant, a striking employee, may not be convicted of disorderly conduct for making an obscene statement to a police officer.

 

975 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Property Clerk, New York City Police Dep't v. Hyne


Index No. 43710/89


Supreme Court of New York, New York County


147 Misc. 2d 774; 557 N.Y.S.2d 244; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 280



May 21, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is denied in its entirety.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff, the police department property clerk (the clerk), brought a forfeiture action in the Supreme Court of New York, New York County, against defendant arrestee. The arrestee filed a motion to dismiss the action and argued that the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which governed forfeiture proceedings, was unconstitutional.


OVERVIEW: The arrestee's vehicle was seized pursuant to New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 14-140 after the arrestee and another individual used the vehicle to travel to a drug purchasing location. The forfeiture complaint filed by the clerk alleged that the vehicle was used by arrestee as the instrumentality of or to aid and further the commission of a crime. The arrestee challenged the Administrative Code provisions at issue and the court found that although those provisions still referred to his duty to prove his right to possession in a civil action, that language, which was previously deemed unconstitutional, was not dispositive where the clerk was required to show a right to forfeiture in the civil proceedings now used for forfeiture requests such as the one before the court. The arrestee failed to show that the forfeiture procedures utilized herein were so punitive in purpose or effect as to negate the legislature's implied purpose in enacting § 14-140 to create a civil, remedial forfeiture statute. As a result, the civil proceeding brought to determine the right of possession were deemed constitutional.


OUTCOME: The court denied the arrestee's motion to dismiss and found the New York City forfeiture provisions constitutional.


HEADNOTES

Forfeitures and Penalties -- Forfeiture of Proceeds or Instrumentality of Crime

New York City's forfeiture procedures, which authorize the Police Department Property Clerk to seize and retain possession of any property suspected of having been "used as a means of committing crime or employed in aid or furtherance of crime" (Administrative Code of City of New York § 14-140), are not unconstitutional due to the lack of express language authorizing the institution of a forfeiture action as is constitutionally required by prior court decisions since the Property Clerk, as a legal claimant to the property, has the right to institute a suit declaring his custody and retention of the property to be lawful. The forfeiture procedures, although predicated on criminal behavior, are civil in nature rather than criminal, and, thus, a forfeiture proceeding does not amount to double jeopardy or violate constitutional safeguards against self-incrimination or deny due process. There is no impropriety in the imposition of both criminal and civil penalties based on the same criminal acts. Accordingly, the Property Clerk may properly maintain a forfeiture proceeding to determine the right of possession to defendant's vehicle, which was seized in connection with defendant's arrest for possession of "crack" cocaine for which defendant eventually pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct and was fined $ 25.

 

976 of 992 DOCUMENTS


New York v. State


Index No. 46770/89


Supreme Court, New York County


146 Misc. 2d 488; 556 N.Y.S.2d 823; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 265



May 21, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For the foregoing reasons, the City's motion is denied and the State's cross motion is granted.


CASE SUMMARY:
