PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiffs, City of New York and associated individuals, filed a motion for summary judgment seeking a declaratory judgment that 1989 N.Y. Laws 773 was violative of the home rule provision of the New York Constitution and the equal protection provisions of the state and federal constitutions. Defendants, State of New York and associated individuals, cross-moved for a declaration of the law's validity.


OVERVIEW: The New York State Legislature enacted Laws of 1989, as amended by Laws of 1990, that provided a procedure for the determination of whether the Borough of Staten Island should separate from the City of New York and become a separate city. Plaintiffs moved for summary judgment seeking a declaratory judgment that 1989 N.Y. Laws. 773 was violative of the home rule provision of the New York Constitution and the equal protection provisions of the state and federal constitutions. Defendant cross-moved for a declaration of the law's validity. The court held that notwithstanding the serious impact of the proposed legislation on all the citizens of New York, it did not violate constitutional standards. It would ultimately be in the authority of the legislature to determine whether separation was in the best interests of the people of New York, including the residents of all the five boroughs. The court held that a state of facts could reasonably be conceived to justify the scheme set up by New York to commence the process given the limited nature of the election and disproportionate interest of Staten Islanders.


OUTCOME: The court denied plaintiffs' motion that sought a declaratory judgment that the statute at issue was violative of the home rule provision of the New York Constitution and the equal protection provisions of the state and federal law. The court granted defendants' cross motion that sought a declaration that the law was valid.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Home Rule Powers -- Legislation Establishing Procedure to Determine if Part of City Should Secede

1. The home rule message provision of the State Constitution (art IX, § 2 [b] [2]), which provides that the Legislature may act in relation to the property, affairs or government of any local government only on request of the locality, does not prevent the State from responding to issues of significant State concern, and inasmuch as the Legislature has the power of municipal creation, Laws of 1989 (ch 773), which provides a procedure for determining whether the Borough of Staten Island should separate from the City of New York and become a separate city, does not fall within the ambit of those matters that require a home rule message. Issues of city boundaries and city creation are matters of significant State concern, and if the subject matter of a statute is of sufficient importance to the State generally to render it a proper subject of State legislation, the State may freely legislate, notwithstanding the fact that the concern of the State may also touch upon local matters. The Legislature may consolidate, add to, or take from the territory of a municipality without its consent and without challenge. Accordingly, there is a clear State concern herein and the enactment of chapter 773 embodies the plenary power of the Legislature that is expressly reserved to it for "the creation and organization of local governments" (NY Const, art IX, § 2 [a]).

Municipal Corporations -- Secession of Part of City -- Legislation Establishing Procedure for Secession -- Equal Protection -- Only Citizens who Would Secede to Vote in Referendum

2. Laws of 1989 (ch 773), which provides a procedure for determining whether the Borough of Staten Island should separate from the City of New York and become a separate city, and which authorizes only residents of Staten Island to vote in a referendum posing the secession question, is constitutionally valid and not a violation of equal protection since the referendum is advisory in nature, rather than determinative, with the State Legislature reserving to itself the power to ultimately decide whether the City of Staten Island is to be created. If an election is of special interest, the State may limit the election to those who will be primarily affected, and the referendum in question serves a limited purpose: to appoint a committee to draft a proposed charter to use in the event that the Legislature votes to permit secession; this is not a situation in which those who are allowed to vote are exercising general governmental powers over those who are disenfranchised. A rational basis for the enfranchisement of Staten Islanders, to the exclusion of other New York City residents, is readily apparent: Staten Islanders will be primarily affected by secession, despite the impact borne by the entire city.

 

977 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Bank Leumi Trust Co. v. Taylor-Cishahayo


Index No. 7679/89


Civil Court of the City of New York, Queens County


147 Misc. 2d 685; 556 N.Y.S.2d 211; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 234



May 11, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Accordingly, the motion is denied without prejudice to renew upon proper papers.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff filed a motion against defendant for contempt of court for failure to comply with an information subpoena.


OVERVIEW: When defendant failed to comply with an information subpoena, plaintiff filed a motion against defendant for contempt. The court found that plaintiff's motion did not comply with the notice requirements of N.Y. Jud. Law § 756. The court found that the language employed by plaintiff's counsel failed to provide defendant with the required notice that the purpose of the hearing was to punish defendant for a contempt of court, and that such punishment may have consisted of fine or imprisonment, or both, according to law. The court also found that the language on the face of the motion did not immediately call defendant's attention to it. Additionally, the warning was both typewritten in capital letters that were not at least eight-point bold in size, and stamped in ink on the bottom right-hand side of the page. The court concluded that granting plaintiff's motion was improper because it failed to give the required notice.


OUTCOME: The court denied plaintiff's motion for contempt without prejudice.


HEADNOTES

Contempt -- Civil Contempt -- Statutory Notice and Warning Requirements

Plaintiff's motion to punish defendant for contempt for failure to comply with an information subpoena is invalid on its face since the typing of a statement, couched in normal "notice of motion" language, to the right of the caption in capital letters equal in size to all capital letters typed on the page fails to provide the requisite statutory "notice that the purpose of the hearing is to punish the accused for a contempt of court, and that such punishment may consist of fine or imprisonment, or both" (Judiciary Law § 756). While eight-point type is not required for the notice, such notice must nevertheless appear on the face of the motion in a manner that will immediately call the defendant's attention to it. In addition, the use of a rubber-stamp warning on the bottom right-hand side of the motion sheet does not satisfy the further statutory requirement that the warning for contempt be "printed or type written" in bold type. The statutory notice and warning requirements must be strictly enforced to insure that defendants are made aware of the severe penalties for their failure to comply with subpoenas.

 

978 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Duffy v. Wetzler


Index No. 7705-89


Supreme Court of New York, Queens County


148 Misc. 2d 459; 555 N.Y.S.2d 543; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 196



April 10, 1990 


SUBSEQUENT HISTORY:  [***1] As Corrected January 28, 1991.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff taxpayers filed suit against defendants, state officials and city officials, regarding income taxes paid under N.Y. Tax Law § 612(c)(3). The taxpayers sought leave to renew and, upon renewal, the certification of their action as a class action, and they moved for partial summary judgment on their declaratory judgment claim. The state and the city officials moved for an order granting summary judgment dismissing the complaint.


OVERVIEW: In response to a federal decision, N.Y. Tax Law § 612 (c)(3) was amended to exempt federal pension benefits from taxation. However, the amendment made no provision for retrospective relief for taxes paid on benefits received prior to January 1, 1989. The taxpayers filed their action. The court denied class certification, but granted partial summary judgment for the taxpayers on their declaratory judgment claim. Further, the court dismissed the taxpayers' 42 U.S.C.S. § 1983 action, as well as their action for money had and received. However, it granted summary judgment for the taxpayers on their claim for injunctive relief. Class action status was inappropriate because the payment of taxes was personal. Under state law, the taxpayers were entitled to seek a refund for income taxes paid on their benefits from 1986 through 1989. The city, the city officials, or the state officials did not personally engage in any activity in connection with the taxation so as to give rise to a § 1983 claim. Because the tax scheme was unconstitutional, taxpayers were entitled to injunctive relief. The taxpayers failed to comply with the protest requirement for their claim of money had and received.


OUTCOME: The court granted the taxpayers' request for renewal, and, upon renewal, the request for class certification was denied. Partial summary judgment was granted for the taxpayers on their claim for a declaratory judgment. The court granted summary judgment against the taxpayers on their § 1983 action and their claim for money had and received. Finally, the court granted summary judgment for the taxpayers on their injunctive relief claim.


HEADNOTES

Actions -- Class Actions -- Tax Refund

1. An action for declaratory and injunctive relief and a tax refund based upon a discriminatory, unconstitutional income tax scheme whereby, prior to January 1, 1989, the State and the City of New York taxed Federal pension benefits while exempting State and local pension benefits from taxation (see, Tax Law § 612 [c] [3] [ii]; Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-1712 [c] [3]), may not be maintained as a class action on behalf of all similarly situated taxpayers (CPLR 901, 902) since class action certification is inappropriate where governmental actions are involved and subsequent plaintiffs will be adequately protected under the doctrine of stare decisis. Moreover, a tax voluntarily paid generally may not be recovered, and a class action may not be used to protect members of the proposed class who paid the tax without registering a protest.

Taxation -- Personal Income Tax -- Exemption for Federal Pension Benefits -- Refund

2. The City of New York (City) and State of New York personal income tax scheme, which taxed Federal pension benefits received prior to January 1, 1989 (Tax Law § 612 [c] [3-a]), while exempting State and local pension benefits from taxation (Federal pension benefits received on or after Jan. 1, 1989 now being exempt; Tax Law § 612 [c] [3] [ii]; Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-1712 [c] [3]) is discriminatory, invalid and unconstitutional and the City and State defendants are therefore enjoined from assessing and collecting personal income taxes on Federal pensions received in the years 1986 through 1988, which may be still due and owing. Further, plaintiffs are entitled to a refund of that portion of their personal income taxes paid on Federal pension benefits for the years 1986 through 1988 provided that they file for a refund and meet all the procedural requirements for claiming a refund (Tax Law § 687 [a]), since overpayments arising out of a tax later held to be unconstitutional are recoverable in the same manner as other overpayments.

Civil Rights -- Federal Civil Rights Claim -- Unlawful State Taxation of Federal Pension Benefits

3. Plaintiffs, who are seeking a tax refund for the State and New York City (City) income taxes they paid on Federal pension benefits for the years 1986 through 1988 pursuant to a discriminatory, unconstitutional tax scheme (see, Tax Law § 612 [c] [3] [ii]; Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-1712 [c] [3]), may not maintain a Federal civil rights action for damages (42 USC § 1983) against the State or the State defendants in their official capacities. Further, plaintiffs' claims under section 1983 against the State defendants in their individual capacities are not viable since there has been no showing that any of the State defendants personally engaged in any activity in connection with the taxation of Federal pensions sufficient to impose personal liability. In addition, since the State took over the collection and administration of the City's personal income tax in 1975 and plaintiffs have failed to establish that the City and the City defendants engaged in any conduct concerning the enforcement of the challenged tax scheme, the section 1983 claims against the City and the City defendants in their official and individual capacities must likewise be dismissed.

Taxation -- Tax Refund -- Injunctive Relief

4. Plaintiffs' cause of action for injunctive relief against the further collection of the tax imposed on Federal pensions for the years prior to 1989 pursuant to a discriminatory, unconstitutional tax scheme has not been rendered moot because of the amendment of the tax scheme to exempt Federal pension benefits received after January 1, 1989 from taxation (Tax Law § 612 [c] [3] [ii]; Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-1712 [c] [3]) since the tax scheme which taxes Federal pension benefits received prior to January 1, 1989 (Tax Law § 612 [c] [3-a]) has not been annulled or repealed. Accordingly, inasmuch as the tax scheme is unconstitutional and plaintiffs are entitled to seek a refund of taxes paid on Federal pension benefits from 1986 to 1988, reverse summary judgment granting injunctive relief is appropriate and the State defendants are, therefore, enjoined from assessing and collecting personal income taxes on Federal pension benefits which may be due and owing for the years 1986 through 1988 and are further enjoined from interfering with plaintiffs' right to file for a refund for personal income taxes paid on Federal benefits for those years.

Money Received -- Refund of Unlawfully Collected Taxes -- Payment under Protest

5. Plaintiffs, who paid income taxes on Federal pensions for the years 1986 through 1988 pursuant to a discriminatory, unconstitutional tax scheme (see, Tax Law § 612 [c] [3] [ii]; Administrative Code of City of New York § 11-1712 [c] [3]), may not maintain a cause of action for money had and received to recover the taxes paid since it is incumbent upon the taxpayer to establish appropriate legal protest prior to or at the time of payment as a prerequisite to recovery in an action seeking refunds and plaintiffs have failed to establish compliance with such protest requirement.

 

979 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Grygas v. New York State Ethics Com.


RJI No. 0189 ST2156


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


147 Misc. 2d 312; 554 N.Y.S.2d 779; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 176



April 6, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner employees filed an action against respondent commission, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78, 3001, for a declaratory judgment that the financial disclosure requirements of the Ethics in Government Act, N.Y. Exec. Law § 94, N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73-a, was unconstitutional, in requiring financial disclosure of state employees earning $ 30,000 per year or designated "policy makers," as an arbitrary invasion of personal privacy.


OVERVIEW: Petitioner employees, who were designated by their state agencies as "policy makers," were required to file disclosures of their personal finances and those of their spouses, pursuant to the Ethics in Government Act (Act), codified at N.Y. Exec. Law § 94, N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73-a. The employees brought a N.Y. C.P.L.R. 78 proceeding to challenge the constitutionality of the reporting requirements as an arbitrary invasion of their personal privacy, and sought a declaratory judgment pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3001. The court held that: (1) the Act was a constitutional exercise of legislative authority, both under the United States Constitution and N.Y. Const. art. III, § 1; (2) the determinations by the agency that the employees were "policy makers" had a rational basis; (3) the application of an employee for deletion of certain items from public disclosure, not having been acted upon, was not ripe for review; and (4) the application of another employee for deletion of certain items, denied pursuant to N.Y. Exec. Law § 94(9)(k), was arbitrary and capricious because no findings of fact were made.


OUTCOME: The court ordered that: (1) the Ethics in Government Act was constitutional; (2) the determinations that the employees were "policy makers" had a rational basis; (3) the application of an employee for deletion of items, not having been acted upon, was dismissed without prejudice; (4) the application of another employee for deletion, denied without findings of fact, was granted and remanded; and (5) all other claims were dismissed with prejudice.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers -- Ethics in Government Act -- Financial Disclosure

The Ethics in Government Act, which requires certain high-salaried and all "policy-making" State employees and public officers to file detailed financial disclosure statements (Public Officers Law § 73-a; Executive Law § 94) does not impermissibly delegate to the State Ethics Commission the authority to determine which State employees are "policy makers" for the purpose of financial disclosure without meaningful standards and guidelines since the term "policy-making" is clearly constitutionally precise and the determination of who is a "policy maker" is uniquely an administrative function (see, Executive Law § 94 [9] [d]). Furthermore, employees aggrieved by being designated "policy makers" may seek redress within the internal workings of the agency in which they are employed and ultimately to the judicial system. However, in order to assure the constitutionality of the statute, it must be interpreted so as to require that all adjudicative decisions and determinations made by the Commission or its Executive Director, including decisions and determinations upon applications for exemption or deletion from the requirements of financial disclosure, be accompanied by written findings of fact or by written statements of the reasons or the basis for such decisions or determinations (see, 9 NYCRR 941.12). Exemption and deletion procedures are necessary to vindicate the privacy rights of government employees subject to financial disclosure. Judicial review is an integral part of the due process required for those safety-valve procedures, and where access to judicial review is flawed or rendered ineffective by a failure of the Commission to make findings of fact or to state the factual bases for its determinations, this is tantamount to no judicial review and no due process.

 

980 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Blanchette


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


City Court of New York, Watertown, Jefferson County


147 Misc. 2d 50; 554 N.Y.S.2d 388; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 181



April 4, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The charges against the defendants Blanchette and Cross based on subdivision (3) of Penal Law § 240.20 are dismissed.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendants filed motions to dismiss their criminal charges for disorderly conduct in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(3) on the ground that § 240.20(3) was unconstitutionally vague and overbroad.


OVERVIEW: Defendants were charge with disorderly conduct in violation of N.Y. Penal Law § 240.20(3). Section 240.20(3) provided that a person was guilty of disorderly conduct when, with intent to cause public convenience, annoyance, or alarm, used abusive or obscene language, or makes an obscene gesture in a public place. The language of § 240.20(3) was identical to the statutory language for the offense of harassment used in N.Y. Penal Law § 240.25(2). Section 240.25(2) was previously found unconstitutionally vague and overbroad on its face because it prohibited a substantial amount of constitutionally protected expression, and because it presented a significant risk of prosecution for the exercise of free speech in violation of N.Y. Const. art. I, § 8 and U.S. Const. amends. I and XIV. Defendants filed motions to dismiss the disorderly conduct charges against them under § 240.20(3) on the grounds that § 240.20(3) was also unconstitutionally vague and overbroad. The court agreed with defendants' claims. The court found that § 240.20(3) was unconstitutional for the same reasons that § 240.25(2) was unconstitutional.


OUTCOME: The court granted defendants' motions to dismiss the criminal charges against them for disorderly conduct.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Disorderly Conduct -- Use of Abusive or Obscene Language in Public Place

The disorderly conduct statute, which proscribes using "abusive or obscene language" or making an obscene gesture in a public place "with intent to cause public inconvenience, annoyance or alarm, or recklessly creating the risk thereof" (Penal Law § 240.20 [3]) is unconstitutional in view of the decision of the Court of Appeals holding the harassment statute containing similar language (Penal Law § 240.25 [2]) invalid for overbreadth on its face for prohibiting "a substantial amount of constitutionally protected expression, and because its continued existence presents a significant risk of prosecution for the mere exercise of free speech" (see, People v Dietze, 75 NY2d 47, 50). Accordingly, neither defendant may be prosecuted under the statute for, respectively, using vulgarities to the continued annoyance of restaurant customers and directing a tirade of verbal abuse at a police officer causing people to stop and cars to slow down.

 

981 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Watkins v. New York State Ethics Com.


RJI No. 0189 018824


Supreme Court of New York, Albany County


147 Misc. 2d 350; 554 N.Y.S.2d 955; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 185



March 21, 1990 


NOTICE:  [***1] EDITED FOR PUBLICATION


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Plaintiff attorney filed an action for a declaratory judgment against defendant New York Ethics Commission that sought a declaration that the N.Y. Pub. Off. Law § 73-a, which required financial disclosure from certain state officers and employees who earned over $ 30,000 a year, was unconstitutional and violated the United States and New York State Constitutions. The Ethics Commission moved for dismissal of the complaint.


OVERVIEW: The attorney's department was designated as a policy maker, which required him to file financial disclosure reports. The court found that § 73-a furthered a compelling state interest in deterring governmental corruption and in fostering public confidence in the system of government. The financial disclosure law's provision for disclosure manifested an acute sensitivity to the reporting individual's right of privacy and any claims of irrelevancy sought to be asserted. The law comported with due process requirement. The court found that the attorney's alleged infringement of his right of association was highly speculative because the law was not adopted with the intent to restrain freedom of association, and there was no showing of actual antagonism that resulted in loss of employment or public hostility. The court found that there were no equal protection infirmities with respect to § 73-a because judicial officers and employees were not exempt from financial disclosure, and were covered under their own law. Thus, the classification of legislative and executive employees was not a suspect classification and rational basis scrutiny applied.


OUTCOME: The court denied the attorney's motion for preliminary injunctive relief and granted summary judgment to New York Ethics Commission.


HEADNOTES

Public Officers -- Ethics in Government Act -- Financial Disclosure

The financial disclosure requirements of the Ethics in Government Act requiring financial disclosure by certain high-salaried and all policy-making State employees, including information about their families ( Public Officers Law § 73-a), are constitutional since the compelling State interest in discovering and deterring corruption and in promoting public confidence in government outweighs whatever constitutionally protected privacy interests that may be affected by the disclosure requirements. The provisions of the Ethics in Government Act manifest an acute sensitivity to the reporting individual's right of privacy, and the statute's privacy mechanism ( Executive Law § 94 [18] [h]) adequately protects the reporting individual's privacy interests and comports with the requirements of due process. Those portions of the act which require covered employees to disclose certain business and organizational associations are not violative of the constitutional rights to freedom of association and freedom of speech since any adverse impact on those constitutionally protected rights is a tangential effect of legislation which promotes the State's compelling interest in encouraging the integrity of government and the public's confidence in government. In addition, even if covered employees have a reasonable expectation of privacy with respect to their financial affairs, the statute's privacy mechanism adequately protects against unnecessary and unreasonable disclosure. Furthermore, the filing of an annual statement of financial disclosure does not violate the privilege against self-incrimination and compelled testimony. Lastly, the fact that officers and employees of the judiciary are subject to disclosure requirements administered by the Chief Administrator of the Courts, rather than the Ethics Commission ( Judiciary Law § 211 [4]), does not result in a denial of equal protection.

 

982 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Grillo


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


CRIMINAL COURT OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 762; 203 N.Y.L.J. 35



 February 22, 1990 

 

983 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Allied-Signal, Inc. v. Commissioner of Finance


Index No. 19702/88


Supreme Court, New York County


146 Misc. 2d 632; 552 N.Y.S.2d 195; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 64



February 15, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petitioner's application made pursuant to CPLR article 78 to annul the final determination made by respondent in the matter of the petition of the Bendix Corporation is denied.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner taxpayer sought to annul the final determination made by respondent Commissioner of Finance, which found it liable for a general corporation tax deficiency after the taxpayer did not include dividend income and capital gains income arising from its ownership and sale of corporate stock.


OVERVIEW: The taxpayer was incorporated in Delaware and headquartered in Michigan. It owned stock in a New Jersey corporation that was headquartered in New York City. Although both the taxpayer and the corporation did business in New York City, at no time did the two engage in any business activity between themselves in New York. The purchase and sale of the taxpayer's stock took place outside of New York and all dividend income was received outside the state. The Commissioner determined that the investment income received was subject to taxation by New York City and the court upheld that decision. It found that even if no unitary business relationship existed between the taxpayer and the corporation, the city could tax foreign investment income if it extended some protection to the activities that generated the income. In this case, the city only sought to tax the amount of the dividends and capital gains that were attributable to the corporation's business activities within the city. Further, it was undisputed that the city gave protection and benefits to the corporation's activities within its borders and that those activities gave rise to the income received by the taxpayer.


OUTCOME: The court denied the taxpayer's application to annul the final determination made by the Commissioner, which upheld a determination of tax deficiency arising from dividend and capital gains income from the taxpayer's ownership and sale of stock.


HEADNOTES

Taxation -- Franchise Tax on Business Corporations -- Taxation of Investment Income of Foreign Corporation

The City of New York may properly tax the investment income of a corporation headquartered in Michigan and incorporated in Delaware where the income consisted of dividends and capital gains resulting from its ownership of stock in a corporation headquartered in New York and incorporated in New Jersey, and where both corporations did business in New York but at no time relevant to the instant proceeding did they engage in any business activity between themselves in New York, since a local government may constitutionally tax foreign investment income if that government has extended some protection to the activities which generate that income; although the United States Supreme Court has held that if an entity doing business within a given jurisdiction receives investment income from another entity having no connection with that jurisdiction, the jurisdiction may tax that income only if the two entities are engaged in a "unitary business", the existence of a "unitary business" relationship is not the only method by which a local government may tax income from a foreign investment. The city has sought to tax the Michigan/Delaware corporation only on the amount of dividends and capital gains which it received and which are attributable to the New York/New Jersey corporation's business activities within the city, and it is undisputed that the city has given protection and benefits to the latter corporation's activities within its borders, activities which gave rise to the investment income in question.

 

984 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Molinari v. City of New York


Index No. SP8120/89, Cal. No. 754


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, RICHMOND COUNTY


146 Misc. 2d 713; 551 N.Y.S.2d 760; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 57



February 13, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] The petition is denied in all respects.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, various interested parties, filed an action in the Supreme Court, Richmond County (New York) in opposition to certain actions by respondents, various municipal groups, and asked the court to prohibit any further action by the municipal groups in approving a site for future construction of the Staten Island Correctional Facility (the project).


OVERVIEW: The interested parties hoped to prevent the municipal groups from taking any further action toward the selection and acquisition of a certain site approved by the New York City Board of Estimate for future construction of the project and hoped to restrain the municipal groups from taking further action for the development and construction of the project until compliance, as perceived by the interested parties, with various environmental laws was accomplished. A claim was asserted that the New York City Board of Estimate (BOE) had no legal authority to approve the project, but the court found otherwise. Similarly, the interested parties claimed the BOE acted improperly when it designated the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) and the Department of City Planning (DCP) as lead agencies for purposes of preparing an environmental impact statement (EIS). The court found, however, that the BOE made the final determinations at to the EIS, and state law did not prevent the BOE from relying upon information or advice received from others, including consultants or other agencies, provided that the reliance was reasonable under the circumstances.


OUTCOME: The interested parties' petition was denied in all respects because the BOE acted with proper authority and was able to rely on advice given by other agencies so long as such reliance was reasonable.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- New York City Board of Estimate -- Authority to Approve Construction of Prison

1. Notwithstanding the holding of the United States Supreme Court in Board of Estimate v Morris (489 U.S. --, 109 S Ct 1433) that the structure of the New York City Board of Estimate is unconstitutional as violative of the "one person, one vote" principle, the Board had proper authority to pass upon the application for approval of the construction of a prison, since it is improbable that the Federal courts intended that the City of New York suddenly function without a governing body authorized to exercise important governmental functions such as land use decisions, contract and franchise approval, zoning changes, and budget recommendations; the statement of the Federal court, "In the meantime, though flawed, the Board of Estimate may continue to function. Six months should be a target area, one year a deadline" (831 F2d 393), is merely an exhortation to prompt curative action and not an injunction staying the Board from governing after a certain date.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Lead Agency 

2. In a proceeding to prevent the construction of a prison in New York City, it was not improper for the New York City Departments of Environmental Protection and City Planning to act as "lead agencies" (see, ECL 8-0111 [6]) for the implementation of the environmental quality review procedures set forth in the State Environmental Quality Review Act (SEQRA) (ECL art 8), where the New York City Board of Estimate, by approving the construction, made the final determination that an environmental impact statement (EIS) was required and had the final EIS before it for review and consideration; the New York City Department of Correction caused a consultant to prepare a draft EIS under the technical supervision of the aforementioned "lead agencies", and there was nothing wrong with the use by the Board of the "lead agencies" as investigative arms, since those agencies had the technical expertise necessary to prepare a draft and final EIS. The Board held a public hearing at which petitioners gave testimony, and the Board had a right to rely on the EIS prepared by the "lead agencies" so long as it reserved the final authority on approval or disapproval of the construction. Accordingly, the letter and spirit of SEQRA were satisfied.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Consideration of Alternatives

3. In a proceeding to prevent the construction of a prison in New York City, the record adequately demonstrates that during the site selection process 23 other sites were considered and evaluated by respondents; every possible alternative need not be discussed in an environmental impact statement (EIS), which must be "analytical" but need not be "encyclopedic". Moreover, petitioners can point to no rule of law, statute, or regulation requiring the municipal respondents to reopen the site selection process when a determination was made to reduce the size of the prison; respondents took the requisite "hard look" at the alternatives during the site selection process and reevaluated them again when the determination to reduce the size of the project was made.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Consideration of Socio-Economic Impact of Project on Community -- Construction of Prison

4. In a proceeding to prevent the construction of a prison in New York City, the final environmental impact statement (EIS) did not fail to adequately consider the socio-economic impact of the prison on the community, where it contained a demographic profile of the surrounding neighborhood and detailed statistics about the population; though reasonable persons may differ as to the conclusions to be reached from the data contained in the final EIS, reasonable doubts should be resolved in favor of administrative findings. Similarly, the EIS reviewed and discussed the environmental impacts with respect to the ecology, traffic, prison demographics, and available medical care for the construction project, and incorporated as conditions mitigative measures that were identified as practicable to minimize or avoid any adverse environmental impacts. The data contained in the EIS and the mitigative measures proposed provide a rational basis to support the determination of the New York City Board of Estimate to go ahead with the project, notwithstanding that other data might be available to support other conclusions.

Environmental Conservation -- Environmental Quality Review -- Construction of Prison -- Waterfront Act

5. In a proceeding to prevent the construction of a prison in New York City, none of the actions taken by the municipal respondents violate the letter and spirit of either the Waterfront Act (Executive Law art 42) or the New York City Waterfront Revitalization Program; the City Planning Commission, in its capacity as the City Coastal Commission, reviewed the proposed project and found it consistent with the policies of the program, and the waterfront revitalization statutes do not require only water-dependent activities within designated waterfront areas. Although reasonable persons may argue that the proposed project may be better suited elsewhere, it is not the role of the court to weigh the desirability of the action or to choose among alternatives, since the court's authority is limited to determining whether the law has been complied with by the municipal respondents; accordingly, inasmuch as the approval by the New York City Board of Estimate was not arbitrary and capricious or an abuse of discretion, the petition is denied.

 

985 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Lemme v. Dolan


Index No. 7455-89


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


146 Misc. 2d 817; 552 N.Y.S.2d 506; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 69



February 9, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner landowner filed an application for a certificate of appropriateness required for a demolition permit. Respondent commission passed a resolution that denied the application. On review, respondent board of appeals issued a decision affirming the commission's resolution. In response, the landowner filed an action, pursuant to N.Y. C.P.L.R. art. 78, seeking review of the commission's resolution and the board of appeals' decision.


OVERVIEW: The landowner possessed a building within the historic district which was subject to the jurisdiction of the commission. The building had become seriously deteriorated as well as structurally unsound. The ravages of time were further compounded by a major fire. Following the fire, the local building commissioner directed the landowner to barricade the premises, stabilize the building, and secure a building permit for restoration of the premises. Consequently, the landowner filed an amended application for a certificate of appropriateness for the demolition of the premises. In its resolution denying the application, the commission in part held it did not have jurisdiction or authority to issue such a certificate unless the landowner submitted and obtained design approval for new development in accordance with Albany, N.Y., Historic Resources Commission Ordinance § 1-135(b)(2). The board of appeals upheld the resolution. On review, the court determined setting aside the resolution and the affirmance was appropriate because those decisions were arbitrary, capricious, and an abuse of discretion.


OUTCOME: The court set aside the resolution of the commission and the decision of the board of appeals affirming the resolution and remanded to the commission with a mandate to grant the landowner a certificate of appropriateness for demolition.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Zoning -- Historic Preservation Ordinance

The determination of respondent Board of Zoning Appeals of the City of Albany affirming a resolution of the city's Historic Resources Commission denying petitioner's application for a "certificate of appropriateness" in order to demolish a structurally unsound building in a designated historic district, unless petitioner submits design approval for new development in accordance with the Historic Resources Commission Ordinance, is arbitrary and capricious and must be set aside since the ordinance's reconstruction requirements are applicable only to the voluntary demolition of a structurally sound and physically viable building, not the involuntary demolition of a structurally unsound, substantially damaged and severely physically deteriorated building that has been declared to be a public safety hazard by the city's Building Commissioner. Other than imposing the obligation of maintenance upon a landowner, government does not have the right to impose upon him the sole burden of an economically unfeasible restoration for the general benefit of society-at-large (see, FGL & L Prop. Corp. v City of Rye, 66 NY2d 111). If the historic value of petitioner's property outweighs the economic cost of historic restoration, and society desires to preserve that historic value, then society, embodied in its government, must condemn the property and bear the burden of the historic preservation. Accordingly, the matter is remanded to the Commission with the mandate that a "certificate of appropriateness" for demolition be granted, upon any reasonable conditions requiring preservation and retention of any artifacts, moldings, and other building materials of significant historic value that can be used in connection with any future new construction at the site.

 

986 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Escobales


Indictment No. 5479/89


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, BRONX COUNTY


146 Misc. 2d 573; 551 N.Y.S.2d 757; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 56



February 9, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant who discovered he had AIDS shortly after he was sentenced, brought a motion to have his prison sentence, which was imposed pursuant to a negotiated plea agreement, to be set aside pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.20, alleging that it was invalid as a matter of law because it constituted cruel and unusual punishment in violation N.Y. Const. art. I, § 5 and U. S. Const. amend. XIII.


OVERVIEW: Defendant discovered that he had AIDS in an advanced stage shortly after beginning a prison sentence as the result of a negotiated plea agreement under which he was sentenced to an indefinite prison term of at least two years but no more then four for felony possession and sale of drugs. Defendant sought a motion to set aside his sentence pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 440.20, alleging that in light of his condition, the sentence was invalid as a matter of law because it constituted cruel and unusual punishment in violation N.Y. Const. art. I, § 5 and U. S. Const. amend. XIII. The court denied defendant's motion, ruling that although defendant's incarceration was unfortunate under his present condition, applying a subjective standard, the court could not find as a matter of law, that his incarceration was so inhuman as to shock the court's conscience because he was receiving proper care and treatment in the prison hospital. The court concluded that it joined in the recommendation that defendant be admitted to a facility devoted to the care of AIDS victims under a special release program.


OUTCOME: The court denied defendant's motion to have his sentence set aside because of his serious health condition of AIDS but joined in the recommendation that defendant be allowed to be a benefactor of a release program that would permit him to live out his life in a facility devoted to the care of AIDS victims.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Sentence

Defendant's motion to set aside his sentence is denied. It was discovered during defendant's incarceration that he is afflicted with AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome), that the disease is in an advanced stage and that his life expectancy is from 12 to 18 months. Defendant argues that his otherwise authorized sentence, an indeterminate term of imprisonment imposed in a narcotics prosecution pursuant to a negotiated plea arrangement, constitutes cruel and unusual punishment in violation of constitutional proscriptions inasmuch as the imposition of the sentence renders it one of life imprisonment given his dire medical condition. Defendant received the minimum allowable statutory sentence; in any event, using an objective standard, severe punishment of drug offenders has not been considered irrationally harsh. Under a subjective analysis, it cannot be said that defendant's incarceration is subhuman so as to shock the court's conscience; defendant is hospitalized and is receiving necessary and appropriate medical care. A defendant's affliction with AIDS, in and of itself, is not an extraordinary circumstance which warrants interference with a sentence imposed within statutory guidelines. Any application to ameliorate the conditions of incarceration should be made to the Department of Correctional Services; the interests of justice would be served by allowing defendant to live out his life in a facility devoted to the care of AIDS victims, and the court recommends that defendant be a benefactor of the Compassionate Release Program.

 

987 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Durham


Ind. No. 626/89


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, QUEENS COUNTY


146 Misc. 2d 913; 553 N.Y.S.2d 944; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 107



February 7, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: The people moved for an order requiring defendant to provide blood samples pursuant to N.Y. Crim. Proc. Law § 240.40(2)(b)(v), following his indictment for rape in the first degree.


OVERVIEW: The people contended that defendant beat and raped his child's babysitter, then told her that he had AIDS. The people requested a blood sample from defendant as non-testimonial evidence to determine whether he could be identified or excluded as the rapist, and whether he in fact had AIDS in order for the rape kit to be safely tested. The court granted the people's application. The people met their burden by establishing the probable cause to believe that defendant had committed the crime, and that the methods they intended to use to secure the blood samples would be safe and reliable. Additionally, the victim had the right to know whether she was exposed to the AIDS virus by reason of having been exposed to the body and sexual fluids of defendant. The taking of blood was not prohibited by N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 2781 because he placed into controversy the issue of his physical condition with respect to having AIDS. N.Y. C.P.L.R. 3121.


OUTCOME: The people's application for an order directing defendant to submit to a blood test was granted.


HEADNOTES

Crimes -- Disclosure -- Compelling Defendant who Claims He Has AIDS to Provide Blood Samples in Rape Prosecution

In a prosecution of defendant for rape and other offenses, the People's motion for an order pursuant to CPL 240.40 (2) (b) (v) requiring the defendant to provide blood samples as nontestimonial evidence is granted. The defendant told the complainant that he had AIDS, and although a Vitullo rape kit was taken from the complainant, the police laboratory would not, as a matter of policy, perform an analysis. The People seek the blood samples to determine whether defendant can be identified or excluded as the perpetrator, and to determine if the defendant has AIDS, in order for the Vitullo kit to be safely analyzed. There is a showing of probable cause that defendant committed the crimes alleged in the indictment, the People have particularized the nature of what they are seeking and the person from whom the blood samples are to be taken, and there is no less intrusive means of obtaining the needed evidence. The People have a sampling of the perpetrator's semen that will not be tested by the police laboratory if the perpetrator had AIDS, and a necessary requirement for allowing the taking of a blood sample is the possession of a viable sample with comparative value. The testing of a Vitullo kit has become a necessary element in the immediate investigation of alleged sexual crimes; where, as here, a defendant announces that he has AIDS, he cannot claim that his constitutional rights would be violated by the taking of a blood sample in order to prevent any further investigation and possible prosecution of the assailant. Further, the victim has a right to know whether she may have been exposed to the AIDS virus. The People should not be prevented from obtaining what ordinarily would be an appropriate and constitutionally recognized request for nontestimonial evidence. Defendant's argument that the taking of such a test would be prohibited by Public Health Law § 2781 is without merit.

 

988 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Consolidated Edison Co.


Docket Nos. 9N551769W, 9N559711W, 9N562831W, 9N587784W, 9N587793W, 9N587804W, 9N587886W, 9N588079W, 9N589990W, 9N589997W, 9N590008W, 9N590022W, 9N590035W, 9N592681W, 9N592682W, 9N592712W, 9N592713W, 9N592864W, 9N592856W, 9N592866W, 9N592873W, 9N592876W, 9N592879W, 9N600069W, 9N600099W, 9N600141W, 9N600142W


Criminal Court of the City of New York, New York County


146 Misc. 2d 547; 551 N.Y.S.2d 754; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 42



February 5, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Defendant utility corporation faced criminal charges for violating New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 19-105 because it did not post warning signs when it excavated public roads. The utility filed a motion to dismiss that argued § 19-105 was void for vagueness because: the Department of Transportation had not published the required form for the signs; and, "obstruction" and "unsafe condition" were not defined in the code section.


OVERVIEW: The utility corporation was criminally charged with not posting warning signs as required by New York City, N.Y., Admin. Code § 19-105 whenever it excavated public roads. In its motion to dismiss, the utility argued that § 19-105 was void for vagueness for two reasons. First, the Department of Transportation had not published the required form for the warning signs and, second, the terms "obstruction" and "unsafe condition" were not defined in the code section. The court held that the acceptable form for the warning notices had been published in the New York City Department of Transportation Highway Regulations, which incorporated by reference therein the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, a publication of the United States Department of Transportation Federal Highways Administration. In addition, the court found that the terms "unsafe condition" and "obstruction" like the terms "intoxicated" and "impaired" had commonly understood meanings sufficient to give the utility adequate notice as to what was required under the code section. Holding that the code section did not have to define common terms, the court denied the utility's motion to dismiss.


OUTCOME: The court denied the utility corporation's motion to dismiss the criminal action brought for its failure to comply with the Administrative Code of the City of New York. The court held that the code section that required the utility to post warning signs when it excavated public roads was not unconstitutionally vague.


HEADNOTES

Municipal Corporations -- Streets -- Excavations -- Warning Notices

Section 19-105 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, which requires the posting of notices regarding unsafe conditions and obstructions created by the excavation of roadways and/or sidewalk cuts and provides that "Such notices shall be in the form prescribed by the [New York City D]epartment" of Transportation, is not unconstitutionally vague since the terms "Unsafe condition" and "obstruction" contained in the statute have an accepted meaning long recognized in law and life so as to afford a defendant sufficient notice as to what is required to avoid liability. Moreover, section 2.0.17 of the New York City Department of Transportation Highway Regulations, and the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways, referred to in the regulation, provide the public with notice of the type and form of signs that must be posted when excavation work is done.

 

989 of 992 DOCUMENTS


In re Adoption of Paul


Docket No. A12749/89


FAMILY COURT OF NEW YORK, KINGS COUNTY


146 Misc. 2d 379; 550 N.Y.S.2d 815; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 30



January 22, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] Should the necessary additional documents not be received by this court by May 1, 1990, the petition for adoption will be dismissed as abandoned.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Mother sought to appear before the court for the purpose of executing a Judicial Consent to the adoption of her son by a married couple.


OVERVIEW: The court found that under the clear language of the statutes governing adoption, together with the policy of the state as articulated in case law, the contract provided for the sale of a child, or, at the very least, the sale of a mother's right to her child in contravention of the law of the state. The surrogacy contract, therefore, was void. Accordingly, only if the mother would have sworn under oath before the court that she had not and would not request, accept or receive the money promised to her in exchange for surrender of her child, thus assuring the court that such surrender was truly voluntary and was motivated by her concern for the best interests of her child and not the promise of financial gain, could the court have accepted such surrender and terminated her parental rights. In addition, consistent with N.Y. Soc. Serv. Law § 374(6), the proposed adoptive parents must have also provided sworn affidavits evidencing their intent not to pay or give any compensation or thing of value to any party in exchange for the child.


OUTCOME: The court requested additional documents.


HEADNOTES

Adoption -- Surrogate Parenting Agreement

A "surrogate parenting agreement" whereby the "surrogate" mother, in exchange for a payment of $ 10,000, agreed to be artificially inseminated with the semen of the father and to then surrender the child to the father and his wife for adoption immediately upon the child's birth is void as against public policy and unenforceable since remuneration to a mother, in exchange for her surrender of the child for adoption, violates New York's well-established policy against trafficking in children (Social Services Law § 374 [6]). "Surrogate motherhood" is not analogous to sperm donation since, unlike a sperm donor, the "surrogate" mother is supplying a life-in-being. Accordingly, only if the surrogate mother swears under oath before the court that she will not receive the $ 10,000 promised to her in exchange for surrender of her child can the court accept such surrender and terminate her parental rights.

 

990 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Cirillo v. 2166 Second Ave., Inc.


Index No. 7A-051246/89


Civil Court of the City of New York, New York, County


146 Misc. 2d 802; 552 N.Y.S.2d 494; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 65



January 20, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioner tenants sought appointment of a N.Y. Real Prop. Acts. Law art. 7-A administrator for their apartment building. Respondent landlords contended that they could not make required repairs to the building on the ground of economic infeasibility.


OVERVIEW: The tenants rented apartments in a six-apartment walkup. In a prior proceeding, the building was determined to be in a condition dangerous to life, health, and safety and the landlords were ordered to make repairs. The tenants then sought appointment of an art. 7-A administrator for the building. The court awarded judgment for the tenants, finding that the landlords had not met their heavy burden of proving an unconstitutional taking of property. The court found that the landlords had not committed to making the repairs, which were required by the prior order, and by case law, N.Y. Mult. Dwell. Law § 78, and New York City, N.Y. Admin. Code § 2005, each of which required landlords to keep residential property in good repair, and had not shown that they could not make the repairs. The court further found that the landlords' claim of economic hardship was vitiated on the ground that the alleged hardship was self-inflicted. The court further found that the city was willing to undertake the necessary financial commitment to meet the costs of the repairs.


OUTCOME: The court awarded the tenants a judgment for appointment of an administrator for the apartment building.


HEADNOTES

Landlord and Tenant -- Rent Regulation -- Appointment of RPAPL Article 7-A Administrator -- Defense of Economic Infeasibility

An RPAPL article 7-A administrator shall be appointed for a building which contains serious conditions dangerous to life, health and safety, where the required number of tenants have joined in the petition and an expert from the Department of Housing Preservation and Development testified that the City of New York was willing to undertake the necessary financial commitment through loans and grants to the administrator to meet the costs of the required work; respondent owners have failed to meet the heavy burden of proof associated with their defense of economic infeasibility since the alleged economic hardship that they now claim they face in making the repairs required by law is self-inflicted and on that ground alone vitiates a claim of economic infeasibility. Respondents have made no commitment to undertake to correct the conditions at the premises, and they offered no proof that they could not do so; respondents apparently would simply like the premises turned over to them free of any imposition to comply with a court order to correct, obtained prior to the tenants initiating the instant proceeding.

 

991 of 992 DOCUMENTS


Fagan v. Axelrod


Index No. 7725-89, RJI No. 0189 ST2387


SUPREME COURT OF NEW YORK, ALBANY COUNTY


146 Misc. 2d 286; 550 N.Y.S.2d 552; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 1; 1990 OSHD (CCH) P28,924



January 10, 1990 


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Petitioners, citizen tobacco users, challenged the constitutionality of the Clean Indoor Air Act, 1989 N.Y. Laws 244, N.Y. Pub. Health Law § 1, and sought to enjoin enforcement of the law as enacted by respondent New York State Department of Health.


OVERVIEW: Citizen tobacco users argued that they were prejudiced and adversely affected by the implementation of Chapter 244, a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas and work sites. They also asserted that the statute further oppressed and discriminated against them and alleged a right of liberty and privacy to smoke, and contended that the statute established irrational classifications and in other diverse ways violated their right to due process and the equal protection of the laws. The court held that the regulation of smoking was a valid use of the state's police power and the legislation did not restrict petitioner's access to public places, only their right to smoke there. The court held that if petitioners in fact have a general "right of privacy" to smoke, this legislation merely requires them to exercise it outdoors or in private and petitioners are not a protected class with immutable characteristics afforded special protections.


OUTCOME: The legislation was declared constitutional and summary judgment was granted to respondents.


HEADNOTES

Parties -- Standing -- Constitutional Challenge to Clean Indoor Air Act

1. Petitioners in a proceeding challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), have demonstrated sufficient standing where they alleged that they are citizens and taxpayers of New York who as regular users of tobacco products in public and private places, both indoors and out-of-doors, are prejudiced and adversely affected by the statute and its implementation; to attack the constitutionality of a legislative enactment, a petitioner must demonstrate that he has suffered or is about to suffer some actual or threatened injury to a protected interest, and although it is debatable whether petitioners herein have in fact suffered such injury, they have demonstrated sufficient standing to make the instant challenge.

Actions -- Conversion of One Form of Action to Another -- Constitutional Challenge to Statute -- Declaratory Judgment

2. An article 78 proceeding challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), is not the proper vehicle to test the constitutionality of the statute, since such a proceeding may not be utilized to test the constitutionality of a legislative enactment, as distinct from the constitutionality of its application; however, inasmuch as all the necessary parties are before the court, the proceeding is converted to a declaratory judgment action. There being only legal issues to address, and no factual issues, the court will proceed to render a determination on the merits.

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Health Hazard to Nonsmokers

3. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), the weight of scientific evidence has shown that secondhand smoke, i.e., that which is not inhaled, represents a significant health hazard to nonsmokers. Accordingly, it is reasonable to conclude that Laws of 1989 (ch 244) is an appropriate response by the Legislature to the need to protect the citizens of the State from involuntary exposure to environmental tobacco smoke. Moreover, even if the scientific evidence demonstrating the deleterious effect of secondhand smoke were not so overwhelming as it is, it would not be the prerogative of the court to contest the wisdom of the Legislature in choosing what evidence to credit since there is a presumption that the Legislature investigated and found facts necessary to support the legislation; petitioners have failed to show that the facts on which the Legislature relied are not only erroneous, but that the issue is not even truly debatable.

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Police Power of State

4. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), petitioners' contentions alleging a "right of liberty and privacy" to smoke are without merit; the statute is a recognition by the Legislature of the medical harm inflicted upon nonsmokers by involuntary exposure to secondhand smoke in indoor areas open to the public, food service establishments and places of employment. Where smoking may be permitted and under what circumstances, along with what is a satisfactory provision of nonsmoking areas, reflect a well-modulated, carefully considered balancing of interest so as to best protect the public without unduly burdening private individuals or businesses. Regulation of smoking is a valid use of the State's police power since there is no more a fundamental right to smoke cigarettes than there is to ingest illegal drugs or run a red light; it is within the province of a State to say how far cigarettes may be sold or to prohibit their sale entirely.

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Restriction of Access of Smokers to Public Places

5. Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), does not restrict the access of smokers to public places, only their right to smoke therein; the statute pertains only to activity of a public dimension and does not apply to significantly private areas, such as private homes, residences, automobiles, hotel or motel rooms or to private events, such as private social functions where the seating arrangements are under the control of the sponsor of the function. The use of considerations of spatial dimensions and proximity of smokers to nonsmokers in certain instances, and complete prohibition of smoking in others, represent an accommodation between the desire to limit the exposure of nonsmokers to tobacco smoke and relevant economic and social considerations.

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Right of Privacy to Smoke

6. If a general "right of privacy" to smoke tobacco exists, Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), merely requires smokers to exercise it outdoors or in private; there is no differentiation between classes of citizens by the statute, and those who smoke have never in law been recognized as a distinct class. Under the statute, no person loses any recognizable right or liberty by virtue of being a smoker; it is not a blanket prohibition against smoking, merely a limitation of smoking in public areas where other persons will involuntarily be exposed to secondhand smoke. The statute is no different from any other law by which conduct, permissible in private, is regulated in public for health reasons.

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Permissible Classification

7. The classification of smokers and nonsmokers created by Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), is rationally related to the legislative objective of protecting the health of nonsmokers since there is no other possible manner of regulating the activity involved than to distinguish smokers from nonsmokers. Inasmuch as the statute does not create or apply to a "suspect" class or affect a "fundamental right", it is not subject to strict judicial scrutiny, but rather to the rational basis standard of review applicable to due process claims; the Equal Protection Clause does not prevent State Legislatures from drawing lines that treat one class of individuals or entities differently from others, unless the difference in treatment is palpably arbitrary or amounts to an invidious discrimination. Petitioners' constitutional arguments concern the wisdom of the legislation, rather than its rationality, and courts do not sit in review of the wisdom of the acts of a Legislature; the fact that the means employed by the Legislature imposes inconvenience or hardship is a plea to be addressed to the ballot box or the Legislature.

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Delegation of Police Power

8. Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), does not unconstitutionally delegate police power and does not utilize vague definitions; authorizing the owner or operator of an indoor area to entirely prohibit smoking in that area effects no change from the common-law right of an owner of private property to curtail smoking on his premises. The statute does not confer substantive rule-making authority on any State agency or municipality since the Commissioner of Health is expressly precluded from promulgating substantive regulations (see, Public Health Law § 1399-x), and no delegation of rule-making authority is conferred on municipalities, only the specific expression of the Legislature that the statute was not intended to preempt local governments from acting in an area (public health) in which they have long been authorized to act (see, e.g. , Public Health Law § 347).

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Penalties

9. The penalties imposed for violations of Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), are neither unreasonable nor disproportionate to the offense, and are neither shocking nor bizarre; they are simply the same penalties long prescribed elsewhere in the Public Health Law (see, Public Health Law §§ 12-a, 309 [1] [f]).

Health -- Tobacco Smoking -- Regulation of Smoking Indoors -- Legislative Motive

10. In an action challenging the constitutionality of Laws of 1989 (ch 244), which established a comprehensive plan regulating tobacco smoking in public areas (see, Public Health Law art 13-E), petitioners' argument that the true purpose of the statute is behavior modification is unavailing, since it has been long settled that, in the enactment of a law, no motive, purpose or intent may be imputed to the Legislature other than such as is apparent upon the face of the law itself.

 

992 of 992 DOCUMENTS


People v. Emmi


[NO NUMBER IN ORIGINAL]


COUNTY COURT OF NEW YORK, CAYUGA COUNTY


146 Misc. 2d 399; 550 N.Y.S.2d 787; 1990 N.Y. Misc. LEXIS 25



January 10, 1990 



DISPOSITION:  [***1] For all the reasons stated in this decision, the judgment of conviction in the City Court charging the defendant with violation of section 1129 (a) of the Vehicle and Traffic Law is hereby reversed, vacated and the information dismissed in the interest of justice.


CASE SUMMARY:


PROCEDURAL POSTURE: Appellant police officer sought review of a conviction of the Auburn City Court (New York), which found the police officer guilty of N.Y. Veh. & Traf. § 1129(a) relative to following another vehicle to closely. The police officer had rear ended another car while answering an emergency call, and the state prosecuted him for the violation of § 1129(a) as a result of the accident.


OVERVIEW: The police officer contended on appeal that § 1129(a) was unconstitutional, that the trial court erred as a matter of law in failing to apply the proper standard of proof of conviction, and that the trial court failed to consider the police officer's vehicle as an emergency vehicle. The court found that § 1129(a) was constitutional as prior case law had already examined the statute and determined the same to have been sufficiently definite to be constitutional. The court also found that since the legislature did not make § 1129(a) all encompassing as to speed, traffic, and highway conditions to be considered in determining when a vehicle follows to closely, the trial court's finding of guilt based solely upon the failure to anticipate a driver's reaction to a traffic device was erroneous. As a result, the court reversed the judgment of conviction charging defendant with the violation of § 1129(a). Further, the court found that the prosecutor failed to disprove the emergency vehicle theory and the record clearly stated that the police officer was operating a police vehicle and following a possible violator.


OUTCOME: The judgment of conviction was reversed, vacated, and the information was dismissed in the interest of justice.


HEADNOTES

Motor Vehicles -- Following Too Closely

Section 1129 (a) of the Vehicle and Traffic Law which provides that the "driver of a motor vehicle shall not follow another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent having due regard for the speed of such vehicle and the traffic upon and the condition of the highway" is constitutional. However, the conviction of defendant, a police officer who had a rear-end collision with the vehicle he was following in his police cruiser, must be reversed since the conviction was improperly based solely upon defendant's failure to anticipate the sudden stop of the other vehicle for the amber traffic light. The proper standard is that a motorist would be guilty of following too closely if, in view of the speed of the vehicles, traffic upon or condition of the highways reasonably to be anticipated, he is guilty of ordinary negligence with respect to following too closely alone. In addition, the failure of the prosecutor to disprove defendant's emergency vehicle theory (Vehicle and Traffic Law §§ 114-b, 1104) warrants a reversal of the conviction and the dismissal of the information.
